AHIS.title: Introduction to Visual Culture
AHIS.description: The description and analysis of various forms of visual culture, including both mass media and "high" art representations, both Western and non-Western images.

AHIS.title: Foundations of Western Art: Prehistoric to Renaissance
AHIS.description: Mediterranean and European art and architecture presented in historical, cultural and social context that introduces art history as a discipline.

AHIS.title: Arts of Asia: Antiquity to 1300
AHIS.description: An introduction to the major art forms and monuments of religious art in India, Southeast Asia, China and Japan from prehistory to1300.

AHIS.title: Digging into the Past
AHIS.description: A broad survey, covering some 8,000 years and focusing on the material culture of the ancient world in a historical and social context.

AHIS.title: Greek Art and Archaeology
AHIS.description: Survey of artistic works and monuments of ancient Greece from the Geometric through the Hellenistic period (c. 1000 - 30 BCE.).

AHIS.title: Late Antique Art and Archaeology
AHIS.description: Investigation of the transformation between classical antiquity and the middle ages through examination of cities, buildings, images and artifacts of the 3rd-8th-century Mediterranean.

AHIS.title: Baroque Art
AHIS.description: Painting, sculpture and architecture in 17th century Europe, north  and south. Recommended preparation: AHIS 121

AHIS.title: Picturing Democracy: American Art and Visual     Culture, 1750-1900
AHIS.description: Studies the art and visual culture of the United States from nation formation to the World's Columbian Exposition of 1893.

AHIS.title: Modern Art II: 1851-1940
AHIS.description: An examination of European modern art and design, focusing on  industrialization, urbanism, primitivisim, colonialism, and their  relations to the arts.

AHIS.title: History and Theory of Photography
AHIS.description: Explores key moments in the history of photography from its invention to the present. Issues include modernity and mass culture; photography as a fine art; technologies of vision.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Apprenticeship
AHIS.description: Independent work in art museums, galleries or art history related  institutes supervised by on-site professionals and USC faculty.    Not available for credit for AHIS majors. CR/NC

AHIS.title: 19th Century French Art
AHIS.description: Exploration of the main movements in 19th century French art, using the city of Paris and its museums. Field trips in conjunction with classwork. Advisement is required for credit for Art History majors.

AHIS.title: East Asian Garden and Designed Landscape
AHIS.description: Explores the transmigration of Japanese art and aesthetics and the politics of their adaptation and assimilation in Los Angeles.

AHIS.title: Directed Research
AHIS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Proseminar in Art History
AHIS.description: Historiography and methodology: introduction to techniques of research and writing. Required of all art history majors, preferably in junior year.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS.title: Methods and Theory of Art History
AHIS.description: Methodologies, theories and critical traditions that have shaped the discipline. Emphasis will vary depending on faculty. Required of all first-year M.A. and Ph.D. candidates. Open to graduate or limited status students in art history only.

AHIS.title: Categories and Collections
AHIS.description: How collections are organized by category -- e.g., period,  culture, materials, or mode of production.  Examines collecting  protocols, historiography and modes of collecting and viewing  associated with that category.

AHIS.title: Directed Research
AHIS.description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.  Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
AHIS.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Open only to Art History doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Research
AHIS.description: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ARCG.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
ARCG.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

ARCG.title: Virtual and Digital Culture, Heritage and Archaeology
ARCG.description: In-depth exploration of 3D digital, immersive, virtual or extended reality visualizations of cultural heritage, archaeology, historical sites and artifacts, including their legal and ethical dimensions.

ARCG.title: Techniques and Issues in 3D Imaging and Modeling
ARCG.description: In-depth exploration of applications, techniques and standards involved in stereoscopic imaging and photogrammetric modeling.

ARCG.title: Greek Art and Archaeology
ARCG.description: Survey of artistic works and monuments of ancient Greece from the Geometric through the Hellenistic period (c. 1000 - 30 BCE.).

ARCG.title: Space, Place, Perception and Power
ARCG.description: The social construction of spaces, places, and landscapes and their reciprocal relationships to human embodied experiences, processes of identity formation and society.

ARCG.title: Jewish Magic in the Ancient World
ARCG.description: A cross-cultural examination of different kinds of magical literature that describe miraculous practices in Jewish mainstream and marginal life in the ancient and classical periods.

ARCG.title: Directed Research
ARCG.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CSLC.title: Introduction to Comparative Media Studies
CSLC.description: Ways of thinking about the differences and relations among different cultural media: literature, film, video, manga/comics, aE*new media,aE* and so forth.

CSLC.title: Introduction to Literary Theory
CSLC.description: Major developments in twentieth-century literary criticism, with special attention to theoretical work of the past three decades. (Duplicates credit in former COLT 502)

CSLC.title: Literary and Cinematic Translingualism and Translation
CSLC.description: Introduces key debates regarding translingualism and translation in postcolonial, comparative, and cross-cultural literary and cinematic contexts

CSLC.title: Directed Research
CSLC.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Graded CR/NC.            Duplicates credit in former COLT 590.

CSLC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
CSLC.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least on semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

CSLC.title: Professional Development I: Publication
CSLC.description: Preparation of book and article manuscripts for publication and placement in presses and journals; revising dissertations for publication; preparing papers for conferences. Students produce an article manuscript ready for submission to a journal. Duplicates credit in former COLT-603. Open only to doctoral students.

CSLC.title: Seminar in Literary Theory
CSLC.description: Intensive study of a theoretical tradition or critical movement, or of an individual topic or thinker, in literary criticism or theory.

CSLC.title: Research
CSLC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units that may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSLC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSLC.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSLC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSLC.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills I
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the low intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills II
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing Skills II
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: High Intermediate Pronunciation
ALI.description: Required for international students whose pronunciation skills are assessed at the high intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills III
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing III
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Intermediate Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Required for international teaching assistants (ITAs) whose oral skills are assessed to be at the intermediate level by the ITA Exam or previous ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Pronunciation
ALI.description: Required for international students whose pronunciation skills are assessed at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills IV
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing Skills IV
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: High Intermediate Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Required for international teaching assistants (ITAs) whose oral skills are assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the ITA Exam or previous ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Classroom interaction skills for International Teaching Assistants, with a focus on the language needed to lead discussions and make presentations. Open to International Teaching Assistants only. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Language Tutorial for International Teaching Assistants
ALI.description: Individualized tutorial on the language and oral skills used by  International Teaching Assistants in the performance of his or her  duties.  Based on observation and feedback.  Open to International  Teaching Assistants only.  Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Academic and Professional Spoken English
ALI.description: Required for International Teaching Assistants (ITAs) who, after taking the ITA Oral Interview Exam, are determined to need the particular skills taught in this course.

ALI.title: Writing for Publication and Dissertations
ALI.description: Elective course for international graduate students focusing on conventions of advanced academic writing and problems in syntax, vocabulary, and register for writing and/or publishing dissertations. Graded CR/NC.

ARAB.title: Arabic I
ARAB.description: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic: Development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills in contemporary cultural contexts. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 122)

ARAB.title: Arabic II
ARAB.description: Continuation of Arabic I. Prerequisite: ARAB-122. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 152)

ARAB.title: Arabic III
ARAB.description: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic. Continued development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prerequisite: ARAB 152. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 222)

ARAB.title: Advanced Arabic I
ARAB.description: Advanced expression in written and spoken Arabic, including reading of original texts, understanding different registers, and exposure to modern Arabic cultures.

EASC.title: East Asian Societies
EASC.description: Main patterns of change in modern China, Japan, and Korea;historical framework and the insights of geography, economics,political science, and other disciplines.

EASC.title: Korean Studies Research Seminar
EASC.description: An advanced undergraduate seminar that joins mentoring in the development of Korea-related research with seminar-style instruction on key issues in Korean history, culture and society.

EASC.title: East Asian Garden and Designed Landscape
EASC.description: Explores the transmigration of Japanese art and aesthetics and the politics of their adaptation and assimilation in Los Angeles.

EASC.title: Directed Research
EASC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EASC.title: Honors Thesis
EASC.description: Writing the honors thesis: for East Asian Area Studies Honors majors.

EASC.title: Directed Research
EASC.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EASC.title: Proseminar on Issues and Trends in Contemporary East Asia
EASC.description: Introduction to graduate level study of policy issues and major trends in contemporary China, Japan, and Korea; contributions of various academic disciplines.

EASC.title: Master's Thesis
EASC.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EASC.title: Master's Thesis
EASC.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EASC.title: Master's Thesis
EASC.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EASC.title: Research Methods and Prospectus Writing
EASC.description: Research skills to launch a specific research project, usually a master's thesis.

EASC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
EASC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

BISC.title: Cellular and Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Cellular and molecular biology with examples related to human biology and diseases. Fundamental life processes examined at the genetic, cellular and molecular levels.

BISC.title: Humans and Their Environment
BISC.description: An examination of the physical and biological laws that influence agriculture, pollution, population dynamics (including humans), climate, biodiversity and ecosystem structure and function. Not available for major credit.

BISC.title: How the Body Works
BISC.description: Structure and function of the human body, including the role of organ systems, tissues, and cells in normal function. Malfunctions resulting from disease, substance abuse and lifestyle. Not available for major credit.

BISC.title: Special Laboratory I
BISC.description: Laboratory component for BISC 120 for entering freshmen or  transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

BISC.title: Special Laboratory II
BISC.description: Laboratory component for BISC 220 for entering freshmen or  transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

BISC.title: General Biology: Organismal Biology and Evolution
BISC.description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of the diversity of life and evolution; origin of life; eukaryotes/prokaryotes; ecology.

BISC.title: Advanced General Biology: Organismal Biology and Evolution
BISC.description: Equivalent to 120Lg, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.

BISC.title: The Nature of Human Health and Disease
BISC.description: The human organism; the nature of inherited and acquired diseases;the biological and societal basis for the AIDS epidemic; therapy,drug design and the future. Not available for major credit.

BISC.title: Introduction to Research I
BISC.description: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors.

BISC.title: General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC.description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of cellular biology and physiology; cell composition/metabolism; gene action; organism structure and function. Recommended preparation: high school chemistry; BISC 120L or BISC 121L.

BISC.title: The Biology of the Brain
BISC.description: Exploration of the unique properties of brain cells that allow complex perceptions and behaviors; examination of structure and activity of brain cells that underlie function.

BISC.title: Introduction to Biological Research
BISC.description: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member.

BISC.title: Cell Culture
BISC.description: Modern biological research laboratory cell culture techniques with an emphasis on mammalian systems; topics include in-vitro cell growth requirements, cryopreservation and transfected DNA expression.

BISC.title: Introduction to Ecology
BISC.description: Organism-environment interactions; dynamics of populations, communities, and ecosystems; evolutionary forces.

BISC.title: Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Structure and synthesis of nucleic acids and proteins; molecular biology of prokaryotes and eukaryotes; principles of genetics and cell biology.

BISC.title: Genetics
BISC.description: Transmission genetics and genotype/phenotype; mapping methods; complex traits; genetics of human disease and population genetics.

BISC.title: Biochemistry
BISC.description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.

BISC.title: Bioethics
BISC.description: Analysis of bioethical dilemmas using classical and contemporary readings in moral reasoning; examination of the ethical, social, legal and business policies associated with health issues.

BISC.title: Phylogenetics and Evolution
BISC.description: Underlying biological philosophies of systematics and phylogenetic algorithms used to infer phylogenetic relationships between organisms. Interpretation and production of cladograms and phylogenetic trees.

BISC.title: Cell Biology
BISC.description: Introduction to the experiments, theories and knowledge of modern cell biology; analysis of cutting-edge research papers; focused on organelles, signaling, cytoskeleton and the cell cycle.

BISC.title: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
BISC.description: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.

BISC.title: Advanced Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Molecular mechanisms and control of DNA replication, DNA repair,   recombination, gene expression, cell growth, and development in    prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms, from bacteria to humans.  Recommended preparation: BISC 313 or BISC 325

BISC.title: Biotechnology
BISC.description: Techniques in molecular biology and biochemistry applied to  prokaryotic and eukaryotic model systems; applications of  recombinant DNA and genomic technology. Recommended preparation:  BISC 313 or BISC 325

BISC.title: Neurobiology
BISC.description: Structure, function, and development of nervous systems; neural integration and mechanisms of behavior; organization and operation of brains.

BISC.title: Nutritional Biochemistry
BISC.description: Metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, fats. Biochemical basis of nutrition's impact on metabolic functions, including vitamins, minerals and biologically active non-nutrients; medical aspects of nutrition.

BISC.title: Practical Analysis of Biological Data in R
BISC.description: Instruction in the open-source statistical program environment R to analyze biological data; manipulation of large datasets and customization of statistical tests using simulations.

BISC.title: Principles of Immunology
BISC.description: Immune processes, humoral and cellular; immunoglobulins; antibody formation; antigen-antibody interactions; immune dyscrasias; transplantation and tumor immunology; basic hematology and immuno-hematology. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

BISC.title: CEED Seminar Series
BISC.description: Topical seminar in marine and environmental biology.  Junior,  senior or graduate standing.

BISC.title: The Cellular Basis of Learning and Memory
BISC.description: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.

BISC.title: Systems Neuroscience: From Foundational Studies to Today
BISC.description: Topical seminar in neurobiology.

BISC.title: Biological Oceanography
BISC.description: Biological, physical, chemical dynamics and analysis of the ocean; primary production of phytoplankton, secondary production by zooplankton, bacterial remineralization; physiology, ecology of fishes, marine mammals.

BISC.title: Regenerative Medicine: Principles, Paradigms and Practice
BISC.description: Examination of molecular and cellular processes that generate, maintain and repair body systems. Special emphasis on stem cell biology with clinical applications to regenerative medicine.

BISC.title: Directed Research
BISC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Honors Seminar
BISC.description: Opportunity to gain experience in experimental biological research and analysis and develop the ability to communicate scientific ideas effectively. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Honors Thesis
BISC.description: Research and writing of an honors thesis under faculty supervision. Opportunity to provide leadership and mentoring for BISC 493 students. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry
BISC.description: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

BISC.title: Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Rotation of graduate students through molecular biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Evolution and Human Biology
BISC.description: Topics in evolution and human biology with emphasis on lifespan, form, function and energy use in the context of genetics, natural selection and ecology

BISC.title: Advanced Seminar in Remote Sensing and Modeling
BISC.description: Modern oceanographic methods for making remote measurements of  aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems using satellite imagery and  other means.  Integrating these data into models that describe  ecosystem structure and enable interpretation of ecosystem  function.

BISC.title: Introduction to Scientific Journal Writing
BISC.description: Development of the skills needed to complete a well-written, correctly formatted literature review or original research paper suitable for journal publication.

BISC.title: Advanced Reading in Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Advanced training for molecular biology graduate students in reading primary journal articles. Emphasis on critical analyses of primary scientific literature.

BISC.title: Hypothesis Design and Scientific Writing
BISC.description: Introduction to grant writing with a focus on scientific health-related fields; hypothesis design, figure construction and clear, concise writing.

BISC.title: Seminar in Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
BISC.description: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.

BISC.title: Readings in Marine and Environmental Biology
BISC.description: Instruction in the critical reading and reviewing of scientific  papers from recently published peer-reviewed articles; practice in development and delivery of scientific presentations.

BISC.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BISC.description: Hands-on introduction to basic bioinformatics skills, software and analysis pipelines for biologists with minimal to no prior command line experience.

BISC.title: Directed Research
BISC.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Practicum in Teaching the Biological Sciences
BISC.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

BISC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
BISC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

BISC.title: Research
BISC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Creative Writing for Non-Majors
ENGL.description: Introductory workshop in writing poetry, short fiction and nonfiction for love of the written and spoken word. Not for English major credit. Not for English major or English (Creative Writing) major credit.

ENGL.title: Los Angeles: the City, the Novel, the Movie
ENGL.description: An exploration of the culture, vibrance, heritage, mythology, variety, and pathology of a city that was born in hopes and captured the worlds imagination. Duplicates credit in ARLT 101g.

ENGL.title: Shakespeare and His Times
ENGL.description: Close study of Shakespeare's plays and poems to introduce his language, stagecraft, literary "genius," social and literary contexts, precursors and rivals, and legacy.

ENGL.title: Literary Arts
ENGL.description: Introduction to theory and practice of literary study.

ENGL.title: English Literature to 1800
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of major writers to 1800.

ENGL.title: English Literature since 1800
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of major writers, 1800-1950.

ENGL.title: American Literature
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of representative writers.

ENGL.title: Studying Narrative
ENGL.description: Introduction to major forms, styles and theories of narrative, with attention to characterization, plot, genres, ethics, empathy, perspective, audience and social conditions.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Narrative Medicine
ENGL.description: Study of literary modes of narrative and their uses in medical understanding, character formation, social identity, and relations between mind and body.

ENGL.title: Introduction to the Genre of Fiction
ENGL.description: An introduction to the close reading of fiction and the understanding of the genre as an aesthetic and historical phenomenon.

ENGL.title: Introduction to the Genre of Poetry
ENGL.description: Historical survey of the traditions of lyric poetry from Shakespeare to the contemporary, examining the genre's multiple forms of literary, visual, and aural expression.

ENGL.title: Writing Narrative
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing narrative in fiction and literary non-fiction

ENGL.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing prose fiction.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing poetry.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction
ENGL.description: Techniques and practice of creative nonfiction writing, including genres such as lyric essay, memoir, personal narrative and/or scientific, medical, nature, culinary and travel writing.

ENGL.title: Editing for Writers
ENGL.description: Practical course in relations between editing and the creative process in fiction, poetry, and exposition

ENGL.title: Pre-Modern Wonders: Magic, Monsters and Marvels
ENGL.description: A study of literature and literary theory through the themes and theories of wonder, magic and the uncanny in English literature before 1800.

ENGL.title: Women in English and American Literature after 1800
ENGL.description: Women as writers and as subjects, with special emphasis on feminist and liberationist traditions and on changing female images after 1800.

ENGL.title: Sexual/Textual Diversity
ENGL.description: Questions of gay and lesbian identity, expression and experience in a variety of literary and cultural forms; emphasis on sexual politics, equality and difference.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Prose
ENGL.description: Study of prose written in English since 1945, principally fiction of the past two decades.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Poetry
ENGL.description: Study of poetry written in English since 1945, with special emphasis on the last two decades.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Drama
ENGL.description: Selected British, Irish, and American drama from the post World War II period (1945 to the present).

ENGL.title: Literary Genres and Film
ENGL.description: Literary studies in the relationship between fiction and drama and their adaptation as films.

ENGL.title: Literature and Related Arts
ENGL.description: An examination of how literature and related arts intersect in a particular cultural milieu. Selected topics.

ENGL.title: Fiction Writing
ENGL.description: A practical course in composition of prose fiction.

ENGL.title: Poetry Writing
ENGL.description: A practical course in poetry writing.

ENGL.title: Advanced Fiction Writing
ENGL.description: Prerequisite: English 405 and/or consent of instructor.

ENGL.title: English Literature of the 17th Century
ENGL.description: Selected studies of prose and poetry in the age of Bacon, Donne,   Jonson, Herbert, Browne, Marvell, and Milton.

ENGL.title: Shakespeare
ENGL.description: Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.

ENGL.title: American Literature to 1865
ENGL.description: American poetry and prose to the Civil War with special attention to Irving, Cooper, Poe, Hawthorne, Emerson, Thoreau, Melville, and Whitman.

ENGL.title: Aesthetic Philosophy and Theory
ENGL.description: Introduction to philosophical and critical writings on the nature  of art and aesthetic experience.  Special attention to  technology's impact on art.

ENGL.title: Directed Research
ENGL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENGL.title: Senior Seminar in Literary Studies
ENGL.description: Selected problems in literary history and criticism.

ENGL.title: Narrative Studies Capstone Seminar
ENGL.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development as a senior capstone experience in the study of narrative.

ENGL.title: Writ in Water: A Creative Writing Lab on Catalina Island
ENGL.description: Studies in the works of one or more authors, or in the development of a theme or genre.

ENGL.title: History of Literary and Cultural Theory
ENGL.description: The assumptions and practices of major theorists and theoretical schools from Plato to literary modernism.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Literary and Cultural Theory
ENGL.description: The assumptions and practices of major post-modern theorists and theoretical schools.

ENGL.title: Literatures and Cultures of the Romantic Period
ENGL.description: Studies in British literature and culture, from the 1790s to  1830s, including gender and genre, authorship and authenticity,  "romance" and revolution, forms of belief and doubt, and other  topics.

ENGL.title: 19th Century British Literatures and Cultures
ENGL.description: Studies in the Romantics and Victorians, gender and genre, the new woman and the novel, authorship and the marketplace, science, imperialism, the crisis of narrative, and other topics.

ENGL.title: Directed Research
ENGL.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Literary Editing and Publishing
ENGL.description: Comprehensive introduction to the MA degree and its range of study, focusing on elements of the craft of editing and the literary marketplace.

ENGL.title: The Editorial Experience: The Craft of Publication
ENGL.description: An intensive workshop in applied English, coordinating literary analysis with editing and publication, including relationships with authors; academic and trade presses; journals; editing and design.

ENGL.title: A Literary-Editorial Focus
ENGL.description: Topics on literary and popular forms: profile portrait; science writing; food writing; place and travel; memoir; and personal essay; with venues for publication.

ENGL.title: The Literary Landscape: Digital Toolkit
ENGL.description: Introduction to skill sets needed to enter the profession; development of student interests as they fit in the literary landscape.

ENGL.title: Internship in Editing and Publishing: Eloquence and Ethics
ENGL.description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.

ENGL.title: Individual Writers
ENGL.description: Studies of major and minor, canonic and non-canonic writers.

ENGL.title: Studies in Genre
ENGL.description: History, transformation, and theory of genre; studies in epic, lyric, drama, comedy, tragedy, the novel, biography, essay, and other forms.

ENGL.title: The Politics of Everyday Life
ENGL.description: Explores the way film has been theorized in relationship to traditional media that preceded it and electronic media that followed.

ENGL.title: Graduate Nonfiction Form and Theory
ENGL.description: Study of conventional and experimental works of creative nonfiction, from memoir to poetry, criticism and scholarship, focusing on issues of form, ethics, style and audience.

ENGL.title: Graduate Poetry Writing Workshop
ENGL.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level poetry writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

ENGL.title: Graduate Fiction Writing Workshop
ENGL.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level fiction writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

ENGL.title: Graduate Poetry Form and Theory
ENGL.description: Seminar. Studies in poetry form and function or critical theory.

ENGL.title: Academic Writing: Journal Articles and Dissertation Chapters
ENGL.description: Academic writing workshop focused on producing dissertation chapters and revising seminar papers for publication.

ENGL.title: Research
ENGL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. GRADED CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit upon acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

COLT.title: On Location: The Place of Literature in Global Cultures
COLT.description: Comparative study of works from a broad range of cultural traditions that originate from, and provide insight into, vital global locations outside the Western sphere.

COLT.title: Literature and Thought of the West Since 1800
COLT.description: Survey of literary and other cultural texts from the 19th to the 21st centuries, with emphasis on the individual and social change.

COLT.title: Medicine, Health and the Body in Literature and Culture
COLT.description: Study of health, the body and medicine through literature and culture in comparative fashion. Taught in English.

COLT.title: Introduction to Literary Theory
COLT.description: Introduction to general forms of reflection on literary discourse.

COLT.title: Fictions of Africa
COLT.description: Introduction to African cultural history by way of a comparative study of major literary works and intellectual thought from representative regions and countries in Africa.

COLT.title: Women Writers in Europe and America
COLT.description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social and cultural contexts.

COLT.title: Gender and Sexuality in Literary Theory
COLT.description: Literary representations and theories of gender difference. Examines questions of gendered voice in writing and the cultural construction of gender in various periods and cultures.

COLT.title: Zen and Daoism in Asian Literature
COLT.description: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Daoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.

COLT.title: Theories and Theorists
COLT.description: Introduction to important trends in recent French philosophy, political and social theory, psychoanalysis, ethnology, semiotics, and media studies. Emphasis to be determined by department. Conducted in English.

COLT.title: The Fantastic
COLT.description: Representative works from the "fantastic" and related currents within the European, U.S., and Spanish American traditions; reading of texts by authors such as Borges, Cortazar, Kafka, and Poe. Discussion of relevant theoretical concepts and critical works.

COLT.title: Dante
COLT.description: Analysis of the Divina Commedia and other works. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 450)

COLT.title: Aesthetic Philosophy and Theory
COLT.description: Introduction to philosophical and critical writings on the nature  of art and aesthetic experience.  Special attention to  technology's impact on art.

COLT.title: Directed Research
COLT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

COLT.title: Senior Honors Thesis
COLT.description: Writing of an honors thesis under individual faculty supervision.

COLT.title: Literary and Cinematic Translingualism and Translation
COLT.description: Introduces key debates regarding translingualism and translation in postcolonial, comparative, and cross-cultural literary and cinematic contexts

COLT.title: Teaching Practicum for Graduate Students
COLT.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife college.

COLT.title: Seminar in Literary Theory
COLT.description: Intensive study of a theoretical tradition or critical movement, or of an individual topic or thinker, in literary criticism or theory.

ENST.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies
ENST.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in environmental studies. Provides students with an overview of how government agencies and societal institutions address (or fail to address) the interrelated social and scientific aspects of environmental problems and policies.

ENST.title: Environmental Issues in Society
ENST.description: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.

ENST.title: Climate Change:  Science, History and Solutions
ENST.description: History and science of anthropogenic climate change; climate dynamics; carbon cycle; climate modeling; fossil fuel economy; climate denial and political tactics; group research of solutions.

ENST.title: Water and Soil Sustainability: Energy and Air Sustainability
ENST.description: Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.

ENST.title: Water and Soil Sustainability: Energy and Air Sustainability
ENST.description: Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.

ENST.title: Environmental Ethics
ENST.description: Explores issues concerning behavior of humans towards the nonhuman world. Examines a wide spectrum of ethical issues.

ENST.title: Public Policy for Sustainability
ENST.description: Through case studies, discussions and hands-on exercises, students develop skills in policy analysis and communication, learning to assess, interpret and effectively convey environmental policy issues.

ENST.title: Economics for Natural Resources and the Environment
ENST.description: An introduction to the economic tools and issues that affect natural resource use and environmental management.

ENST.title: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
ENST.description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.

ENST.title: Public Engagement for Nature Conservation
ENST.description: An exploration of the science behind public engagement for biodiversity conservation, climate resilience and humanity's sense of health and vitality.

ENST.title: Sustainable Aquaculture and Food Security
ENST.description: Assessing the potential for aquaculture, the fastest growing component of food production systems, to contribute to food security goals while maintaining environmental, social and economic sustainability.

ENST.title: Environmental Politics
ENST.description: The political realities of selected environmental issues; resolving and implementing social priorities; interests, attitudes, strategies, and tactics of pressure groups; institutional biases and opportunities.

ENST.title: Global Climate Negotiations: Research and Communication
ENST.description: An immersive course in qualitative field research, justice-based policy analysis and effective climate communication through study of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change negotiations.

ENST.title: Environmental Hydrogeology
ENST.description: Concepts in hydrogeology and application to environmental problems. Topics include groundwater and surface water hydrology, chemistry, and contamination. Includes labs, guest lectures, and field trips. Recommended preparation: GEOL 105, GEOL 160, or equivalent.

ENST.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ENST.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural   resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air,      water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct         regulation.

ENST.title: Directed Research
ENST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENST.title: Directed Environmental Policy and Science Internship
ENST.description: Provides opportunities for professional development in environmental policy and science and prepares students for career or graduate school in environmental-related fields. Students are placed in internships and guided before and during the internship period and gain practical experience and learn how government and nongovernmental organizations pursue and implement environmental policy and science work.

ENST.title: Senior Seminar in Environmental Studies
ENST.description: Students form multidisciplinary teams and are asked to study and resolve a major environmental problem facing a particular region or target population.

ENST.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Environmental Studies
ENST.description: Students will develop advanced skills to address complex environmental issues that society faces today. Different approaches for studying environmental processes and resources will be examined.

ENST.title: California Coastal Zone Science and Policy
ENST.description: Science and policy issues used to characterize and manage California coastal resources. Key issues include: coastal pollution, public health, ecosystem management, and marine reserves. Recommended preparation: ENST-500.

ENST.title: Directed Research
ENST.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EALC.title: Conversational Chinese and Intercultural Communication
EALC.description: Basic Mandarin conversational skills for effective communication in familiar, everyday Chinese contexts and better understanding of intercultural communication through content-based language acquisition. Graded CR/NC. Not available for credit to East Asian Area Studies, East Asian Languages and Cultures, and East Asian Studies majors and minors.

EALC.title: Language, Art and Culture: Calligraphy
EALC.description: This course introduces students to the origin of the basic  components of Chinese scripts and the basic principles and styles  of calligraphy.

EALC.title: Chinese I
EALC.description: The sound system of modern Chinese; aural comprehension, oral expression, basic patterns, and writing system.

EALC.title: Chinese II
EALC.description: Dialogue practice and conversation; reading of simple stories and essays; comparison of Chinese and English grammar; writing of paragraphs.

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Chinese
EALC.description: Develops reading fluency in Chinese through the Extensive Reading method, emphasizing large-volume reading with minimal unfamiliar vocabulary to build comprehension and enjoyment.

EALC.title: East Asian Humanities: The Great Tradition
EALC.description: Introduction to the major humanities traditions of China, Japan, and Korea through an examination of representative works drawnfrom literature, aesthetics, philosophy, religion, and historicalwriting.

EALC.title: Korean I
EALC.description: Basic Korean conversation practice, aural comprehension, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing with Hangul (Korean alphabet).

EALC.title: Korean II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 115, basic conversation practice, aural comprehension, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing.

EALC.title: Japanese I
EALC.description: Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana (Japanese alphabetical systems) and some basic kanji (Chinese characters).

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Japanese I
EALC.description: Development of reading skill in Japanese for elementary level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native Japanese speakers.

EALC.title: Japanese II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 120.  Basic Japanese conversation practice,  basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing  Hiragana and Katakana and basic kanji.

EALC.title: Introduction to Chinese Culture, Art and Literature
EALC.description: Introduction to the civlization, art and literature of pre-modern China through the lens of the cultural products of identity.

EALC.title: Global Chinese Cinema and Cultural Studies
EALC.description: Examination of the transnational production and circulation of Chinese-language cinema. Analysis of the larger sociocultural significance of films by engaging their historical context.

EALC.title: Chinese III
EALC.description: Conversational practice: reading of stories and essays; writing of short essays.

EALC.title: Chinese IV
EALC.description: Continuation of 204, with emphasis on reading and writing, frequent interaction with native speakers.

EALC.title: Korean III
EALC.description: Drill to increase proficiency in dialogue, reading, and writing;  intermediate level readings.

EALC.title: Japanese III
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 122.  Conversation practice, basic to  intermediate grammar, and building proficiency of reading and  writing Hiragana and Katakana with additional kanji.

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Japanese II
EALC.description: Development of reading skills in Japanese for intermediate level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native speakers.

EALC.title: Japanese IV
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 220. More sophisticated grammar and  vocabulary for natural conversation. Enhancing fundamental reading  and writing skills, expanding the knowledge of kanji.

EALC.title: Advanced Modern Chinese I
EALC.description: Reading selections from different styles of modern Chinese        writings, analysis of stylistic techniques and syntactic           structure, composition, and translation.

EALC.title: Advanced Korean I
EALC.description: Advanced reading in modern Korean materials; improvements of      skills in conversation, composition, and translation.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese I
EALC.description: Strengthen intermediate Japanese language proficiency.  Oral/aural  communication skills as well as reading and writing skills.   Promote an understanding of the present-day Japanese culture.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 320.  Improve and strengthen abilities to  speak, listen, read and write, coping with more involved materials  and situation.

EALC.title: Japanese Literature and Culture
EALC.description: Japanese literature from the earliest times to the present; development of prose, poetry and the novel; evolution of theatre; Japanese literature under Western influence. Conducted in English.

EALC.title: Chinese Civilization
EALC.description: Highlights of Chinese civilization from ancient times to the present, both in their original historical context and how they influence China and the United Sates today.

EALC.title: Transnational Chinese Literature and Culture
EALC.description: An introduction to Sinophone literatures and cultures (in English translation) from the Asia-Pacific region, including Taiwan, Hong Kong, Tibet, Southeast Asia, and North America.

EALC.title: Chinese Professional Internship: Communication and Culture
EALC.description: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional, "real world" employment context.

EALC.title: Cultural Topics in East Asian Literature
EALC.description: Selected themes, genres, and periods in East Asian literature, e.g., Taoism and Buddhism, women, folktales.

EALC.title: Korean Studies Research Seminar
EALC.description: An advanced undergraduate seminar that joins mentoring in the development of Korea-related research with seminar-style instruction on key issues in Korean history, culture and society.

EALC.title: Chinese Through Literary Works and Texts
EALC.description: Designed to enhance students' advanced Chinese proficiency and deepen cultural insights through critical engagement with literary masterpieces and representative texts from modern China since 1919.

EALC.title: Business Chinese
EALC.description: Practice in the basic vocabulary and idioms of foreign trade and other commercial transactions in Mandarin. Prerequisite: EALC 306.

EALC.title: Korean Multiliteracy in Contemporary Contexts
EALC.description: Develop advanced literacy and intercultural competency through contemporary Korean literature and digital content from social media.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese III
EALC.description: Students develop advanced levels of Japanese linguistic knowledge  and communication skills through speaking, listening, reading and  writing activities using authentic Japanese texts and discourse.

EALC.title: Chinese Fiction
EALC.description: Development of Chinese fiction and readings from English translations of major Chinese novels such as the Dream of the Red Chamber, All Men Are Brothers, and others. Conducted in English.

EALC.title: East Asian Garden and Designed Landscape
EALC.description: Explores the transmigration of Japanese art and aesthetics and the politics of their adaptation and assimilation in Los Angeles.

EALC.title: Directed Research
EALC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EALC.title: Honors Thesis
EALC.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty  member.

EALC.title: Honors Thesis
EALC.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty  member.

EALC.title: Proseminar in Chinese Visual Culture
EALC.description: Chinese visual culture through the complex interface of art and thought. Examines architectural layout, pictorial representation, decorative motif as part of cultural production that intertwines with intellectual trends.

EALC.title: Directed Readings
EALC.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC.title: Directed Readings
EALC.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC.title: Directed Research
EALC.description: Research leading tothe Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied tothe degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EALC.title: Teaching Practicum for East Asian Studies
EALC.description: Enhances the teaching experience of teaching assistants in East Asian studies through a collaborative study of relevant pedagogical principles, resources, and techniques.

EALC.title: Master's Thesis
EALC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EALC.title: Master's Thesis
EALC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EALC.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.
