EALC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EALC.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH.title: Body, Mind and Healing: Introduction to Medical  Anthropology
ANTH.description: The body, illness and healing from a cultural perspective, including comparative studies of folk healing systems, curing rituals and Western biomedical practices.

ANTH.title: Mesoamerican Cosmovision and Culture
ANTH.description: An exploration of the nature and contributions of pre-Columbian high civilizations (Maya, Aztecs, etc.) and their descendants as they resist and assimilate to the modern world.

ANTH.title: The Human Animal
ANTH.description: Foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people. Laboratory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 200Lg.

ANTH.title: Introduction to Social and Cultural Anthropology
ANTH.description: Introduction to social and cultural anthropology, emphasizing the study of human values and social structures across diverse examples. Readings in ethnography and social analysis. Gateway course for the Anthropology Major.

ANTH.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
ANTH.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

ANTH.title: Global Media
ANTH.description: An anthropological approach to examine social and cultural practices of media production, circulation and consumption, engaging with a variety of multimedia.

ANTH.title: Introduction to Global Studies and Cross-cultural Research
ANTH.description: The effects of globalization on social life in diverse communities, approaching related issues from an ethnographic perspective. Gateway course for the Global Studies Major.

ANTH.title: Anthropology of the Environment
ANTH.description: Introduces students to anthropological inquiry into human relationships with the environment and provides foundational training in qualitative research methods to investigate environmental issues.

ANTH.title: Exploring Culture through Film
ANTH.description: Concepts of social anthropology, using filmic representations of societies throughout the world. Gateway course for the Anthropology major.

ANTH.title: Mindfulness and Culture
ANTH.description: Examine the concept of mindfulness as a cultural practice in various spiritual traditions and contemporary social settings. Mindfulness, or attentive awareness of the present moment.

ANTH.title: Shamans, Spirits and Ancestors: Non-Western Religious Tradit
ANTH.description: An intensive study of local systems of belief and knowledge in selected societies in the Pacific, Asia, Africa, the Caribbean and Latin America with emphasis on ideas of the spirit world.

ANTH.title: Evolution, Ecology, and Culture
ANTH.description: The roles of biology, culture, and the environment in shaping human society, integrating evolutionary biology and cultural theory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 300.

ANTH.title: Origins and Evolution of Human Behavior
ANTH.description: Examination of the evidence for and against evolutionary bases of a range of human behaviors. Topics include sex differences, human reproductive strategies, race, IQ, human ecology. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 308.

ANTH.title: Virtual and Digital Culture, Heritage and Archaeology
ANTH.description: In-depth exploration of 3D digital, immersive, virtual or extended reality visualizations of cultural heritage, archaeology, historical sites and artifacts, including their legal and ethical dimensions.

ANTH.title: Native Americans in American Public Life
ANTH.description: Role of Native Americans in American public life from colonial times to the present; Native American societies and governments and their relations to the U.S.

ANTH.title: Space, Place, Perception and Power
ANTH.description: The social construction of spaces, places, and landscapes and their reciprocal relationships to human embodied experiences, processes of identity formation and society.

ANTH.title: Anthropology and Narrative Medicine
ANTH.description: Exploration of illness, disability, and healing narratives, how narratives are culturally shaped, and their significance for western biomedical practices.

ANTH.title: Health, Gender and Ethnicity
ANTH.description: Cross-cultural notions of the body, health, and healing; historic and cultural variability of ideas of reproduction, birth, sexuality, mental illness and disability.

ANTH.title: Food in Culture and Society
ANTH.description: An introduction to the field of food studies, as a historical and cross-disciplinary study of the place of food in culture and society.

ANTH.title: Interpretation of Myth and Narrative
ANTH.description: Oral narratives from non-Western cultures; communications about deeply-held moral beliefs, psychological tensions, social problems, and the structure of the mind.

ANTH.title: Directed Internship
ANTH.description: Real-world work experience in an internship position, while also learning to apply anthropological theory and research methods to complete a related research project. Enrollment requires permission from department.

ANTH.title: Ethnographic Research Methods
ANTH.description: Survey of methods for acquiring and analyzing qualitative research data, emphasizing ethnographic methods for field research in Anthropology.

ANTH.title: Global Issues Seminar
ANTH.description: Advanced seminar on a key theme or topic in Global Studies selected by the instructor, with specific focus subject to change with each offering.

ANTH.title: History of Anthropological Theory
ANTH.description: Ideas about man, culture, and society which have formed the field of anthropology as a research discipline; present trends and problems.

ANTH.title: Cities of the Middle East
ANTH.description: An examination of the economic, political and cultural forces operating in a number of Middle Eastern cities.

ANTH.title: Directed Research
ANTH.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ANTH.title: Directed Research for Honors
ANTH.description: Individually guided research and readings culminating in the production of an honors thesis. prerequisite: 3.0 gpa; 201g plus 8 units of upper division ANTH courses.

ANTH.title: History and Foundations of Anthropology
ANTH.description: A brief critical introduction to the history of anthropological thought over the course of the discipline's long twentieth century, from the 1880s to the present.

ANTH.title: The Practice of Ethnography
ANTH.description: Major approaches to ethnographic fieldwork are explored in classic cases.

ANTH.title: Ethnofiction
ANTH.description: A hands-on approach to contemporary topics in ethnographic media arts and creative nonfiction cinema.

ANTH.title: Seminar in Ethnographic Film
ANTH.description: Survey of ethnographic film using both the dimensions of natural history descriptions and process, contrasted with naturalism and structuralism as tools of controlled comparison and analysis.

ANTH.title: Directed Research
ANTH.description: Research conducted at the master's or pre-PhD candidacy level. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded C/NC.

ANTH.title: Practicum for Teaching in Anthropology
ANTH.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within the discipline of Anthropology. Intended for teaching assistants in Anthropology.

ANTH.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
ANTH.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

ANTH.title: Infrastructure and the Environment
ANTH.description: An advanced introduction to anthropology of infrastructure and its relation to ecological concerns, with an emphasis on urban settings.

ANTH.title: Research
ANTH.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum number of units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ANTH.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ANTH.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ECON.title: Free People, Free Thought and Free Markets
ECON.description: The philosophical foundations of modern political and economic thought, including economic rationality, neoclassical economics, free-market vs. socialist economies and behavioral economics.

ECON.title: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON.description: Behavior of firms and consumers, functions of the price system, competition and monopoly, labor markets, poverty, government regulation, international trade, and the environment.

ECON.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON.description: Unemployment, inflation and output determination and links.Effects of government taxation and spending on growth, investment,saving, consumption, and trade.

ECON.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
ECON.description: Decision-making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.

ECON.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
ECON.description: The determinants of aggregate income, employment, and inflation; economic fluctuations; fiscal and monetary policy; financial markets; the national debt.

ECON.title: Introduction to Statistics for Economists
ECON.description: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.

ECON.title: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON.description: Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.

ECON.title: Economic Development of Sub-Saharan Africa
ECON.description: Contemporary economic problems of sub-Saharan economies: policies  and endowments.  Focus on issues of poverty, agriculture, health,  macroeconomy and political economy.

ECON.title: Microeconomics for Business
ECON.description: Development and business applications of: theory of the firm;      theory of the consumer; inter-temporaldecisions; decisions under   risk; market failures; industrial and enterprise structure.        Prerequisites: MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226. Not   for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social     Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 351.

ECON.title: Macroeconomics for Business
ECON.description: Theoretical development and significance to business and markets   of economic growth; inflation;unemployment; monetary and fiscal    policy; business cycles; savings and investment; exchange rates.   Corequisite: ECON 351. Recommended preparation: introductory       economics course, high school math, and algebra. Not for major     credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences      (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 352.

ECON.title: Money, Credit, and Banking
ECON.description: The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio     choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates;           inflation; interactions between financial markets and government   policies.

ECON.title: Urban Economics
ECON.description: Urban trends and problems, including changing urban form and      function, urban public finance, housing, renewal, poverty, race,   transportation, and the environment.

ECON.title: Economic Policy Issues
ECON.description: Selected policy dilemmas in economics. Topics vary.

ECON.title: Games and Economics
ECON.description: Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environment depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.

ECON.title: Experimental Economics
ECON.description: Examination of economic theories and patterns of behavior useful in building new theories. Prerequisite ECON-303; Recommended preparation: ECON-317.

ECON.title: International Trade
ECON.description: Determinants and economic consequences of international trade patterns; effects of trade restrictions and trading blocs; trade negotiations and arrangements.

ECON.title: International Finance
ECON.description: Consequences of trade deficits; theories of capital and currency markets, exchange rate regimes, and international monetary coordination.

ECON.title: Financial Markets
ECON.description: General equilibrium analysis of economics with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.

ECON.title: Economic Applications of Machine Learning
ECON.description: A capstone course that introduces state-of-the-art estimation methods for high-dimensional data.

ECON.title: The Principles of Market Design
ECON.description: Fundamental principles in designing successful market mechanisms to allocate resources.

ECON.title: Economic Consulting and Applied Managerial Economics
ECON.description: Economic consulting and managerial economic methods applied in real world problems. Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.

ECON.title: Topics in Philosophy, Politics and Economics
ECON.description: The analysis of public policy debates combining the different tools and perspectives of philosophy, political science and economic theory.

ECON.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ECON.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural   resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air,      water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct         regulation.

ECON.title: Directed Research
ECON.description: Supervised individual research. Not available for graduate credit. Requires departmental approval.

ECON.title: Honors Thesis
ECON.description: Individual research supervised by a faculty advisor. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.

ECON.title: Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON.description: Theories of the household and the firm; product and factor markets; perfect and imperfect competition; welfare criteria.

ECON.title: Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON.description: Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

ECON.title: Game Theory with Economic and Financial Applications
ECON.description: Applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. Witnessing the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.

ECON.title: Neurofinance
ECON.description: Investigate human behavior in Economics. Use neuroscience as a new lens on financial decision-making; focus on specific topics in behavioral and neuro-finance.

ECON.title: Practice of Econometrics
ECON.description: Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

ECON.title: Time Series Analysis
ECON.description: Understanding and implementing models commonly used in time series econometrics. Emphasis is placed on intuition and application. Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.

ECON.title: International Macroeconomics and Financial Policy
ECON.description: The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history.

ECON.title: Applied Trade Policy
ECON.description: Introduction and exploration of quantitative methods and data sources used for applied trade policy analysis.

ECON.title: Introduction to Market Design
ECON.description: Introduction to market design; combined use of economic theory, experiments and empirical analysis; analyze and engineer market rules and institutions.

ECON.title: Big Data Econometrics
ECON.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of causal econometrics in modern settings of large-scale data. Major algorithms from machine learning focused on methodology and applications.

ECON.title: Economics of Digital Platforms
ECON.description: Introduces the novel business model and important features associated with digital platforms and analyzes firms various competitive behavior and anticompetitive conducts in the digital space.

ECON.title: Foundations of Financial Economics
ECON.description: Broad training in theoretical and empirical finance. Choice under uncertainty; equilibrium asset pricing; static portfolio choice; factor pricing models, asset allocation; the Black-Scholes-Merton Formula.

ECON.title: Industrial Organization, Innovation and Applications
ECON.description: Explores topics in industrial organization by examining models of competitive, oligopolistic and monopolistic markets. Emphasizes innovation and technology through incentives, intellectual property rights, royalty rate determination and economic methods.

ECON.title: Economic Consulting and Applied Econometrics
ECON.description: Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value and consumer demand, using an applied econometric approach.

ECON.title: Advanced Economics Consulting and Antitrust Methods
ECON.description: Advanced methods used in applied economics and consulting. Topics are case based.

ECON.title: Directed Research
ECON.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
ECON.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Open only to doctoral students in Economics. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
ECON.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's  field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship  offer. Job must be related to students major. The internship must  be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually  supervised by faculty. Students must have been in F-1 student  status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program  before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course  does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.

ECON.title: Microeconomic Theory I
ECON.description: Optimization of the consumer and the firm; duality and imputed value; perfect and imperfect competition in product and factor markets.

ECON.title: Macroeconomic Theory I
ECON.description: Aggregate demand, supply and government policy; theories of economic growth and business cycles; static and dynamic implications of government policies.

ECON.title: Advanced Neuroeconomics
ECON.description: Advanced methodology of neuroeconomics including neural activity, memory, value and reward systems, emotions and risk.

ECON.title: Probability and Statistics for Economists
ECON.description: Introduction to probability theory and statistical inference to    prepare students for graduate courses in econometrics and economic theory; probability, random variables, distributions, estimation,  testing, asymptotics.

ECON.title: Economic and Financial Time Series I
ECON.description: Simultaneous equation models, dynamic structural econometric models, vector autoregressions, causality, forecasting, univariate and multivariate nonstationary time series, tests for unit roots, cointegration, autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity models, time series models with changes in regime. Prerequisite: ECON 609.

ECON.title: Experimental Methods I
ECON.description: Experimental methods of and design of computer-based experiments. Use of standard software for data collection in individual decision-making experiments and games.

ECON.title: Political Economy of Institutions
ECON.description: The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution. Prerequisites: ECON-500 or ECON-601.

ECON.title: Health Economics I
ECON.description: Techniques of microeconometric analysis to inform health policy. Topics include: demand for health, medical care, and insurance, risk selection, medical innovation.

ECON.title: Poverty, Human Resources and Economic Development
ECON.description: Household production models and intra-household models of behavior and their empirical implementation, focus on poverty, human resource investments and their interaction with public policies. Prerequisites: ECON 501 and ECON 609.

ECON.title: International Trade Theory
ECON.description: General equilibrium theory applied to theory and practice of commercial policy, economic growth, and trade. Prerequisites: ECON-500 or ECON-601.

ECON.title: Empirical Methods in Economics
ECON.description: Think about and design empirical studies in economics using cutting-edge approaches to causal inference -- experiments, quasi-experiments, non-parametrics and semi-parametrics.

ECON.title: Seminar in Economic Theory
ECON.description: Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Econometrics
ECON.description: Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Economic Development
ECON.description: Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Applied Economics and Public Policy
ECON.description: Current research in applied microeconomics, macroeconomics, and public policy presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Dynamic Economics
ECON.description: Topics in dynamic economics involving business fluctuations, economic growth and development, microeconomic adjustments and market mechanisms; related quantitative and qualitative methods; empirical research involving economic change. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Empirical Microeconomics Seminar
ECON.description: Presentations on current research in empirical microeconomics by  outstanding scholars from leading Economics departments and  faculty at USC.  Open only to Economics Ph.D. students.  Graded  CR/NC.

ECON.title: Applied Micro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Econometrics Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Macro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Micro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

FSEM.title: (W)rites of Passage--Navigating the Transition to College
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: Achieving Happiness and Balance Amid Uncertainty
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: China on the World Stage
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: Feeding the World Sustainably
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: How We Learn--Strategies for Surviving and Thriving
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: Interconnective Significance of Diet, Sleep, and Exercise    Health
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: Our Favorite Books
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: What are Earthquakes and Tsunamis All About?
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FSEM.title: Writing to be Read
FSEM.description: A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen;       limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4      units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.

FREN.title: French 120 Language Practicum
FREN.description: English grammar as it relates to French in order to improve students' French language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice. Requires concurrent enrollment in either FREN 120 French I or MPVA 261 French Language and Diction.

FREN.title: French 150 Language Practicum
FREN.description: English grammar as it relates to French in order to improve students French language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice.

FREN.title: French I
FREN.description: Introduction to current French. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

FREN.title: French II
FREN.description: Continuation of 120.

FREN.title: French III
FREN.description: Continuation of FREN 150.  Review of structural patterns of  French; selected cultural and literary readings; conversation and  composition.

FREN.title: Intermediate Conversational French
FREN.description: Designed for non-majors/minors interested in maintaining and developing French language competency. Builds vocabulary, ease of communication, and cultural knowledge through discussion of contemporary topics. Graded Credit/No Credit. Not available for credit to French majors. Not open to French majors.

FREN.title: French IV
FREN.description: Introduction to French literature through the study of texts and audiovisuals organized around a central theme; develops close-reading techniques and discursive skills; reviews French grammar.

FREN.title: Black Europe
FREN.description: Study of African migration to Europe and the formation of 'black'/African communities in Europe, focusing on France and Italy. Conducted in English.

FREN.title: Medicine, Health and the Body in Literature and Culture
FREN.description: Study of health, the body and medicine through literature and culture in comparative fashion. Taught in English.

FREN.title: French Grammar and Composition
FREN.description: Grammatical structure and vocabulary building with practical application to written composition. Prerequisites: FREN 250.

FREN.title: Critical Writing in French
FREN.description: Advanced composition through critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics. Prerequisite: FREN 300.

FREN.title: Race, Gender and Power in Francophone Literature
FREN.description: Study of post-colonialism as a ferment for literary creation in the literature of French expression from Africa, the Caribbean and Canada. Conducted in French.

FREN.title: French Foreign Policy: 1945 to the Present
FREN.description: Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy. (Paris semester only).

FREN.title: French Women Writers
FREN.description: Major figures and their roles in French society and contributions to French literature. Conducted in French. Corequisite: FREN 330.

FREN.title: Theories and Theorists
FREN.description: Introduction to important trends in recent French philosophy, political and social theory, psychoanalysis, ethnology, semiotics, and media studies. Emphasis to be determined by department. Conducted in English.

FREN.title: Studies in an Author
FREN.description: Close readings in works of a single influential French or Francophone author. Focused study of style, creative developments, historical context. Conducted in French. Prerequisite: FREN 330.

FREN.title: France and Islam
FREN.description: Historical and theoretical analyses of the complex history of Western perceptions of Islam, focusing on France.Taught in French. Prerequisites: FREN 330. Recommended preparation: REL 137g for Religion majors and minors.

FREN.title: Studies in French Civilization
FREN.description: (Paris Semester only) An analysis of the prestige of Paris, past   and present, based upon close examination of literary texts and    graphic materials, and visits to sites and monuments.  Recommended  preparation: FREN 300

FREN.title: Cultural Politics and Traditions
FREN.description: Selected topics such as the press, educational institutions, French cinema today, and French colonial history. Conducted in French.

FREN.title: Directed Research
FREN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

FREN.title: Pro-Seminar in French and Francophone Studies
FREN.description: Introduction to the field of French and Francophone studies, including the history of the field, critical research methodologies and contemporary issues in the profession.

FREN.title: Practicum in Teaching French
FREN.description: Introduction to the approaches and techniques of teaching French as a second language. Open only to Master and PhD students who will be Assistant Lecturers in French.

GEOL.title: Planet Earth
GEOL.description: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles ofplate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountainbuilding, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism,development of landforms by running water and glaciers. Lecture, 3hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or two-day field triprequired.

GEOL.title: Oceanography
GEOL.description: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans andocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents.Economic value of the oceans. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day field trip required.

GEOL.title: Climate Change
GEOL.description: Exploration of factors that influence climate and the scientific basis for concern about rising greenhouse gases, the threat to human society know as global warming.

GEOL.title: Introduction to Geosystems
GEOL.description: Survey of natural geological/ environmental processes (systems) and variability active near the earth's surface in the region that houses most life (the biosphere).

GEOL.title: Earthquakes
GEOL.description: Causes of earthquakes and nature of large faults; earthquake hazard and risk; world's great earthquakes; understanding the Richter scale. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours; one fieldtrip required.

GEOL.title: Tba
GEOL.description: Laboratory component for GEOL 105Lg, 107Lxg, 108Lg, 125Lxg,  130Lxg, 150Lxg, or 240Lxg for students with equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

GEOL.title: Surficial Processes and Stratigraphic Systems
GEOL.description: Processes of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition that      shape the land surface; landscape response to tectonism;           recognition and interpretation of depositional environments in the stratigraphic record.

GEOL.title: Data Analysis in the Earth and Environmental     Sciences
GEOL.description: Introduction to mathematical methods giving insight into Earth and  Environmental data. Topics include: probability and statistics, timeseries analysis, spectral analysis, inverse theory,  interpolation.  Recommended Preparation: MATH 126, familiarity  with matrix algebra.

GEOL.title: Introduction to Field Techniques
GEOL.description: Introduction to field techniques used in a variety of Earth Science disciplines. Field and digital techniques for map making including use of GIS, GPS, and digital tablets. Field analyses of rocks and rock structures. Map interpretation and digital processing of field data. Includes weekly labs and some weekend field trips.

GEOL.title: Environmental Hydrogeology
GEOL.description: Concepts in hydrogeology and application to environmental problems. Topics include groundwater and surface water hydrology, chemistry, and contamination. Includes labs, guest lectures, and field trips. Recommended preparation: GEOL 105, GEOL 160, or equivalent.

GEOL.title: Directed Research
GEOL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GEOL.title: Senior Thesis
GEOL.description: Writing of a thesis under individual faculty supervision.  Not  available for graduate credit.

GEOL.title: Paleobiology
GEOL.description: Concepts and methods for functional morphologic analysis of       fossil marine invertebrates. Systematics theory and methodology,   macroevolution, and broad biotic trends in the Phanerozoic.        Prerequisite: 333L recommended.  Recommended preparation:  GEOL-333L

GEOL.title: Practical Carbonate Chemistry
GEOL.description: In-depth review of carbonate chemistry, aqueous and solid phase; speciation, calculations of carbonate parameters, carbonate biogeochemistry, sedimentary diagenesis and sedimentary records.

GEOL.title: Isotope Geochemistry
GEOL.description: Variations in the isotopic composition of elements in the earth's crust with applications to geological problems, including          geochronology, geothermometry, ore genesis, and crustal evolution.

GEOL.title: Geochemistry Seminar
GEOL.description: Current topics in geochemistry.

GEOL.title: Directed Research
GEOL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GEOL.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
GEOL.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GEOL.title: Earth Sciences Colloquium
GEOL.description: Exploration of prominent topics at the frontiers of research in  the geosciences, through weekly talks presented by leading  researchers in the field. Specific topics vary by semester.

GEOL.title: Seminar in Earthquake Physics
GEOL.description: Current research on the physics governing earthquakes and faults, including results from continuum and fracture mechanics, statistical physics, lab experiments and seismological observations.

GEOL.title: Research
GEOL.description: Research leading to the doctorate.  Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GERM.title: German I
GERM.description: Introduction to modern German. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension. Basic structures necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

GERM.title: German II
GERM.description: Continuation of German I. Introduction to German culture. Prerequisite: 101.

GERM.title: German III, Conversation and Composition
GERM.description: Intermediate German. Increasing emphasis on listening and speaking skills and a review of basic structures of German. Discussion of cultural aspects. Prerequisite: 101 and 102.

GERM.title: Conversational German IV
GERM.description: Conversational German in a variety of topical settings and vocabulary domains. Prerequisite: 3rd semester German or equivalent.

GR.title: Greek II
GR.description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary, continued.   Basic reading skills.

GR.title: Homer and the Greek Epic
GR.description: Selections from the Iliad and/or Odyssey. Problems of oral composition and transmission.

AMST.title: Race and Class in Los Angeles
AMST.description: Analysis of race and the economic, political, gender, and social dimensions of contemporary Los Angeles including topics such as residential segregation, economic inequality, and city politics.

AMST.title: Peoples and Cultures of the Americas
AMST.description: An introduction to cultures and people in the Americas; the social, historical, economic and cultural formations that together make up the Latino/a American imaginary.

AMST.title: The American War in Viet Nam
AMST.description: Examination of the ways that different nations and cultures have remembered the Vietnam War or the American War as it is called in Vietnam. (Duplicates credit in former AMST 377)

AMST.title: Introduction to American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Introduction to American studies and ethnic studies. Provides an overview of major theories, concepts, and issues.

AMST.title: LGBTQ America
AMST.description: Examines how U.S. sexual identity and experience are represented in the 20th and 21st century and introduces the interdisciplinary field of LGBTQ Studies.

AMST.title: Introduction to American Popular Culture
AMST.description: Examines the relation between U.S. national culture, race, and popular culture.

AMST.title: The Politics and Culture of the 1960s
AMST.description: Examines political and cultural change in the United States during the decade of the 1960s.

AMST.title: Black Social Movements in the U.S.
AMST.description: This course examines black social movements for freedom, justice, equality, and self determination. Beginning with Reconstruction, movements include labor, civil rights, radical feminism, socialism, reparations, Black Nationalism, prisoners' rights, and Hip Hop.

AMST.title: Exploring Ethnicity through Film
AMST.description: Examination of the constructions of American ethnicity/race in film.

AMST.title: America, the Frontier, and the New West
AMST.description: Introduction to an interdisciplinary study of American political, cultural and social life with a particular emphasis on the Western United States as a region. Recommended preparation: HIST 200, ENGL 263

AMST.title: Latinx Media Studies
AMST.description: Introduces students to critical analyses of media texts, industries and technologies that shape the lives of Latinx communities in the United States.

AMST.title: Asian American Politics
AMST.description: Examines political attitudes, behavior and participation of Asian  Americans in diverse U.S. society.

AMST.title: Food, Health and Culture in Los Angeles
AMST.description: Examination of Los Angeles diverse food cultures as well as the food justice issues that affect many low-income residents of neighborhoods surrounding USC campus.

AMST.title: Law and American Indian Studies
AMST.description: Examines indigenous sovereignties and the historical andcontemporary legal histories and cases which inform them.

AMST.title: Junior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity: Theories and Methods
AMST.description: Advanced study in interdisciplinary theories and methods for  analyzing race and ethnicity in the United Stes, including a  comparative study of topics such as inequality, gender, and class.

AMST.title: Leadership in the Community -- Internship
AMST.description: 8-10 hours per week in a community-based internship plus 2 hour  class discussion.  Theoretical and practical issues associated  with community leadership.

AMST.title: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Communities
AMST.description: Survey of current social and political issues facing Asian         American communities with emphasis on Los Angeles region; design   and implementation of community-based research projects.

AMST.title: Jews in American Popular Culture
AMST.description: Social and cultural history of American Jewish contributions to the arts, science, literature, economics and politics.

AMST.title: Undergraduate Research Methods
AMST.description: Examination of processes of scholarly research; quantitative and qualitative research methods; faculty mentorship; experiential learning; research proposal writing; careers in research. Sophomore or junior standing in the major. Departmental approval.

AMST.title: Social Media Storytelling for Latinx Audiences
AMST.description: Create native journalistic content for current social media and emerging platforms with an emphasis on engaging content for Latinx audiences and underrepresented communities.

AMST.title: Latina/o Screen Cultures
AMST.description: Examination of Latino/a moving image production including film, video, and digital media in the context of the politics of race, class, gender, sexuality, and international relations.

AMST.title: Political Participation and American Diversity
AMST.description: Examines how diverse groups in the U.S. interact with the American  political system.

AMST.title: Directed Research
AMST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AMST.title: Research Methods in American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Develop research proposal, methods and research for a thesis or capstone project for students in American Studies and Ethnicity, American Popular Culture or related fields.

AMST.title: Introduction to American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: An exploration of themes, theoretical influences, and  methodological approaches current in American studies and ethnic  studies.  Open to first-year graduate students in American Studies  and Ethnicity only.

AMST.title: Archives and Subcultures
AMST.description: Introduction to the practice of archival research with an emphasis  on the literary and historical methods of documenting subcultural  groups, particularly racial and sexual minorities.

AMST.title: Readings in Chicano/Latino History
AMST.description: Readings, analyses, and discussion of various approaches, topics,  and genres in the field of Chicano/Latino history.

AMST.title: The Practice of Ethnography
AMST.description: Major approaches to ethnographic fieldwork are explored in classic cases.

AMST.title: Directed Research
AMST.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the program.  Graded  CR/NC.

AMST.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts: American Studies
AMST.description: Practical principles for the long term development of effective teaching within college disciplines, intended for teaching assistants in American Studies and Ethnicity. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in MDA 593)

AMST.title: Latinx Writing Lab
AMST.description: Leads graduate students in Latinx Studies in developing or revising a dissertation or masters thesis chapter, or research seminar paper, or adapting manuscripts for publication.

AMST.title: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Cultural Studies
AMST.description: Explores theoretical approaches to cultural studies as an  interdisciplinary field and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper. Recommended  preparation: graduate reading course in cultural studies

AMST.title: Theories and Practices of Professional Development
AMST.description: Offers students a structured environment in which to write their  dissertation proposals and focuses on professional development.   Completion of qualifying exam.  Graded CR/NC.

AMST.title: Research
AMST.description: Research leading to the doctorate.  Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASTR.title: The Universe
ASTR.description: Survey of the universe: planets, satellites, comets, stars, nebulae, galaxies. Practical component includes planetary observations and dark-sky field trip. Not available for major credit.

ASTR.title: Special Laboratory
ASTR.description: Laboratory component for ASTR 100Lxg for transfer students with  equivalent lecture credit from another institution.  For transfer  students only.  Departmental approval.  Graded CR/NC.

ASTR.title: The Universe for Astronomy Majors
ASTR.description: Introduction to the physical characteristics and structure of the Universe, with detailed discussions and labs emphasizing the underlying physics and mathematics.

ASTR.title: Life in the Universe
ASTR.description: Survey of the prospects for life in our solar system and beyond, based on the evolution of life on Earth.

ASTR.title: The Solar System
ASTR.description: Earth's motions; planets and their satellites; comets; meteorites; interplanetary matter; elementary celestial mechanics. Prerequisite: Mathematics 226.

ASTR.title: Directed Research
ASTR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GSEC.title: Foundations of Global Security
GSEC.description: A survey of theories and challenges relating to International Relations and security studies broadly defined from WWI to present conflicts including human, environmental and economic concepts.

GSEC.title: National Intelligence and Global Security
GSEC.description: Exploration of how intelligence affects global security and the formation and implementation of foreign and security policy.

GSEC.title: Global Human Rights
GSEC.description: Explores competing conceptions of human rights, whether human rights are universal, problems of enforcement and the role of human rights in foreign policy.

INDS.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS.description: Research and Study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS.title: Field Study
INDS.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions     under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS.title: Senior Thesis
INDS.description: Writing the IDM senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty guidance committee.

ITAL.title: Italian 120 Language Practicum
ITAL.description: English grammar as it relates to Italian in order to improve students' Italian language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice. Requires concurrent enrollment in either ITAL 120 Italian I or MPVA 260 Italian Language and Diction.

ITAL.title: Italian 150 Language Practicum
ITAL.description: English grammar as it relates to Italian in order to improve students Italian language skills; explicit pronunciation and intonation practice.

ITAL.title: Course in Reading Italian
ITAL.description: For graduate students who wish help in meeting the Italian reading  requirement for the Ph.D. degree. Synoptic presentation of Italian  grammar. Emphasis on development of reading skills. Graded CR/NC.  Not available for degree credit.

ITAL.title: Italian I
ITAL.description: Introduction to current Italian. Oral practice, hearing and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression. Lecture, classroom drill, laboratory drill.

ITAL.title: Accelerated Italian for Speakers of Spanish and  Other Romance Languages
ITAL.description: Accelerated introduction to written and spoken Italian for students with a high level of proficiency in Spanish or another Romance Language.  Students completing this course may enroll in the third semester of the basic language sequence ITAL 220.

ITAL.title: Italian III
ITAL.description: Continuation of Italian II. Review of structure of the language, drill in aural and reading comprehension, practice in oral expression.

ITAL.title: Italian Professional Internship: Communication and Culture
ITAL.description: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional employment context.

ITAL.title: Italian IV
ITAL.description: Continuation of Italian III.  Review and expand upon abilities to create with the language in concrete exchanges, descriptions, comparisons, questions and discussions relevant to current issues and topics.

ITAL.title: Black Europe
ITAL.description: Study of African migration to Europe and the formation of 'black'/African communities in Europe, focusing on France and Italy. Conducted in English.

ITAL.title: Inventing Modern Italy
ITAL.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the literary, artistic, and  political movements which contributed to the shaping of modern  Italy. Taught in English.

ITAL.title: Women Writers in Europe and America
ITAL.description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social and cultural contexts.

ITAL.title: Dante
ITAL.description: Analysis of the Divina Commedia and other works. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 450)

ITAL.title: Directed Research
ITAL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

HIST.title: State and Society in the Ancient World
HIST.description: Achievements of the near East, Greece, and Rome with emphasis on the development of ideas, arts, and institutions which have influenced modern man.

HIST.title: The Emergence of Modern Europe
HIST.description: Political, intellectual, and cultural developments in Europe,1300-1815. Renaissance and Reformation; absolute monarchy,scientific changes, and Enlightenment; French Revolution andNapoleon.

HIST.title: The Latin American Experience
HIST.description: Introduction to Latin American history and cultures, providing tools to grasp the importance of the region within the larger Americas and the world.

HIST.title: History of Early Africa
HIST.description: Surveys the major dynamics of economic and political change in Sub-Saharan Africa before the imposition of European colonial rule in the late nineteenth century.

HIST.title: Approaches to History
HIST.description: Methods and theories of historical interpretation of evidence; uses of archives; modes of presenting the past to the public. Required of all History majors. Duplicates credit in former HIST-300.

HIST.title: How to Be An American: Global Histories of U.S. Citizenship
HIST.description: History of United States citizenship from its origins to the present day, with particular attention to relationship between law and culture.

HIST.title: Introduction to the American West
HIST.description: The history of the American West from ca. 1400 to the present, with a focus on environment, race and the formation of American identity

HIST.title: Climate Change:  Science, History and Solutions
HIST.description: History and science of anthropogenic climate change; climate dynamics; carbon cycle; climate modeling; fossil fuel economy; climate denial and political tactics; group research of solutions.

HIST.title: History of Science, Technology and Medicine
HIST.description: The political, cultural, and social forces that have shaped  scientific achievements in the modtern age.

HIST.title: Business and East Asian Culture, 1800-Present
HIST.description: Business history of East Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong) as related to culture, politics, and society.

HIST.title: Women and Gender in the Ancient and Spanish Americas
HIST.description: A history of gender in the Ancient and Spanish Americas, focusing on the ways women participated in the livelihood, politics and rituals of their communities.

HIST.title: Native Americans in American Public Life
HIST.description: Role of Native Americans in American public life from colonial times to the present; Native American societies and governments and their relations to the U.S.

HIST.title: The Victorians
HIST.description: Britain in the 19th century, politics, industrialization, and imperialism, change and continuity in social and cultural aspects, especially class, gender, and race relations.

HIST.title: History of the Samurai
HIST.description: Development of the Japanese samurai from the 6th to the 16th centuries. Recommended preparation: a course in East Asian history

HIST.title: Japan Since 1945
HIST.description: Survey of the impact of World War II, American occupation, and rapid economic growth on Japan's politics, society, economy, and culture; Japan as a post-modern nation.

HIST.title: Mexican Migration to the United States
HIST.description: Mexican migration from the 1850s to the present, emphasizing labor migrants to the United States.

HIST.title: 20th Century U.S. History
HIST.description: Critical turning-points in the twentieth century; sources of major social and political change. Course materials include primary documents and historic radio/television recordings.

HIST.title: Authenticity in Twentieth Century Popular Music
HIST.description: Explores how the idea of authenticity shaped American popular music and influenced iconic musicians in the twentieth century.

HIST.title: History of Mexico
HIST.description: History of Mexico traces the crucial themes and events informing Mexicos history from the sixteenth century to the contemporary period.

HIST.title: Early Modern European Cultural History
HIST.description: Examines themes in European and English cultural history 1500-1800, including identity, power, group dynamics, display, space, communication, control.

HIST.title: Migration and Displacement in the Indian Ocean World
HIST.description: History of the Indian Ocean world as a major arena of political, economic and cultural contact during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

HIST.title: Tea Culture in Premodern East Asia: Politics, Art and Trade
HIST.description: Explores the cultural, political and economic history of pre-modern Japan and China via the theme of tea culture.

HIST.title: Race, Slavery, and the Making of the Atlantic World
HIST.description: Introduction to the literature of the Atlantic World with a focus on slavery and its role in the emergence of the modern era. Seminar enrollment limited to 15 students.

HIST.title: War, Race, and the Constitution
HIST.description: Examines the World War II incarceration of Japanese Americans and its impact on issues of civil liberties as well as national security.

HIST.title: The United States since 1939
HIST.description: A survey of the accelerating changes that transformed the nation's domestic life and revolutionized America's role in world affairs.

HIST.title: Directed Research
HIST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

HIST.title: Honors Thesis
HIST.description: Writing of the honors thesis; for students in the History Honors Program.

HIST.title: Law, History and Culture Honors Thesis Seminar
HIST.description: Writing of the honors thesis; capstone for students in the Law, History and Culture major.

HIST.title: Introduction to Graduate Historical Studies
HIST.description: Techniques, theories, and sub-disciplines of history.

HIST.title: Studies in Modern European History: Europe's 20th Century
HIST.description: Readings in the history and historiography of Europe in the 20th  century.

HIST.title: Studies in Japanese History
HIST.description: Selected topics in historical problems dealing with Japan.

HIST.title: Readings in Science, Technology and Society
HIST.description: Reading course in science and technology studies from a historical perspective.

HIST.title: Readings in Chicano/Latino History
HIST.description: Readings, analyses, and discussion of various approaches, topics,  and genres in the field of Chicano/Latino history.

HIST.title: Topics in Global South Histories
HIST.description: Introduces students to the critical methodologies in the historiography of the Global South, focused on the nineteenth century to the present day

HIST.title: Historical Scholarship on 20th and 21st Century America
HIST.description: Introduction to historiography and research in the political,  economic, social, cultural, and intellectual history of the 20th  and 21st Century United States.

HIST.title: Directed Research
HIST.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Historiography
HIST.description: Historical criticism; form and mechanics of presenting research; writers of history, their works and philosophies; theories of historical development.

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
HIST.description: Basic principles of history pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first semester teaching assistants in history. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Research
HIST.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

HIST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.
