HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

LAT.title: Latin I
LAT.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.

LAT.title: Latin II
LAT.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued.  Basic  reading skills.

LAT.title: Latin III
LAT.description: Reading Latin literature.  Introduction to reading and translation  of classical Latin prose and poetry.  Extensive grammar review.

LAT.title: Roman Historians
LAT.description: Readings from Sallust, Livy, and Tacitus.

LAT.title: Readings in Latin Literature
LAT.description: Readings in various authors and genres of latin literature.

LAT.title: Directed Research
LAT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

JS.title: Jewish History
JS.description: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.

JS.title: Judaism
JS.description: Jewish beliefs, practices, and history from the biblical period to the present; Judaic contributions to Western civilization.

JS.title: The Holocaust
JS.description: Historical background and responses to the Holocaust, withspecial emphasis on ethical implications.

JS.title: Holy War And History: Jews, Christians, Muslims
JS.description: Investigates the engagement in war by Judaism, Christianity and Islam by examining history and theology and looks at religious justifications and condemnations of war.

JS.title: Jewish Magic in the Ancient World
JS.description: A cross-cultural examination of different kinds of magical literature that describe miraculous practices in Jewish mainstream and marginal life in the ancient and classical periods.

JS.title: Jews in American Popular Culture
JS.description: Social and cultural history of American Jewish contributions to the arts, science, literature, economics and politics.

JS.title: Directed Research
JS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JS.title: Directed Research
JS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HBIO.title: Introduction to Human and Evolutionary Biology
HBIO.description: Introduction to the major and field of human and evolutionary biology; sub-disciplines, career options and areas for research; guest speakers.

HBIO.title: The Human Animal
HBIO.description: Foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people. Laboratory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 200Lg.

HBIO.title: Nutrition for Life
HBIO.description: To develop an understanding of Nutrition, especially as it         pertains to optimal health and prevention of diseases. A study of  macro and micro nutrients.

HBIO.title: The Science of Sport
HBIO.description: The physiological and nutritional basis of human performance. Factors that facilitate and limit athletic achievement. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. Not available for major credit. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 205Lxg.

HBIO.title: Mediterranean and Healthy Lifestyles in the World
HBIO.description: Explores and contrasts the core components of the traditional mediterranean lifestyle to those of other lifestyles in the world. Biological and anthropological perspectives for following sustainable lifestyles to improve and maintain personal health.

HBIO.title: The Pharmacology of Performance-Enhancing Drugs
HBIO.description: Evaluation of drugs, nutritional supplements, and ergogenic aids that are purported to enhance human athletic performance.

HBIO.title: Evolution, Ecology, and Culture
HBIO.description: The roles of biology, culture, and the environment in shaping human society, integrating evolutionary biology and cultural theory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 300.

HBIO.title: Human Anatomy
HBIO.description: Major organ systems; functional implications of their relationships; gross and microscopic examination with an emphasis on practical skills in recognizing, dissecting, and differentiating anatomical structures. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 301L.

HBIO.title: Nutrition and Metabolism
HBIO.description: Gastrointestinal physiology and energy metabolism as it relates to macronutrient intake. Theories and principles of nutrition and     their impact on metabolic regulation. Prerequisites: BISC 220L or  BISC 221L. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 200.

HBIO.title: Origins and Evolution of Human Behavior
HBIO.description: Examination of the evidence for and against evolutionary bases of a range of human behaviors. Topics include sex differences, human reproductive strategies, race, IQ, human ecology. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 308.

HBIO.title: The Human Machine
HBIO.description: An exploration of how the human body works and why it works the way it does; draws from the fields of anatomy, biomechanics, physiology, engineering and paleoanthropology.

HBIO.title: Nutrition and Disease
HBIO.description: Principles of diet therapy for the prevention and treatment of human disease.

HBIO.title: Biomechanics
HBIO.description: Kinematic and kinetic analysis of human motion. Emphasis on performance enhancement and injury prevention.

HBIO.title: Applied Human Physiology
HBIO.description: The physiology of the respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, musculoskeletal, digestive, endocrine and nervous systems in humans, with application to human health and pathology.

HBIO.title: Prevention of Athletic Injuries
HBIO.description: Application of scientific principles to conditioning, protecting, and rehabilitating the athlete.

HBIO.title: Laboratory Experience in Kinesiology
HBIO.description: Practical laboratory experience in basic and applied exercise physiology, biochemistry, and/or biomechanics. Emphasizing development of laboratory techniques. Prerequisites: HBIO 203, HBIO 301, HBIO 302, HBIO 320. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 491.

HBIO.title: Integrative Pathophysiology
HBIO.description: Selected topics in Human and Evolutionary Biology.

HEBR.title: Hebrew I
HEBR.description: Focuses on the acquisition of proficiency and communicative skills in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehension as well as cultural literacy.

HEBR.title: Hebrew III
HEBR.description: Continuation of Hebrew II; stress on grammar, composition, and conversation. Prerequisite: HEBR 150.

CLAS.title: State and Society in the Ancient World
CLAS.description: Achievements of the near East, Greece, and Rome with emphasis on the development of ideas, arts, and institutions which have influenced modern man.

CLAS.title: The Legacy of Rome
CLAS.description: Ancient Roman values, ideas, and institutions of relevance to later periods of civilization.

CLAS.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
CLAS.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

CLAS.title: Classical Mythology in Art and Literature
CLAS.description: Classical Greek and Roman mythology as inspiration for literature, art, music, and film in various historical contexts.

CLAS.title: Law and Society in Classical Greece
CLAS.description: Investigations of the legal culture of classical Greece, focusing on regulation of social practices and on the role of social values in defining crime.

CLAS.title: Greek Art and Archaeology
CLAS.description: Survey of artistic works and monuments of ancient Greece from the Geometric through the Hellenistic period (c. 1000 - 30 BCE.).

CLAS.title: Late Antique Art and Archaeology
CLAS.description: Investigation of the transformation between classical antiquity and the middle ages through examination of cities, buildings, images and artifacts of the 3rd-8th-century Mediterranean.

CLAS.title: Ancient Drama
CLAS.description: Tragedies and comedies of the ancient world; later influences.

CLAS.title: Athens in the Age of Democracy and Empire
CLAS.description: Democratic Institutions and practices, empire building, and cultural innovations of fifth and fourth century B.C. Athens using historical, rhetorical, dramatic, philosophical, and artistic sources.

CLAS.title: Capstone Research Seminar
CLAS.description: Required capstone for classics majors; overview of research methods and resources in classical studies culminating in final capstone project.

CLAS.title: Directed Research
CLAS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CLAS.title: Introduction to Byzantine Studies
CLAS.description: Study in the history and theory of classical scholarship. Recommended Preparation: knowledge of Greek or Latin.

CLAS.title: Ovid's Fasti and Imperial Rome
CLAS.description: Early Latin literature through Virgil.

CLAS.title: Women's Health in the Ancient Mediterranean
CLAS.description: Introduces students to theoretical approaches useful for modeling Greek and/or Roman culture and literature.

CLAS.title: Directed Research
CLAS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Practicum in Teaching Liberal Arts: Classics
CLAS.description: Basic principles of philosophical pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first-semester teaching assistants in Classics. Open only to doctoral students in Classics. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

SWMS.title: Identity Development of the Contemporary Female
SWMS.description: Exploration of identity development in terms of social, political, and cultural constructs; examination of collegiate athletics and the contributions of women of color.

SWMS.title: Social Analysis of Gender
SWMS.description: Multidisciplinary survey of gender assumptions in relation to sexuality, mental health, social and political relations, and artistic expression.

SWMS.title: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality: International Perspect
SWMS.description: History and theory of global feminist movements; case studies in bodily autonomy; labor rights; gender justice.

SWMS.title: Introduction to Feminist Theory
SWMS.description: Emergence of feminist thought from the Enlightenment to the present; historical development of female subjectivity; advancement of womens rights; feminisms from alternative ideological perspectives.

SWMS.title: Contemporary Issues in LGBTQ Studies
SWMS.description: Interdisciplinary analysis of LGBTQ issues; examination of the intersections of gender and sexuality with social class, race, religion and nationality.

SWMS.title: Advanced Gender Theory
SWMS.description: Contemporary debates and research in three areas: health bodies, science technologies; feminist/queer analytics in media and representation; critical approaches to race, culture and power.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality Studies: Internship
SWMS.description: Intensive experience with gender-focused community organizations; analysis of relationships between organizations and feminist and queer theory.

SWMS.title: Gender and Global Issues
SWMS.description: An examination of the role women have played in world politics     focusing on issues of war and peace, the environment and the       global economy.

SWMS.title: Health, Gender and Ethnicity
SWMS.description: Cross-cultural notions of the body, health, and healing; historic and cultural variability of ideas of reproduction, birth, sexuality, mental illness and disability.

SWMS.title: Sexual/Textual Diversity
SWMS.description: Questions of gay and lesbian identity, expression and experience in a variety of literary and cultural forms; emphasis on sexual politics, equality and difference.

SWMS.title: Transgender Studies
SWMS.description: Analysis of transgender behaviors, from androgyny and transvestism to transexuality. Discussion of changing laws, representations, medical standards, and social attitudes towards transgender and intersex people.

SWMS.title: Women Writers in Europe and America
SWMS.description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social and cultural contexts.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality in Literary Theory
SWMS.description: Literary representations and theories of gender difference. Examines questions of gendered voice in writing and the cultural construction of gender in various periods and cultures.

SWMS.title: Sex, Power, and Politics
SWMS.description: An evaluation of the ways in which different ideologies, institutions, and policies contribute to differences in political power between men and women.

SWMS.title: French Women Writers
SWMS.description: Major figures and their roles in French society and contributions to French literature. Conducted in French. Corequisite: FREN 330.

SWMS.title: Gender, Media and Communication
SWMS.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: mediarepresentations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's rolein communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

SWMS.title: Senior Seminar in Gender and Sexuality Studies
SWMS.description: Application of gender and sexuality research methods to individual student projects with an emphasis on feminist, queer and post-colonial scholarship.

SWMS.title: Queer Cinema
SWMS.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

SWMS.title: Women's Spaces in History: 'Hussies,' 'Harems,' and 'Housewi
SWMS.description: Methods for studying patterns of spatial differentiation of women throughout history from home to city, embodied in gender specific language and gendered spaces.

SWMS.title: Directed Research
SWMS.description: Independent research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SWMS.title: Seminar in Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Studies
SWMS.description: Interdisciplinary cross-cultural, historical, psychological, sociological, and contemporary political perspectives on female and male homosexual eroticism, and the emergence of gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender identities.

SWMS.title: Directed Research
SWMS.description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry Tutorial
CHEM.description: Weekly tutorial for selected students in CHEM 105aL.  Strong  emphasis on chemical mathematics and key concepts in general  chemistry.  Topics parallel lectures in CHEM 105aL.  Not available  for degree credit.  Graded CR/NC.  Discussion, 2 hours.

CHEM.title: The Molecular World
CHEM.description: Basic chemistry and its impact on the contemporary world. Topics include: structures and reactions of molecules, stoichiometry, nomenclature, gases, solutions.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry for the Environment and Life
CHEM.description: Chemistry for environmental studies, neuroscience and other life sciences: organic and inorganic structures, nomenclature, stoichiometry, solutions, gases, non-covalent interactions, equilibria, acid-base and redox reactions. Not for major credit in chemistry.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures. Prerequisite to all more advanced courses in chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. Quiz, 1 hour.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry for Chemistry Majors
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry emphasizing contemporary chemistry; laboratory work focuses on quantitative procedures. Open only to Chemistry majors. (Duplicates credit in CHEM 105a and CHEM 115a)

CHEM.title: Advanced General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Equivalent to 105agL-bL, but taught at a higher level forexceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to course bydepartmental approval only. Lecture, 3 hours; lab and discussion,4 hours; quiz, 1 hour. Prereq: 1 year high school chemistry andmathematics through pre-calculus.

CHEM.title: Pandemics Shaping Our World: Past, Present and Future
CHEM.description: Coronavirus 101! We explore pandemic diseases from historic plagues to Covid-19 and beyond, discussing their societal impact and the "science" of drugs, vaccines and tests.

CHEM.title: Chemical Forensics: The Science, and Its Impact
CHEM.description: Scientific principles underlying forensic approaches to the investigation of crimes and its societal impact on law, culture and media. Not available for major credit.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry Tutorial A
CHEM.description: Major principles of organic chemistry and its relevance. Topics covered parallel to those of CHEM 322A. Prerequisite: CHEM 105bL. Corequisite: CHEM 322aL. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. Prereq: Consent of department head.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Supervised Research
CHEM.description: Supervised undergraduate research experience.

CHEM.title: Undergraduate Research Seminar
CHEM.description: Seminars in current research in the chemical and molecular sciences.

CHEM.title: Analytical Chemistry
CHEM.description: Theory and practice in chemical analysis, emphasizing              instrumental techniques; error analysis, fractional distillation,  extraction; chromatograhpy; visible, ultraviolet, and infrared     spectroscopy; introductions to electrochemistry and nuclear        magnetic resonance spectroscopy.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Required of majors in chemistry.

CHEM.title: Biochemistry
CHEM.description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.

CHEM.title: Molecular Principles of Biochemistry
CHEM.description: Biomolecular structures, protein and nucleic acid chemistry and functions, carbohydrates, lipids, membranes, enzyme catalysis and kinetics, coenzymes, biochemical signaling, major metabolic pathways, control of gene expression, replication, transcription, and translation.

CHEM.title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Advanced treatment of organic chemistry from a mechanistic point  of view according to the following topics: polar and isopolar      reactions, intermediates. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 1 hour.

CHEM.title: Physical Chemistry: Thermodynamics and Kinetics
CHEM.description: Kinetic theory; equations of state; thermodynamics; phase equilibria; chemical equilibrium; statistical thermodynamics; kinetics; electrochemistry; surface and colloid chemistry; polymers.

CHEM.title: Directed Research
CHEM.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CHEM.title: Advanced Research Experience
CHEM.description: Directed undergraduate research supervised by faculty, with advanced capstone research experience. Not available for graduate credit.

CHEM.title: Biological Therapeutics Development
CHEM.description: The development of biological therapeutics - the core approach to modern pharmaceuticals - through an exploration of biopolymer structures, principles of recognition and considerations for therapeutic implementation.

CHEM.title: Structure and Bonding in Inorganic and Organometallic Chemis
CHEM.description: An integrated core course of structure and bonding in inorganic, coordination, and organometallic chemistry within an oxidation state framework; symmetry, electronic properties.

CHEM.title: Synthesis, Reactivity, and Mechanism in Inorganic and Organo
CHEM.description: A reactivity framework for inorganic and organometallic chemistry. Synthesis, reaction mechanisms and energetics. Homogeneous catalysis.

CHEM.title: Advanced Chemical Biology
CHEM.description: Chemical approaches to investigate biological processes from transcription to protein inhibitors. Recommended preparation: CHEM 322ab and BISC 330 (or equivalent).

CHEM.title: Basic Principles of Physical Methods in Biochemistry
CHEM.description: Principles underlying physical analytical methods commonly  utilized in research in biochemistry and molecular biology.

CHEM.title: Structure and Mechanism in Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Review of modern structural theory of organic chemistry; and relation to the mechanisms of organic chemical reactions.

CHEM.title: Mathematical Techniques of Physical Chemistry
CHEM.description: Fundamentals and techniques of mathematics and physics. Linear algebra, differential equations, mechanics, electricity and magnetism. Applications to physical chemistry/chemical physics.

CHEM.title: Introduction to Quantum Chemistry
CHEM.description: Basic principles of quantum mechanics and their application to Chemistry. Electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

CHEM.title: Theory and Practice of Molecular Electronic Structure
CHEM.description: Provide working knowledge and hands-on experience in current  quantum chemical methods for chemists who would like to employ  these techniques in their own research.

CHEM.title: Special Topics in Chemical Physics
CHEM.description: Study of selected areas of chemical physics. Critical evaluation of recent advances in the field. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

CHEM.title: Seminar in Chemical Biology
CHEM.description: Introduce students to emerging research areas in chemical biology  through a thorough discussion of seminal research articles and  presentations of current research topics. Recommended preparation: some research experience and familiarity with literature search

CHEM.title: Current Topics in Inorganic Chemistry and Nanoscience
CHEM.description: Introduction to emerging research areas in Inorganic Chemistry & Nanoscience through a discussion of seminal research articles and presentations of current research topics.

CHEM.title: Directed Research
CHEM.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Practicum in Teaching Chemistry
CHEM.description: Practical principles for effective teaching in the laboratory. Intended for teaching assistants in Chemistry. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
CHEM.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

CHEM.title: Basic Principles and Methods for Multiscale Structural       Biology
CHEM.description: Special topics in chemistry.

CHEM.title: Kinetics and Mechanism of Catalytic Reactions

IR.title: International Relations
IR.description: Basic concepts of world affairs for non-majors. Development ofcompetency to understand and critically evaluate global relationsand international events, stressing empirical approaches. Not available for major credit.

IR.title: Environmental Issues in Society
IR.description: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.

IR.title: International Relations: Introductory Analysis
IR.description: Comprehensive introduction to contending theoretical and analytical approaches; development of critical, evaluative, cognitive, and analytical competencies regarding historical and contemporary issues.

IR.title: International Relations: Approaches to Research
IR.description: Introduction to theoretically oriented research approaches and designs; emphasis on the logic of argumentation.

IR.title: Historical Approaches to International Relations
IR.description: Introduction to historical research methods with an emphasis on historical texts and modes of discourse.

IR.title: The Global Economy
IR.description: Economic and political concepts necessary to the understanding of the modern global economy. Topics include international trade, foreign investment and migration.

IR.title: National Intelligence and the Shaping of Policy
IR.description: The focus is intelligence to improve the making of policy, with attention to collection; overt and covert, operations; domestic intelligence; and oversight in democracies.

IR.title: Managing New Global Challenges
IR.description: Examines the strategies for managing global issues in the post Cold War period. Explores ways that international institutions, national governments and non-state actors work separately and together to provide order and control over complex international issues areas. Issues that will receive attention could include financial and monetary relations, trade and foreign investment, preservation of the environment, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, population and migration, terrori

IR.title: Coercion in the Globalized Economy
IR.description: Analysis of recent events, forces, and conditions in the international political system.

IR.title: Ethics and World Politics
IR.description: Analysis of recent events, forces, and conditions in the international political system.

IR.title: Human Rights in Post-Soviet Eurasia
IR.description: Analysis of recent events, forces, and conditions in the international political system.

IR.title: Religions and Political Violence
IR.description: An introduction to debates about the intersection of religion and conflict in politics and international affairs; theoretical, classical, and contemporary issues.

IR.title: Gender and Global Issues
IR.description: An examination of the role women have played in world politics     focusing on issues of war and peace, the environment and the       global economy.

IR.title: Violent Conflict
IR.description: Origins and evolution of violent conflict among humans; modern efforts to end conflict; recent research in archaeology, anthropology, biology, economics, political science and psychology.

IR.title: Technology and International Relations
IR.description: Impact of technological advances to global security and development. Focus on surveillance and cyber conflict; nuclear weaponry, aviation and UAVs missiles and BMD; submarines and ASW.

IR.title: Multinational Enterprises and World Politics
IR.description: Political implications of interactions between different types of multinational enterprises and all levels of U.S. government, other industrial nations, and less-developed countries.

IR.title: Politics of the World Economy
IR.description: Exploration of questions and concepts in international economics and politics, especially as they relate to flows of trade, capital, people, and problems across borders.

IR.title: Public Health and International Relations
IR.description: Examination of threats to global security, state sovereignty and population health posed by infectious diseases, natural disasters, war and civil conflict.

IR.title: Foreign Policy Analysis
IR.description: Basic concepts and analytical approaches in the study of decision-making at the international level. This is a case-based class, requiring participation of students in interactive discussions of decision forcing and retrospective foreign policy cases.

IR.title: The Politics and Strategy of Weapons of Mass Destruction
IR.description: Causes and effects of use and spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons; responses to WMD, including deterrence, preventive war, and non-proliferation policies and negotiations.

IR.title: The Political Economy of Latin American Development
IR.description: The main economic development themes and strategies in Latin  America over the past century.  The interplay between domestic and  international variables, and the resulting dynamic changes.

IR.title: French Foreign Policy: 1945 to the Present
IR.description: Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy. (Paris semester only).

IR.title: Introduction to International Security
IR.description: Key concepts in international security studies; historical evolution of international warfare and diplomacy; contemporary international security issues.

IR.title: Asian Security Issues
IR.description: Introduction to key security trends in the Asia-Pacific region, emphasizing strategic competition between U.S., Russia, and China; regional military capabilities; rise of neutrality politics.

IR.title: Directed International Relations Field Study
IR.description: Intensive internship experience in international relations professional areas with academic research component (may be repeated for credit different semesters)

IR.title: The United Nations and World Order
IR.description: The contribution of the United Nations to world order,focusing on its history, principal organs, relationships with global actors, andprospects for reform.

IR.title: Theories of War
IR.description: Causes of war; means of prevention and consequences of war.

IR.title: Applied Data Science for International Relations 1
IR.description: Introduction to statistical computing and data visualization in R. Focus on visualization of descriptive statistics; create publication-ready figures for actual faculty research projects.

IR.title: Commercial and Financial Globalization-Trends,   Challenges
IR.description: Factors determining the feasibility, desirability and limits of economic globalization; the dynamics triggered by the Global Financial Crisis and the backlash against Globalization.

IR.title: Formulation of U.S. Foreign Policy
IR.description: Critical discussion of alternative approaches explaining the formulation and implementation of U.S. foreign policy: domestic politics, organizational processes, group dynamics, individual personality and perception.

IR.title: Cities of the Middle East
IR.description: An examination of the economic, political and cultural forces operating in a number of Middle Eastern cities.

IR.title: The International Political Economy of Development
IR.description: Provides a critical introduction to scholarship on international  political economy (IPR), the interaction of states and markets in  a global context.

IR.title: The Political Economy of Autocracy
IR.description: Survey of autocracy, the world's most common form of government: its political economy, the role of elections, parties, repression, propaganda and civil resistance.

IR.title: Directed Research
IR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

IR.title: Honors Thesis Seminar
IR.description: Preparation and oral defense of senior honors thesis before supervising faculty and fellow honors students. Senior status and acceptance to program required. Recommended preparation: IR 311.

IR.title: Democracy, Economic Growth and Human Security in             Contemporary Africa
IR.description: Selected topics in various special areas within international relations, which may vary from semester to semester or within semesters.

LING.title: In a Word
LING.description: Words as tools for discovering properties of the human mind. How words are formed of and form various units. Experiments exploring judgments about word interpretation.

LING.title: Language and Society
LING.description: Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.

LING.title: American Sign Language I
LING.description: Familiarization with ASL and fingerspelling. Covers visual and gestural communication, comprehension through receptive language skills, basic conversational proficiency, general insights into American Deaf culture.

LING.title: American Sign Language II
LING.description: Increased development of inflectional and non-manual behavior patterns presented with incorporation of selected aspects of Deaf culture and community within receptive and expressive conversations.

LING.title: Introduction to Linguistics
LING.description: Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language;syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.

LING.title: Language and Mind
LING.description: Language within cognitive science: speech physiology and acoustics, language acquisition, reading, language disorders, perception and mental representation of words, linguistic diversity and computer analysis of speech.

LING.title: Human Language and Technology
LING.description: Study of human linguistic competence and technologies that simulate it. Phonetics, vibration and signal processing, speech recognition, neural networks.

LING.title: Introduction to Syntax
LING.description: A survey of topics in syntax.

LING.title: Introduction to Semantics and Pragmatics
LING.description: Introduction to meaning in natural language and the methods from logic applied to its study.

LING.title: Psycholinguistics
LING.description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of how spoken and written language is produced and understood, learned during childhood, and affected by brain damage.

LING.title: Children's Learning and Cognitive Development
LING.description: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.

LING.title: Forensic Speaker Identification
LING.description: Overview of methods used to identify voices on the basis of their characteristic speech patterns.

LING.title: Directed Research
LING.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

LING.title: Honors Thesis
LING.description: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.

LING.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING.description: (LING-505abc) Exploration of the professional world of linguistics for first semestr graduate students.Graded CR/NC.

LING.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING.description: Preparation and presentation of M.A./Ph.D. screening papers;  discussion of student research.  Graded CR/NC.

LING.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING.description: Colloquium for presentation and discussion of student research     paper.  Graded CR/NC.

LING.title: Practicum in Phonetics and Phonology
LING.description: Professional development in phonetics and phonology. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Practicum in Syntax and Semantics
LING.description: Professional development in syntax and semantics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Practicum in Psycholinguistics
LING.description: Professional development in psycholinguistics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Generative Syntax
LING.description: Introduction to syntax ; transformational-generative syntax.

LING.title: Phonology
LING.description: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.

LING.title: Semantics
LING.description: Current linguistic approaches to the semantics of natural language; analysis of concepts of meaning and reference.

LING.title: Psycholinguistics
LING.description: Theories of acquisition; sentence and discourse processing; language and thought.

LING.title: General Phonetics
LING.description: Familiarization with articulation, transcription, production, and  acoustic analysis of the speech sounds found in the world's  languages.  Also speech technology, perception, and disorders.   Includes laboratory exercises.

LING.title: Topics in Advanced Phonology
LING.description: Topics in advanced formal phonology; theoretical issues in the  interface of phonology with other areas of linguistics; literature  study on themes of current theoretical relevance. Recommended  Preparation  LING 531ab.

LING.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts: Linguistics
LING.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Graded CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

MDES.title: The Middle East
MDES.description: Introduction to the natural and cultural diversity of the Middle East.

MDES.title: Iran: From Antiquity to Modernity
MDES.description: Examines Iran from antiquity to modernity, emphasizing the complex interplay of cross-cultural continuity, rupture and transformation that marks the country's long history.

MDES.title: Arabic Literature: Classical to Contemporary
MDES.description: Trends and genres in Arabic literature from the classical (pre-modern), through the modern and contemporary periods. In English.

MDES.title: Politics and Society in the Contemporary Middle East
MDES.description: Examination of a relevant and timely issue in Middle East Studies.

MDES.title: Cities of the Middle East
MDES.description: An examination of the economic, political and cultural forces operating in a number of Middle Eastern cities.

MDES.title: France and Islam
MDES.description: Historical and theoretical analyses of the complex history of Western perceptions of Islam, focusing on France.Taught in French. Prerequisites: FREN 330. Recommended preparation: REL 137g for Religion majors and minors.

MDES.title: Seminar in Middle East Studies
MDES.description: Major theoretical and methodological currents and approaches to the study of the Middle East through a close reading of important recent contributions.

MDES.title: Directed Research
MDES.description: Individual research and readings. Not for graduate credit.

MDA.description: Students explore different understandings of work and career in  American society while testing theories in an actual work  setting.

NEUR.title: Neurobiology
NEUR.description: Structure, function, and development of nervous systems; neural integration and mechanisms of behavior; organization and operation of brains.

NEUR.title: Neuropsychology
NEUR.description: Effects of brain damage on human behavior and abilities, particularly language, memory, and emotion.

NEUR.title: Neuropsychopharmacology
NEUR.description: Pharmo-chemical nature of the brain; diseases of the brain and     drug treatments. Recommended Preparation: background in biological  psychology, biology and/or neuroscience.

NEUR.title: Foundations of  Cognitive Neuroscience
NEUR.description: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

NEUR.title: Systems Neuroscience: From Foundational Studies to Today
Directed Research
NEUR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Departmental approval.

NEUR.title: Neuroscience Honors Seminar
NEUR.description: Students attend lectures of distinguished neuroscientists visiting USC and give short, chalk-talk presentations summarizing the lecture. The presentations are critiqued by the students. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: BISC-220L or BISC-221L. Recommended preparation: BISC 421.

NEUR.title: Honors Thesis
NEUR.description: Not available for graduate credit.  Programmatic approval.

NSCI.title: Advanced Overview of Neurosciences
NSCI.description: Study of the nervous system at multiple levels through the analysis of four themes: Motor Control; Emotion, Motivation, and Decision-Making; Memory and Learning; and Vision. Prerequisites: BISC 421. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 524.)

NSCI.title: Seminar in Neurobiology
NSCI.description: Seminar in Neurobiology. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 539.)

NSCI.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
NSCI.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

NSCI.title: Research
NSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to master and doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 790.)

PHIL.title: Free People, Free Thought and Free Markets
PHIL.description: The philosophical foundations of modern political and economic thought, including economic rationality, neoclassical economics, free-market vs. socialist economies and behavioral economics.

PHIL.title: Reasoning and Argument
PHIL.description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others. (Duplicates credit in former PHIL 250a)

PHIL.title: Reasoning and Argument
PHIL.description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others. (Duplicates credit in former PHIL 250b)

PHIL.title: Introduction to Philosophy, Politics and Economics and Law
PHIL.description: Topics include economic models of human behavior and their limits; models of justice, morality and law, and the politics and administration of institutions.

PHIL.title: Freedom, Equality, and Social Justice
PHIL.description: Explores the nature of justice, and how apparently conflicting ideals, such as freedom and equality, are to be balanced within a just society.

PHIL.title: Introduction to Feminist Philosophy
PHIL.description: Feminist perspectives on various political problems; evaluate and apply different analyses of complex social phenomena like patriarchy, misogyny and intersectionality.

PHIL.title: Moral Dilemmas in the Legal Domain
PHIL.description: Philosophical theories of law and applications to controversies of importance to society and our legal system, such as free speech, civil disobedience, and selfdefense.

PHIL.title: Introduction to Logic
PHIL.description: Introduction to the aims and basic techniques of formal logic, including propositional and quantificational logic.

PHIL.title: Existentialism in Philosophy, Literature and Film
PHIL.description: A study of existentialist philosophy and its influence in 19th and 20th century culture, including both literature and film. Focus on works by Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre, Beauvoir, Dostoevsky, Godard, and others.

PHIL.title: Probability and Rational Choice
PHIL.description: Explores formal tools for thinking about uncertainty. In an uncertain world, how is it rational to form our beliefs, make decisions, and interact with others?

PHIL.title: Conceptual Foundations of Conflict
PHIL.description: Explore the nature of interpersonal conflict: war, polarization, abuse, silencing, public reason, democracy, cancel culture and resistance.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Mind and Language
PHIL.description: Explores how language shapes thought, how social norms impact meaning and communication, the nature of speech acts, with applications to hate speech and pornography.

PHIL.title: Intermediate Logic
PHIL.description: Basic techniques of propositional and quantificational logic, and elements of probability. Especially useful to philosophy, mathematics, science and engineering majors.

PHIL.title: Epistemology and Metaphysics
PHIL.description: Examination of problems in metaphysics and/or epistemology. Conducted at the intermediate level.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Perception
PHIL.description: Philosophical investigation of sense perception as it relates to issues in epistemology, metaphysics, the philosophy of mind, and the philosophy of science.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Law
PHIL.description: Philosophical theories about the nature of law, relations between law and morality, and analysis of normative concepts central to law, such as responsibility, punishment, negligence.

PHIL.title: Law, Society, and Politics
PHIL.description: A systematic presentation of the main philosophical perspectives on the interactions between law and the social-political aspects of our lives.

PHIL.title: Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL.description: The nature of man and society, the nature and justification of state and government, political rights and political obligation, justice and equality.

PHIL.title: Modal Logic
PHIL.description: Elements of propositional and quantified modal logic and the logic of counterfactual conditionals with an eye to some of their applications in contemporary philosophy.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL.description: Examination of contemporary theories of mind and its place in the natural world.

PHIL.title: Theories of Action
PHIL.description: Systematic investigation of action, the mental states involved in action, the reasoning processes that lead to action, and related concepts including intentionality and free will.

PHIL.title: Wittgenstein
PHIL.description: A detailed study of the philosophical works of Ludwig Wittgenstein.

PHIL.title: Topics in Philosophy, Politics and Economics
PHIL.description: The analysis of public policy debates combining the different tools and perspectives of philosophy, political science and economic theory.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL.description: The nature of mathematical truth and the nature of mathematical entities.

PHIL.title: Directed Research
PHIL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PHIL.title: Senior Thesis
PHIL.description: Independent studies for philosophy majors, and guidance in the preparation of the senior thesis for students who wish to graduate with honors in philosophy.

PHIL.title: Introduction to Contemporary Philosophical Literature
PHIL.description: Analysis of selected philosophical problems and theses of current interest; explication of major contemporary papers and/or books is emphasized.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Recent Philosophy
PHIL.description: Contemporary philosophical issues and literature.

PHIL.title: Studies in Ancient and Medieval Philosophy
PHIL.description: Problems in research in selected portions of ancient and medieval philosophy.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL.description: Advanced literature on selected topics in social and political philosophy, including the nature of law, man, and society; ideals such as justice and freedom.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Language
PHIL.description: Philosophical issues in the empirical study of language concerning the relationship between linguistic meaning and the use of sentences to assert and convey information.

PHIL.title: Directed Research
PHIL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.       Graded CR/NC.

PHIL.title: Teaching Philosophy
PHIL.description: Basic principles of philosophical pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first-semester teaching assistants in philosophy.

MATH.title: Basic Mathematical Skills
MATH.description: Review of Algebra. Real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, functions, graphs, systems of equations, exponents, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, radicals, quadratic equations and solutions. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Contemporary Precalculus
MATH.description: Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.

MATH.title: Foundations of Statistics
MATH.description: An introduction to the basic tools of statistics. Descriptive statistics; probability; expected value; normal approximation sampling; chance models; tests of significance.

MATH.title: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
MATH.description: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.

MATH.title: Calculus for Business and Economics
MATH.description: Derivatives and extrema. The definite integral and u-substitutions. Functions of several variables and their extrema; constrained optimization.

MATH.title: Calculus I
MATH.description: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.

MATH.title: Calculus II
MATH.description: A continuation of MATH 125: trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.

MATH.title: Calculus II for Engineers and Scientists
MATH.description: Trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 125. (Duplicates credit in MATH 126 and MATH 127)

MATH.title: Elementary Probability and Statistics
MATH.description: Descriptive statistics, probability, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Emphasis on health science. Prerequisite: MATH 118xg or MATH 125.

MATH.title: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
MATH.description: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.

MATH.title: Calculus III
MATH.description: Vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem, Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem.

MATH.title: Calculus III for Engineers and Scientists
MATH.description: A continuation of 129; vectors, vector valued functions;           differential and integral calculus of functions of several         variables; Greens theorem. Engineering and physics applications.   Prerequisite: MATH 126, or MATH 127, or MATH 129.(Duplicates       credit in MATH 226 and MATH 227)

MATH.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
MATH.description: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.

MATH.title: Mathematical Reasoning and Problem Solving
MATH.description: Preparation for reading and writing proofs with applications from major branches of mathematics, focusing on axiomatic structures and transformations that preserve structure.

MATH.title: Statistical Inference and Data Analysis I
MATH.description: Probability, counting, independence, distributions, random variables, simulation, expectation, variance, covariance, transformations, law of large numbers, Central limit theorem, estimation, efficiency, maximum likelihood, Cramer-Rao bound, bootstrap.

MATH.title: Seminar in Problem Solving
MATH.description: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory and games.

MATH.title: Probability Theory
MATH.description: Probability spaces.  Main families of discrete and continuous distributions and relations among them.  Moments, characteristic functions, sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, Central Limit Theorem.

MATH.title: Mathematical Statistics
MATH.description: Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, confidence intervals, methods of moments, maximum likelihood, information inequality, likelihood ratio tests, goodness of fit and nonparametric methods.

MATH.title: Fundamental Concepts of Modern Algebra
MATH.description: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.

MATH.title: Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
MATH.description: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.

MATH.title: Theory of Numbers
MATH.description: Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions and certain diophantine equations.

MATH.title: Applied Combinatorics
MATH.description: Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications.

MATH.title: Euclidean and Non-Euclidean Geometries
MATH.description: The Euclidean plane and its isometries. Models for the hyperbolic metric, isometries, linear fractional maps, geodesics.  Spherical geometry.

MATH.title: Topology
MATH.description: Cardinals, topologies, separation axioms. Compactness, metrizability, function spaces; completeness; Jordan curve theorem.

MATH.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
MATH.description: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations.

MATH.title: Data Science with Python
MATH.description: Python implementations of: data collection, data wrangling, exploratory data analysis, dimensionality reduction, unsupervised / supervised learning, clustering, classification, common predictive statistical / machine learning algorithms, model validation.

MATH.title: Mathematics of Machine Learning
MATH.description: Mathematical aspects of Machine Learning. PAC Learning, VC-dimension and complexity. Linear predictors (regression, perceptron, SVM). Convex learning and gradient descent. Neural networks and backpropagation.

MATH.title: Numerical Methods
MATH.description: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

MATH.title: Theory and Computational Methods for Optimization
MATH.description: Methods for static, dynamic, unconstrained, constrained optimization. Gradient, conjugate gradient, penalty methods. Lagrange multipliers, least squares, linear, nonlinear dynamic programming. Application to control and estimation.

MATH.title: Directed Research
MATH.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MATH.title: Numerical Analysis
MATH.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear       systems of equations; approximation theory using functional        analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential  equations.

MATH.title: Applied Probability
MATH.description: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions, conditional probability and expectation,; binomial, poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor.

MATH.title: Theory of Probability
MATH.description: a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic           functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable   and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions.                                      b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic    theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

MATH.title: Stochastic Differential Equations
MATH.description: Brownian motion, stochastic integrals, the Ito formula, stochastic differential equations, analysis of diffusion processes, Girsanov transformation, Feynmann-Kac formula, applications.

MATH.title: Algebra
MATH.description: Groups: Sylow theorems, simple, solvable, nilpotent, and linear groups; group extensions, free groups, finitely-generated abelian groups.  Fields: Galois correspondence, algebraic extensions, finite fields, cyclotomic fields

MATH.title: Data Analysis
MATH.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

MATH.title: Data Analysis
MATH.description: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package.  Includes laboratory.

MATH.title: Financial Informatics and Simulation (Computer Labs and Prac
MATH.description: Experimental laboratory trading for financial markets using double auctions: handling statistical packages for data analysis. Practical training in virtual market environments, using financial trading system software.

MATH.title: Lie Theory
MATH.description: Introduction to complex semisimple Lie algebras including classification via root systems, Cartan and Borel subalgebras, and the classification of representations via dominant weights.

MATH.title: Real Analysis
MATH.description: a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.

MATH.title: Stochastic Calculus and Mathematical Finance
MATH.description: Stochastic processes revisited, Brownian motion, Martingale theory, stochastic differential equations, Feynman-Kac formula, binomial models, basic concepts in arbitrage pricing theory, equivalent Martingale measure. Recommended preparation: Math-225, Math-407. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-503.

MATH.title: Combinatorial Analysis
MATH.description: Inversion formulas, generating functions and recursions, partitions, Stirling numbers, distinct representatives, Ramsey's theorem, graph theory, block designs, difference sets, finite geometrics, Latin squares, Hadamard matrices.

MATH.title: Differential Geometry
MATH.description: Geometry of manifolds. Connections and curvature. Riemannian manifolds and geodesics. Symplectic manifolds, complex manifolds and Kahler manifolds.

MATH.title: Algebraic Topology
MATH.description: Spaces up to homotopy equivalence. CW complexes. Fundamental group and covering spaces. Simplicial and singular homology and cohomology. Homological algebra. Manifolds and Poincare duality.

MATH.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
MATH.description: Hypotheses testing, Neyman-Pearson lemma, generalized likelihood ratio procedures, confidence intervals, consistency, power, jackknife and bootstrap. Monte Carlo Markov chain methods, hidden Markov models.

MATH.title: Mathematical Statistics for Data Science
MATH.description: Introduction to mathematical statistics for data science including theory of estimation and inference for parametric statistical models, point estimation, hypothesis testing, algorithms and implementation.

MATH.title: Mathematical Foundations of Statistical Learning Theory
MATH.description: Binary classification, empirical risk minimization, support vector machines, voting algorithms and AdaBoost, Vapnik-Chervonenkis combinatorics, concentration-of-measure inequalities, sparse recovery problems, high-dimensional convex geometry.

MATH.title: Foundations of Mathematical Data Science
MATH.description: An introduction to the principles behind and algorithms employed in data science including methods of linear algebra, probability theory and optimization theory; data science applications.

MATH.title: Statistical Consulting and Data Analysis
MATH.description: Coverage of modern statistical methods as applied to practical consulting and data analysis, and the use of the R statistical language.

MATH.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH.description: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic,          parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave  equations.

MATH.title: Mathematical Fluid Dynamics
MATH.description: Navier-Stokes equations, Euler equations, Helmholtz decomposition, weak solutions, strong solutions, pressure, vorticity, conditional regularity, partial regularity.

MATH.title: Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
MATH.description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant to genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

MATH.title: Directed Research
MATH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Master's Thesis
MATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

MATH.title: Master's Thesis
MATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

MATH.title: Master's Thesis
MATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts: Mathematics
MATH.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
MATH.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

MATH.title: Computational Complexity in Algebraic Combinatorics
MATH.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of mathematics.

MATH.title: Topics in Representation Theory
MATH.description: Structure and representation theory of various algebraic structures, such as groups, Lie algebras, Hopf algebras, algebraic groups, or group schemes.

MATH.title: Seminar in Numerical Analysis
MATH.description: Seminar in Numerical Analysis

MATH.title: Seminar in Combinatorics
MATH.description: Topics in combinatorics

MATH.title: Seminar in Statistics
MATH.description: Seminar in statistics.

MATH.description: Seminar in Partial Differential Equations

MATH.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
