PHED.title: Weight Training
PHED.description: Improvement of body shape, muscle endurance, and muscle  strength; understanding of weight training and nutrition  principles that can be utilized for future weight training  development.

PHED.title: Self-Defense
PHED.description: Basic instruction of self-defense for beginners; strategies for  standing and ground fighting situations with and without weapons.

PHED.title: Principles of Self Defense and Personal Safety
PHED.description: Application of learned skills and strategies for identifying physical threats; increased situational awareness; understanding of when physical force may be required.

PHED.title: Physical Conditioning
PHED.description: a: Improvement in cardiorespiratory endurance, body composition,  muscle endurance and flexibility; running, circuit training,  resistance exercises; fitness principles and nutrition to develop  individualized program.

PHED.title: Swimming
PHED.description: a: Instruction and practice of basic strokes for beginners and  intermediate swimmers; elementary springboard diving; water safety  techniques; endurance training as a fitness program.

PHED.title: Surfing
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of surfing skills; water safety and wave etiquette; wave recognition and forecast interpretation; surf culture; board selection; surf related strengthening and conditioning.

PHED.title: Sustainability and Self-Care
PHED.description: Alternative ways to integrate sustainability practices into a daily routine; develop individual self-care modalities and connect to our planet; navigate climate anxiety.

PHED.title: Sleep for Peak Performance
PHED.description: Introduction to sleep as it relates to physical and mental performance; breathing and meditation modalities to support healthy sleep; study of sleep systems, disorders, strategies.

PHED.title: Introduction to Mindfulness
PHED.description: Introduction to the principles of mindfulness; application of learned techniques to enhance mind body awareness; cultivate strategies to improve physical and mental health.

PHED.title: Course Emphasis: Athletic Performance
PHED.description: Introduction to the principles of mindfulness; application of learned techniques to enhance mind body awareness; cultivate strategies to improve physical and mental health.

PHED.title: Yoga
PHED.description: Introduction to meditation, breathing techniques and postures as a means towards relaxation; increase muscle flexibility, understanding of basic anatomy and nutritional guidelines.

PHED.title: Yoga
PHED.description: A continuing study of intermediate and advanced yoga postures,  breathing techniques and meditation as a means toward relaxation  and stress-reduction.

PHED.title: Kundalini Yoga
PHED.description: Ancient yoga practice combining postures, meditation, breathing, mantras and focus techniques; designed to improve mind body awareness, balance, strength, flexibility, techniques and nervous system function.

PHED.title: Yoga Therapy
PHED.description: Holistic discipline combining traditional yoga techniques with a modern medicine approach to treating a variety of health conditions; includes physical, mental and breathing practice.

PHED.title: Walking for Fitness
PHED.description: Develop a strong fitness foundation through walking; fitness assessment and individualized programs; gait biomechanics and power walking; injury prevention; strategies for special populations.

PHED.title: AcroYoga
PHED.description: Groups work together to build strength, balance, coordination and communication skills, emphasizing dynamic movement of acrobatics, mindfulness of yoga, spotting and handstand training.

PHED.title: Principles of Yoga Through Community Outreach
PHED.description: Introduction and reinforcement of yoga postures, breathing techniques and meditation; sharing yoga principles and benefits with grade schools; teaching and community service opportunity.

PHED.title: Cardio Group Fitness
PHED.description: Group fitness instruction incorporating a variety of training methods such as cycling, HITT (high intensity interval training), step, circuits; nutritional guidelines.

PHED.title: Distance Running
PHED.description: Introduction to distance running while training for a 5k, 10k or half marathon; gait biomechanics and running efficiency; injury prevention; nutrition guidelines.

PHED.title: Hiking
PHED.description: Introduction to hiking; specific conditioning to develop muscle strength and endurance; equipment; various terrain, weather conditions, safety; environmental impact and trail etiquette.

PHED.title: Backpacking
PHED.description: Acquisition of backpacking knowledge and skills; conditioning plan; nutrition and equipment selection; ethics and environmental considerations; navigation, safety and wilderness first aid; trip planning.

PHED.title: Beach Volleyball
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to sand volleyball and related physical conditioning; rules and strategies; history and culture.

PHED.title: Volleyball
PHED.description: a: Introduction to beginning and intermediate volleyball skills, rules, game tactics, and strategies. Emphasis on the development of: passing, setting, hitting, serving, blocking, and digging.

PHED.title: Tennis
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and  intermediate players; rules, scoring, court etiquette, strategies;  singles and doubles; practice and match play.

PHED.title: Pickleball
PHED.description: Introduction to pickleball; develop basic skills, techniques and fundamentals; rules, scoring, etiquette and strategies of play (singles/doubles play).

PHED.title: Archery
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of archery technique for beginners and intermediates; historical origins; form; the shot cycle; mindfulness; scoring; equipment; sport specific training.

PHED.title: Table Tennis
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginning and intermediate players; rules, scoring strategies; singles and doubles; practices and match play.

PHED.title: Badminton
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, strategies; footwork and court positioning; practical drills and games.

PHED.title: Futsal
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to Futsal; rules; strategies; elements of play that differ from soccer; conditioning, drills and games.

PHED.title: Soccer
PHED.description: Development of basic skills for beginners, intermediate and  advanced players; rules, positioning elements of play, small group  and team tactics; full field scrimmages.

PHED.title: Golf
PHED.description: Basic skills development and knowledge in stance, grip and swing mechanics; course strategy; use of woods, irons and putting; history rules and etiquette.

PHED.title: Basketball
PHED.description: a: Basic skill development in dribbling, passing, shooting,  rebounding and defense; rules, history, and etiquette; drills and  full court games.

PHED.title: Stress Management for Healthy Living
PHED.description: Instruction on the effects of stress as it relates to work, sport  and academics; coping strategies are discussed and applied through  physical conditioning interventions.

PHED.title: First Aid
PHED.description: First aid safety education and infant, child, and adult CPR; demonstrated proficiency and successful completion of exam prepares students for Red Cross certification.

PHED.title: Principles of Athletic Coaching
PHED.description: Introduction to coaching strategies; team management; philosophy; ethics; leadership. Methodologies in sport specific training; skill progression; conditioning; athlete motivation; budgeting; fundraising.

PHED.title: Health Coaching
PHED.description: Skills and strategies of coaching principles promoting healthy lifestyle change. Motivational communication techniques; goal setting; designing safe, effective exercise program; health coach certification exam preparation.

PHED.title: Varsity Athletics
PHED.description: Participation in the University's intercollegiate programs as      sanctioned and governed by the PAC-10 conference and/or the NCAA.   Graded CR/NC.

PHED.title: Leadership Considerations In Sport/Health/Movement
PHED.description: Selected topics in Physical Education, including mindfulness and  stress management, offered in a variety of settings.

POSC.title: Theory and Practice of American Democracy
POSC.description: Theoretical, institutional, and functional aspects of American national, state, and local government and politics; contemporary issues. Recommended for freshmen and sophomores.

POSC.title: Comparative Politics
POSC.description: Gateway to the major in political science. Comparative analysis of political institutions and processes in selected industrial, developing and socialist countries, in terms of contrasting ideologies, parties, elites, and economies.

POSC.title: Law, Politics and Public Policy
POSC.description: Interaction between law and politics; overview of the American legal system; value conflicts and public policy questions which arise within it.

POSC.title: Law and Politics
POSC.description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.

POSC.title: Social Analysis of Gender
POSC.description: Multidisciplinary survey of gender assumptions in relation to sexuality, mental health, social and political relations, and artistic expression.

POSC.title: Human Rights
POSC.description: Overview of human rights controversies across the globe. Introduction to techniques of analysis for social issues, interdisciplinary research methods, and interpretation of complex political problems.

POSC.title: Environmental Challenges
POSC.description: Examination of the challenges of environmental problem-solving at the personal, local, national and global scales, focused on the issue of climate change.

POSC.title: Urban Politics
POSC.description: Evolution of contemporary institutions; differing views of community power; major policies; state and federal relations to local governments; metropolitan community problems.

POSC.title: Asian American Politics
POSC.description: Examines political attitudes, behavior and participation of Asian  Americans in diverse U.S. society.

POSC.title: Interest Groups and Elite Behavior
POSC.description: Introduction to interest group and elite views of the American system, including recent interest group theory and findings and the general critiques of power distribution in American society.

POSC.title: International Law
POSC.description: Nature, origin, and development of international law; basic principles analyzed and illustrated with cases.

POSC.title: Politics of Latin America
POSC.description: Theories of development and nation-building; revolutionary and evolutionary modernization; role of history, culture, socioeconomic conditions in affecting political structures and functions.

POSC.title: Middle East Politics
POSC.description: Political development in the Middle East, emphasizing historical, cultural, and socioeconomic conditions affecting political structures and functions; modernization and countervailing social, economic and religious forces.

POSC.title: Politics of East Asia
POSC.description: Institutions and processes of advanced societies; political culture, interest articulation and aggregation, the governmental process.

POSC.title: Politics of Sub-Sahara Africa
POSC.description: Theories of development and nation-building; revolutionary and evolutionary modernization; role of history, culture, socioeconomic conditions in affecting political structures and functions.

POSC.title: Terrorism and Genocide
POSC.description: Comparative analysis of the determinants of political violence, terrorism, and genocide and their social and moral consequences; application of theories to contemporary case studies.

POSC.title: European Political Thought I
POSC.description: Basic concepts of Western political thought from Plato through the contract theorists.

POSC.title: Political Theories and Social Reform
POSC.description: Political theories and philosophies in modern times and their relation to public policy and social reform.

POSC.title: Sex, Power, and Politics
POSC.description: An evaluation of the ways in which different ideologies, institutions, and policies contribute to differences in political power between men and women.

POSC.title: Honors I: Undergraduate Seminar
POSC.description: Selected topics in designated area of political science. Discussion of readings and presentation of papers.

POSC.title: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
POSC.description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.

POSC.title: Trial Advocacy: Theory and Practice
POSC.description: Course covering substantive law, evidence, public speaking and use  of societal mores in courtroom advocacy. Open only to Mock Trial  team members.

POSC.title: Political Participation and American Diversity
POSC.description: Examines how diverse groups in the U.S. interact with the American  political system.

POSC.title: Political Economy of Mexico
POSC.description: Examination of contemporary Mexico: the role of the state in the Mexican economy; development of the government party and opposition groups.

POSC.title: Politics of Local Criminal Justice
POSC.description: Roles and behavior of major legal and political participants in the criminal justice system including the police, the legal profession, judges, and the public.

POSC.title: Environmental Politics
POSC.description: The political realities of selected environmental issues; resolving and implementing social priorities; interests, attitudes, strategies, and tactics of pressure groups; institutional biases and opportunities.

POSC.title: Mass Media and Politics
POSC.description: Analysis of political content of mass media. Audience response to alternative sources of political information. Consideration of the institutional and economic as well as political aspects of the mass media.

POSC.title: Fixing American Democracy: Electoral Institutions and        Reforms
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

POSC.title: The Politics of Human Differences: Diversity and Discriminat
POSC.description: A comparative perspective on social and cultural forces that affect American laws and policies concerning discrimination on the basis of race or ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, and disability.

POSC.title: Politics of Resources and Development
POSC.description: Comparison of relationships between rich and poor countries involving political and economic resources and prospects for development; impact on industrialized states; interdependence; new international economic order.

POSC.title: Contemporary Civil Rights Law
POSC.description: Intensive examination of special topics in the field of law and public policy.

POSC.title: Current Issues in International Human Rights
POSC.description: Intensive examination of special topics in the field of law and public policy.

POSC.title: The Politics of Rights.
POSC.description: Intensive examination of special topics in the field of law and public policy.

POSC.title: Politics and Film in Comparative Perspective
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.

POSC.title: Soft Power in Political Science and International Relations
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.

POSC.title: Critical Issues in Political Thought
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of political thought.

POSC.title: Directed Research
POSC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PDF.title: Postdoctoral Fellows
PDF.description: Course created for visiting postdoctoral fellows scholars.  The  course is created for enrollment purposes, zero units, full time  status, scheduled in session 018, and never appears in the student  academic records system.

RNR.title: International Academy Holding Course
RNR.description: Course created per request from the International Academy to  create a zero unit, zero charge course for the purpose of enabling  services for the student  population.  Tuition is paid directly to  the Academy.

RNR.title: International Academy Holding Course (Part II)
RNR.description: Course created per request from the International Academy to  create a zero unit, zero charge course for the purpose of enabling  services for the student population. This course serves the  popuation that has successfully completed RNR-050.  Tuition is  paid directly to the Academy.

RUSS.title: Beginning Russian I
RUSS.description: Introduction to the Russian language with emphasis on basic conversational skills, major points of grammar and reading.

RUSS.title: Intermediate Russian I
RUSS.description: Development of thematic conversational skills with emphasis on extended dialogue. Review of basic morphology with special attention to verbs of motion. Reading of authentic material is emphasized.

RUSS.title: Advanced Russian in Popular Culture
RUSS.description: Advanced conversation, reading, grammar and topical analysis of Russian press, films and other popular sources. Conducted in Russian.

SLL.title: Elementary Polish I
SLL.description: Structure of the language, pronunciation, basic communication, and reading in modern Polish.

SLL.title: Chess and Critical Thinking
SLL.description: Analysis of significant chess games, reflecting societal attitudes  towards science, competition, art, gender, psychology, politics,  and technology.  Graded CR/NC.

SLL.title: Readings in Polish Literature I
SLL.description: Continuation of elementary Polish and introduction to outstanding works in Polish literature. Prerequisite: 122 and 152.

SLL.title: Russian Thought and Civilization
SLL.description: Russian cultural identity from its beginnings until today. The Eastern Orthodox tradition, its traumatic confrontation with Western culture, and their continuous interaction.

SLL.title: Topics in Advanced Russian
SLL.description: Study of Russian required for graduate work and professional activities.

SLL.title: Proseminar in Russian Literature
SLL.description: Introduction to graduate study of Russian literature; research methods, bibliography, transliteration, development of critical writing skills.

SLL.title: Structure of Modern Russian
SLL.description: Covers fundamental aspects of the linguistic structure of modern Russian. Examines linguistic and pedagogical approaches to the analysis of morphology, syntax, phonetics and vocabulary.

SLL.title: Methods of Teaching Russian as a Foreign Language
SLL.description: Introduces future Assistant Lecturers to the communicative method of teaching Russian and focuses on theories and methods of teaching the language, as well as key concepts of second language acquisition.

SLL.title: Soviet Literature I (1917-1953)
SLL.description: Survey of the major writers and literary schools of Soviet literature in the crucial period from the Revolution to the death of Stalin.

SLL.title: Directed Research
SLL.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SLL.title: Research
SLL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IRAN.title: Persian I
IRAN.description: Introduction to contemporary Persian (Farsi). Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for simple spoken and written expression. (Duplicates credit in former MDES-120)

IRAN.title: Persian III
IRAN.description: Intermediate Persian (Farsi). Building conversational skills, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for intermediate level spoken and written expression. Prerequisite: IRAN 150. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 220)

IRAN.title: Advanced Persian I
IRAN.description: Advanced verbal and written expression in Persian, including deeper understanding of Persian culture. Prerequisite: IRAN 250. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 320)

POIR.title: Directed Research
POIR.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

POIR.title: Practicum in Teaching Politics and International Relations
POIR.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within political science and international relations disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
POIR.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

POIR.title: Political Economy and Public Policy
POIR.description: Subjects in one or more fields in Political Science.

POIR.title: Research Design
POIR.description: The course will cover the design of experimental and observational research. We will examine both quantitative and qualitative approaches to social science research. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Introduction to Regression Analysis
POIR.description: The course will introduce students to regression analysis and its application to social science research. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Topics in Quantitative Analysis
POIR.description: Introduces statistical models beyond the standard linear regression model. Topics include maximum likelihood estimation, generalized linear models and advanced methods.

POIR.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods
POIR.description: Bayesian inference in the social sciences and causal inference literature, including experiments, matching, difference-in-difference and regression discontinuity.

POIR.title: Seminar in Problems of American Politics
POIR.description: Theoretical and methodological problems in American politics with emphasis on emerging research paradigms. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

POIR.title: American Politics Field Seminar Part II
POIR.description: A theoretical and empirical overview of the American politics field. Theoretical topics include behavioralism, rational choice, political psychology; empirical topics include causality. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: International Law
POIR.description: Topics and cases illustrating general principles and problems in international law. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

POIR.title: Introduction to International Relations Theory
POIR.description: The primary objective of this course is to introduce Ph.D. students to theoretical and empirical issues related to the study of international relations. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Research
POIR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

POIR.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Immigrant America
SOCI.description: Examination of the immigrant experience in the United States. Comparative analysis of social context of migration, formation of immigrant communities, and social integration of immigrants.

SOCI.title: Introduction to Sociology
SOCI.description: Basic concepts of sociology with special reference to group life,social institutions, and social processes.

SOCI.title: Science, Technology, and Social Conflict
SOCI.description: Science and technology change society and how we understand ourselves. In turn, social struggles influence science. We will explore the interplay between these forces.

SOCI.title: Sociology, Demography and Health
SOCI.description: Sociological and demographic concepts focusing on the causes of disease, health and wellness. Empirical analysis of population composition and its connection to health.

SOCI.title: Sociological Theory
SOCI.description: Historical and contemporary approaches to sociological theory; analysis of conceptual frameworks applied to the study of society and social interaction.

SOCI.title: Sociology of Childhood
SOCI.description: Social construction of childhood; children's social relations and cultures; issues of childcare, poverty, violence and children's rights; effects of children on adults.

SOCI.title: Sociological Research Methods
SOCI.description: Logic of theory construction, research design, elementary data collection and analysis.

SOCI.title: Analyzing Social Statistics
SOCI.description: Sociological measurement, univariate description, elementary correlation, introduction to statistical inference.

SOCI.title: Applied Social Research Methods
SOCI.description: Use quantitative or qualitative analysis skills to study major social issues using large existing survey data sets or qualitative methods. Become conversant in describing data to a variety of audiences.

SOCI.title: Health, Gender and Ethnicity
SOCI.description: Cross-cultural notions of the body, health, and healing; historic and cultural variability of ideas of reproduction, birth, sexuality, mental illness and disability.

SOCI.title: Crime, Punishment and Society
SOCI.description: Explores cultural definitions, media constructions and measurement of crime. Places crime and punishment in larger social context and examines socio-cultural, economic and political factors.

SOCI.title: Social Inequality: Class, Status and Power
SOCI.description: Inequalities in wealth, prestige and power in the United States; the American class structure and the extent of upward mobility in that structure.

SOCI.title: The Family in a Changing Society
SOCI.description: Changing family patterns; personality development; family unity, predicting success in marriage; the family in transition; crises such as economic changes, death, divorce; family reorganization.

SOCI.title: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Communities
SOCI.description: Survey of current social and political issues facing Asian         American communities with emphasis on Los Angeles region; design   and implementation of community-based research projects.

SOCI.title: Environmental Sociology
SOCI.description: Explores the causes and possible solutions to the environmental crisis, with emphasis on the politics of environmental knowledge and regulation.

SOCI.title: Sociology of Gender and Work
SOCI.description: Examination of gender inequality in the U.S. labor market; work-family conflict; employer remedies; comparative social policy.

SOCI.title: Medical Sociology
SOCI.description: Social and cultural factors in causation of disease, health care utilization and health care delivery.

SOCI.title: Directed Research
SOCI.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SOCI.title: Sociology Professional Seminar
SOCI.description: Introduces students to the theoretical questions and methodological approaches that comprise the discipline of sociology. Experts in each subfield share their latest research with students.

SOCI.title: Sociological Theory I
SOCI.description: Developments in sociological theory from the discipline's nineteenth century origins to World War II.

SOCI.title: Quantitative Methods and Statistics I
SOCI.description: Introduction to the logic and tools of quantitative analysis in sociology; covers the basic elements of designing research, summarizing and exploring patterns in data, and making generalizations about populations based on characteristics of samples.

SOCI.title: Directed Research
SOCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
SOCI.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within college disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Advanced Methods--Qualitative Research
SOCI.description: Seminar and practicum in conducting and interpreting original qualitative research. Prerequisite: SOCI 520. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 524.

SOCI.title: Political Sociology: Politics, Symbols and Everyday Life
SOCI.description: Political power, conflict and apathy; public symbols, debate and discourse; nationalism; relations between politics, provision of social services and economics in comparative and historical perspective. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 537.

SOCI.title: Social Movements
SOCI.description: Theories explaining collective action and the outcomes of those struggles.

SOCI.title: Research
SOCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be     applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded   CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SMGT.title: Introduction to Sustainability
SMGT.description: History and evolution of sustainability, including definitions, models and policies relevant to current global sustainability and advocacy.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Fundamentals
SMGT.description: Evolution of business sustainability; environmental, social and governance (ESG) performance; and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

SMGT.title: Business Strategy for a Sustainable World
SMGT.description: Business strategies, practices, and performance metrics that champion sustainability as part of organizational purpose.

SMGT.title: Leading Organizational Transformation for Sustainability
SMGT.description: Organizational transformation through integration of sustainability into values, culture, leadership, talent, workflow and strategy.

SMGT.title: Sustainable Supply and Global Value Chains
SMGT.description: Sustainable management of supply chains and global value chains to increase benefits to business, the environment and society.

SMGT.title: The Circular Economy and Sustainable Design
SMGT.description: Interrelationship of circular economy and sustainable design strategies to reduce waste and negative social and environmental impacts.

SMGT.title: Sustainable Finance and Capital Markets
SMGT.description: Sustainable investment and finance strategies for both investors and companies.

SMGT.title: Business Strategies for Addressing Climate Change
SMGT.description: Principles of climate science and the role of business in mitigating the effects of a changing climate.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Metrics and Reporting
SMGT.description: Strategies for organizations to identify, measure and report on prioritized sustainability issues.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Management Strategy Capstone
SMGT.description: Knowledge and skills gained throughout the Sustainability Management program are synthesized in a culminating capstone project.

SPAN.title: Spanish I
SPAN.description: For students with limited proficiency in Spanish. Practice in     listening comprehension, oral communication, elementary reading    and writing.

SPAN.title: Spanish II
SPAN.description: Continuation of Spanish 110 or 120; increased emphasis on listening comprehension, oral expression, reading and writing.

SPAN.title: Spanish III
SPAN.description: Continuation of SPAN 150; intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication, reading, and writing with emphasis on free expression; readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization. Prereq: SPAN 150 or equivalent.

SPAN.title: Spanish IV
SPAN.description: Intensive review of Spanish grammar with emphasis on four skills. Audio-visual materials and readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization.

SPAN.title: Advanced Spanish: Arts and Sciences
SPAN.description: Development of students' oral and writing skills using literary and scientific materials; grammar review. Duplicates credit in the former SPAN 266.

SPAN.title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers
SPAN.description: Culture-based course designed for Spanish speakers not formally trained in the language. Review language and grammar and hone presentational skills.

SPAN.title: Conversational Spanish
SPAN.description: Discussions of short films, cultural and literary texts and other activities designed to improve conversational skills. Prerequisite: SPAN 220. Not for credit for Spanish majors.

SPAN.title: Gender and Sexuality in Latin American and Spanish Cinema
SPAN.description: Examines the representation of gender and sexual discourses and  the intersection with wider social, political and theoretical  issues in Latin American and Spanish cinema. Taught in English.

SPAN.title: Introduction to Literature and Film
SPAN.description: Introduction to critical reading and interpretation of poetry, narrative fiction, drama and film from Spain and Latin America.

SPAN.title: Structure of Spanish
SPAN.description: A systematic study of the structure of Spanish. Topics include fundamental aspects of the sound system; word classes; sentences and their meaning; linguistic change and variation; standard and colloquial usage.

SPAN.title: Advanced Grammar and Translation
SPAN.description: Contrastive study of Spanish and English structures designed to explore the similarities and differences between the two languages and to familiarize students with translation techniques. Emphasis on a variety of text types with the aim of increasing linguistic and cultural appreciation of the Spanish language.

SPAN.title: Journalism and Social Media
SPAN.description: The language and culture of a particular area of study or profession, such as medicine and healthcare, political and social sciences, business and the law. Limited to 4 units for major or minor credit.

SPAN.title: Medicine and Healthcare
SPAN.description: The language and culture of a particular area of study or profession, such as medicine and healthcare, political and social sciences, business and the law. Limited to 4 units for major or minor credit.

SPAN.title: The Culture of Food in Hispanic Los Angeles
SPAN.description: Experiential learning and project-based course designed to familiarize students with the food culture of Hispanic Los Angeles. Students create Spanish language blogs about their experiences.

SPAN.title: Gender and Sexuality
SPAN.description: An examination of gender, sexuality, and power in Iberian and Latin American literatures and cultures.  Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN.title: Cultural Narratives of Spain and Latin America
SPAN.description: Theoretical and methodological approaches to cultural narratives in Spanish and Latin American literary and cultural studies.

SPAN.title: Practicum in Teaching Spanish
SPAN.description: Approaches and techniques in the teaching of Spanish and/or Portuguese as a second language.Open only to Master and Doctoral students in Comparative Literature, Comparative Culture in Literature and Studies (Spanish and Latin American Studies), Linguistics (Hispanic Linguistics) and Spanish.

SSCI.title: Maps in the Digital World
SSCI.description: The role of formal reasoning, abstract representation and empirical analysis in building maps for sharing knowledge across the physical, life and social sciences and humanities.

SSCI.title: Sustainability Science in the City
SSCI.description: The influence of sustainability science on public policy and vice versa in the context of social/ethical theories, analytical methods and solutions.

SSCI.title: Food, Health and Place
SSCI.description: The role of food systems in human nutrition and environmental health, and system transformations needed to achieve good health, equity and sustainability.

SSCI.title: Principles of Geodesign
SSCI.description: Foundations of geodesign combining place-making, design, collective action, and the science of location-based information to improve human interaction with the functioning of the Earth.

SSCI.title: Principles of Geospatial Intelligence
SSCI.description: Introduction to basic geospatial intelligence knowledge and related practical applications that assist in informing decision-making in a variety of human security settings.

SSCI.title: Human Populations and Natural Hazards
SSCI.description: Introduction to the complex relationship between human development and natural hazards, which are increasingly causing damage and displacement to human populations throughout the world.

SSCI.title: Spatial Data Collection Using Drones
SSCI.description: Develop the requisite knowledge and practical skills to source, analyze, and produce GIS and simulation-based projects with unmanned aerial systems-derived data.

SSCI.title: The Water Planet
SSCI.description: An exploration of earth's water, ranging from water properties, chemistry, and pollution, to groundwater dynamics, watershed processes, and oceanic-atmospheric circulation. Implications for past and future societies. Lecture and laboratory.

SSCI.title: Maps and Spatial Reasoning
SSCI.description: Role of maps and spatial reasoning in the production and use of geographic information for representing and analyzing human and environmental activities and events.

SSCI.title: Global Geodesign and Stakeholder Engagement
SSCI.description: Concepts, practices and contexts of public engagement and their importance to the geodesign process.

SSCI.title: Statistics for the Spatial Sciences
SSCI.description: Conceptual foundations and techniques of statistics and how they can be used with geographic data to produce actionable information across spatial science domains.

SSCI.title: Spatial Sciences Internship
SSCI.description: Intensive experience in local public agency, private firm, or nonprofit agency engaged in applied geospatial analysis, modeling and mapping work.

SSCI.title: Geospatial Technology Management for Sustainability Science
SSCI.description: Principles and techniques for leveraging geospatial technologies and information in support of sustainability, with emphasis on coupling human and natural systems for global sustainable development.

SSCI.title: Directed Research
SSCI.description: Individual research and readings. Open only to juniors and seniors. Not available for graduate credit.

SSCI.title: GIS and Landscape Architecture
SSCI.description: The use of GIS, spatial analysis, modeling, and 2- and 3-D mapping to support landscape architecture projects that span multiple spatiotemporal scales.

SSCI.title: Spatial Econometrics
SSCI.description: Introduction to the theoretical foundations, methods, and software systems for spatial econometrics using a variety of use cases.

SSCI.title: Spatial Data Science
SSCI.description: Introduce the spatial data scientific approach to issues and present a holistic generalizable analysis pipeline.

SSCI.title: Human Security and Disaster Management
SSCI.description: The relationship between human security (population growth, urbanization, conflict) and disasters, both man-made and natural, where complex emergencies are impactful to human populations.

SSCI.title: Geospatial Intelligence Tradecraft
SSCI.description: Typical geospatial intelligence tasks and their use in military operations, national and homeland security, international relief work and disaster management. Recommended preparation: SSCI-581.

SSCI.title: Concepts for Spatial Thinking
SSCI.description: The unique characteristics and importance of spatial information as they relate to the evolving science, technology, and applications of Geographic Information Systems.

SSCI.title: Spatial Analysis and Modeling
SSCI.description: Provides the knowledge and skills necessary to investigate the spatial patterns which result from social and physical processes operating at or near the Earth's surface.

SSCI.title: GIS Programming and Customization
SSCI.description: Design, coding, and implementation of GIS-based software and models using the Python programming language. Recommended preparation: SSCI 582. Duplicates credit in former GEOG 586.

SSCI.title: Spatial Data Acquisition
SSCI.description: Role of global positioning systems, maps, geocoding, and other kinds of sensors as geospatial data sources. Includes field data acquisition excursion on Catalina Island. Recommended preparation: SSCI-581. Duplicates credit in former GEOG 587.

SSCI.title: Cartography and Visualization
SSCI.description: Principles of visual perception, spatial cognition and cartographic design and their contributions to the maps, animations, virtual reality and multimedia displays produced with modern GIS. Recommended preparation: SSCI 581.

SSCI.title: Directed Research
SSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Internship in Spatial Sciences
SSCI.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study at an off-campus facility under faculty direction.

SSCI.title: The Geography of Life and Death
SSCI.description: Meaning and significance of place and role of social, natural, and built environments in disease occurrence in different places and populations. Open only to doctoral students.

SSCI.title: Advanced Quantitative Methods for Population, Health and Pla
SSCI.description: Fundamentals of temporal and spatiotemporal data analysis; modern methods for evaluating, managing, and visualizing spatiotemporal data; hands-on use cases.

SSCI.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
SSCI.description: Principles of pedagogy for teaching the liberal arts, focusing on issues and technologies for spatial thinking. Required for first-semester teaching assistants in spatial sciences.

SSCI.title: Research
SSCI.description: Research leading to the doctoral degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open  only to doctoral students.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

CORE.title: Symbols and Conceptual Systems: Thematic Option Honors Progr
CORE.description: Study of the structures through which we shape our experience in religion, philosophy, literature, music, and the visual arts, and of competing theories of interpretation. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: Culture and Values: Thematic Option Honors Program
CORE.description: Systematic reasoning about values and ways of living; close reading of great literary and philosophical works from a range of classical traditions to the present.

CORE.title: The Process of Change in Science: Thematic Option Honors Pro
CORE.description: Critical problems in the development of scientific thought, studied as vehicles for understanding the content and structure of the sciences. Specific subject matter in selected scientific disciplines will be presented. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: Change and the Future: Thematic Option Honors Program
CORE.description: Analysis of historical change; social and political theory and revolutionary thought; introduction to competing images of future states of affairs; the continuing process of change. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: Writing Seminar I: Thematic Option Honors Program
CORE.description: The first level writing course focuses on the relationship between critical thinking and analytic writing through the close reading of primary texts. Seminars are supplemented with biweekly one-on-one tutorials.

CORE.title: Liberal Arts Reading Salon
CORE.description: Critical readings of a series of texts in the liberal arts  designed to promote discussion of important themes, theoretical  approaches, research directions, and interdisciplinary  connections.  Graded CR/NC.

CORE.title: Los Angeles: A Polymathic Inquiry
CORE.description: A guided polymathic inquiry into Los Angeles as fact and imaginative creation, featuring in-depth student research and projects.

CORE.title: Teaching Analytical Writing through Readings in the Humanities
CORE.description: Theories and practices in university-level teaching of  close-reading and analytical writing, using texts central to  Western tradition.  Graduate student professionalization throught  topical workshops and discussions.  Open to assistant lecturers  and teaching assistants only.  Graded CR/NC.

PORT.title: Portuguese I
PORT.description: For students with no proficiency in Portuguese.  Practice in  listening comprehension, oral communication, elementary reading  and writing.

PORT.title: Portuguese III
PORT.description: Intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication,  reading and writing, with emphasis on free expression; readings  related to Portuguese culture and civilization.

PEPP.title: Political Economy of Institutions
PEPP.description: The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution. Prerequisites: ECON-500 or ECON-601.

USC.title: WBB Semester At Large
USC.description: This is a zero unit, zero cost class to maintain USC student  status for WBB students while they are away studying at KHUST and  Bocconi.  Enrollment in this class will grant full time student  status at USC with access to student services.

USC.title: TEMPORARY ENROLLMENT/FILL COURSE
USC.description: The registration for this course should only be temporary. There is no instruction in this course. (Used for special purposes by Registration.)

USC.title: Overseas Block Enrollment
USC.description: Block enrollment course for registration purposes only.

USC.title: Off-Campus Studies
USC.description: Course created to accomodate situations in which students enrolled  in block overseas enrollment courses fail to complete the course.   Depending upon the particular circumstances, the student will be  assigned a mark of W or NC.

USC.title: Off Campus Studies
USC.description: Off campus coursework; course serves as a block enrollment until  transcript from host institution is provided and can be  articulated into an MOI that results in individual courses on the  USC transcript with section titles that reflect the title of the  course at the host institution.

VISS.title: Introduction to Visual Studies:  Methods and Debates
VISS.description: A critical introduction to the field of visual studies focusing on interdisciplinary approaches to images, objects, and visual technologies as well as key texts and interpretive debates.

QBIO.title: Statistics for Biological Sciences
QBIO.description: Statistical methods in biological science and medicine, including populations and samples, random sampling, confidence intervals, paired samples and regression.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
QBIO.description: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.

QBIO.title: Principles and Applications of Systems Biology
QBIO.description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Machine Learning in Biology
QBIO.description: Fundamentals of ML; regression analysis, classification methods, clustering techniques; dimensionality reduction methods, ensemble learning and deep learning technologies; applications in various biological contexts; project-based.

QBIO.title: Statistical and Evolutionary Genetics
QBIO.description: Introduction to the mathematical modeling and statistical analysis of genetic variation, including genetic drift, natural selection, mutation, migration, population structure, family studies and GWAS.

QBIO.title: Structural Bioinformatics: From Atoms to Cells
QBIO.description: Introduction to physical and statistical methods, molecular simulations, machine learning and AI for structural bioinformatics studies of proteins, nucleic acids, molecular complexes and whole cells.

QBIO.title: Directed Research
QBIO.description: Individual research and readings. Project approval by  faculty adviser and QCB department required.

QBIO.title: Quantitative Biology Honors Seminar
QBIO.description: Student-led discussions of recent research in quantitative biology and presentation of their own research.

QBIO.title: Probability and Statistics for Computational Sciences
QBIO.description: Graduate-level introduction to probability theory and mathematical statistics for students in the sciences and engineering, with examples largely from biology.

QBIO.title: Seminar in Computational Biology
QBIO.description: Experience and training in giving science research presentations. Students will discuss recent research in computational biology and bioinformatics.

QBIO.title: Ethics and Professional Conduct in Computational Biology
QBIO.description: Discussion-based ethics course for graduate students, with topics including authorship, peer review, publication, research misconduct, discrimination in science, data privacy and algorithmic bias.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms for Science
QBIO.description: An introduction to scientific data analysis; fundamentals of data structures and algorithms; specialized algorithms used in the sciences; challenges posed by large scientific data sets.

QBIO.title: Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
QBIO.description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant to genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

QBIO.title: Computational Molecular Biology
QBIO.description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Statistics for genomic sequence data: DNA sequence assembly, significance of alignment scores, hidden Markov models, genetic mapping, models of sequence evolution and microarray analysis.

QBIO.title: Directed Research
QBIO.description: Research leading to a graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

QBIO.title: Practicum in Teaching Quantitative and Computational Biology
QBIO.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within science and engineering disciplines. Intended for teaching assistant training as required by the university.

QBIO.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
QBIO.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed one semester of enrollment in a graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. The course is graded CR/NC.

QBIO.title: Research
QBIO.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

QBIO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
QBIO.description: For doctoral students who have passed the qualifying exam. Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

QBIO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
QBIO.description: For doctoral students who have passed the qualifying exam. Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

QBIO.description: For doctoral students who have passed the qualifying exam. Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

REL.title: Introduction to Christianity: Antiquity to 1500
REL.description: Survey of the changing beliefs and practices of the Christian religion from its origins through early modernity (100 CE - 1500 CE), with special attention to different varieties of Christian literature.

REL.title: Indian Traditions of Mind and Body
REL.description: Explores a variety of sophisticated theories and practices from India relating to the mind, body, medicine and religion.

REL.title: Chinese Religions and Culture
REL.description: Historical and thematic survey of Chinese religious history from earliest times to the present.

REL.title: Spirituality in America
REL.description: Examination of the historical continuities and disjunctions between "spiritual but not religious" Americans; the relationship between spirituality, politics and social change, and the role of media.

REL.title: Introduction to the Study of Religion
REL.description: Survey of academic approaches to the study of religion. When possible this course will be taken during the first year of the major or minor.

REL.title: Virtual and Digital Culture, Heritage and Archaeology
REL.description: In-depth exploration of 3D digital, immersive, virtual or extended reality visualizations of cultural heritage, archaeology, historical sites and artifacts, including their legal and ethical dimensions.

REL.title: Introduction to Indian Philosophy
REL.description: An introduction to Indian philosophy, including major schools of thought in Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain philosophies. No previous knowledge of Indian religions or philosophy required.

REL.title: Technology, Culture, and Ethics
REL.description: Examination of value questions arising from the impact of  technology on  individuals, social institutions, and culture.

REL.title: Islamic Spirituality: Mysticism and the Sufi Tradition
REL.description: Examination of the origins, development, and basic concepts and practices of Sufism, as well as its relationship to other areas of Islamic life.

REL.title: Law and Religion
REL.description: Explores the intersection between law and religion including ways in which religious traditions conceive of, create, order, and contest law.

REL.title: Zen and Daoism in Asian Literature
REL.description: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Daoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.

REL.title: Seminar in Buddhism
REL.description: Seminar on selected aspects of the Buddhist tradition.

REL.title: France and Islam
REL.description: Historical and theoretical analyses of the complex history of Western perceptions of Islam, focusing on France.Taught in French. Prerequisites: FREN 330. Recommended preparation: REL 137g for Religion majors and minors.

REL.title: Directed Research
REL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

REL.title: Undergraduate Honors Research
REL.description: Individual research for honors in the major leading to a  substantial project.

REL.title: Directed Research
REL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

REL.title: Professionalization Proseminar in Religious Studies
REL.description: Offers students a structured environment in which to consider issues in professional development and to discuss their dissertation proposals. Graded CR/NC.

REL.title: Buddhist processual social philosophy
REL.description: Study of varied Asian Buddhist texts in translation and in original languages. Exploration of the major secondary literature on Buddhist texts.

REL.title: Research Seminar in Religious Studies
REL.description: Skills for academic professionalization, presentation of research in progress and formal responses to academic writing.

REL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

REL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Psychology
PSYC.description: Introduction to psychological science, including historical and contemporary approaches. Behavior examined from biological, cognitive, social, developmental, and personality perspectives. Disorders and treatments.

PSYC.title: Social Analysis of Gender
PSYC.description: Multidisciplinary survey of gender assumptions in relation to sexuality, mental health, social and political relations, and artistic expression.

PSYC.title: Statistics
PSYC.description: Introduction to the use of statistics in psychology: basic ideas in measurement; frequency distributions; descriptive statistics; concepts and procedures in statistical inference.

PSYC.title: Language and Mind
PSYC.description: Language within cognitive science: speech physiology and acoustics, language acquisition, reading, language disorders, perception and mental representation of words, linguistic diversity and computer analysis of speech.

PSYC.title: Supervised Research in Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised Research with department faculty.

PSYC.title: Cognitive Processes
PSYC.description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of human memory, perception, thinking, and language. Lectures, demonstrations, and individual experiments. Prerequisite: 100g or departmental approval.

PSYC.title: Sensation and Perception
PSYC.description: Receptor processes and stimulus organization; traditional topics  in the perception of objects, space, time. Laboratory              demonstrations and exercises.

PSYC.title: Learning and Memory
PSYC.description: Principles involved in classical and operant conditioning.        Concentration on basic causes of behavior; consideration of the    relevance of simple behavioral laws to complicated human behavior.

PSYC.title: Experimental Research Methods
PSYC.description: Experimental research methods in psychology; nature and concepts of scientific method.

PSYC.title: Non-Experimental Research Methods
PSYC.description: Non-experimental research methods in psychology. Observational, survey and data analysis exercises

PSYC.title: Behavioral Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Neural bases of behavior. Concentration on sensory and motor processes and the interaction of neural, chemical, and hormonal systems.

PSYC.title: Developmental Psychology
PSYC.description: Child and adolescent behavior and associated theories;            exploration of the continuity between child and adult behavior.    Laboratory projects.

PSYC.title: Adult Development and Aging
PSYC.description: Genetic, physical, and social influences during adult years on    perception, learning and memory, intelligence, personality, social roles, and normal and deviant behavioral patterns. Laboratory      demonstrations and exercises.

PSYC.title: Close Relationships
PSYC.description: Scientific perspective of close relationships: intimate relationships, friendships and others, evolutionary and biological bases of attraction and love, historical, social , cultural influences. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. (Duplicates credit in PSYC 359)

PSYC.title: Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Theoretical and experimental analysis of human behavior. Social   processes involved in attitudes, conformity, compliance,           interpersonal perception, liking, affiliation, aggression,         altruism, and group dynamics.

PSYC.title: Psychological Disorders
PSYC.description: The commonly diagnosed behavior pathologies; biological, social, cultural and developmental antecedents of abnormal behavior; principles of learning, perception and motivation, as they relate to psychopathology.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Introduction to the scientist-practitioner model of clinical psychology, including research methods, psychological assessment and diagnosis, psychotherapeutic interventions, and treatment of special populations.

PSYC.title: Criminal Behavior
PSYC.description: Genetic, biological, psychological, and sociological characteristics of those who evidence criminal behavior; theoretical formulations to be reviewed and appraised. Prerequisites: PSYC 100. Duplicates credit in former PSYC 463.

PSYC.title: Stress, Health, and the Mind-Body Connection
PSYC.description: Introduction to psychological, biological and behavioral processes affecting physical health, including stress, coping with disease, health behaviors and socioeconomic and cultural influences on health.

PSYC.title: Psycholinguistics
PSYC.description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of how spoken and written language is produced and understood, learned during childhood, and affected by brain damage.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Humor
PSYC.description: Extensive examination of select current research in social psychology, based on original research papers. Specific topics change by semester.

PSYC.title: Neuropsychology
PSYC.description: Effects of brain damage on human behavior and abilities, particularly language, memory, and emotion.

PSYC.title: Motivated Behaviors and Addiction
PSYC.description: Social, environmental, and physiological influences on behaviors associated with aggression, eating, reproduction, and sleep. Will focus on behavioral disorders such as addiction.

PSYC.title: Neuropsychopharmacology
PSYC.description: Pharmo-chemical nature of the brain; diseases of the brain and     drug treatments. Recommended Preparation: background in biological  psychology, biology and/or neuroscience.

PSYC.title: Children's Learning and Cognitive Development
PSYC.description: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.

PSYC.title: Intelligence, Problem Solving and Creativity
PSYC.description: Psychometric and experimental approaches to the study of  intelligence, problem solving, reasoning and creativity, including  analysis of mental test construction and validity.

PSYC.title: Developmental Neuroscience of Human Behavior
PSYC.description: The biological underpinnings supporting social, emotional, and cognitive development from infancy through adolescence; Focus on neuroscience to understand typical and atypical development, including psychopathology.

PSYC.title: Adolescent Development
PSYC.description: The adolescent years from both an applied and a research-oriented perspective. Topics include physical, cognitive, and moral development; socialization; and sexual and sex-role development.

PSYC.title: Foundations of  Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

PSYC.title: Neural Network Models of Social and Cognitive Processes
PSYC.description: Introduction to using neural network or connectionist models to simulate cognitive, social, emotional and motivational processes; basic concepts and tools in computational neuroscience.

PSYC.title: Industrial/Organizational Psychology
PSYC.description: I/O Psychologists develop and apply scientifically supported solutions to the workplace. "Industrial" deals with human resource functions, and "Organizational" with psychological aspects of the organization. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. Recommended preparation: PSYC 316.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Marriage and the Family
PSYC.description: Theories and research on family relationships across the life  span, including research methods, cultural and developmental  perspectives, communication, conflict, attachment, individual  psychopathology, and family violence.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorder
PSYC.description: A comprehensive overview of the assessment, diagnosis and treatment of individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.

PSYC.title: Happiness:  Research in Neuroscience and Positive Psychology
PSYC.description: Neuroscientific and psychological perspectives that investigate the basis of happiness and well-being.

PSYC.title: Directed Research
PSYC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PSYC.title: Classic and Modern Statistical Methods I
PSYC.description: An introduction to classic statistical techniques as well as modern robust methods for dealing violations of standard assumptions.

PSYC.title: Research Methods in Applied Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Various research techniques that are useful in a variety of different real world settings, such as business, governmental agencies and charities. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Applied Psychology
PSYC.description: Examines qualitative research in applied settings. Learn to design, execute and report qualitative research in response to stakeholder needs.

PSYC.title: Seminar in Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Problems and theories of the person in the social context. Person perception, interpersonal relations, attitude dynamics, social systems.

PSYC.title: Psychopathology
PSYC.description: Study of psychopathology: in-depth survey of theory and research concerning psychological disorders; introduction to diagnosis. (One of 4 clinical psychology core courses: 514, 515, 619, 620.)

PSYC.title: Clinical Assessment
PSYC.description: Study of clinical assessment: test construction, measurement and predicition of behavior, major cognitive and personality assessment instruments. (One of 4 clinical psychology core courses: 514, 515, 619, 620.)

PSYC.title: Group Dynamics and Leadership
PSYC.description: Theory and research on effective teams and characteristics of strong leaders. Negotiation, morale-building, managing expectancies, utilization of cultural diversity as a strength. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Professional Issues for Clinical Scientists
PSYC.description: Focus is on professionalism topics and skills central to developing as a clinical scientist, explored within a cultural context.

PSYC.title: Cross Cultural Psychology in Applied Settings
PSYC.description: Examination of major theoretical frameworks mapping worldwide cultures and values with a focus on applying thatknowledge in organizations. Open only to master students in Applied Psychology.

PSYC.title: User Experience (UX) Research
PSYC.description: Provides a broad introduction to the social science methods UX researchers most commonly use, including qualitative approaches, and quantitative approaches.

PSYC.title: Concepts and Principles of Behavior Analysis
PSYC.description: Provides intensive training in behavioral principles and laws of learning and motivation. Focuses on broad application of principles, from basic research with nonhumans, to application across human clinical populations.

PSYC.title: Behavioral Assessment
PSYC.description: Studies theory and application of behavioral methods for skill assessment, functional assessment of destructive behavior, and learner motivation. Discusses relative strengths and limitations of direct versus indirect methods.

PSYC.title: Ethics for Behavior Analysts
PSYC.description: Provides training in legal and ethical issues as they pertain to the professional practice of behavior analysis. Reviews the Guidelines for Responsible Conduct for Behavior Analysts, as well as the American Psychological Associations Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct.

PSYC.title: Applied Developmental Psychology
PSYC.description: Review of theories of cognitive development. Analysis of research on brain functioning, perception, memory, language, reasoning and academic skills from birth to adolescence.

PSYC.title: Functional Neuroanatomy
PSYC.description: Regional organization and systems of the mammalian nervous system and their functions.

PSYC.title: Proseminar in Human Behavior
PSYC.description: The nature of the human mind, social interactions, conflicts, cooperative behavior, mutual influence and effectiveness. Application of psychological principles to the dynamics of commercial entities. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Proseminar in Human Behavior
PSYC.description: Application of psychological principles to the dynamics of commercial entities. Develop practical skills with a focus on professional development.

PSYC.title: Principles of Consumer Psychology
PSYC.description: Examination of the attitudes and decisions of consumers, and how to effectively reach consumers by using persuasion and proper positioning in the marketplace. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging
PSYC.description: The physical and physiological bases of MRI and fMRI.  Design and  analysis of fMRI experiments.  Operation of a magnetic resonance  imaging system.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Interactive Media
PSYC.description: Examination of the diverse methods of communicating with a target audience with a special emphasis on the newest computer-based tools for providing information and influence.

PSYC.title: Organizational Psychology
PSYC.description: Examination of the psychological factors that impact employee motivation, job satisfaction, teamwork, leadership, and organizational development. Open only to Master of Applied Psychology students. Not available for major credit for GSBA majors

PSYC.title: Foundations of Statistical and Data Analytic     Methods in Psychology
PSYC.description: Model comparison approach to analyzing experimental and non-experimental data; including moderated, mediated and nonlinear models as well as models with a categorical outcome.

PSYC.title: Psycholinguistics
PSYC.description: Theories of acquisition; sentence and discourse processing; language and thought.

PSYC.title: Analysis of Covariance Structures
PSYC.description: Multivariate analysis of non-experimental data, including          structural equation modeling, path analysis, and confirmatory      factor analysis. Computer applications using variety of            optimization routines and purpose-written software.

PSYC.title: Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis
PSYC.description: Provides supervised practical experience in implementing behavior analytic assessment and treatment services. Meets supervision requirements for the Board Certified Behavior Analyst exam. Students meet with course instructor to present and discuss cases for two hours per week every semester, including one summer session. Practicum hours in the field vary from 18-20 hours per week during the academic year to 30 hours per week during the summer.

PSYC.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
PSYC.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

PSYC.title: Directed Research
PSYC.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Applied Psychology Internship
PSYC.description: Internship in a non-university setting, such as business, governmental agency, or NGO. Graded CR/NC. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Applied Psychology Treatise
PSYC.description: Requires a research paper of substantial length and high quality that integrates the Internship experience with concepts and principles of human behavior. Credit/No Credit. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Practicum in Teaching Psychology
PSYC.description: Techniques for working with undergraduates, lesson planning, leading discussions and lecturing, tools for development as a teaching professional. Open to first-semester Psychology TAs only. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Practicum in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised experience in interviewing skills and in assessment, including psychological test administration, and the preparation of reports. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Advanced Behavioral Theory
PSYC.description: Examines advanced topics in behavioral theory and philosophy, including a comprehensive behavioral approach to language and cognition. Discusses the nature of productive relations between behavior analysis and other psychological theories.

PSYC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PSYC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least two semesters of enrollment in the graduate program.

PSYC.title: Capstone Project in Behavioral Analysis
PSYC.description: Supervision for completing independent project, consisting of practical treatment evaluation, program development, or literature review.

PSYC.title: Computational Models of Cognition
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Self-Report
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: The Infant Mind and Brain
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Applied Research Design
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Seminar in Advanced Social Psychology
PSYC.description: An intensive consideration of selected concepts, theories, and research problems in social psychology.

PSYC.title: Text as Data
PSYC.description: Focuses on applications of natural language processing, guided by psychological theories, for identifying various social and cognitive properties evident in language.

PSYC.title: Internship in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised clinical work in an approved mental health setting. Graded CR/NC. Prerequisite: Good standing in clinical program and departmental approval.

PSYC.title: Advanced Practicum in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Didactic practicum combining theory and research on psychological intervention with clinical practice in assessment and treatment, focused on particular client groups or disorders. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Externship for Practical Training
PSYC.description: Externship for Practical Training is for clinical-related training experience in the students fieldof study. Students are individually supervised at their site.

PSYC.title: Research
PSYC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

WRIT.description: A writing workshop that allows students to deepen their writing skills while working collaboratively with diverse groups, programs, or populations outside of USC.
