WRIT.description: Advanced training in analytical and argumentative writing for particular purposes in professional and practical contexts.

WRIT.title: Theory and Practice in Teaching Expository Writing
WRIT.description: Pedagogical application of rhetorical and linguistic theory to teaching university-level expository writing. Accompanies supervised teaching. Limited to assistant lecturers and teaching assistants. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: The Physical World
PHYS.description: The fundamentals of physics are presented, exploring the structure and beauty of physical laws and their manifestations, ranging from events observed in everyday life to subatomic and cosmic phenomena.

PHYS.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
PHYS.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areasrelated to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences,Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs.

PHYS.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
PHYS.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas       related to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences,    Medicine, Dentistry, and Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs.    (Duplicates credit in 105abLg and 125L).

PHYS.title: Special Laboratory I
PHYS.description: Laboratory component for PHYS 151Lg for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Special Laboratory II
PHYS.description: Laboratory component for PHYS 152L for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics I: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
PHYS.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Statics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation principles, gravitation, simple harmonic oscillators, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, wave motion, sound waves, electromagnetic waves.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics III: Optics and Modern Physics
PHYS.description: Geometrical optics, interference, diffraction, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, solid state physics.

PHYS.title: Advanced Principles of Physics II
PHYS.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, electric and magnetic properties of matter, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, propagation of light.

PHYS.title: Physics Discovery Series
PHYS.description: Introduction to current research activities of the faculty of the Department; topics of current and popular interest among the wider community of physicists. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: The Physics and Technology of Energy
PHYS.description: Investigation of energy technologies, including development and implementation issues. Topics include the Industrial Revolution, electromagnetic induction, power transmission, combustion engines, fission and fusion. Not available for major credit.

PHYS.title: Mechanics
PHYS.description: Dynamics of particles, kinematics of rotations, rigid body motion, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalism, theory of small vibrations.

PHYS.title: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS.description: a: Electrostatics; thermal, chemical, magnetic effects of steady currents; DC circuits.

PHYS.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
PHYS.description: Relativity, atomic spectra, quantum statistics, nuclear models, nuclear reactions, elementary particles.

PHYS.title: Physical Biology: From Molecules to Cells
PHYS.description: Length, time, and energy scales of life; statistical mechanics of biomolecules and cellular processes; physics of cell shape; biological fluid dynamics; electron transfer and metabolism. Recommended preparation: BISC 220. Prerequisites: PHYS 152 or PHYS 162.

PHYS.title: Directed Research
PHYS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

PHYS.title: Senior Lab
PHYS.description: Projects will include experiments in mechanics, thermodynamics,  electricity and magnetism.  Emphasis on laboratory work with  discussion of theoretical background.  Lecture, 2 hours;  laboratory, 6 hours.

PHYS.title: Senior Project
PHYS.description: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

PHYS.title: Graduate Colloquium
PHYS.description: Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy.   Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the  department and by outside speakers.  Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Advanced Mechanics
PHYS.description: Newtonian formulation of dynamics; Hamilton's principle; Lagrangian formulation; rigid body motion; Hamiltonian formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi theory; vibrations.

PHYS.title: Methods of Theoretical Physics
PHYS.description: Vector analysis; infinite, asymptotic Fourier series; complete  sets; Dirac delta function; Fourier, Laplace transforms; Legendre  functions; spherical harmonics; Sturm-Liouville theory; orthogonal  polynomials; gamma-factorial function; complex variables.

PHYS.title: Methods of Experimental Physics
PHYS.description: Techniques of general utility in contemporary physics research, with emphasis on the use of commercially available instrumentation.

PHYS.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
PHYS.description: Principles of, and relations between, thermodynamics, and statistical mechanics; ensembles, partition function formalism; quantum statistics; fluctuations.

PHYS.title: Quantum Mechanics
PHYS.description: b: Approximation schemes and application to atomic and molecular physics and scattering theory; identical particles; electromagnetic properties of atoms.

PHYS.title: Quantum Devices
PHYS.description: Idealized and real-world descriptions of quantum hardware; design principles, methods of operation and possible improvements; applications, advantages and limitations of different technologies.

PHYS.title: Directed Research
PHYS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Practicum in Teaching Physics and Astronomy
PHYS.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within the physical sciences. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Master's Thesis
PHYS.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

PHYS.title: Master's Thesis
PHYS.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

PHYS.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PHYS.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

PHYS.title: Off Campus Studies
PHYS.description: Coursework taken on campus at Caltech as part of the Caltech-USC  cross-registration program.  Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Research
PHYS.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design I
ARCH.description: Introduction to principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the design of simplified architectural projects.

ARCH.title: History and Theory of Architecture, Technology, Innovation
ARCH.description: Introduction to and critical examination of history, theory and cultural significance of architecture, technology and innovation through lectures and readings.

ARCH.title: Fundamentals of Design Communication
ARCH.description: Visual communication techniques applicable to the design of the built environment; drawing, photography, modeling.

ARCH.title: Workshop in Architecture
ARCH.description: Introduction to the ways architecture is created and understood, for minors and non-majors. Hands-on discussion and laboratory session with some drawing and model building. Not available for credit to architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Architecture: Culture and Community
ARCH.description: Introduction to the ways architecture represents aspirations of culture, satisfies practical and spiritual needs, shapes the social and urban environment, and helps preserve the planet.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design II
ARCH.description: Continuing development of principles and processes: sequence of projects selected to broaden awareness of design issues at various scales in the urban context. Prerequisite: 102abL.

ARCH.title: Visualizing and Experiencing the Built Environment
ARCH.description: Methods for direct observation and recording of the directly experienced built environment through drawing, diagramming, photographing, and writing. Course includes exercises and field experience.

ARCH.title: Building Science I
ARCH.description: The process and communication of building design: physical building shell, systems for structure, enclosure, and space ordering. Prerequisite: CE 106L.

ARCH.title: Building Structures and Seismic Design
ARCH.description: Investigation and design of elements and systems for buildingstructures; applied mechanics, strength of materials, structuralinvestigation as a design tool. Recommended preparation: PHYS 125 and MATH 108

ARCH.title: World History of Architecture
ARCH.description: A world-wide perspective of architectural history as a product of social, cultural, religious and political dimensions, 1500 CE to present.

ARCH.title: Design for the Thermal and Atmospheric Environment
ARCH.description: Ideas, problems, and computations related to the design of buildings in response to the thermal and atmospheric environment; passive solar systems, mechanical control systems.

ARCH.title: Design at the Scale of the Human Body Workshop
ARCH.description: A design-based exploration of the scale of the human body and how it informs, interferes or interacts with furniture, goods, fixtures and furnishings.

ARCH.title: The Architect's Sketchbook
ARCH.description: The architect's sketchbook as a portable laboratory for perceivingand documenting space introduces the study of the builtenvironment. On-site sessions develop drawing, observation, and visualization skills.

ARCH.title: Social Environments
ARCH.description: Exploration of the intersection between the urban form and the social life of cities, looking at systemic problems of urban societies and potential design solutions.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design III
ARCH.description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to  housing.

ARCH.title: Intensive Survey: Prehistory to the Present
ARCH.description: An intensive historical overview of architecture from prehistory  to the present, emphasizing interrelationships of various global  cultures and how social considerations were translated into form.   Not available for credit to architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Building Science II
ARCH.description: The design of a building as a complex of interacting systems;     relations of subsystems; influences of production and marketing on design.

ARCH.title: Digital Tools for Architecture
ARCH.description: Exploration of digital tools with an emphasis on building information modeling (BIM), parametric modeling, and interoperability including special topics in Architecture/Engineering/Construction (AEC) and sustainable design. Recommended preparation: basic computer skills.

ARCH.title: Design of Building Structures
ARCH.description: Problems and processes of design of building structures; structural investigation for design; codes and standards; design of elements and systems of wood, steel, masonry, and concrete for gravity and lateral loads.

ARCH.title: History of Architecture: Contemporary Issues
ARCH.description: Examination of the buildings, issues and images, the polemics and personalities that are animating current architectural discourse and practice.

ARCH.title: Place and Culture
ARCH.description: (Study abroad programs only)  Study of the relationships between places and culture through readings, lectures, discussion and  weekly field trips.

ARCH.title: Experimental Futures
ARCH.description: Examination of experimental architecture, both historically, in the present day and the future. New waves of experimentation have the potential to bring about positive change in architecture.

ARCH.title: Architectural Product Design Workshop
ARCH.description: Exploration into development of students' own architectural product and working prototype, using digital fabrication techniques for creating a physical prototype or coding for development of an app.

ARCH.title: Architectural Studies- Expanding the Field
ARCH.description: Survey of opportunities, specializations, and professions related  to architecture provides a resource for professional growth for  architecture majors, and introduction to the field for non-majors.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design IV
ARCH.description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with  advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern.

ARCH.title: Principles of Spatial Design II
ARCH.description: Emphasis on developing advanced urban spatial design solutions set within contemporary urban conditions, with a particular emphasis on ecology, public space, neighborhoods and districts. Prerequisite: Arch 303.

ARCH.title: Building Science III
ARCH.description: Design of building systems as an experimental process. Prerequisite: 305abL.

ARCH.title: Global Studies: Topics in                        Architecture, Urbanism, History and Art
ARCH.description: Offered for particular geographic areas of study. Required prerequisite for all full semester undergraduate global programs. Also intended for general interest in focused study on particular geographic area.

ARCH.title: Design Foundation
ARCH.description: Introduction to basic architectural design principles for problem solving scenarios; foundational architectural design course for systematic thinking.

ARCH.title: Computer Transformations
ARCH.description: To explore the potential of computer-integrated design software; to develop techniques for critical analysis of architectural precedents; to expand the ability to visualize options; to expand perception; and to learn the basics of computer-integrated design.

ARCH.title: Slums and the City
ARCH.description: Perspectives in Architecture and Urbanism is an advanced course that allows students to delve deeply into one aspect of world history, theory and/or contemporary issues to develop more focused and critical understanding of that discourse.

ARCH.title: Visual Communication and Graphic Expression
ARCH.description: An exploratory study of fundamental and innovative visual communication principles and graphic expression techniques to facilitate the design enquiry process for architects.

ARCH.title: Architectural Photography- Film and Digital
ARCH.description: See how light alters the visual impact of architectural forms; master high-resolution images both with film and digital; become a professional image developer/processor utilizing photographic software.

ARCH.title: Light, Color and the Character of Material
ARCH.description: Color theory, constructed drawings, constructed shadows, descriptive geometry, constructed perspective drawing, and layered wash techniques lead to experimentation with methods representing materiality and construction in design projects.

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Architecture
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in architecture.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Urbanism
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in urbanism.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Tectonics
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in tectonics.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Women's Spaces in History: 'Hussies,' 'Harems,' and 'Housewi
ARCH.description: Methods for studying patterns of spatial differentiation of women throughout history from home to city, embodied in gender specific language and gendered spaces.

ARCH.title: Great Houses of Los Angeles
ARCH.description: An introduction to the architectural philosophies of seven influential California architects through reading and site visits to significant case studies.

ARCH.title: Architectural Studies Capstone
ARCH.description: Introduction to methods of inquiry, research framework, and scholarly writing necessary to develop a comprehensive foundation for the Architectural Studies Capstone (ARCH 470b)

ARCH.title: Conversations on the Expanded Role of the Architect
ARCH.description: Modeled after Renaissance Salons, this "flipped classroom" course relies on lectures by luminaries and discussions as a means to interrogate the role of the architect.

ARCH.title: Furniture Design
ARCH.description: An investigation into 20th century furniture design and its relationships to architecture, art and design.

ARCH.title: Directed Research
ARCH.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ARCH.title: Exterior Architectural Light and its Effect on Community and Nature
ARCH.description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of architecture.

ARCH.title: Comprehensive Architectural Design
ARCH.description: Selected areas of specialization; projects chosen from a variety of studio offerings, all with an emphasis on the comprehensive design of buildings. Prerequisite: 402abL. Corequisite: ARCH 501.

ARCH.title: Critical Topics in Architecture
ARCH.description: Seminar supporting the research, development, and writing of Degree Project Paper provides a comprehensive base of information for the final Bachelor of Architecture studio.

ARCH.title: Themes
ARCH.description: A general introduction to architectural principles, intended to develop design and critical thinking skills and proficiency to communicate those ideas effectively. Open to graduate architecture majors only.

ARCH.title: Digital Fabrication- Materials and Methods of Production
ARCH.description: Overview of multiple fabrication, manufacturing, and construction techniques used in the production of architecture, furniture and industrial design.

ARCH.title: Building Systems: Materials and Construction
ARCH.description: Studies of construction system development within the architectural design context; processes and issues of selection, evaluation, optimization, integration, design control, and innovation, Departmental approval.

ARCH.title: Seminar: Advanced Structures
ARCH.description: Issues and problems in the development of structural systems for buildings; design criteria, system choice, design development, optimization, subsystem integration. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

ARCH.title: Global History of Architecture
ARCH.description: A historical survey of global architecture, analyzed as a product of social, cultural, religious and political forces.a: 4500 BCE to 1500 CE; b: 1500 CE to present.

ARCH.title: Seminar: Advanced Environmental Systems
ARCH.description: A compressed course in design criteria and calculation methods for mechanical and passive solar systems (loads, plant system, duct, and storage sizing) and lighting and acoustics (CIE and IES methods, dBA and NC systems). Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

ARCH.title: Super Chunks
ARCH.description: Critical studies in building science ranging from sustainability, lighting, acoustics, materials and methods, structures, energy issues, digital media, and fabrication. Students focus on minimum of two topics.

ARCH.title: Drawing Architecture
ARCH.description: Critical studies in building science ranging from sustainability, lighting, acoustics, materials and methods, structures, energy issues, digital media, and fabrication. Students focus on minimum of two topics.

ARCH.title: Structural Design and Analysis
ARCH.description: a. Introduction to behavior and analysis of building structures. Structural loading, materials, and element types will be explored to understand the basic building blocks of buildings. b. Investigation and design of building structural systems for gravity, wind and seismic loading. Comprehensive design exploration of framing type, materials, detailing, layout, form and integration. Recommended preparation: One-semester college-level course in physics or calculus.

ARCH.title: Professional Practicum
ARCH.description: Comparative studies of professional practice between U.S. firms and firms in other countries. Open to international upper-division undergraduate and graduate architecture students only. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic        Context, Project Documentation
ARCH.description: The laws and regulations that affect architecture as well as building economics and financing.   Development of comprehensive project documentation, detailing, specifications, drawing formats and organizations.

ARCH.title: Urban Housing: Types and Typologies
ARCH.description: Applications and precedents for the architect interested in  designing multi-family housing.  Review of the sources of modern  housing types, the impact of building codes and technology on the  form and construction of housing, and study of housing densities,  comparative analysis of multi-family residential patterns.  Major  emphasis on critical knowledge of historic housing typologies as  they are applied to site conditions and groupings, building form,  section, organization, and the design of individual dwellings.   Recommended preparation: two years of undergraduate architectural  studies.

ARCH.title: Urban Ecology
ARCH.description: Lectures, laboratory exercises and field trips introducing basic knowledge of the continually transforming landscape as a base for human settlement.

ARCH.title: Planting Design
ARCH.description: Principles of planting design for landscape architecture focusing on form/space and sustainable performance. Planting design strategies for improved planetary health and resilience.

ARCH.title: Media for Landscape Architecture
ARCH.description: Development of methods and skills for the study of landscape architecture design and for project presentation, including natural resource and urban mapping.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH.description: Projects on urban sites with emphasis on cultural and ecological  purpose and on urban place and form; use of traditional and  digital media.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH.description: Project strategies for urban infrastructure repair and  intervention, phasing, and design of initial catalytic projects.

ARCH.title: Research Methods
ARCH.description: Introduction to methods of inquiry and documentation including  critical review of published materials, techniques for systematic  observation, generating findings from comparative studies of  relevant precedents and problems, and legible presentation of  outcomes.

ARCH.title: Test Plot
ARCH.description: A broad range of developing urban landscape conditions and issues, both domestic and global, are given focused attention.

ARCH.title: Fundamentals of Heritage Conservation
ARCH.description: Concepts and strategies for conservation of significant elements of the built environment: buildings, sites and communities as revealed by readings, site visits, and case studies.

ARCH.title: Introduction to Historic Site Documentation
ARCH.description: Survey of basic guidelines and standards for documentation in  historic preservation, including cultural resource surveys,  historic structures reports and Historic American Building Survey  and Historic American Engineering Record recordation.

ARCH.title: History of American Architecture and Urbanism
ARCH.description: History of American architecture and urbanism from prehistory to World War II examined in relation to European influences and indigenous developments.

ARCH.title: Readings in Heritage Conservation Theory
ARCH.description: Trans-disciplinary intensive reading and discussion course related to issues in contemporary heritage conservation.

ARCH.title: Sustainable Conservation of the Historic Built Environment
ARCH.description: Analysis of the intersection between green building and historic resources with an emphasis on stewardship and sustainability.

ARCH.title: Architecture Themes and Case Studies
ARCH.description: Architectural themes and case studies focusing on the design and development of architecture, from the industrial city to today.

ARCH.title: Descriptive and Computational Architectural Geometry
ARCH.description: Introduction to the history, methods, and cases of descriptive and computational geometry impacting representational, modeling, and historically significant paradigms of architectural design. Introduces a range of geometric first principles, technologies and techniques through contemporary design tools.

ARCH.title: Global History of Designed Landscapes
ARCH.description: Understanding of the global history of landscape design in relation to social, political, religious, environmental and aesthetic principles; current design theory, projects and their historical references are critically reviewed and analyzed.

ARCH.title: Cross Cultural Topics in Landscape Architecture History
ARCH.description: Comparative analysis and appreciation of landscape architecture as  a manifestation of nature, society, and design.  Topics and world  regions vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when   subject matter is different.

ARCH.title: Community-Based Design, Conservation and Planning
ARCH.description: Introduces methods of designing with communities rather than for them. It focuses on public history, cultural asset mapping and participatory design.

ARCH.title: Advanced Building Skins: Designing High-Performance Facade S
ARCH.description: Fundamental technical skillset applicable to the design and delivery of high-performance facade systems. The predominant focus will be the design of contemporary glazed curtainwalls and rainscreen systems in their many forms.

ARCH.title: Systems
ARCH.description: Application of the scientific principles governing the thermal environment and human physiology to contemporary issues of environmentally responsive building energy concepts and systems. Recommended preparation ARCH 505aL.

ARCH.title: Lighting Design
ARCH.description: The physics, technical knowledge, professional knowledge, design, and documentation processes used in architectural lighting design, including first principles, manual calculations and computer simulations..

ARCH.title: AI in Sustainable Architecture Practice
ARCH.description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of how artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms can be integrated with various aspects of sustainable architecture.

ARCH.title: Directed Research
ARCH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis Preparation
ARCH.description: Exploration of topics leading to development of a thesis           prospectus.  Topics may be in the areas of building structures,    seismic design, environmental control, passive and active energy,  or other relevant topics.  Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Integration
ARCH.description: a: Principles of structural (seismic/wind and gravity), HVAC, building envelope, access/egress, building service systems; and sustainable strategies critically integrated through tectonic performative goals. . Prerequisite: ARCH-505b. Open only to Architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Landscape Construction: Assembly and Documentation
ARCH.description: Learn and practice the process by which a landscape design is assembled through materials systems and design documentation.

ARCH.title: Media for Landscape Architecture: Dynamic Systems
ARCH.description: Computational capacities of parametric software, including flow dynamics, procedural media, and geospatial analysis, to analyze and generate both existing and emergent systems at the landscape scale.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH.description: Fully integrated landscape place design; reclamation sites at  significant urban or natural locations.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in heritage conservation.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree.

ARCH.title: Advanced Design-Research
ARCH.description: Directed research option for the MLArch degree.

ARCH.title: Advanced Graduate Architecture Design- Themes
ARCH.description: Advanced thematic topical investigations emphasizing diverse areas of specialization. Projects will be faculty-led research investigations that concentrate on diverse areas of vital concern.

ARCH.title: Advanced Graduate Architecture Design- Topics
ARCH.description: Advanced topical investigations emphasizing diverse areas of specialization. Projects will be faculty-led research investigations that concentrate on diverse areas of vital concern. Prerequisite: ARCH 605bL or ARCH 702L. Open only to Architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Architecture Directed Design Research Option I
ARCH.description: Directed Design Research option for graduate level architecture degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Prerequisite: ARCH 605bL or ARCH 702L. Open only to Architecture majors. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ART.title: Art and Design Studio I
ART.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of  process and critical analysis.

ART.title: Art and Design Studio II
ART.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including the key principles of process and critical analysis.

ART.title: Drawing for Art and Design
ART.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts and design.

ART.title: Painting I
ART.description: Practical introduction to oil and acrylic pigments, painting tools, mediums, processes and contemporary concepts. Primary experience in: color, composition and perception through representational and abstract painting.

ART.title: Ceramics I
ART.description: Practical and theoretical exploration of the nature of surface, form, volume and mass as fundamental elements of clay sculpture and the ceramic object.

ART.title: Wheel Throwing
ART.description: An introductory course using wheel throwing techniques for ceramics to explore a variety of forms through three-dimensional exercises.

ART.title: Sculpture I
ART.description: Practical and theoretical introduction to sculpture as dimensional manipulation. Primary exploration of form, mass, gravity, surface, structure and associative recognition in three-dimensional art.

ART.title: Creating and Understanding Visuals
ART.description: Lecture-studio course on the theory and history behind contemporary art, design, and visual communication; students also create work, informed by ideas from the lecture.

ART.title: Black and White Film and Darkroom Photography
ART.description: Introduces film cameras, development, and darkroom techniques, photographic history, theory and practice within an art context.

ART.title: Introduction to Photography: Process and Concept
ART.description: Digital photography as a medium of contemporary art. Includes  concept development, DSLR cameras, lighting, digital workflow,  software, large format printing and installation.

ART.title: Foundation Studio Intensive
ART.description: Cohort building studio intensive that ensures incoming transfers have foundational concepts and skill sets for intermediate and advanced studio courses.

ART.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
ART.description: Studio practice to develop drawing fundamentals for game designers, animators and narrative artists.

ART.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
ART.description: Continuation of ART 207a.

ART.title: Introduction to Video: Projection and Virtual Worlds in Art
ART.description: An introductory course exploring contemporary processes and practices of video experimentation in art including the camera, editing, digital manipulation and spatial and virtual platforms.

ART.title: Studio Critique I
ART.description: Interdisciplinary forum where students develop research skills, learn how to best articulate their artistic production, discuss materials related to their research interests, and critique the work of their peers.

ART.title: Drawing II
ART.description: Directed examination of personal approaches to drawing with emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing additional skills and sources of inspiration. Individual expression will be encouraged.

ART.title: Comics Project
ART.description: All aspects of comics will be covered, from writing and composition to inking and marketing through the production of an individual multi-page comic creation.

ART.title: Illustration for Art and Design
ART.description: Illustration techniques and professional practices across the range of fine art, comics, editorial illustration, narrative arts, visual development and others. Digital and hybrid approaches.

ART.title: Painting II
ART.description: Directed examination of historic and contemporary painting concepts and aesthetics, investigation into personal ideas towards the development of a creative visual language and practice in painting.

ART.title: Ceramics II
ART.description: Directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

ART.title: Intermediate Photography: Studio, Field, Independent Project
ART.description: Continued examination of the conceptual, technical, aesthetic and historical tools necessary for a well-informed deliberate art practice. Emphasis on generating self-directed ideas.

ART.title: Studio Critique II
ART.description: A continuation of ART 280 for third-year students, providing an interdisciplinary forum for artistic practice and a deepening critique of one's work and the work of peers.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Drawing
ART.description: Examination of personal approaches and professional careers in drawing and 2D art making, emphasis on making a body of work with creative freedom in committed studio space.

ART.title: Advanced Illustration for Art and Design
ART.description: Creation of consistent and mature portfolio of images reflecting student interests, voice and sensibilities, in any medium(s), and to learn professional practices for careers in Illustration.

ART.title: Figure Drawing
ART.description: A studio examination of rotating topics in drawing/painting, either media-based or content-driven, with individual and collaborative projects; topics change each semester.

ART.title: Ideation of Visual Worlds
ART.description: Explore the principles of ideation to create imaginary worlds, visualization and drawing techniques on paper (and screen) and communicate them effectively to a viewer.

ART.title: 2D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: 3D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: 4D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: Professional Internship in the Arts
ART.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis and working internship.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Ceramics
ART.description: Continued directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

ART.title: Installation Art
ART.description: Students challenge the traditional art object as they explore the use of space and time in their artwork.

ART.title: Woodworking
ART.description: Exploration of the essential skills in woodworking through lecture, demonstration and hands-on training. Includes instruction in joinery and relevant machinery and hand tools.

ART.title: Modeling and Mold Making
ART.description: Introduction to plaster mold making using clay and wax for both ceramics and sculpture. Exploration of various casting materials.

ART.title: Metal
ART.description: Introduction to metal in fine art. Emphasis on technical proficiencies and effective solutions working in a variety of metals.

ART.title: Large Format Photography
ART.description: Exploration of photographic  traditions in large-format, high resolution sheet film cameras, which have their roots in both the field, the studio, in commercial and documentary traditions.

ART.title: Post-Material Studio
ART.description: Advanced studio and discussion course that affords the student a conceptual and practical platform from which to discuss and realize a major work or series.

ART.title: Motion Graphics for Art and Video
ART.description: An intensive investigation of the mechanics and methodology of contemporary software for video art. Recommended to be taken concurrently with ART 260.

ART.title: Studio Capstone
ART.description: A faculty-mentored course supporting advanced conceptual exploration and the development of an ambitious, self-defined series or body of work; may culminate in a group exhibition or individual project.

ART.title: Visiting Artist and Scholar Seminar
ART.description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars. (Duplicates credit in FA 515)

ART.title: Individual Studies
ART.description: Investigation of creative problems through various media. Course may be repeated. (Duplicates credit in former FA 520)

ART.title: Group Critique
ART.description: Presentation and critique which builds students' skills in presenting and contextualizing their artwork for peer review; analytic discussion regarding directions in contemporary art.

ART.title: Professional Practice
ART.description: A seminar exploring professional practices essential for visual artists.

ART.title: Directed Research
ART.description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 590)

ART.title: Master's Thesis
ART.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 594a)

ART.title: Master's Thesis
ART.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 594z)

FDN.title: Race, Fashion and Pop Culture
FDN.description: Exploration of fashion, pop culture, entertainment, beauty and style politics through the lens of race, class and gender.

DES.title: Design Fundamentals
DES.description: Introduction to the basic elements and processes of visual communication and design. Instruction includes studio projects, lectures and readings. Various media used.

DES.title: Art and Design Studio I
DES.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of  process and critical analysis.

DES.title: Art and Design Studio II
DES.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including the key principles of process and critical analysis.

DES.title: Drawing for Art and Design
DES.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts and design.

DES.title: The Design Challenge: Exploring the Design Process
DES.description: An overview of the creative design process and introduction to techniques to solve visual problems.

DES.title: Design II
DES.description: Exploration of essential elements of traditional and digital design, including color and image-text integration, editing information, typography and sequencing.

DES.title: Digital Design Fundamentals
DES.description: Exploration of digital processes for the creation of art and design. Centered around the use of the computer and its peripherals for production of 2D media.

DES.title: Foundation Studio Intensive
DES.description: Cohort building studio intensive that ensures incoming transfers have foundational concepts and skill sets for intermediate and advanced studio courses.

DES.title: Digital 3D Design
DES.description: Exploration of digital methods and computational tools for art and design. With an emphasis on three-dimensional physical and virtual output.

DES.title: 3D Design: Materials and Tools
DES.description: Introduction to the study of 3-D Design. Includes a wide investigation of materials, tools, and techniques specific to dimensional design as they apply to package, product, and environmental design.

DES.title: Design III
DES.description: Advanced exploration of typography and image-text integration, including collaborative projects, pre-press and proofing techniques, narrative concepts and information architecture.

DES.title: Advanced Digital Design
DES.description: Exploration of digital processes for art and design with a focus on interactivity, motion, and sound in the virtual realm.

DES.title: Graphic Design in Fashion
DES.description: An intensive studio and lecture course focusing on the applications of graphic design in fashion and related fields.

DES.title: Illustration for Art and Design
DES.description: Illustration techniques and professional practices across the range of fine art, comics, editorial illustration, narrative arts, visual development and others. Digital and hybrid approaches.

DES.title: Publication Design
DES.description: Application of layout, typography, design principles and image making in the design and production of books, magazines, zines and digital books.

DES.title: Design Theory
DES.description: A comprehensive study of visual communication focusing on graphic design from 1900 to the present. An introduction to design thinking, language and principles including political and cultural implications.

DES.title: Typography
DES.description: The study of visual communication through the use of letterforms from historical tradition to contemporary experimental rebellion.

DES.title: Typography
DES.description: Continuation of DES 332a.

DES.title: Advanced Design Projects
DES.description: Advanced information design within a flexible curriculum. Emphasis on team-oriented projects.

DES.title: Professional Practice in Design
DES.description: A summation of one's practice, with a focus on transitioning to a career as a professional designer.

DES.title: Advanced Illustration for Art and Design
DES.description: Creation of consistent and mature portfolio of images reflecting student interests, voice and sensibilities, in any medium(s), and to learn professional practices for careers in Illustration.

DES.title: Independent Studies in Design
DES.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

DES.title: Professional Internship in the Arts
DES.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis and working internship.

DES.title: Special Projects in Design
DES.description: Students work on projects for outside clients, and receive instruction in professional practices, advanced design techniques, and sophisticated technology. By invitation or portfolio review only. Only open to upper division students.

DES.title: Senior Thesis
DES.description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

DES.title: Senior Thesis
DES.description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

DES.title: Contemporary Issues in Design
DES.description: An analytic seminar of topics, ideas and concepts in the contemporary design world.

DES.title: Visiting Designers Forum
DES.description: Professional practice of design featuring formal presentations by visiting designers.

DES.title: Individual Studies
DES.description: Investigation of creative problems through various design media.

DES.title: Design Studio Co-Lab
DES.description: A critical examination of contextual issues, theories, movements and ideas that are relevant to the contemporary design practice in collaboration with a professional client.

DES.title: Group Critique
DES.description: Investigation of issues relative to the student's work in individual studies and thesis; analysis, conceptual development and subjective observations by faculty and student peers.

DES.title: Design Pedagogy
DES.description: A critical examination and application of the issues, theories, and ideas that support the studio practice and teaching of contemporary design.

DES.title: Directed Research
DES.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

DES.title: Field Internship Experience
DES.description: Supervised internship in a design firm, or with an independent designer, on projects and research specific to design practice.

DES.title: Master's Thesis
DES.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

DES.title: Master's Thesis
DES.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

DES.title: Master's thesis
DES.description: Credit upon acceptance of master's thesis.

CRIT.title: Histories of Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRIT.description: A loosely chronological, thematic survey of art, visual culture, design, and critical theory from the early modern period through modernism (1500  1950).

CRIT.title: Critical Theory in Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRIT.description: An issues-based introduction to critical theory in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, especially as it relates to philosophy, art, design, and visual culture.

CRIT.title: Global Art, Design and Visual Culture since 1960
CRIT.description: A critical history of art, design, visual culture, and visual theory since 1960, addressing through a postcolonial/decolonial lens the concepts and practices of "global" art.

CRIT.title: Race, Fashion and Pop Culture
CRIT.description: Exploration of fashion, pop culture, entertainment, beauty and style politics through the lens of race, class and gender.

CRIT.title: Theory and History of Performance Studies
CRIT.description: Exploration of the various theories and methodologies associated with performance and visual studies as interrelated with the histories of practice in these fields.

CRIT.title: History and Theory of Art and Exhibitions
CRIT.description: Gives broad and deep overview of history of art as a conceptual and practical category, emphasizing development of exhibitionary sites and engagement with public sphere.

CRIT.title: Art and Curatorial Visits
CRIT.description: Site visits relating to art and curatorial practices, from art museums and artists studios to public art offices and performance venues, and meet professionals.

CRIT.title: Visiting Artist and Scholar Seminar
CRIT.description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars. (Duplicates credit in FA 515)

CRIT.title: Curatorial Practicum: Individual/Group Projects
CRIT.description: Second in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public. Prerequisite: CRIT 555. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 555b)

CRIT.title: Directed Research
CRIT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 590)

CRIT.title: Field Internship Experience
CRIT.description: Supervised internship in an art institution or an art agency, or with an independent curator or artist, on projects and research specific to public space. Recommended preparation: Completion of first year of courses. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 591)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594a)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Recommended preparation: 28 units of coursework. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594b)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Recommended preparation: 28 units of coursework. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594z)

ACCT.title: External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT.description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to financial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

ACCT.title: Introduction to Accounting Systems
ACCT.description: Understanding of technology and controls needed to capture data used by professionals in financial and managerial accounting, auditing and taxation.

ACCT.title: Introduction to Sustainability Reporting
ACCT.description: Overview of the current corporate sustainability reporting  structure. Analysis and critical evaluation of corporate  sustainability reports and popular sustainability rating systems.

ACCT.title: Foundations of Accounting
ACCT.description: Non-technical presentation of accounting for users of accounting information; introduction to financial and managerial accounting. Not open to students with course credits in accounting. Not available for unit or course credit toward a degree in Accounting or Business.

ACCT.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT.description: Analysis of corporate financial reports from a decision-maker's perspective.

ACCT.title: Tax Analysis with Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Capabilities to identify and analyze relevant tax issues; apply research tools to find solutions and provide alternate approaches using data analytics.   Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 374 and the former ACCT 474.

ACCT.title: Auditing with Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Auditing with data analytics from the perspective of management    and other users of financial statements including external         auditors and assurance professionals.  Duplicates credit in the    former ACCT 373 and the former ACCT 473.

ACCT.title: Advanced External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT.description: Develop capabilities to identify and resolve advanced external financial reporting challenges, focusing primarily on operating, financing, and investing activities of business enterprises.

ACCT.title: Directed Research
ACCT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ACCT.title: Marshall Honors Research and Thesis
ACCT.description: Experience in conducting research and writing a thesis under supervision of a faculty adviser.

ACCT.title: Business Sustainability Reporting and Analysis
ACCT.description: A critical analysis of practices in business sustainability reporting.  Provides guidance for synthesizing information from corporate sustainability disclosures into traditional financial and valuation analyses.

ACCT.title: Fair Value Accounting: GAAP, IFRS and Emerging Issues
ACCT.description: Case study approach to explore fair value issues in accounting; research and analysis of causes of valuation differences.

ACCT.title: Tax Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Tax analytics from management's perspective; sources of accounting data, introduction to database and ERP tools; application of data and analytics to tax issues.

ACCT.title: Taxation of Cross-Border Transactions Using Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Introduction to income taxation of cross-border transactions, state/local and multinational tax rules; application of data and analytics tools to multijurisdictional tax issues.

ACCT.title: Financial Accounting for Mergers and Acquisitions
ACCT.description: Practical problems in accounting for business combinations. Consolidated financial statements: fair value, acquisition and equity basis accounting. Duplicates credit in former ACCT 582.

ACCT.title: Mergers and Acquisitions: Tax Planning and Strategy
ACCT.description: Tax planning and strategy in corporate restructuring including mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures.  Tax background not required to be successful in this course.  Duplicates credit in former ACCT 582.

ACCT.title: Advanced Enterprise Systems and Technologies
ACCT.description: Design, control and development of advanced enterprise systems, using reengineering, focusing on accounting and financial systems, using a wide range of emerging existing technologies.

ACCT.title: Taxation of Partnerships
ACCT.description: Federal taxation of flow-through entities including partnerships, limited liability partnerships (LLPs), and limited liability companies (LLCs).

ACCT.title: Research, Theory and Ethics in Taxation
ACCT.description: Basic theories of tax law, application of research tools, interpretation of statutes, cases and rulings, within the context of the professional responsibilities of tax practice. Duplicates credit in ACCT 550T and ACCT 560T.

ACCT.title: Strategy and Operations Through CFO Lens
ACCT.description: Examination of strategic objectives and operations within specific industries and companies. Chief Financial Officers present how they view the business as a whole and measure performance effectively.

ACCT.title: Income Tax of Corporations and Their Shareholders
ACCT.description: Concepts and principles governing the taxation of corporations and their shareholders; the effect of taxes on corporate formation, capital structure, distributions, and liquidations. Recommended preparation: ACCT-550T or ACCT 554T or ACCT 560T or LAW 600.

ACCT.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT.description: Analysis of corporate financial reports from a decision-maker's perspective. This course is case-and-applications-oriented. Applications include credit analysis, equity valuation, and financial distress. Duplicates credit in ACCT 527.

ACCT.title: Professional Responsibilities in Accounting
ACCT.description: A case study approach to the integration of accounting and auditing knowledge; research, communication, and interpersonal skills developed through extensive written and presentation requirements.

ACCT.title: Selected Topics in Accounting Research
ACCT.description: Advanced Seminar to address issues/topics covered in accounting research. Open only to doctoral students.

ACCT.title: Financial Reporting Research
ACCT.description: Introduction to research in financial accounting; develop critical thinking skills for evaluating research; facilitate the generation of ideas for conducting original research. Duplicates credit in  ACCT-605.

ACCT.title: Research Forum
ACCT.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Accounting. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students.  Open only to Marshall Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.

ACCT.title: Capital Markets Research in Accounting
ACCT.description: Introduction to foundational capital markets research, the limitations of foundational archival capital markets research. Provide students with basis for identifying new opportunities.

ACCT.title: Advanced Capital Markets Research in Accounting
ACCT.description: Examination of accomplishments and limitations of advanced capital markets research. How to critically evaluate advanced capital markets research and identify new opportunities.

ACCT.title: Evaluating Earnings Quality
ACCT.description: Examination of multiple approaches researchers use to define earnings quality with a focus on investors as the primary users of financial statements.

IDSN.title: Professional Practices Residential
IDSN.description: One-week off-campus residential. Applied, intensive workshop format focused on solutions for real-world problems with input from industry experts.

IDSN.title: Designing Brand Identity for Startups
IDSN.description: Introduction to branding; brand design and development of a brand identity; brand attributes; visual aspects; social and ethical implications; curation of brand identity.

IDSN.title: Physical Product Design
IDSN.description: Initial design and development of consumer products; from ideation through visualization, market research, and prototyping to ready-to-market solutions; 3D modeling and 3D printing.

IDSN.title: Marketing Strategy for Startups
IDSN.description: A focus on ideal marketing strategies for early-stage startups seeking to build communities of early adopters and beta testers for products, services, and systems.

IDSN.title: Front End Web Programming
IDSN.description: Front-end (user-facing) development of interactive web pages; tools, techniques and practice.

IDSN.title: Extended Reality Technologies
IDSN.description: Provides context for creating augmented and virtual reality by examining the technologies that enable them and the perspectives for new applications in virtual and physical spaces.

IDSN.title: Processes and Perspectives
IDSN.description: Discipline-specific, cross-disciplinary and shared approaches to products, services, projects, systems, organizational development. Topics include creative and user-focused perspectives, feasibility analytics, lean startup techniques.

IDSN.title: Introduction to Machine Intelligence
IDSN.description: Concepts and applications of artificial intelligence and machine learning; topics include agents, knowledge representation, classification systems, training models, decision trees, decision trees and ensemble learning

IDSN.title: Industry and Impact Projects
IDSN.description: Practicum through which student teams serve as design strategists for industry collaborators, and learn advanced methods and processes to solve problems in collaborative, field-specific environments.

IDSN.title: Finance for Entrepreneurs
IDSN.description: The life cycle of a new venture from idea to construction of an    enterprise to a decision about financial viability. Recommended  preparation: IDSN 525 Business Essentials.

IDSN.title: Introduction to the Global Fashion System
IDSN.description: Analysis of the current fashion system exploring strategic interventions within existing models to imagine future systemic change; examines the role of seasonal structures.

IDSN.title: Directed Research
IDSN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units, which may be applied to the degree, to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IDSN.title: Mobile Application Development
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

IDSN.title: Product Management
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

IDSN.title: Social Media Incubator: Data-Driven Growth for Founders
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

IDSN.title: Social Media Incunator: Data-Driven Growth for Founders
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

IDSN.title: Rapid Visualization
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

ACAD.title: Innovators Forum
ACAD.description: Leaders in diverse disciplines, industries and the arts present and discuss problems facing society and critique real-world projects that challenge the concept of innovation.

ACAD.title: Rapid Visualization
ACAD.description: Techniques, methods, concepts, tools, and materials that are used to quickly visualize and communicate ideas and develop problem-solving skills.

ACAD.title: Digital Toolbox: Design
ACAD.description: Basics of industry-standard creative, analytical and presentation software. Applications include design, illustration, presentation and publishing.

ACAD.title: Case Studies in Innovation
ACAD.description: Employing a case-study methodology, students analyze the artistic, technological, and entrepreneurial factors and address the conceptual, ethical, and logistical issues that lead to disruptive innovation.

ACAD.title: Product Management for Challenge-Based Innovation
ACAD.description: Product management and innovation through hands-on frameworks; market analysis, financial modeling and leadership techniques for dynamic, high-stakes environments.

ACAD.title: Modeling Products with Solidworks
ACAD.description: Tools and techniques for Solidworks CAD design and design improvements, specially focused on the ideation and development of new products.

ACAD.title: 3D Tools for Product Design
ACAD.description: Investigation of a range of tools and techniques specific to intermediate CAD design and design improvements, focused on the ideation and development of new products.

ACAD.title: Making with Materials
ACAD.description: Material properties, fabrication processes and their interdependencies; the transformation of ideas into reality through simulated and traditional fabrication techniques.

ACAD.title: Python for Machine Intelligence
ACAD.description: Python programming for machine learning; topics include classification systems, training models, support vector machines, decision trees and random forests and ensemble learning.

ACAD.title: Statics
ACAD.description: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.

ACAD.title: Mechanics of Materials and Structures
ACAD.description: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; plates, shells, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design, trusses.

ACAD.title: Communication and Culture
ACAD.description: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.

ACAD.title: Extended Reality Design
ACAD.description: Students design and develop live immersive experiences in a variety of mediums including AR, VR and small- to large-scale interactive environments.

ACAD.title: Introduction to Interactive Physical Computing
ACAD.description: Design and development of physical computing prototypes within the intersection of electronics, computing, design, consumer electronics and product design.

ACAD.title: Fundamentals of Product Design
ACAD.description: Introductory course in learning how to design physical products, including the processes for determining consumer need, market opportunity and competitive product analysis.

ACAD.title: Designing Interactive Data Systems
ACAD.description: The design of interactive interfaces for data systems and simulations; introduction to business intelligence, data engineering, web development and user experience design.

ACAD.title: Dev II
ACAD.description: Fundamentals of server-side scripting and web templates. Design and creation of data structures and databases. Visualize analytics and data.

ACAD.title: Dreams and Madness: The Art of Japan's Golden Age of Animation
ACAD.description: An in-depth look at the art, politics, and cultural impact of  several Japanese filmmakers including Isao Takahata, Hayao  Miyazaki, Satoshi Kon, Mamoru Hosoda and Makoto Shinkai.

ACAD.title: Design for User Experience
ACAD.description: Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.

ACAD.title: Materials Behavior and Processing
ACAD.description: Mechanical behavior of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Structure-process-property relationships. Mechanical testing, stress-strain relationships, microstructural characteristics and analysis. Material failure (fracture, fatigue, creep) and degradation.

ACAD.title: Basics of Project and Operations Management for Non-Majors
ACAD.description: Introduction to tools and methods for the design, production, and delivery of goods and services. Techniques for planning, monitoring, and controlling complex projects. Not available for degree or major credit for business and accounting majors. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 313.

ACAD.title: The Practice of Design: Ideation to Innovation
ACAD.description: History and application of proven collaborative design processes and methodologies as they relate to ideation and innovation.

ACAD.title: Human Technology Interaction and the User Experience
ACAD.description: The user experience lifecycle from ideation to prototype evaluation with a focus on principles, processes and practices essential for designing effective digital products and experiences.

ACAD.title: iOS App Development
ACAD.description: Introduction to the Swift programming language, various frameworks, and design patterns needed to develop applications for iOS mobile devices such as iPhones and iPads.

ACAD.title: Managing Data in C++
ACAD.description: Data structures in C++ including vectors, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs and parallelism.

ACAD.title: Business and Professional Communication
ACAD.description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204

ACAD.title: Industry Practicum I: Designing and Implementing  Real-World Solutions
ACAD.description: Practicum through which students serve as design strategists for high-profile industry collaborators, and learn advanced methods and processes to solve problems in field-specific environments.

ACAD.title: Mobile Game Development
ACAD.description: Application of techniques used to develop games for mobile devices. Sprites, mobile input, mobile graphics and monetization.

ACAD.title: Advanced Front-End Web Development
ACAD.description: The technologies, techniques, conventions and best practices used in contemporary front-end web development.

ACAD.title: Purpose-Driven Innovation Incubator
ACAD.description: Evolve student projects into investor-ready ventures through exposure to industry best practices including market sizing, defining/pursuing key performance indicators, customer development, validated learning and innovation accounting.

ACAD.title: Professional Internship
ACAD.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in an arts, technology and business related facility. Written analysis, evaluation, and working internship.

ACAD.title: Web Application Security
ACAD.description: Examine web applications from an offensive security standpoint. Topics include information gathering, vulnerability discovery and validation, exploitation and privilege escalation techniques.

ACAD.title: Designing Products for Industry
ACAD.description: Develop desirable, feasible and viable solutions for specific industry prompts, implementing all aspects of R&D including consumer insights, competitive analysis, ideation, prototyping, testing and manufacturability.

ACAD.title: Applications of Machine Learning
ACAD.description: Hands-on approach to the fundamental modeling techniques and machine learning algorithms that enable students to build robust predictive models of real-world data and test their validity.

ACAD.title: The Garage Experience
ACAD.description: Academy capstone leading to innovative outcomes, including advanced research artifacts, operational prototypes, and breakthrough enterprises across multiple fields and industries.

ACAD.title: Technologies for Interactive Marketing
ACAD.description: Technologies, concepts and strategies in the emerging online advertising ecosystem; learn to drive traffic to a website and measure efficacy; work with a real client and budget to craft and execute an online marketing plan.

ACAD.title: Designing Brand Identity for Startups
ACAD.description: Introduction to branding; brand design and development of a brand identity; brand attributes; visual aspects; social and ethical implications; curation of brand identity.

ACAD.title: Introduction to the Global Fashion System
ACAD.description: Analysis of the current fashion system exploring strategic interventions within existing models to imagine future systemic change; examines the role of seasonal structures.

ACAD.title: Understanding AI
ACAD.description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of art, technology and the business of innovation.

PRIN.title: Industry and Impact Projects
PRIN.description: Practicum through which student teams serve as design strategists for industry collaborators, and learn advanced methods and processes to solve problems in collaborative, field-specific environments.

HT.title: Global Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: History, theories, trends and impacts relevant to global hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Managing Service Quality in Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Strategic management of service quality in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Marketing Strategies for Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Principles, strategies and techniques relevant to marketing in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Financial Management in Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Financial analysis methods to support sound, evidence-based decision-making in hospitality and tourism organizations.

HT.title: Revenue Management for Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Key principles and best practices in revenue management and pricing for hospitality and tourism organizations.

HT.title: Ethics in Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Ethical theories applied to common and strategic situations in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Hospitality and Tourism Events
HT.description: Analysis, planning and evaluation of meetings and events in hospitality and tourism settings.

HT.title: Hospitality and Tourism Capstone
HT.description: Students synthesize knowledge and skills gained throughout the program in a culminating capstone project.

HRM.title: Human Resource Strategy
HRM.description: Explores the strategic role that human resources management plays in providing organizations with sustained competitive advantages by unlocking the productive potential of employees human and social capital.

HRM.title: Organizational Culture and Employee Outcomes
HRM.description: Prepares students to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best in order to retain talent and reduce costs in a sustainable way.

HRM.title: Leadership in Human Resources
HRM.description: Focuses on developing the critical social intelligence skills needed to lead people and change through increased self-awareness, understanding of interpersonal differences, and greater influence.

HRM.title: Organization Design
HRM.description: Equips students with a deeper understanding of how to design and develop organizations to increase performance and effectiveness and includes sections on strategy, work, and management processes.

HRM.title: Talent Management
HRM.description: Examines talent management processes that impact employee experience and engagement and explores ways to improve data driven decision making processes including workforce and succession planning.

HRM.title: Total Rewards
HRM.description: Provides a comprehensive look at the employee rewards strategies that human resource practitioners promote and manage including compensation, performance management, benefits, and non-monetary rewards.

HRM.title: Learning and Development
HRM.description: Prepares students to identify, design, and implement effective learning and development interventions and strategies that drive results and enhance organizational competitiveness.

HRM.title: Employee Relations
HRM.description: Applies practical approaches to building positive employee and labor relations and solving related problems through increased employee motivation, effectiveness, and retention.

HRM.title: Human Resources Analytics
HRM.description: Examines and emphasizes strategies and techniques to enable improved organizational and human capital decisions by directing the organizational analytics for more actionable insights.

HRM.title: Management of Diverse and Global Human Resources
HRM.description: Analyzes global diversity in todays environment, fostering a broad understanding of diversity and inclusion and the impact of diversity, inclusion, and inclusive behaviors on organizations.

HRM.title: Change Management and Organization Development
HRM.description: Identifies the common challenges in organizational change management and explores the limitations and opportunities of different models of organizational change.

HRM.title: Anticipating the Future of Human Resources
HRM.description: Explores the forces and emerging trends that are reshaping work, the workforce and workplace  and how to address these transformational changes and be effective as a Human Resources leader.

LIM.title: Foundations of Library and Information Science
LIM.description: History and evolution of libraries and information organizations, including their structure, funding, role in society, and impact on the communities they serve.

LIM.title: User-Centered Collection Development
LIM.description: Collection development focused on the needs of patrons, in service of the institutional mission to serve and partner with the broader community.

LIM.title: Information Organization and Description for User Engagement
LIM.description: Theories, standards, and tools for the organization and description of information with the goal of equitable and inclusive access for users.

LIM.title: Social Science Research Methods in Library and Information S
LIM.description: Application of social science research methods in library and information science, including research question development, sampling, design methodologies, and data collection and analysis.

LIM.title: Information Sources and Services
LIM.description: Developments in reference and user services, including tools and processes for ethical information evaluation, retrieval and delivery for users in diverse library settings.

LIM.title: Leading Values-Driven Information Organizations
LIM.description: Effective application of interdisciplinary, community-centered leadership concepts in libraries and information organizations, with a focus on mission-driven, inclusive strategic planning and change management.

LIM.title: User Services and Community Engagement in Libraries
LIM.description: Investigation of various users and communities served by libraries and information organizations, and the development of programs and services tailored to their needs.

LIM.title: Archives and Digital Curation
LIM.description: History and evolution of archival practice, and the strategies and tools needed for contemporary and future-facing archival management, preservation and digital curation.

LIM.title: Justice, Equity and Ethics in Information Organizations
LIM.description: History, theory and potential of social justice in library and information organizations, with the goal of implementing services and programs for diverse stakeholders.

LIM.title: Capstone in Library and Information Management
LIM.description: Knowledge and skills gained throughout the MMLIS program are synthesized in a culminating capstone project, and deployed in service of career advancement.

PJMT.title: Principles of Project Management
PJMT.description: Concepts including delivering project scope within cost, schedule, and resource constraints and the exploration of the traditional or waterfall project management methodology will be explored.

PJMT.title: Requirements Elicitation and Business Analysis
PJMT.description: Tasks, techniques, and perspectives on how to approach business analysis along with methods for developing requirement process tools and techniques and best practices.

PJMT.title: Schedule Management
PJMT.description: Structured approach to project schedule management, demonstrating how to be proactive and in control of projects by implementing effective schedule management.

PJMT.title: Cost Estimation and Forecasting
PJMT.description: Approaches to project cost estimation and the tools and methodologies best suited for estimates and forecasts that need to be prepared.

PJMT.title: Risk Management
PJMT.description: Coursework will enable students to prepare a comprehensive risk management plan and discover different approaches to identify, assess, and quantify risks and their impacts.

PJMT.title: Agile Project Management Methodologies
PJMT.description: Agile project management concepts and a set of frameworks that covers the people, products, and techniques required to successfully implement projects.

PJMT.title: Quality and Process Improvement
PJMT.description: Quality and performance improvement projects and methodologies used to implement them with a focus on Six Sigma, Lean, and Total Quality Management.

PJMT.title: Specialized Project Management
PJMT.description: Explores several industries and entities and their developed project management methodologies to meet industry-specific needs through traditional approaches and partnerships in various sectors.

PJMT.title: Organizational Change Management and Business Relationships
PJMT.description: Students learn to cultivate the necessary components for stakeholder management on nearly any change within an organization through change management and business relationship management.

PJMT.title: Program Management
PJMT.description: Managing and coordinating multiple organizational projects with a focus on project alignment, organizational goals, performance maximization, risk minimization, and program success.

PJMT.title: Portfolio Management
PJMT.description: Structured approach to design, build, and manage a project portfolio, focusing on strategic implementation and operational initiatives to create sustainable value.

PJMT.title: Project Management Capstone
