PJMT.description: Utilize skills gained throughout the program to demonstrate the ability to plan and implement a project from conception to conclusion.

EM.title: Principles of Emergency Management
EM.description: Explores the historical development of emergency management as a distinct discipline in the United States and abroad, including theories, terminology and international coordination.

EM.title: Emergency Management Policies and Regulations
EM.description: Examines policies, regulations, politics and budgets that impact emergency management domestically and internationally in the government, non-profit and private sectors.

EM.title: Social and Cultural Competency in Emergency Management
EM.description: Explores how emergency management practices and community interactions can help address social, economic and cultural inequities while building increased resilience.

EM.title: Emergency Management Administration
EM.description: Examines the administrative functions of an emergency manager, including project management, policy implementation, acquisition of funding and managing diverse teams.

EM.title: Operational Coordination in Emergency Management
EM.description: Focuses on the complexity of post-disaster immediate and long-term response and recovery challenges in local, state, federal and international jurisdictions.

EM.title: Critical Infrastructure in Emergency Management
EM.description: Examines the wide spectrum of security threats to critical infrastructure and how to strengthen infrastructure protection and resilience through collaborative partnerships across sectors.

EM.title: Equity and Resilience in Emergency Management
EM.description: Examines equity and resilience in emergency management as they pertain to areas such as planning, mitigation, disaster logistics and supply chains.

EM.title: Emergency Management Capstone
EM.description: Demonstrate knowledge and skills developed throughout the emergency management program in an integrated way.

CJ.title: Criminology
CJ.description: Key theories and frameworks used to explain crime and inform responses to crime.

CJ.title: Analysis of Criminal Justice Systems
CJ.description: The criminal justice systems response to crime through a theoretical and interdisciplinary lens.

CJ.title: Criminal Justice Leadership
CJ.description: Theory and practice of traditional and contemporary approaches to leadership in the context of criminal justice.

CJ.title: Applied Research Methods for Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Fundamental research methods and design commonly used to answer questions related to criminal justice.

CJ.title: Applied Statistics and Data Analysis in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Fundamentals of statistics and statistical analyses commonly used to interpret crime data for evaluation and performance.

CJ.title: Ethical Decision-Making in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Examination and analysis of how societal expectations for ethical behavior and regulatory oversight affect leaders and managers in criminal justice.

CJ.title: Criminal Justice Policy and Program Development
CJ.description: In-depth analysis of all major stages of the criminal justice policymaking process.

CJ.title: Criminal Investigations
CJ.description: Explores criminal investigative techniques such as search and seizure, use of technology, and multi-jurisdictional and transnational crime investigations.

CJ.title: Corrections and Community Supervision
CJ.description: Examines evidence-based corrections and community supervision practices including offender rehabilitation, bail, restorative justice and victims issues.

CJ.title: Making a Difference in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Preparing for the critical role of leadership through policy evaluation and policy change initiatives.

GSBA.title: The Role of the Manager
GSBA.description: Fundamental roles of a manager and skill sets necessary to performing these roles. Open only to online MBA students.

GSBA.title: Operations Management
GSBA.description: Formulation, modeling, analysis, and optimization of business decision problems; survey of concepts and techniques necessary to manage the operations function of a firm. Duplicates credit in GSBA-534 and the former GSBA-504.

GSBA.title: Fundamentals of Business
GSBA.description: Fundamentals of financial accounting, microeconomics, statistics, analytics and communication.

GSBA.title: Foundations of Business Success
GSBA.description: Foundational knowledge and skills needed to achieve long-term career success and satisfaction.

GSBA.title: Marketing Management
GSBA.description: Development of analytical, strategic, and planning skills. Application within an integrated strategic framework to the development of a comprehensive marketing plan for a product, service, and/or organization. Duplicates credit in GSBA 528 and GSBA 546.

GSBA.title: Accounting Concepts and Financial Reporting
GSBA.description: Information systems for public reporting and for management decision-making; theory of asset and income measurement; interpretation and uses of accounting data and financial statements; analysis of cases.

GSBA.title: Microeconomics for Management
GSBA.description: Microeconomic theory with business applications; consumer demand, production theory, cost theory and market theory; decision making within the firm under different market and regulatory environments.

GSBA.title: Essentials of Data Analysis and Modeling
GSBA.description: Data collection, data analysis, and critical understanding of the role of data in making business decisions. Ways to quantify uncertainty and model decision problems. Duplicates credit in GSBA 506ab, GSBA 524, and GSBA 545.

GSBA.title: Communication for Management
GSBA.description: Internal and external communication, research methods; reports for decision making; oral presentations and briefings; strategies to assure communication; field studies. Duplicates credit in GSBA-502, GSBA-542, and the former GSBA-502ab.

GSBA.title: Data Science for Business
GSBA.description: Principles of probability theory and classical statistics applied to business decision problems; survey analysis, estimation and prediction methods, evaluation, and control techniques. Duplicates credit in GSBA 506ab, GSBA 516, GSBA 545.

GSBA.title: Introduction to Management and Strategy
GSBA.description: Introduction to the concepts, tools, and first principles of strategy formulation and competitive analysis.

GSBA.title: Marketing Management
GSBA.description: Marketing is treated as a managerial decision-making process. Emphasis is given to understanding the concepts, tools, and techniques that comprise a comprehensive marketing strategy. Duplicates credit in GSBA 509, the former GSBA 509ab, and GSBA 546.

GSBA.title: Leading People, Teams and Organizations
GSBA.description: How to make sound decisions, build and leverage social capital, negotiate effectively and influence and motivate others without relying on formal authority. Duplicates credit in GSBA 507, GSBA 522ab, GSBA 533, and GSBA 543.

GSBA.title: Operations Management
GSBA.description: Formulation, modeling, analysis, and optimization of business decision problems; survey of concepts and techniques necessary to manage the operations function of the firm. Recommended preparation: GSBA 506b or GSBA 524 or GSBA 516 or GSBA 545. (Duplicates Credit in GSBA 504ab)

GSBA.title: Managing Inside the Firm
GSBA.description: Thematic exploration of managerial accounting, employment law, operations management and organizational behavior. Application of analytics and communication to optimize internal operations.

GSBA.title: Managing Outside the Firm
GSBA.description: Thematic exploration of operations management, corporate finance, marketing, and microeconomics. Coordinating production processes, marketing strategies, and corporate financial plans in order to maximize growth.

GSBA.title: Contemporary Issues in Competitive Strategy
GSBA.description: Introduces the role industry and competitive analysis serves in an organization. Topics covered include global competition, innovation, the use of standards, competence, and building organizational capabilities to sustain competitive advantage. Duplicates credit in GSBA 529.

GSBA.title: Foundations of Your Professional Value
GSBA.description: Foundational knowledge to discover, identify and leverage the      professional value each person brings to today's job market.

GSBA.title: Communication for Management
GSBA.description: Internal and external communication, research methods, reports for  decision-making, oral presentations and briefing, strategies to  assure communication; field studies. Duplicates credit in GSBA  502, GSBA 523, GSBA-523T, and the former GSBA-502ab.

GSBA.title: Managerial Perspectives
GSBA.description: Managerial careers, development of critical executive and  managerial abilities, and the dynamics of organizational  environment and systems as they impact managerial progression and  growth. Duplicates credit in GSBA 507, GSBA 522ab, GSBA 532, GSBA  533.

GSBA.title: The Firm in the Global Economy
GSBA.description: The economic environment of business and the forces influencing the firm. Duplicates credit in GSBA 549.

GSBA.title: Data Driven Decision Making
GSBA.description: Data analysis technologies for business decision making; principles and techniques of statistical inference for business problem solving; foundations of data-driven regression and time series analytics. Duplicates credit in GSBA 506ab, GSBA 516, and GSBA 524.

GSBA.title: Corporate Finance
GSBA.description: Modern theory of corporate investment and financing decisions. (Duplicates credit in GSBA 521a and GSBA 521b.)

GSBA.title: Entrepreneurship
GSBA.description: Introduction to and overview of the fundamentals of entrepreneurship and corporate entrepreneurship - the practice of employing entrepreneurial skills and approaches within an organization. (Duplicates credit in BAEP 549, BAEP 551,           GSBA 550ab.)

GSBA.title: The Perspective of Top Management
GSBA.description: Using cases, students are introduced to top management issues of   executive leadership, environmental and strategic analysis, use of financial statements, organizational assessment and design,        technology management and decision support systems.  Graded CR/NC. =

GSBA.title: Evaluating Market Performance
GSBA.description: Evaluation of the firm by the market forces that affect its success; financial accounting and reporting; competitive market analysis; external communication; microeconomics; labor, customer and financial markets, statistical and decision analysis, financial and organization measures of effectiveness.

GSBA.title: Evaluating Business Performance
GSBA.description: Thematic introduction to finance, statistical and decision analysis, marketing, financial accounting and reporting, competitive market analysis, external communication, and financial and organization measures of effectiveness.

GSBA.title: The Role of the Senior Executive
GSBA.description: Introduction to strategic management; executive leadership;        environmental analysis; international context; financial growth    strategies; social, legal and macroeconomic issues; role of CEO    with boards, media and other publics; business ethics, strategic   planning project.  Recommended preparation: GSBA 534

GSBA.title: Environmental Analysis: Establishing Competitive Advantage
GSBA.description: Development of strategic planning processes; analysis of economic, social, political environment; forecasting; futures research; macroeconomics; international economics; technological developments; multinational management simulation; field projects.

GSBA.title: Strategic Planning for Growth
GSBA.description: Formulation and implementation of strategies in different organizational and environmental contexts; financial growth strategies; comparative management; impact of taxation; technology strategies; product development and new market strategies. (Duplicates credit in GSBA-572)

GSBA.title: The Global Context of Business (IELP)
GSBA.description: The economic and political realities of cross-border commerce in the 21st century. IELP. Requires international travel.

GSBA.title: Internship in Business
GSBA.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training) Graduate business students only. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Consulting Project in Business
GSBA.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to master and doctoral students.

GSBA.title: Selected Issues in Economic Theory I
GSBA.description: Methodology and research perspectives of economics; contribution of the economics paradigm to accounting, management, finance, marketing, and decision sciences. Recommended preparation: Admission to doctoral program in business administration or departmental approval.

GSBA.title: Regression and Generalized Linear Models for Business Applications
GSBA.description: Theory and application of linear regression models; role of  substantive theory in statistical model building; model  specification, estimation, diagnostic checking; the general linear  hypothesis.

GSBA.title: Experimental Design and Analysis for Behavioral Science
GSBA.description: Introduction to design, implementation and analyses of experiments. Designing experimental procedures (manipulations, measurements). Analyzing ANOVAs with manipulated and measured factors, mediation, reliability and discrimination analyses.

GSBA.title: Research
GSBA.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

FBE.title: The Power of Personal Finance
FBE.description: Develop knowledge and skills in areas of money management, budgeting, financial goal attainment, insurance, credit cards, and investments.

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE.description: Introduction to income-producing real estate from the perspective of finance, market analysis, capital markets, development and investment. Includes focus on analytical techniques and computer applications. Duplicates credit in FBE 400.

FBE.title: Introduction to Real Estate Finance and Development
FBE.description: Case analysis examining economic and financial aspects of real  estate decisions for non-business majors. Focuses on dynamics of  financing, markets and the development process. Not available for  degree credit for business majors. Duplicates credit in FBE 391.

FBE.title: Introduction to the Legal Environment of Business
FBE.description: Legal principles of business: litigation process, constitutional  law, torts, product liability, crimes, contracts, and leases,  intellectual property, international law, agency, employment law,  and ethics.

FBE.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE.description: Develops and uses tools of financial analysis to evaluate the performance and assess the value of individual companies in an industry context.

FBE.title: Introduction to Venture Capital and Private Equity
FBE.description: Introduction to venture capital and private equity. Topics include fundraising, valuation of new firms and venture capital securities, and exiting investments through public offerings.

FBE.title: Financial Institutions and Capital Markets
FBE.description: Money and capital markets; derivative markets; foreign exchange    markets; investment banks and nonbank finance, financial crises;   commercial banks, Federal Reserve and conduct of monetary policy.  Duplicates credit in former FBE 324.

FBE.title: Real Estate Law
FBE.description: Principles of law regarding real property transactions; buyer-seller, debtor-creditor, landlord-tenant relationships; environmental law and land use control; investments and syndication.

FBE.title: Introduction to Employment Law
FBE.description: Survey of current employment law topics including employment discrimination arising within modern workplaces. Legal and business strategies for managing diversity for organizational success.

FBE.title: International Business Law
FBE.description: Introductory course on the legal and regulatory environment of  international business transactions.

FBE.title: Introduction to Decentralized Finance - DeFi
FBE.description: Introduction to decentralized finance and the markets for cryptocurrencies, decentralized borrowing and lending, digital assets and nonfungible to tokens.

FBE.title: Corporate Financial Strategy
FBE.description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy, the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

FBE.title: Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
FBE.description: Emphasis on hedging tools necessary for portfolio managers. Introduction of all securities available in fixed income and provision of tools to analyze investments.

FBE.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management    for Developing Firms
FBE.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE.title: Investments
FBE.description: Theories and applications of investment decision-making; the behavior of security prices, portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency, bond valuation and term structure, derivative securities.

FBE.title: Practicum in Investment Management - Security Selection
FBE.description: Application of investment management techniques in a laboratory setting. Stock selection, asset allocation, industry analysis, investment thesis research; off-site visits; oral and written presentations. Duplicates credit in the former FBE 453a.

FBE.title: Law of Forming, Financing and Managing Businesses
FBE.description: Law and ethics of agency, partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, governmental regulation, mergers, creditor rights, secured transactions, bankruptcy, securities regulation and antitrust.

FBE.title: Financial Derivatives
FBE.description: A rigorous introduction to the pricing and corporate use of financial derivatives -- futures, options, forwards and swaps -- on stocks, exchange rates, bonds and commodities.

FBE.title: Real Estate Analysis and Computer Modeling
FBE.description: Real estate valuation. Three approaches to valuation: Market comparison, income, and cost. Highest and best use analysis. State of the art real estate software.

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance Colloquium
FBE.description: The roles of economics and finance in real estate. Lessons from history, the origin of real estate bubbles, how real estate markets work.

FBE.title: Investment Banking Fundamentals
FBE.description: The role of an investment banking associate. Students will effectively function as a junior banker through a sell-side merger and acquisition (M & A) process.

FBE.title: Behavioral Finance
FBE.description: Applications of behavioral finance and how psychological forces influence investor behavior, asset prices and corporate decision-making.

FBE.title: Quantitative Methods in Finance
FBE.description: The development of single and bivariate mathematical and statistical methods used in modern finance and economics and applications of these methods. Duplicates credit in former FBE 506ab.

FBE.title: Venture Capital and Private Equity
FBE.description: Advanced analysis of the economics of the private equity markets. Consider and value private securities in venture capital, initial public offerings, and leveraged buyouts. Prerequisites: GSBA-521b or GSBA-548.

FBE.title: Money and Capital Markets
FBE.description: Review of financial institutions and markets, the determinants of interest rates, the impact of government regulation and policy on the financial system. Prerequisite: GSBA 521b or GSBA 548.

FBE.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management    for Developing Firms
FBE.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash            flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk  analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE.description: An applications-oriented course to develop the financial and accounting tools required to do financial planning valuation and assessment of financial performance.

FBE.title: Decentralized Finance (DeFi)
FBE.description: The structure of decentralized finance and implications for the functioning of financial markets. Analysis of cryptocurrencies, smart contracts in finance, digital assets and nonfungible tokens.

FBE.title: Corporate Financial Policy and Corporate Governance
FBE.description: Advanced analysis of the determinants of corporate capital structure and payout policies, allocation and value of corporate control, and security issuance and retirement.

FBE.title: Corporate Financial Strategy
FBE.description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy; the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

FBE.title: Quantitative Investing
FBE.description: Build, test and implement the types of models in use by quantitative asset managers.

FBE.title: Applied Portfolio Management
FBE.description: Application of portfolio management techniques in a laboratory setting. Stock selection, asset allocation, industry analysis, investment thesis research; off-site visits; oral and written presentations.

FBE.title: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
FBE.description: Analysis and management of common stocks and fixed income securities; development of modern portfolio theory and the efficient market hypothesis; organization of securities markets.

FBE.title: Law for Structuring, Financing, and Managing Businesses
FBE.description: Legal environment of agency law, general and limited partnerships, limited liability companies, corporate formation and financing, corporate governance, securities law, acquisitions, bankruptcy, and business ethics.

FBE.title: Management of Financial Risk
FBE.description: Analysis of commodity, futures, and options contracts; theoretical and empirical approaches; spot and futures price relationships, speculation and hedging strategies; market efficiency.

FBE.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
FBE.description: Practical application of the critical components of M&A: deal flow strategies, preliminary negotiations, deal structures, due diligence, valuation, post-merger integration, and regulations.

FBE.title: Mortgages and Mortgage-Backed Securities and Markets
FBE.description: Valuation and analysis of residential and commercial mortgages and mortgage-backed securities and related markets.

FBE.title: Directed Research
FBE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE.description: Analysis of investment in and financing of real estate assets including projections, valuation, deal structure, contracts, portfolio and tax and entity considerations.

FBE.title: Independent Research in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Internship in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.) Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Research Practicum in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Finance and Business Economics Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Consulting Project in Finance or Business        Economics
FBE.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations.

FBE.title: Research Forum
FBE.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Finance and Business Economics. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open only to Marshall PhD students.

FBE.title: Advanced Corporate Finance
FBE.description: Advanced and frontier issues in corporate finance. A: financial intermediation, investment-cash flow sensitivity, internal capital markets, diversification, and business groups.

FBE.title: Advanced Corporate Finance
FBE.description: Advanced and frontier issues in corporate finance. B: mergers and divestitures, product market competition, corporate governance, and finance and development.

FBE.title: Advanced Asset Pricing
FBE.description: Advanced asset pricing in financial economics focusing on advanced empirical methods: (a) emphasis on quantitative models, (b) emphasis on GMM and regression. Duplicates credit in the former FBE 634.

FBE.title: Advanced Asset Pricing
FBE.description: Advanced asset pricing in financial economics focusing on advanced empirical methods: (a) emphasis on Quantitative models, (b) emphasis on GMM and regression. Duplicates credit in the former FBE 634.

FBE.title: Psychology and Financial Markets
FBE.description: Exploration of emerging topics, literature and research techniques in contemporary finance and/or business economics.                           May be repeated only if topic is different.

RISK.title: Introduction to Enterprise Risk Management
RISK.description: Understand the concept of risk, risk assessment, and management frameworks. Learn to identify, analyze, manage and mitigate, and communicate this risk to stakeholders. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 380.

RISK.title: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
RISK.description: Understand the underlying economics, structure, and business models of an organization (often an insurance carrier) willing to accept risk for diverse situations: property, life, healthcare. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 385.

RISK.title: Risk Management in Entertainment, Sports and the Arts
RISK.description: Knowledge and skills needed to identify, analyze, control, finance and report on the risks particular to entertainment, sports and the arts. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 387.

RISK.title: Advanced Enterprise Risk Management
RISK.description: The practical application of enterprise risk management across a broad spectrum of business settings and industry types, from start-up to multinational organizations.

RISK.title: Conduct, Culture and Ethics Risk Management Through Films
RISK.description: Current developments in the field of Risk Management. Topics vary from semester to semester. May be repeated only if topic is different.

BUCO.title: Managing Communication and New Media
BUCO.description: Individual and team exploration of 21st century media tools and their impact on communication strategies in business. Course uses social media, collaborative software, virtual immersion, and video conferencing.

BUCO.title: Advanced Managerial Communication
BUCO.description: Optimize individual, interpersonal communication dynamics and advance skill development through executive coaching model and applied business communication theory. Recommended preparation: Prior course work or experience in management or business communication.

BUCO.title: Independent Research in Management Communication
BUCO.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Social and Ethical Issues in Business
MOR.description: Explores ethical issues in business from diverse perspectives including the roles and responsibilities of institutional actors, corporate social responsibility and balancing stakeholder interest.

MOR.title: AI Technology Strategic Management
MOR.description: How to develop strategy approaches for managing new technology in business with a focus on artificial intelligence.

MOR.title: Management Consulting
MOR.description: Role of professional consultants; data gathering methods;  consulting approaches from strategy, finance, operations,  information systems, marketing, and human resources; action  planning; ethical and career issues.

MOR.title: Negotiation and Persuasion
MOR.description: Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and  persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies.   Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective  negotiation and persuasion.

MOR.title: Global Leadership
MOR.description: Major theories and practices of leading people in multi-national  firms.  Skills for facilitating cooperation, communication, and  motivation among people from different cultures. Recommended  preparation: BUAD 304

MOR.title: Power, Politics and Influence
MOR.description: Theories and practices about how power, politics and influence  affect organizational life.  Knowledge and skills for diagnosing  and managing these features of an organization.

MOR.title: The Art of Leadership - Self Discovery
MOR.description: Introductory leadership. Self-examination of personal leadership  styles using survey tools, comparative models and in-class  exercises. Duplicates credit in former MOR 476a. Open only to  students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars Program.

MOR.title: The Business of Sports
MOR.description: Addresses the business side of the sports industry; examines  professional sports franchises, amateur athletics, and collegiate  sports and how they relate to corporate America, the media, and  the public sector. Recommended Preparation BUAD 304.

MOR.title: Sports Business Innovation: Impacts on Decision Making
MOR.description: Investigates how innovation in sports business influences industry cash flow and executive decision making. Examines emerging areas of innovation and their impacts on industry stakeholders.

MOR.title: Global Strategy
MOR.description: Examination of corporate strategy practices in an international  context.  Effects of cultures, political systems, markets, and  economic systems on developing effective global strategies.

MOR.title: Leadership and Sustainability
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory. (Graded CR/NC)

MOR.title: Technology for Good
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory. (Graded CR/NC)

MOR.title: Power, Players and Platforms in Global Sports
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Product Management 1 - Essentials and Frameworks
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Strategic Leadership in Product Management
MOR.description: Equip students with strategic and managerial skills in product  management, focusing on leading cross-functional teams, leveraging  technology, and integrating generative AI for innovation.

MOR.title: Applied Product Management
MOR.description: Hands-on experience managing real products from start to finish.  Essential processes and tools to enhance skills and improve  professional prospects.

MOR.title: Strategic Issues for Global Business
MOR.description: Globalization strategies from entry to maturity; alternative approaches from going alone to alliances; strategy implementation issues in different cultures and political systems. Cases, videos and speakers.

MOR.title: Designing High Performance Organizations
MOR.description: Theory and practice of organization design. How to maximize organization performance by aligning structure, rewards, staffing, processes, and culture with strategy and environment.

MOR.title: Strategy and Organization Consulting
MOR.description: How consultants assist clients to formulate strategic plans and realign organizations; approaches used by major consulting firms; information about consulting industry, fee-setting and proposals. Consultant speakers and project.

MOR.title: Strategic Renewal and Transformation
MOR.description: Dynamic strategic planning; how businesses re-invent themselves; why change is difficult; politics of change process; leadership steps for implementing successful strategic changes. Cases and readings.

MOR.title: Strategic Choice and Valuation Analysis
MOR.description: Advanced strategic planning using tools of scenario development and activity valuation for assessing market entry, expansion and business portfolio configuration. Exercises, cases and project.

MOR.title: Interpersonal Influence and Power
MOR.description: Legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings, cases.

MOR.title: Negotiation and Deal-Making
MOR.description: Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.

MOR.title: Leadership and Executive Development
MOR.description: Contemporary approaches to leadership, including corporate practices to develop leaders; examples of successful and derailed executives. Students self-assess personal leadership and draft development plans. Readings, speakers, cases.

MOR.title: Leading and Coaching: Foundations and Practicum
MOR.description: Marshall MBA Leadership Fellows Program (MLFP). Learn, practice and teach leadership. Engage in critical thinking and problem solving. (a) Foundations. (b) Practicum. Application required.

MOR.title: The Business of Sports Entertainment
MOR.description: Business practices and issues in different sports markets including growth opportunities and innovative marketing strategies for attracting and retaining fans and corporate sponsors. Industry speakers.

MOR.title: Leadership and Improvisation
MOR.description: Build leadership skills through improvisation.  How to lead more effectively by being open, agile and flexible.

MOR.title: Corporate Strategy and Competitive Dynamics
MOR.description: Central challenges facing executives in multi-business firms; toolkit for analyzing and executing strategic and operational aspects of corporate advantage, M&As; and competitive dynamics.

MOR.title: Directed Research
MOR.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Field Research in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Individual or team projects studying the management practices of an industry, company, government agency, country geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Independent Research in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Internship in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.)

MOR.title: Research Practicum in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Management and Organization Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Consulting Project in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an   existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written  presentations. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Seminar in Organizational Behavior
MOR.description: In-depth review of the theories and empirical research in the discipline of organizational behavior. Topics include: personality, motivation, job design, leadership, and others.

MOR.title: Seminar in Strategic Management
MOR.description: Survey of strategic management. Topics include historical overview of strategic management, research methods used, current theory, and empirical research on the developing paradigms. Open only to Business Administration doctoral students.

MOR.title: Research
MOR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Open only to Marshall Ph.D. students specializing in Management and Organization. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Introduction to Marketing Analytics
MKT.description: Analyze marketing data and develop actionable insights to guide marketing decisions. Apply statistical tools, machine learning, and economic analysis to digital marketing problems.

MKT.title: Marketing Communication and Promotion Strategy
MKT.description: Develop skills for effective marketing communication and promotion. Consider objectives and components of a strategic plan (including marketplace analysis, research, campaign development, and media planning).

MKT.title: Professional Selling
MKT.description: Principles of business-to-business selling and its function in marketing strategy and the marketing mix. Explore professional selling as a career option.

MKT.title: Digital Marketing Fundamentals
MKT.description: Examine the changing world of the connected consumer. Gain introductory knowledge about consumers online and digital marketing tactics across industries.

MKT.title: Social Media Strategy for Business
MKT.description: Examine the use of social media for business across industries. Understand theories and frameworks for strategic content creation and posting as technology and platforms evolve.

MKT.title: New Product Development and Branding
MKT.description: Learn how marketers create new brands, products and services. Discuss and examine creative ideation, research and development, brand image management and legal issues in branding.

MKT.title: Consumer Behavior and Marketing
MKT.description: Examine diverse consumers behavior including acquisition, usage and disposition of products. Understand the psychological, social and cultural influences that drive consumers decisions.

MKT.title: Marketing in the Entertainment Industry
MKT.description: Examine the marketing of products and brands in the entertainment industry (including movies, TV shows, music and video games).

MKT.title: Multicultural Marketing
MKT.description: Examine how marketers adapt the marketing mix to serve consumers from diverse cultures, considering differing social norms and regulations across the global marketplace.

MKT.title: Marketing in the Gaming Industry
MKT.description: Examine issues traditionally crucial to the marketing of games including launch marketing, consumer insights, brand management, data analytics, performance marketing and community engagement.

MKT.title: Customer Insights and Analysis
MKT.description: Use of marketing research techniques and technologies such as databases and statistical tools to collect, analyze and act upon customer information.

MKT.title: Consumer Behavior
MKT.description: Analyze theories of consumer behavior and their relevance to the modern marketplace; examine psychological, social, and cultural factors influencing consumers across contexts.

MKT.title: Sales Management: The Art and Science of Sales
MKT.description: Emphasis on creating a sales strategy, planning and delivery of sales presentations, and techniques to persuade people to change their opinions in face-to-face meetings.

MKT.title: New Product Development
MKT.description: Systematic approach to product development and management; processes, techniques, and concepts firms use to develop, test, and introduce products and to manage products over their lifecycle.

MKT.title: Brand Strategy and Management
MKT.description: Analyze the behavioral foundations of brands and brand development; explore various marketing tools and tactics for brand development and management.

MKT.title: Pricing Strategies
MKT.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of pricing and pricing strategy. Develop a conceptual framework and a set of analytical tools used to make sound pricing decisions.

MKT.title: From Strategy to Execution: User Experience (UX) and Design
MKT.description: Explores the dynamic relationship between user experience (UX) and marketing strategy. Students utilize UX design principles to address product and marketing challenges.

MKT.title: Decision Making Using Marketing Analytics
MKT.description: Applications and models of marketing-related data analyses to the development of data-driven marketing strategies and making data-driven marketing decisions.

MKT.title: Geographic Information Systems Applications in Marketing
MKT.description: Fundamentals of geographic information systems; location analytics and spatial thinking as they relate to data-driven decision-making in marketing strategy and tactics.

MKT.title: Fashion, Luxury and Lifestyle Marketing
MKT.description: Examination of marketing issues and challenges within a variety of business settings in the fashion, luxury goods and lifestyle sectors in the global marketplace.

MKT.title: The CMO: Driving Shareholder Value in the Intelligence Age
MKT.description: Explores roles of the Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) in driving shareholder value in an era dominated by intelligence technologies and evolving customer expectations.

MKT.title: Directed Research
MKT.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Field Research in Marketing
MKT.description: Individual or team projects studying the marketing practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Independent Research in Marketing
MKT.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Internship in Marketing
MKT.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the field of marketing. (Curricular Practical Training.) Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Research Practicum in Marketing
MKT.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Marketing Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Consulting Project in Marketing
MKT.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC

MKT.title: Strategic and Marketing Mix Models
MKT.description: Modeling research o marketing with a focus on discrete choice  models, consideration set models, purchase timing models,  accounting for consumer heterogeneity, Baysian models, dynamic  models of consumer choice, market entry effects, product quality,  advertising and carry over effects, price, and promotion. Open to  students in the doctoral program in business administration only.

MKT.title: Research Forum
MKT.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Marketing. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open to Marshall Ph.D. students only. Graded CR/NC.

BAEP.title: Management of Small Businesses
BAEP.description: Strategic, organizational, financial, and human issues facing the small business.

BAEP.title: Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Starting and managing one's own business: developing a viable concept, organizing the enterprise, market and financial planning, and controlling the organization. (Duplicates credit in BAEP 451)

BAEP.title: Feasibility Analysis
BAEP.description: Students develop, analyze, and validate entrepreneurial concepts (including marketing, operational, and financial considerations) using customer feedback and risk assessment to conclude worthiness to pursue.

BAEP.title: Venture Management
BAEP.description: Design and application of organization structures and systems in management of new ventures.

BAEP.title: Founder's Dilemmas
BAEP.description: Prepares potential founders, hires, and investors for the decisions they will face both before and during their involvement with new ventures.

BAEP.title: Toy Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Perspectives into the art and science of entrepreneurship under the guidance of a master instructor. Specific topics vary.

BAEP.title: The Science of Peak Performance
BAEP.description: Ingrains expertise and application of the science of peak performance, broadens preparation for personal challenge, and builds business-centered critical thinking and applied analytical skills.

BAEP.title: Sales Mindset for Entrepreneurs
BAEP.description: The sales planning decisions that entrepreneurs make, including how to accelerate startup revenue, what metrics drive success and how to build great sales teams.

BAEP.title: Entertainment Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Explore the current entrepreneurial trends and opportunities in the entertainment industry and uncover the key success factors for entrepreneurs in this industry.

BAEP.title: Entrepreneurial Family Business
BAEP.description: Explores the dynamics of family and privately held businesses. Exploring generational and extended family issues, opportunities and obstacles faced in today's environment.

BAEP.title: Introduction to Social Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Analysis of social enterprise models from micro-finance to job development. Analysis of basic issues regarding the difference between socially responsible companies, for-profit, and non-profit-run enterprises.

BAEP.title: Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
BAEP.description: Combined classroom discussion and field application of business  theories and practices; part-time internship employment.  Project  to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor.  Graded  CR/NC.

BAEP.title: Field Project in Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Individual or team projects solving real problems for an enterprise. Situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Open only to Juniors and Seniors. Graded Credit/No Credit.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneurial Journey
BAEP.description: An introduction to entrepreneurship with a focus on opportunity recognition and the entrepreneurial mindset. Development of knowledge and skills in launching new ventures. Duplicates credit          in BAEP 551, GSBA 550, GSBA 550ab, and GSBA 551.

BAEP.title: Introduction to New Ventures
BAEP.description: Study and development of analytical and conceptual skills in the management of new enterprises and new ventures within large organizations. Duplicates credit in BAEP 549, GSBA 550, GSBA 550ab and GSBA 551.

BAEP.title: Venture Feasibility
BAEP.description: Assess the viability of and develop potential new business opportunities through the application of analytic frameworks and field research. Duplicates credit in BAEP 556 and BAEP 566.

BAEP.title: Cases in New Venture Management
BAEP.description: Cases and readings expose students to the challenges of developing long-range strategies for entrepreneurial ventures. Case work emphasizes developing new industries, growth through strategic alliances, and issues involved in the long-term strategic positioning of emerging companies.

BAEP.title: Founder's Dilemmas: Anticipate and Avoid Startup Pitfalls
BAEP.description: Delves into founders' early decisions about when and whether to found, co-founders, hires, and investors that tend to get them into trouble down the road.

BAEP.title: Technology Feasibility
BAEP.description: Assess the viability of and develop potential technology business opportunities through the application of analytic frameworks and field research. Duplicates credit in BAEP 552 and BAEP 566.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneurial Advisor: Problem Solving for Early-Stage Companies
BAEP.description: Experiential course designed to develop skills in framing and      solving complex problems in young companies. Apply skills to real  ventures participating in course projects.

BAEP.title: Investing in New Ventures
BAEP.description: Focus on the entrepreneurial skill set applied to new venture opportunities. Taught from the business plan reader's point of view; focus on selecting opportunities, structuring the relationship, adding value and realizing the value of that investment.

BAEP.title: Investing in Impact Ventures
BAEP.description: Exploring the field of social impact investing, learn how social entrepreneurs attract for-profit investors and how conscious investors are utilizing investments to achieve social impact.

BAEP.title: Cases in Feasibility Analysis for Social Ventures
BAEP.description: Deploy analytic frameworks and conduct fieldwork to evaluate the real-world potential of new business concepts with a specific focus on  new social ventures. Recommended preparation: BAEP 589 or BAEP 591. Duplicates credit in BAEP 552 and BAEP 556.

BAEP.title: Social Innovation Design
BAEP.description: Use innovative problem-solving approaches to design radically affordable solutions to challenges faced by under-resourced communities. Engage in early-stage market and rapid prototyping.

BAEP.title: Performance Mindset for Business
BAEP.description: Develop a performance mindset to better the  ability to integrate challenges and define personal growth in startups and innovative organizations.

BAEP.title: Entrepreneurship in the Media and Entertainment Industry
BAEP.description: Introduction to the ever-evolving field of media and entertainment with a focus on entrepreneurial opportunities within the industry.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneurial CEO: The Real World of Leading Startups
BAEP.description: Practical tools for entrepreneurial leaders to manage themselves,  hire and manage people in their growing start-ups (and beyond),  and make decisions in fast-changing environments.

BAEP.title: Seminar: The Entrepreneurial Mindset
BAEP.description: Explore the art and science of entrepreneurship under the guidance of a master entrepreneur.

BAEP.title: Directed Research
BAEP.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may   be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

BAEP.title: Field Research in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Individual or team projects studying the business practices of an  entrepreneurial industry, company, government agency, country,     etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report.      (Recommended Preparation: completion of required MBA, MAcc, MBT,   MKT, MSEI or MSSE course work)

BAEP.title: Independent Research in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required.

BAEP.title: Internship in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.) Recommended             preparation: completion of required MBA, MAcc, MBT, MKT, MSEI, or  MSSE coursework.

BAEP.title: Research Practicum in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a faculty member in the Lloyd Greif Center for Entrepreneurial Studies on an ongoing research project.

BAEP.title: Consulting Project in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to Master and Doctoral Students

BAEP.title: The High-Growth Startup: The Promise and Perils of Success
BAEP.description: Current developments in the field of entrepreneurship: topics to be selected each semester. May be repeated only if topic is different.

BUAD.title: Foundations of Finance and Accounting
BUAD.description: Accounting information in decision-making from the perspective of users and preparers. Basics of financial asset valuation. Consideration of time-value of money and risk. Not available for major or minor credit.  Graded CR/NC.

BUAD.title: Freshman Leadership Seminar
BUAD.description: Colloquium of leading researchers, authors, and administrators in the Marshall School of Business and other schools at USC. Industry leaders will also be invited to talk about leadership challenges. Graded CR/NC. Open by invitation only to freshman business and             accounting majors.

BUAD.title: World Bachelor in Business Program Freshman Academy
BUAD.description: Introduction to selected academic subject matter, development of intercultural communication skills, and access to business professionals. Graded CR/NC.

BUAD.title: AI for Business Freshman Academy
BUAD.description: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence for Business, both in curriculum and resources, and access to industry professionals. (Graded CR/NC)

BUAD.title: Real Estate Finance and Development Freshman Seminar
BUAD.description: Introduction to the Real Estate Finance and Development program curriculum and resources and the current landscape of the real estate industry. (Graded CR/NC)

BUAD.title: Economic Foundations for Business
BUAD.description: Examines fundamental concepts of both microeconomics and macroeconomics as they pertain to business and financial decisions. Not available for degree credit to business majors.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Business for Non-Majors
BUAD.description: Introduction to the principles and practices of businesses, sequence of exercises developing the basic skills, and influence of the economy on business and individual decisions. Not available for credit for business or accounting majors.

BUAD.title: Choosing and Planning a Future Career in Business
BUAD.description: Explore and plan for future career choices and options in business. Learn theoretical principles, best practices and strategies, and contemporary workplace issues/trends. Graded CR/NC.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
BUAD.description: Emphasis on understanding financial statements and the impact of business transactions on information presented to management and interested stakeholders.  Duplicates credit in BUAD 305.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
BUAD.description: An emphasis on how accounting information, combined with a variety of techniques and best practices, supports enhanced management decision making. Duplicates credit in BUAD 305.

BUAD.title: Technology Entrepreneurship
BUAD.description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

BUAD.title: Communication Strategy in Business
BUAD.description: Theory, practices, and techniques of business communication strategy essential to external and organizational communication; group and interpersonal communication; development of skill in oral and written communication.

BUAD.title: Organizational Behavior and Leadership
BUAD.description: The role of leadership in business organizations; concepts and skills for managing oneself and others.

BUAD.title: Abridged Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD.description: Uses of accounting information in decision-making; accounting issues concerning income and cash flows, economic resources and capital. Duplicates credit in BUAD 280 and BUAD 281. Open only to transfer business and accounting majors.

BUAD.title: Business Finance
BUAD.description: Financial problems of business enterprise; function of financial manager; sources of funds; instruments, institutions, and practices of finance; problems of financial management using case studies. Recommended Preparation: foundational courses in  microeconomics, financial accounting, and business statistics. Duplicates credit in the former BUAD 215x and BUAD 308.

BUAD.title: Marketing Fundamentals
BUAD.description: Develop a managerial viewpoint in planning, executing, and evaluating marketing decisions of the firm, including decisions related to products, pricing, distribution channels and promotion.

BUAD.title: Advanced Business Finance
BUAD.description: Rigorous coverage of principles and practices of financial management; valuation of cash flows; capital budgeting; risk and return; cost of capital; corporate financial policy. Recommended Preparation: foundational courses in microeconomics, financial  accounting, and business statistics. Duplicates credit in the former BUAD 215x and BUAD 306.

BUAD.title: Applied Business Statistics
BUAD.description: Statistical methods for business analysis; data exploration and description; sampling distributions; estimation; hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression; model building. Extensive computer applications. (Duplicates credit in BUAD 312 and the former ITP 251.)

BUAD.title: Operations Management
BUAD.description: Fundamentals of operations management. Skills needed to analyze, manage, and improve business processes. Topics include: process, capacity, service, and inventory management and optimization. (Duplicates credit in BUAD 313 and BUAD 315x.)

BUAD.title: Statistics and Data Science for Business
BUAD.description: Statistical methods for exploration, visualization, and analysis of large business datasets; simulation; hypothesis testing, multiple regression modeling, and confidence intervals. Coding taught through data applications. (Faster-paced version of BUAD-310g. Duplicates credit in BUAD 310g and the former ITP 251.)

BUAD.title: Advanced Operations Management and Analytics
BUAD.description: Advanced operations management techniques to analyze and improve business processes.  Decision making under uncertainty through case studies with real data, using state-of-the-art simulation and optimization. (Faster-paced version of BUAD 311. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 315.)

BUAD.title: Basics of Project and Operations Management for Non-Majors
BUAD.description: Introduction to tools and methods for the design, production, and delivery of goods and services. Techniques for planning, monitoring, and controlling complex projects. Not available for degree or major credit for business and accounting majors. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 313.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Business Analytics
BUAD.description: Leveraging large corporate datasets; slice and dice data; dash boards; data mining and statistical tools; neural network; multiple and logistic regression; decision tree; gain inference and decision making; clustering.

BUAD.title: Directed Research
BUAD.description: Individual research and readings under the supervision of a faculty advisor. Application and proposal required. Not available for graduate credit.

BUAD.title: Marshall Honors Research and Thesis
BUAD.description: Experience in conducting research and writing a thesis under the supervision of a faculty adviser.

BUAD.title: Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
BUAD.description: Combined classroom discussion and structured, supervised field application of business theories and practices within a part-time employment context. Graded CR/NC.

BUAD.title: Strategic Management
BUAD.description: Examination of managerial decision-making, planning, and policy under changing environments; readings, cases, exercises, simulations.

DSO.title: Business Forecasting
DSO.description: A variety of forecasting techniques used by a variety of businesses. Emphasis on learning to apply these techniques to real data.

DSO.title: Digital Transformation of Business: AI and Smart Contracts
DSO.description: How to make use of recent advances in artificial intelligence and blockchain to improve the effectiveness of business processes and decisions across multiple industries.

DSO.title: Digital Innovation as Competitive Advantage
DSO.description: Implementing transformative digital technologies. Strategies to complete with ERP, blockchain, cloud, cryptocurrency, fintech, insurtech, API economy, digital platforms/ecosystems, open data, AI and ML.

DSO.title: Enterprise Data Architecture
DSO.description: Management of enterprise data architecture including data structures, conceptual data modeling, logical data modeling, structured query language (SQL), and physical optimization of high performance data architecture. Duplicates credit in former IOM 435.

DSO.title: Project Management
DSO.description: Topics related to project management in a variety of industries such as real estate projects, new product launch, plant location, etc.

DSO.title: Frontiers of Digital Business Platforms
DSO.description: Analysis of digital platforms business models focusing on their impact, competitive strategies, and future trends. Develop critical thinking and analytical skills for digital commerce.

DSO.title: Managing a Small Business on the Internet
DSO.description: Foundational knowledge for managing a small business on the internet including strategies, tools, and resources integrated with hands-on skills for developing a small business website. Duplicates credit in former IOM-462.

DSO.title: Deep Learning for AI and Business Applications
DSO.description: Basics of deep learning technologies for AI and utilizing current technologies in deep learning that are reshaping and driving the modern business with Big Data.

DSO.title: Sports Data Science and Management
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, information systems, operations management, and statistics. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Sustainable Supply Chains
DSO.description: Sustainability concepts and frameworks, design for environment, closed-loop supply chains, sustainability in sourcing, green facilities, renewable energy, facility location and transportation decisions, strategic sustainability implementation.

DSO.title: Sourcing and Supplier Management
DSO.description: Factors to consider when making sourcing decisions (costs, prices, ethics, globalization); impact of sourcing on other activities such as product design or inventory management.

DSO.title: Business Analytics
DSO.description: Foundational knowledge for business analytics, including strategies, methods, and tools integrated with hands-on skills for defining business analytics for data-driven decision making and innovation.

DSO.title: Smart City Tactics, Technologies and Operations
DSO.description: Application of modern smart city technologies, data tools and digital strategy to solve real-world urban challenges, such as public safety, transportation, health and environmental sustainability.

DSO.title: Applied Time Series Analysis for Forecasting
DSO.description: Survey of forecasting and time series methods. Models for stationary and nonstationary time series; ARIMA model identification, estimation, and forecast development. Seasonal and dynamic models. Recommended preparation: (GSBA 506a and GSBA 506b) or GSBA 516 or GSBA 524 or GSBA 545.

DSO.title: Blended Data Business Analytics for Efficient Decisions
DSO.description: Build Analytical Models for Classification, Clustering and Association Problems. Leverage third party "Big Data" for enriching and monetizing data. Develop data mining and business analysis.

DSO.title: Advanced Regression Analysis
DSO.description: Computer-assisted analysis of business data; advanced multiple regression analysis, survey analysis, ANOVA testing for Marketing-type applications and Times Series Analysis methods will be covered.

DSO.title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business Insights
DSO.description: Application of decision analysis, simulation and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business models.

DSO.title: Applying Analytics to Human Capital in Business
DSO.description: Human capital measurement and metrics, predictive analytics tools and methods, reporting standards and core analytic study methods with advanced visualization and storytelling.

DSO.title: Digital Transformation in the Global Enterprise
DSO.description: Leveraging large enterprise system applications for strategic value; managing organizational transformation of global enterprises through digital business platforms; coping with disruptive technologies.

DSO.title: SQL Databases for Business Analysts
DSO.description: SQL; relational database systems; data storage; data manipulation; data aggregation.

DSO.title: Business Models for Digital Platforms
DSO.description: Managing Business models in digital platform ecosystems; designing new products and services for digital platforms; establishing digital platform leadership; assessing emerging niches in digital spaces.

DSO.title: Global Supply Chain Management in International Settings
DSO.description: Study of global logistics infrastructures - water, rail, road, and air - through readings, team research and presentation, international site visits, and final written report. Open only to Global Supply Chain Management majors. Duplicates credit in former IOM 557a.

DSO.title: Global Supply Chain Management in International Settings
DSO.description: The influence of value-added services and regulatory issues on suppliers and supply chains. Readings, team research and presentation, site visits (LA), and final written report. Open only to Global Supply Chain Management majors. Duplicates credit in former IOM 557b.

DSO.title: Text Analytics and Natural Language Processing
DSO.description: Acquire, analyze, visualize and perform natural language processing (NLP) on text data. Apply Python, machine learning packages, statistical methodology and computer code to business decision-making.

DSO.title: Generative AI & Automation: Business & Societal Implications
DSO.description: Analysis of digital transformation, industrial economics and digitization research. How companies use AI and automation technologies. Transformation of Generative AI on economy, society and business.

DSO.title: Data Analytics for the Games Industry
DSO.description: Solve analytical problems for strategic game business improvement. Utilize product understanding, consumer behavior and analytical    abstraction of player experiences to build and launch games.  Recommended preparation: DSO 510 or DSO 530 or DSO 545 or DSO 547  or DSO 559.

DSO.title: Healthcare Analytics
DSO.description: Healthcare analytics challenges, opportunities, real vs. speculation vs. hype. Hands-on analysis of healthcare data. Presentation of actionable business strategy insights and recommendations.

DSO.title: Driving Business Transformation with GenAI and ML
DSO.description: Modernize cloud and big data platforms. Build and Implement long-term GenAI/ML strategies for business transformations using LLMs in the Cloud.

DSO.title: Algorithmic Thinking with Python
DSO.description: Writing complex Python programs to solve challenging problems in business analytics and performing competently in coding interviews. Thinking processes for planning, implementing and debugging code.

DSO.title: Optimization Modeling for Prescriptive Analytics
DSO.description: Formulate linear optimization models and implement them to create reusable optimization software in inventory management, revenue management, resource allocation, matching, scheduling and portfolio optimization.

DSO.title: Fundamentals of Sports Performance Analytics
DSO.description: Statistical models for pro sports industry business application. Effectively communicate findings for practical actionable results. Sports science data protocol.

DSO.title: Project Management
DSO.description: Applications of systems theory and concepts, matrix organizational structures, PERT/CPM project modeling, and management information systems to the management of complex and critical projects.

DSO.title: Supply Chain Management
DSO.description: Issues in supply chain management. Supply chain performance and dynamics. Tools for planning, control and coordination. Supply chain design and strategy. Recommended preparation: GSBA 504b or GSBA 534.

DSO.title: Service Management: Economics and Operations
DSO.description: Examination of the service industry from a managerial and entrepreneurial perspective; emphasis on the tactical decisions needed to design and deliver successful and profitable services. Recommended preparation: GSBA 504b or GSBA 534.

DSO.title: Global Operations Management
DSO.description: Exposure to issues crucial to the globalization of operations and their successful/unsuccessful operations management approaches in several countries and industries.

DSO.title: Data-Driven Consulting
DSO.description: Hands-on application of descriptive, predictive and prescriptive analytics to a unique business problem. Use business intelligence, programming and available tools to implement analytics-based solutions.

DSO.title: New Trends in Supply Chain Network Design
DSO.description: Tools, processes and applications for optimizing agile, resilient and sustainable supply chains. Hands-on experience in designing integrated supply chain networks to address user/customer demand.

DSO.title: Directed Research
DSO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to master's students. Duplicates credit in former IOM-590.

DSO.title: Field Research in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Individual or team projects studying the practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC. Recommended Preparation: completion of required M.B.A, M.Acc., or M.B.T. courses. Open only to graduate students. Duplicates credit in former IOM-592.

DSO.title: Independent Research in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

DSO.title: Internship in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest (Curricular Practical Training). Recommended preparation: completion of required MBA, MSGSCM, or MSBA courses.

DSO.title: Research Practicum in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Data Sciences and Operations Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC. Recommended Preparation: completion of all required courses in the student's program. Open only to graduate students. Duplicates credit in the former IOM-596.

DSO.title: Consulting Project in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to graduate business students.

DSO.title: Causal Inference with Machine Learning for Business          Analytics
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Demography in Business
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Agile Frameworks for Data Science Deployment
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Large Language Models for Business
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Causal Inference with Modern Machine Learning Methods
DSO.description: A comprehensive introduction to advanced machine-learning tools specifically designed for causal inference.

DSO.title: Modern Statistical Inference
DSO.description: Comprehensive introduction to advanced statistical inference, focusing on uncertainty quantification, individual-level analysis and modern challenges like multiplicity and model calibration in data science.

DSO.title: Probability for Data Sciences and Operations
DSO.description: Fundamentals of measure-theoretic probability for data science, operations research, reinforcement learning and the theory of machine learning. Mathematically rigorous and proof-based treatment of measure-theoretic probability.

DSO.title: Research Forum
DSO.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Data Sciences and Operations. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open only to Marshall PhD students. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Introduction to Cinema
CTCS.description: Introductory course in the study of cinematic arts. Study of technique, aesthetics, criticism, and social implications of cinema consisting of lectures, screenings and discussions.

CTCS.title: History of the International Cinema I
CTCS.description: The development of international cinema from its beginnings to World War II. Lectures, screenings, and discussions.

CTCS.title: History of American Cinema to 1960
CTCS.description: The development of American cinema from its beginnings to the decline of the studio system. Lectures, screenings and discussions.

CTCS.title: Documentary Film and Media
CTCS.description: An international survey of documentary, informational, and independent experimental film and media.

CTCS.title: Romanian Cinema
CTCS.description: Detailed investigation of traditions, achievements, and trends of film and/or electronic media in a particular country or region.

CTCS.title: Amateur Cinema and Media
CTCS.description: Detailed examination of film/television from the perspectives and insights of Cultural Studies; focus on the production and reception of cultural texts, practices, and communities.

CTCS.title: Queer Cinema
CTCS.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

CTCS.title: Latina/o Screen Cultures
CTCS.description: Examination of Latino/a moving image production including film, video, and digital media in the context of the politics of race, class, gender, sexuality, and international relations.

CTCS.title: Asian Horror
CTCS.description: Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.

CTCS.title: The Gangster Film
CTCS.description: Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.

CTCS.title: Theatrical Film Symposium
CTCS.description: Lectures and readings on creative problems in the motion picture industry; current films; interviews with visiting producers, directors, writers, performers.

CTCS.title: The Star Wars Phenomenon
CTCS.description: Intensive topical study of the social, political and economic contexts in which media are produced, distributed and monetized.

CTCS.title: LYNCH-VERSE: David Lynch's Cinema and Art
CTCS.description: Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.

CTCS.title: Memories on Film & Media
CTCS.description: Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.

CTCS.title: The Wonderful World of Wicked
CTCS.description: An examination of transmedia, or cross-platform, entertainment: commercial and grassroots texts, theoretical framework, historical context, and commercial projects. Developing transmedia strategies for existing media properties.

CTCS.title: Seminar in Film Theory
CTCS.description: Introduction to classical and contemporary film theory;  exploration of their relationship to filmic experimentation.

CTCS.title: World Cinema After 1945
CTCS.description: Historical survey of film from a global perspective from 1945 until the present.

CTCS.title: Survey of Television History
CTCS.description: An exploration of the historical, cultural, business, creative,  and technological aspects of television.

CTCS.title: Survey of Interactive Media
CTCS.description: A survey course exploring the historical, cultural, business,  creative, and technological aspects of the new interactive media.

CTCS.title: Critical Studies Colloquium/Professional Seminar
CTCS.description: Provides orientation to the profession, opportunities for academic and professional growth and development. Recommended for entering students.

CTCS.title: Film Genre in the Age of the Global Shuffle
CTCS.description: Advanced study of a selected genre of film and/or television  its relationship to history, society, and culture, as well as to genre theory.

CTCS.title: Birth of the Cool: Jazz and Film
CTCS.description: Seminar in the style of an auteur, studio, filmmaking, or televisual mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film and/or television.

CTCS.title: Seminar in Film/Television Critical Theory and Production
CTCS.description: A conjoint theory/production seminar, in which the study of media texts will be combined with media production informed by the theoretical study. Specific themes and are of focus may vary.

CTCS.title: The Politics of Everyday Life
CTCS.description: Explores the way film has been theorized in relationship to traditional media that preceded it and electronic media that followed.

CTCS.title: Research
CTCS.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
