CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CNTV.title: Reality Starts Here
CNTV.description: Introduction to emerging forms of immersive entertainment, to Cinematic Arts faculty, and to guest speakers who will comment on the changing nature of the industry.

CNTV.title: Breaking Into the Entertainment Industry
CNTV.description: An overview of the entertainment industry and the tools needed to secure jobs and survive and succeed in the market.

CNTV.title: The Business of Motion Pictures, TV, Animation,  Video Games, and Interactive Entertainment
CNTV.description: An in-depth analysis of the history, evolution, and current state of the motion picture, television, animation, video game, and interactive entertainment industries.

CNTV.title: Producing and Marketing Feature Length Films
CNTV.description: The principles and business practices of producing and marketing feature length films in the motion picture industry.

CNTV.title: Television: Integrating Creative and Business Objectives
CNTV.description: An investigation of the creative and business sides of television and how they connect, including changes caused by fractionalization and digital technology.

CNTV.title: Directed Research
CNTV.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

CNTV.title: Internship in Cinematic Arts
CNTV.description: On-the-job film, television, and interactive industry experience in the areas of interest of the individual student. Requires departmental approval.

CNTV.title: The Future of AI Media: From Workflows to Worldbuilding
The World of the Producer
CNTV.description: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer in creating  television programming, feature films, and new media content.

CNTV.title: Feature Film Financing and the Studio System
CNTV.description: An overview of the motion picture studio system and how to finance  feature films. Principles, business practices, and future trends.

CNTV.title: Entertainment Marketing in Today's Digital Environment
CNTV.description: Entertainment industry marketing disciplines, covering motion pictures, television, music, theme parks, home entertainment, and video games. Current principles and business practices.

CNTV.title: The Business of Representation
CNTV.description: Various roles an agent, manager, attorney and publicist play in representing talent, producers and writers. Taught by professionals who are at the forefront of the entertainment industry.

CNTV.title: Directed Research
CNTV.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

CNTV.title: Professional Practicum
CNTV.description: Film, media, archival and interactive industry experience in areas of interest to the individual student, and development of a personal brand. Requires departmental approval.

IML.title: Short Form Video Storytelling for the Web
IML.description: Introduction to the expressive potential of multimedia as a critical and creative tool, supplementing traditional forms of academic work.

IML.title: The Languages of Digital Media
IML.description: An in-depth investigation of the close interrelationships among technology, culture and communication to form a solid foundation for digital authoring. Duplicates credit in former IML 101.

IML.title: Media Arts and Practice Studio I
IML.description: Intermediate laboratory exploring the foundations of visual culture through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on the creative process, project documentation and the development of a personal design methodology.

IML.title: Introduction to Visual Design
IML.description: An introduction to the principles of visual and graphic design within the field of media art.

IML.title: Introduction to Creative Coding
IML.description: An introduction to the design of poetic and creative artworks using foundational programming concepts.

IML.title: Introduction to Creative Web Programming
IML.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of creative web coding and design, with best practices and new creative directions.

IML.title: Professionalism for Media Arts
IML.description: Development of documentation and archival strategies, with an emphasis on techniques of personal and professional representation.

IML.title: Introduction to Sound
IML.description: An introduction to audio and sound technologies, focusing on creating artwork using sound as a primary modality.

IML.title: Introduction to Video
IML.description: An introduction to digital storytelling with a focus on cameras, sound recording and editing techniques to create short, professional video projects.

IML.title: Methods in Digital Research
IML.description: Emphasizing rigorous multimedia research and authorship strategies, this course prepares students to undertake large-scale digital projects.

IML.title: Introduction to 3-D Modeling
IML.description: An introduction to 3-D modeling, with an emphasis on the fundamentals of texturing and lighting for use in animation, game art and interactive 3-D spaces.

IML.title: The Music Festival Experience
IML.description: Exploring the cultural significance of music festivals as spaces where music, media and culture intersect; learning experience design and planning innovative experiences for music festivals.

IML.title: Narrative Across Media
IML.description: Traditions and emerging practices in multimedia storytelling. Narrative convergences of literature, film, television, comics, mixed reality, videogames or physical/virtual environments.

IML.title: Advanced Platform: Visual Design
IML.description: Exploration of advanced techniques in visual and graphic design within the field of media art.

IML.title: Thesis Studio
IML.description: Production of a digital thesis project.

IML.title: Digital Studies Symposium
IML.description: Lectures, presentations, and readings introducing cutting-edge digital media innovations and applications. Analysis of the critical and creative challenges of contemporary digital media practices.

IML.title: IMAX: The Art and Practice of Giant Screen Cinema
IML.description: A hands-on mentored research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

IML.title: Embodied Storytelling and Immersive Docu-Narratives
IML.description: Examination of art, media, and theatre, to create an immersive, installation-based intervention utilizing the embodied 360-degree docu-narrative form.

IML.title: Directed Research
IML.description: Individual research and readings.

IML.title: Digital Media Authorship and the Archive
IML.description: An in-depth examination of emergent technologies in their cultural and historic contexts, with an equal emphasis on production and analysis. Open only to graduate students.

IML.title: Embodied Knowledge and the Fantastical
IML.description: Exploration of conceptual approaches from the sciences, arts, and humanities that challenge the mind/body split. Investigation of  epistemologies that are considered fantastical.

IML.title: Ethnofiction
IML.description: A hands-on approach to contemporary topics in ethnographic media arts and creative nonfiction cinema.

IML.title: World Building, Narrative Design and Design Visualization
IML.description: A hands-on mentored graduate research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

IML.title: Directed Research
IML.description: Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IML.title: Practice of Media Arts
IML.description: Introduction to a range of technologies and media types, while identifying and developing a specialization in one or more areas of practice. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 602)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794a)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794b)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794c)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794d)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794z)

CTIN.title: Fundamentals of Procedural Media
CTIN.description: Introduction to the procedural nature of interactive media and games, though the coding language Processing. Students will develop proficiency in reading and creating computational media.

CTIN.title: Introduction to Interactive Entertainment
CTIN.description: Critical vocabulary and historical perspectives on interactive entertainment; students articulate their own ideas, while wrestling with the larger conceptual issues at play within the field.

CTIN.title: Survey of Themed Entertainment
CTIN.description: Introduction to the field of themed entertainment and education design, covering its history, and, especially, current practice.

CTIN.title: Crew for Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Hands-on creating experiences for students who want to work as crew on an advanced game project.

CTIN.title: Game Development Principles
CTIN.description: Concepts and projects relating to the implementation and presentation of digital games; core level design preproduction techniques.

CTIN.title: Miniature Golf Design
CTIN.description: Workshop on the design of miniature golf holes, considering theming, experience and build.

CTIN.title: Interface Design for Games
CTIN.description: Introduction to the aesthetics, terminology and common trends of interface design for games. Topics include 2-D and 3-D spaces and user/camera perspectives.

CTIN.title: Producing Interactive Projects
CTIN.description: An in-depth exploration of the development and production concepts woven into the USC Games curriculum and utilized in the professional games industry.

CTIN.title: Tabletop Game Mechanics Seminar
CTIN.description: Seminar on the design patterns and mechanics of successful tabletop games. Includes guest speakers on the latest trends in gaming content, tools, business and culture.

CTIN.title: Interactive Systems Design
CTIN.description: An overview of systems thinking, complex systems, game economies and emergence with practical applications towards designing and balancing systems for games and interactivity.

CTIN.title: Audio Expression
CTIN.description: Foundational aesthetic principles and creative technologies for game audio. Processing, mixing, and controlling sound for games for expressive effect.

CTIN.title: Themed Entertainment Design
CTIN.description: The fundamentals of design, technology, operations and process for the creation of themed entertainment experiences and story-centric place-making.

CTIN.title: Themed Entertainment Business Operations
CTIN.description: The business of themed entertainment, focused on teaching literacy to communicate with business partners and understanding the basic needs of a themed entertainment project.

CTIN.title: Business and Management of Games
CTIN.description: Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright and intellectual property.

CTIN.title: Anatomy of a Game
CTIN.description: Examine two game products from concept to delivery; introduce students to each of the professional disciplines involved in making digital games. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488.

CTIN.title: Advanced Games Business
CTIN.description: An advanced dive into the structure of the games industry with a focus on emerging trends and the future of games as business and entertainment.

CTIN.title: Streaming Explorations: Games and Entertainment for Communit
CTIN.description: Best practices and strategies for streaming. Students build a personality and audience through the course, receiving advice and feedback from emerging leaders in the field.

CTIN.title: Game Design Workshop
CTIN.description: An introduction to making games. Students will explore the principles of game design through the entirely analog creation of card, board and tabletop games.

CTIN.title: Intermediate Game Design and Production
CTIN.description: A follow-up to the introductory game design class, this course will introduce more advanced concepts in game design and game theories, including ideation, digital prototyping and level design.

CTIN.title: Directed Research
CTIN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CTIN.title: Advanced Game Project I
CTIN.description: Students work in teams on pre-production and production of a functional digital game suitable for showcases, festivals, and further development.

CTIN.title: Experimental Game Topics
CTIN.description: Development of a game or interactive media experience that utilizesand pushes the boundaries and understanding of emerging technologiesand interactive techniques.

CTIN.title: Advanced Themed Entertainment Design
CTIN.description: Design and planning for themed attractions. Large scale multidisciplinary teams work together to develop themed entertainment experiences.

CTIN.title: Generative AI in Games
CTIN.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema,  television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by  visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTIN.title: GLO - Gaas and Live Operations Workshop
CTIN.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema,  television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by  visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTIN.title: Streaming Production for Games
CTIN.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema,  television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by  visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTIN.title: Unreal Game Engine Fundamentals
CTIN.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema,  television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by  visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTIN.title: Graduate Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Capstone course for assigned Game Directors or Area Leads to start an innovative, large-scale game project.

CTIN.title: Interactive Design and Production I
CTIN.description: The development of interactive experiences with an emphasis on prototyping and development.

CTIN.title: Experiments in Interactivity I
CTIN.description: Experimental studio course to explore concepts of structure, aesthetics and content of interactive experience design.

CTIN.title: Design for Interactive Media
CTIN.description: Practical exploration and practicum on the fundamental process and principles of interactive media design. Students develop design and prototyping skills while working in collaborative teams.

CTIN.title: Health and Interactive Entertainment Research Lab
CTIN.description: Emerging transdisciplinary research methods for conducting formative or summative evaluation of interactive entertainment-based interventions.

CTIN.title: Game Development for Designers
CTIN.description: The fundamentals of 3-D real time game engines, scripting for interactivity, and building games with digital tools.

CTIN.title: Directed Research
CTIN.description: Research project leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units  which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the  department.  Graded CR/NC.

CTIN.title: Crew for Graduate Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Students from many disciplines work in large teams to create an innovative, large-scale interactive media or game project.

CTIN.title: Integrative Project: Media-based Interventions in Healthcare
CTIN.description: A project that showcases integrative mastery of prior and newly acquired knowledge, skills and interests. Permission of instructor required.

CTIN.title: Master's Thesis
CTIN.description: Credit on acceptance of theis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.  Open to M.F.A.,  Interactive Media majors only.

CTIN.title: Master's Thesis
CTIN.description: Credit on acceptance of theis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.  Open to M.F.A.,  Interactive Media majors only.

CTIN.title: Research Practicum in Interactive Media
CTIN.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a faculty member in the Interactive Media and Games Division on one or more ongoing research projects.

CTIN.title: Ideation and Concept Development
CTIN.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of interactive  media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental  subjects.

CMPP.title: Producing Workshop
CMPP.description: Hands-on workshops in creative and physical filmmaking. Open to PFTM students only. Duplicates credit in CTPR 504 and CMPP-541.

CMPP.title: Introduction to Producing for Television
CMPP.description: An introduction to the creative and business aspects of producing for television. Open only to PFTM students.

CMPP.title: Script Analysis for the Producer
CMPP.description: Detailed evaluation of completed scripts and of the producer's role in bringing them to fruition. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Motion Picture and Television Marketing
CMPP.description: Analysis and preparation of film and television show marketing campaigns from creative concept to targeting across various media. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Producing Symposium
CMPP.description: Lectures on creative aspects of producing. Open to PFTM students only. Graded CR/NC.

CMPP.title: Scheduling and Budgeting
CMPP.description: Concept and preparation of a complete schedule and budget. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Finance
CMPP.description: Seminar of financial aspects of film industry and methods of financing films. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Seminar in Filmic Storytelling
CMPP.description: Guides students through the building blocks of screenwriting, from building compelling and proactive characters to understanding the basic format and structure of storytelling, while improving their understanding and facility with the story and the screenplay format.

CMPP.title: Graduate Film Business Seminar
CMPP.description: Economics of the entertainment industry, including entertainment law, and rights acquisition. Includes weekly film screening.

CTWR.title: Story: Character, Conflict, and Catharsis
CTWR.description: Fundamentals course on the elements of scene writing, story structure, and character development.

CTWR.title: Genesis of the Screenplay
CTWR.description: The evolution of the screenplay from its roots in myths, plays, and short stories. Writing original treatments for film and television inspired by literary masters.

CTWR.title: Writing the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Development of synopsis and treatment for a theatrical or documentary screenplay: theme, plot, character, mise-en-scene and utilization of cinematic elements.

CTWR.title: The Television Writer: An Agent of Change
CTWR.description: The television writer as an agent of change across current social issues including, but not limited to: race, gender, and class.

CTWR.title: Advanced Screenwriting: The Relationship Screenplay
CTWR.description: An inquiry into the complex nature of human relationships by writing an original feature length screenplay that examines the multidimensional world of characters and the ties that bind them together.

CTWR.title: Advanced Script Analysis
CTWR.description: Advanced critical analysis of story and character across film, television, and other mediums. Identification of key story elements of structure, character and emotion journey.

CTWR.title: Breaking the Hour-Long Television Series
CTWR.description: Introduction to hour-long television staff writing. Breaking of a complete season and writing episodes. Special attention to season construction, pitching, character and story engine.

CTWR.title: Breaking the Half-Hour Television Series
CTWR.description: The fundamentals of writing for half-hour television. Writing an episode of an existing half-hour television series, with emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.

CTWR.title: Writing the Narrative Podcast Series
CTWR.description: Development of an original narrative podcast. Emphasis on dramatic elements of auditory storytelling and character development.

CTWR.title: Foundations of Comedy
CTWR.description: Study of comedy theory and practical applications in film, television, and social media. Lectures and screenings of comedic forms tracing past, present and future.

CTWR.title: Fundamentals of Screenwriting: Character, Conflict and Story
CTWR.description: Introduction to writing compelling scenes, creating authentic characters, three-act structure and feature film outlining.

CTWR.title: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CTWR.description: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to  gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in  interactive entertainment. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488

CTWR.title: Writing the Short Script I
CTWR.description: Preparation of scripts for short films: form, structure, planning. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.

CTWR.title: The Screenplay
CTWR.description: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, write a short script for possible production, a feature film outline and first act. Recommended preparation: CTWR-416. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.

CTWR.title: Motion Picture Script Analysis
CTWR.description: Critical analysis of story structure from classic films to  contemporary works. Identification of key story concepts and  elements of three-act structure. 2.0, not repeatable.

CTWR.title: Script Coverage and Story Analysis
CTWR.description: Evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production.  Coverage and analysis of scripts as potential properties from the  perspective of a production company.

CTWR.title: Senior Thesis
CTWR.description: a: Creation of feature-length treatment and first draft Senior Thesis screenplay, including "pitching" experiences. B: Completion and revision of Senior Thesis project and introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives.  Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and  Television students only.

CTWR.title: Senior Thesis in Dramatic Television
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop developing an original hour-long dramatic series including characters, world, and story lines for season one. Final assignment is completed hour-long pilot episode.

CTWR.title: Writing the Hour-Long Dramatic Series
CTWR.description: Writing an episode of an existing dramatic television series within the hour-long format with an emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.

CTWR.title: Creating the Dramatic Television Series
CTWR.description: Examination and creation of the world, characters, and concept for an original hour-long dramatic series. Writing an outline for an original dramatic pilot.

CTWR.title: Writing the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script.

CTWR.title: TV Genre: The Rules and How to Break Them
CTWR.description: Detailed investigation of various television writers' styles, the worlds they have created, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting television writers.

CTWR.title: Writing the Half-Hour Comedy Series
CTWR.description: Writing an episode of an existing half-hour comedy series, with emphasis on the anatomy of a joke, comedic structure and character.

CTWR.title: Writing the Original Situation Comedy Pilot
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop for writing an original half-hour comedy series, including a pilot script, summary of characters and story lines for first season.

CTWR.title: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop in creation of an original dramatic series, including a first draft of the pilot and a summary of characters and storylines.

CTWR.title: Creative Consciousness and Cinematic Dreams
CTWR.description: An exploration of artistic and scientific practice to deepen our understanding of the intuitive process of creating cinematic dreams.

CTWR.title: Narrative Design of the Contained Story
CTWR.description: Analysis and practice of storytelling techniques when faced with imposed story limitations.  Weekly screenings and lectures of classic and contemporary works.

CTWR.title: Staff Writing the Multi-Camera Television Series
CTWR.description: Working on the writing staff of an original multi-camera television series, with emphasis on the writers' room experience and how to executive produce an episode.

CTWR.title: Straight to Series:  Writing and Producing the   Episodic Drama
CTWR.description: Staff writing and producing the original episodic drama, from development to post-production.

CTWR.title: Creating the Short Film
CTWR.description: Strengthening and deepening the ability to conceive and develop  ideas that will lead to compelling, authentic, and personally  meaningful films.  Duplicates credit in CTWR 528.

CTWR.title: Screenwriting: Imagination and Technique
CTWR.description: Intensive introductory course in writing for the screen with emphasis on developing imagination and specific screenwriting techniques, culminating in an original short screenplay.

CTWR.title: Practicum in Screenwriting
CTWR.description: Creation of a feature screenplay from presentation through treatment, including some scene work.

CTWR.title: Advanced Motion Picture Script Analysis
CTWR.description: Critical analysis of the structure of films from the classics to  current award winners.  Students will learn how to identify key  story concepts and break down three act structure in finished  films and scripts.

CTWR.title: Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
CTWR.description: Developing an original half-hour comedy television series, including characters, world and storylines for season one. Completion of a first draft script, polish, and series bible.

CTWR.title: Thesis in Television Drama
CTWR.description: Part A -- writing the pilot -- is an intensive workshop in which master's students develop an original television 1-hour series including characters, world and storylines for season one. Final assignment is the finished pilot episode of the series.

CTWR.title: Advanced Scene Writing Workshop
CTWR.description: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and rewriting the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.

CTWR.title: Advanced Hour-Long Television Drama
CTWR.description: Writing the first draft and revision of an episode of an existing dramatic television series.

CTWR.title: Advanced Hour-Long Television Development
CTWR.description: Investigation of development process for hour-long television, addressing issues of character, world, story and concept. Vetting of multiple series ideas for viability.

CTWR.title: Introduction to the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script. Prerequisite: CTAN 536 or CTWR 505 or CTWR 518. Recommended preparation: CTWR 516.

CTWR.title: Advanced Storytelling for Interactive Media
CTWR.description: Advanced writing workshop addressing issues specific to interactive storytelling regarding construction of narrative and character as seen in games and other forms of interactive media. Prerequisite: CTWR 518.

CTWR.title: Intermediate Screenwriting
CTWR.description: Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original or adapted theatrical-length script.

CTWR.title: Rewriting the Feature Screenplay
CTWR.description: Rewriting the feature-length screenplay.  Focus on macro to micro approach to revision.

CTWR.title: Advanced Half-Hour Television Comedy
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop in writing the first draft and revision of an episode of an existing comedic television series. The comedy writing room will be emphasized.

CTWR.title: The Character-Driven Screenplay
CTWR.description: Advanced screenwriting wherein a first draft of a feature-length script will be developed and written with an emphasis on character as story engine.

CTWR.title: Advanced Rewriting Workshop
CTWR.description: Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.

CTWR.title: The Business of Writing for Screen and Television
CTWR.description: Examination and in-depth analysis of the studio system, the television development process, literary representation, new emerging markets, and the Writers Guild of America.

CTWR.title: Practicum in Directing Actors for Film
CTWR.description: Seminar in directing actors for film; emphasis on demonstration and laboratory exercises, script analysis, and study and character motivations.

CTWR.title: Adapting from the Public Domain
CTWR.description: Development and execution of writing in various genres of film, television, or new media scripts. Prerequisite: CTWR 514b.

CTAN.title: Introduction to the Art of Animation
CTAN.description: Theory and practice of animation across organic and digital media with an emphasis on self-exploration. Open to freshman in Animation and Digital Arts majors only.

CTAN.title: Design Fundamentals for Animation II
CTAN.description: Applying design principles in image-making and motion with software skills in After Effects to produce creative content and expand animation practice.

CTAN.title: Introduction to Storyboarding
CTAN.description: A practical introductory course that emphasizes the fundamentals of digital storyboarding to include storyboarding basics, proper composition, staging for clarity, pitching and critique.

CTAN.title: Intermediate Character Animation for Games
CTAN.description: An applied introduction to the techniques used for animating 3-D bipedal human character content for the movement and interactive experience within 3-D video games.

CTAN.title: 3-D Character Performance Animation
CTAN.description: Advanced 3-D character animation with an emphasis on performance, lip-syncing, timing and execution. Prerequisite: CTAN 202L. Open only to juniors in Animation and Digital Arts.

CTAN.title: Professionalism of Animation
CTAN.description: Understanding the business of the animation industry. Developing presentation skills for interviewing and pitching, preparing personal marketing tools, researching employment opportunities, and practicing networking techniques.

CTAN.title: Cinematography for Animators
CTAN.description: The basic cinematic principles for animation, and how to shoot storyboards for the best composition to serve the story.

CTAN.title: Senior Project
CTAN.description: Understanding the requirements and relationships between theory and practice regarding the complexity of an animated film in idea and execution.

CTAN.title: Concept Design for Animation
CTAN.description: Creating characters and environments for animation, live action, and video games.

CTAN.title: Studio Careers: Story to Screen
CTAN.description: Seminar featuring guest speakers from major animation studios to provide an overview of a feature animation pipeline from development to pre-production, production and post-production.

CTAN.title: Writing for Animation
CTAN.description: Workshop exploring concept and structure of long and short form animated films through practical writing exercises.

CTAN.title: Story Structure for Animation
CTAN.description: Storytelling principles as they pertain to episodic and serialized animated television series and animated feature films.

CTAN.title: History of Animation
CTAN.description: In depth survey of historical developments, styles, techniques, theory and criticism of animation as an art form.

CTAN.title: Introduction to 3-D Computer Animation
CTAN.description: Lecture and laboratory in computer animation: geometric modeling, motion specification, lighting, texture mapping, rendering, compositing, production techniques, systems for computer-synthesized animation using Maya software.

CTAN.title: Organic Modeling for Animation
CTAN.description: The art of digital sculpting for animated characters, with visual effects integration. Recommended preparation: CTAN-452 or CTAN-462.

CTAN.title: Character Design Workshop
CTAN.description: The basics of character design for animation: anatomy, poses, facial expressions, silhouettes, and anthropomorphism. Development of a portfolio.

CTAN.title: Visual Effects
CTAN.description: Survey of contemporary concepts and approaches to production in  the current state of film and video effects work.  Digital and  traditional methodologies will be covered, with a concentration on digital exercises illustrating modern techniques.

CTAN.title: Digital Lighting and Rendering
CTAN.description: Concepts, tools and techniques used to create cinematic lighting and rendering in computer-generated imagery (CGI).

CTAN.title: Animation for Projection Mapping and Live Performance
CTAN.description: An exploration of animation for projection mapping with hands-on learning and projects providing professional skills and workflows for helping students create their own content.

CTAN.title: Character Modeling
CTAN.description: Create 3D character models from 2D designs and incorporate fundamental human anatomy into practice. Includes concepts for creating hair, fur, feathers and clothing for characters.

CTAN.title: Visual Music
CTAN.description: Creating visual music animation in a variety of forms and styles. Exploring the relationship between music, movement, and visual expression. Freshmen and sophomores not eligible.

CTAN.title: Directed Studies
CTAN.description: Individual research under faculty guidance.

CTAN.title: Animation: The Art and the Industry
CTAN.description: Seminar on the growth and development of animation studios and how they became part of the Hollywood studio system.

CTAN.title: Creative Production in Virtual Reality
CTAN.description: A creative studio course in producing both a linear cinematic virtual reality short film and associated real-time immersive experience.

CTAN.title: The Business of Animation
CTAN.description: Overview of the global production, media and entertainment industries and fundamental business skills, with an emphasis on animation and the animation professional.

CTAN.title: Design Fundamentals for Animation
CTAN.description: A creative design course for animators, combining visual design aesthetics with practical technique and software skill learning.

CTAN.title: Fundamentals of 2-D Animation
CTAN.description: Exploring techniques of classical hand-drawn character animation, with emphasis on performance, personality, and observation, specializing in classical Hollywood animation.

CTAN.title: Foundations of 3-D Computer Animation
CTAN.description: Foundations of computer animation: generating and editing movement, lighting, textures, rendering, creating and outputting full animated projects using Maya software.

CTAN.title: Production Design for Animation
CTAN.description: Design with an emphasis on storytelling through character design, environment design, moment paintings, color script and look of picture. Development of a project style guide.

CTAN.title: Animation Design and Production
CTAN.description: Exploring creative strategies to designing form and content. Developing style and investigating multiple techniques, including live action and sound. Production of a 30-60 second work.

CTAN.title: Motion Capture Fundamentals
CTAN.description: Fundamental principles of motion capture technology explored while  working through a structured series of assignments based around  performance, gesture and motion.

CTAN.title: 2-D Motion Graphics
CTAN.description: A creative 2-D motion graphics course covering animation technique, visual design aesthetics and software skills.

CTAN.title: Animation Storyboarding Practicum
CTAN.description: Current storyboarding techniques for film and television animation, simulating a professional studio workflow. Emphasis on telling a story with pictures, not storyboarding tools or software.

CTAN.title: Directed Studies in Animation
CTAN.description: Individual exploration in the areas of contemporary technology, animation techniques or experimental film through internships, residencies or directed studies. Open only to Animation and Digital Arts master students.

CTAN.title: Master's Thesis
CTAN.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

CTPR.title: Originating and Developing Ideas for Film
CTPR.description: Exercises in observation, imaginative association, visualization,  etc., that deepen the creative process, leading to ideas, stories,  characters, and images for narrative, documentary, and  experimental films.

CTPR.title: Cinematic Communication
CTPR.description: Introduction to the interrelationship of visuals, sound, and editing in cinematic communication. Workshops in directing and producing. Individual and group projects.

CTPR.title: Directing in Documentary, Fiction and New Media
CTPR.description: Basic concepts of directing in new media, documentary and fictional narrative. Includes work with actors, documentary concepts, and creation of short new media projects.

CTPR.title: Cinematic Arts Laboratory
CTPR.description: The aesthetics and tools of the major disciplines of cinematic arts: producing, cinematography, sound, and editing.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Production
CTPR.description: Principles of visual and aural communication; idea development and realization using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; small crew projects.

CTPR.title: Motion Picture Cinematography
CTPR.description: Use of high definition motion picture equipment to explore the fundamentals of shot design, movement and lighting.  In class group projects.

CTPR.title: Motion Picture Editing
CTPR.description: Theory, techniques, and practices in picture editing; use of standard editing equipment; individual projects.

CTPR.title: Creating the Motion Picture Sound Track
CTPR.description: Techniques and aesthetics for recording production sound, editing dialogue, sound effects, music, Foley and preparing for the mix. For film, television, and other media.

CTPR.title: Colloquium: Motion Picture Production Techniques
CTPR.description: Basic procedures and techniques applicable to production of all types of films; demonstration by production of a short film from conception to completion.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Podcast Production
CTPR.description: The practice of video podcast production and the skills to develop, produce, record and post original episodes. Podcast formats vary by semester.

CTPR.title: Trojan Vision, Live Television Production
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Game Show
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Morning Brew
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Remodel Reality
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Unscripted
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Water Cooler
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: The Entertainment Industry: From Idea to Audience
CTPR.description: An exploration of the worldwide media and content business and the roles and careers of the people who develop and monetize creative ideas and storytelling.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Editing
CTPR.description: Workshop in how editing can shape storytelling, using content from a variety of media and in various styles. Modern non-linear equipment and techniques.

CTPR.title: Makeup for Motion Pictures
CTPR.description: Lecture-laboratory in makeup relating it to mood of the story and emulsion of the camera stock.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CTPR.description: Introductory workshop in the aesthetics and practices of special   effects, embracing both the classical and contemporary modes.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Cinematography
CTPR.description: Camera and lighting workshop in color cinematography, beginning with digital still photography and moving into 16mm and advanced digital cameras. In-class exercises.

CTPR.title: Production Planning
CTPR.description: Theory, discussion, and practical application of production planning during preproduction and production of a film.

CTPR.title: The Production Experience
CTPR.description: To provide students with basic working knowledge of both the  skills of the motion picture set and production operations through classroom lectures and hands-on experience.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Color Grading
CTPR.description: Exploration of the various aspects of color grading and how it can enhance storytelling.

CTPR.title: Developing the Documentary Production
CTPR.description: The tools and skills necessary to turn an idea into a documentary story, using sample reels, pitches, and writing to develop a professional proposal.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Producing
CTPR.description: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer. How projects are conceived, developed, packaged, financed and marketed.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Sound
CTPR.description: Aesthetic and technical skills of production and post-production sound necessary to create a motion picture soundtrack.

CTPR.title: Sound Design
CTPR.description: The historical, theoretical, and practical aspects of sound design for genre films. Exploration of the techniques and processes for creating sounds that do not exist.

CTPR.title: The Capstone Project Crew Experience
CTPR.description: Assistant crew experience on a capstone project including specified weekends. Overview of roles and fundamental thinking typical of each craft.

CTPR.title: Acting for Film and Television
CTPR.description: Intensive examination of skills and techniques necessary for successful performances in film and television. Practical application through in-class exercises and assigned projects.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Art Direction
CTPR.description: Introduction to drafting, set design, set decoration and creating models for students with diverse abilities. Guest lectures, group discussions and hands-on workshop.

CTPR.title: Creating Poetic Cinema
CTPR.description: An investigation of poetic cinema from four different perspectives: found poetry; applied poetry; poetry as image; and poetry in narrative fiction. Production of short films.

CTPR.title: Organizing Creativity: Entertainment Industry    Decision Making
CTPR.description: Analysis of the unique structures in the entertainment industry for organizing and managing creativity. Students research and chart pathways to leadership. Open only to juniors, seniors, and graduate students.

CTPR.title: Film Business Procedures and Distribution
CTPR.description: Financing, budgeting, management as applied to films; problems of distribution, including merchandising, cataloging, evaluation, and film library management.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Production Design
CTPR.description: Practical instruction in script breakdown, location surveys, traditional and computer-aided working drawings, model making, set decoration, construction and scenic departments.

CTPR.title: Spotting Music for Cinema
CTPR.description: A real world approach to spotting music for film: why film music exists and the many ways it is used in storytelling.  For filmmakers as well as composers.

CTPR.title: Documentary Production
CTPR.description: Pairs produce, direct, shoot, and edit a short documentary on a subject of their choice. Finished projects will be suitable for broadcast/festivals.

CTPR.title: Directing The Comedic Scene
CTPR.description: Directing comedy: casting, rehearsing, directing actors, scene analysis, staging, shooting, and editing, leading to the filming of a two-person comic scene

CTPR.title: Practicum in Directing
CTPR.description: Concepts of directing for motion pictures, emphasizing the working relationship of actors and directors. Scenes will be staged in class and filmed for class presentation.

CTPR.title: Development of Episodic TV Series
CTPR.description: Development of an original episodic television series. Episodes will be shot on stage and on location during the following semester.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Directors, producers, cinematographers, editors and sound designers collaborate to produce, shoot, edit and deliver fictional, documentary or experimental projects.

CTPR.title: Comedy Television Production
CTPR.description: Exercises and practical application for writing and producing a comedy television project.

CTPR.title: Recording for Film Scores
CTPR.description: Exploration of the role of the recording studio in professional film and video productions. Emphasis on technical and hardware considerations.

CTPR.title: Viral Comedy
CTPR.description: Translating traditional storytelling tools into short form comedy that stands out online. Writing, directing and producing creative projects designed for current online platforms.

CTPR.title: Women in the Entertainment Industry
CTPR.description: Discusses women's roles in the entertainment industry and career opportunities available for women in the business, corporate and creative sectors.

CTPR.title: Music Video and Commercial Production
CTPR.description: Writing, budgeting, shooting, editing and directing a music video and commercial. Getting the job, dealing with the band, working with the record and advertising companies.

CTPR.title: Fundamentals of Directing
CTPR.description: Introductory directing course, emphasizing collaboration, working  with actors, camera techniques and storytelling through filmed  exercises to develop foundational skills in cinematic  communication and visual narrative.

CTPR.title: Visual Expression
CTPR.description: Exploring the relationship between story structure and visual structure, discussion of aesthetics and technical controls, in-class examples and screenings, photographic assignments.

CTPR.title: Production I
CTPR.description: The effective communication of ideas through the language of cinema. Individual and small group exercises; introductions to producing, directing, editing, cinematography and sound.

CTPR.title: Production II
CTPR.description: Practicum in group production, emphasizing the collaborative process and the expressive use of sound and image.

CTPR.title: Realtime CG Filmmaking
CTPR.description: Introduction to the software necessary to create previs, pitchvis, CG films and quick experiments to practice creativity without being on set.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Multiple-Camera Production
CTPR.description: How to direct comedy or dramatic scenes, using multiple camera  techniques.  Students also serve as crew members, learning  lighting, mixing, studio controls, and stage management.

CTPR.title: Virtual Production
CTPR.description: Collaboration on projects using motion-tracking technology to raise the CG production value and realize the vision of previously produced animatics.

CTPR.title: Planning the Documentary Production
CTPR.description: A preproduction workshop for the research and planning of a documentary project to be executed in CTPR 547 or an advanced production workshop class. Prerequisite: CTPR 508.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Directing
CTPR.description: Practical experience in staging dramatic narrative scenes,  emphasizing directing actors, rehearsal techniques and camera  blocking.

CTPR.title: Directing AI: Future Filmmaking
CTPR.description: Practicum in more complex directing issues concentrating both on performance and exploration of shaping scenes visually through blocking of action and placement of camera.

CTPR.title: Production Design in the Visual Narrative
CTPR.description: Exercises concentrating on script analysis, blocking the scene, ground plans, elevations, visual research and concepts, departmental collaboration, and presentation of work.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Editing
CTPR.description: Editorial construction of sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Cinematography
CTPR.description: Close study through practical in class exercises of the technical and aesthetic principles of cinematography. Introduction to 16mm film and advanced digital cameras.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Producing
CTPR.description: Definition, examination and practical experience in the role of the line producer as it relates to preproduction, production and post production.

CTPR.title: Virtual Production in LED Volumes
CTPR.description: Introduces filmmaking in LED volumes, blending cutting-edge technology with cinematic arts. Students engage in hands-on exercises and creative collaboration, laying the groundwork for future virtual production exploration.

CTPR.title: Production III, Fiction
CTPR.description: An intensive workshop experience in which students, crewing in their area of specialization, complete the shooting and postproduction of projects up to 12 minutes in length. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 532, and for cinematographers, CTPR 537;

CTPR.title: Production III, Documentary
CTPR.description: Intensive workshop; students shoot and finish documentary projects up to about 25 minutes. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 431 or CTPR 531; for cinematographers, CTPR 424 or CTPR 537.

CTPR.title: Directing in a Virtual World
CTPR.description: Telling cinematic stories using visual effects and virtual backgrounds, environments, and characters. Hands-on exercises emphasizing directing. Prerequisite: CTAN 462. Recommended preparation: CTAN 555 or CTPR 532 or CTPR 537. Open only to Cinematic Arts students.

CTPR.title: Advanced Directing
CTPR.description: An advanced production class in directing. Encounters with         experienced directors; and individual student production of a      short. Recommended Preparation: CTPR 533.

CTPR.title: Advanced Cinematography
CTPR.description: Advanced camera and lighting techniques for those considering a professional career in cinematography.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing
CTPR.description: Defines and examines the role of the Executive/Feature Producer through the preproduction, production and post production phases. Prerequisites: CTPR-538 or one of the following in equivalent crew position: CTPR 486, CTPR 546, CTPR 547.

CTPR.title: Making Media for Social Change
CTPR.description: Each student will produce and direct a film incorporating a social issue of his/her choice into the narrative of the film. Prerequisites: CTPR 310 or CTPR 508.

CTPR.title: The Pitch Class: Film and TV
CTPR.description: Developing, pitching and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects.

CTPR.title: The World of Television: From Concept to Air and Everything in Between
CTPR.description: Takes projects from conception to sale, including development,  production, post-production, and marketing.  Students will develop  original projects.

CTPR.title: Developing and Producing the Advanced Project
CTPR.description: An advanced preproduction workshop in which students complete the development and production planning of an advanced project to be executed in CTPR 581, CTPR 582 or CTPR 587a.

CTPR.title: Virtual Production
CTPR.description: An advanced preproduction workshop in which students complete the development and production planning of an advanced project to be executed in CTPR 581, CTPR 582 or CTPR 587a.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources.  Open to Production students only.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers).

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

CTXA.title: Documentary Animation Production
CTXA.description: Examination of the history, techniques, and methods of documentary animation production. Collaboration on a short film project.

CTXA.title: Animated Art and the Principles of Motion
CTXA.description: Analysis and application of animated motion for contemporary practices, with an emphasis on the synergistic relationship between traditional mastery and non-traditional exploration.

CTXA.title: Advanced Animation Research Seminar
CTXA.description: A weekly academic forum in which guest researchers, academics, and professionals in the leading edge of their fields share their research and engage students in their process.

CTXA.title: Visualizing Science Production
CTXA.description: Principles of 2-D and 3-D digital animation and AI applied to scientific themes and research topics.

CTXA.title: Survey of World Animation
CTXA.description: A historical survey of world animation. Independent and studio animation from around the world will be examined.

CTXA.title: Art of Animation
CTXA.description: Animate frame-by-frame with Dragonframe software to bring objects and physical materials to life. Incorporate animation principles and experiment with sand, paint, clay, paper and more.

CTXA.title: Cinematic Animation - the Art of Motion in Virtual Space
CTXA.description: A study and an experimentation in cinematic expression through motion across social, esthetic and scientific realms. Lab experiments in virtual space.

CTXA.title: Stop Motion Puppet and Set Design
CTXA.description: Puppet and set design for stop motion animation while providing guidance on armature rigs that allow the character to be animated effectively.

CTXA.title: Animation Sound Design Practice
CTXA.description: Theory, aesthetics and practice for recording dialogue, sound effects, music, Foley, track development and mixing for animation films.

CTXA.title: Expanded Animation
CTXA.description: Incorporation of traditional image making methods as well as digital and new media technologies to convey non-linear narratives over internal and external landscapes.

CTXA.title: Directed Research
CTXA.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ASCJ.title: Navigating Media and News in the Digital Age
ASCJ.description: Students will be engaged as discriminating media/news consumers and contributors. Emphasis on critical skills needed to understand, employ, enjoy and help shape our media landscape.

ASCJ.title: Contours of Change in Media and Communication
ASCJ.description: Provides an introduction to cultivating a curious, critical, and proactive approach to the challenges of social change. Students will be encouraged to develop an expansive and critical definition and understanding of change as it relates to the role of media and communication in producing and responding to political and cultural transformations that shape our status as citizens and our ideas of citizenship.

COMM.title: Communication and Social Science
COMM.description: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories  of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and    organizational contexts.

COMM.title: Public Speaking
COMM.description: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis  of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of  speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.

COMM.title: Communication Practicum
COMM.description: Students address communication issues in a field setting. They will evaluate communication practices using appropriate methodology. Projects are jointly evaluated by internship supervisor and professor. Sophomore standing. Graded: CR/NC. Not for major credit for Communication majors.

COMM.title: Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.

COMM.title: Communication and Media Economics
COMM.description: Economic and political economic principles for the analysis of communication and media industries including broadcasting, newspapers, motion pictures, music, video games, advertising and public relations.

COMM.title: Empirical Research in Communication
COMM.description: Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.

COMM.title: Persuasion
COMM.description: Theories and research in social influence; strategies and tactics of persuasive communications in such settings as politics, public relations, advertising, business.

COMM.title: Interpersonal Communication
COMM.description: Analysis of face-to-face interaction; role of communication in the development, maintenance and destruction of relationships; communication processes in managing interpersonal conflict.

COMM.title: Understanding Social Science Research
COMM.description: Students learn to be consumers rather than creators of social science research. Examines the challenges and opportunities of communicating research through mass media.

COMM.title: Communication and Technology
COMM.description: Cultural, social, political, and economic dynamics of communication technologies, including internet architecture, social media, participatory cultures, privacy, surveillance, networked journalism, big data, algorithms, online activism.

COMM.title: Communication and Publics
COMM.description: Forms of civic life; opportunities and obstacles in forming, participating in, and disrupting community; issues of knowledge, power, identity; theories/methods of rhetorical analysis and production.

COMM.title: The Business and Culture of Celebrity
COMM.description: Employs the concept of "celebrity" as an optic through which to view and assess some of the key aspects of the communication revolution.

COMM.title: Screen time: How Media Shapes Us
COMM.description: Investigate medias role in daily activities. Examine usage trends, research methods and industry analytics. Analyze media impacts, policy issues and research-informed strategies.

COMM.title: The Evolution of K-Pop
COMM.description: Examines the various stages of K-pop's transformations and related issues in the process of its rise as a global popular culture.

COMM.title: Small Group and Team Communication
COMM.description: Group process theories relevant to communicative behavior in small group/team settings, including information exchange, decision making, leadership, and meetings; student team projects testing theoretic propositions.

COMM.title: Communication and Social Media
COMM.description: Social media within the broader social, political, and historical contexts; key themes include labor, Web 2.0, self-branding, celebrity, participation, privacy, online shaming, and activism.

COMM.title: Argumentation and Advocacy
COMM.description: Basic argumentation theory including analysis.  Research and  evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics,  organizations, interpersonal relations.

COMM.title: Intercultural Communication
COMM.description: Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.

COMM.title: Latinx Media Studies
COMM.description: Introduces students to critical analyses of media texts, industries and technologies that shape the lives of Latinx communities in the United States.

COMM.title: Rhetoric in Classical Culture
COMM.description: Theories of communication and persuasion in ancient Greece and Rome; cultural and social contexts of classical rhetorical theory; major historical figures and concepts.

COMM.title: Communication Technology and Culture
COMM.description: This course examines philosophies and popular representations of  technology from the origins of western culture to the present and  identifies the complex attitudes toward technology.

COMM.title: Social and Economic Implications of Communication Technologies
COMM.description: Social and economic impacts of information and communication technologies; social factors that shape technological change; issues include access, privacy, freedom of expression, productivity, democratic control.

COMM.title: Video Games: Business, Science and Culture
COMM.description: Introduction to the medium; history of video games; video games as aesthetic products, cultural products, economic outputs; policy issues, effects, and sites of community.

COMM.title: Los Angeles: Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Representations of Los Angeles communicated in diverse media; the city as a rhetorical text; analysis of cultural identities, art, architecture and representations in popular culture.

COMM.title: Community Engagement and Service Learning
COMM.description: Students engage with a community partner, bridging classroom learning with "real world" experiences by working within the diverse community surrounding USC.

COMM.title: Business and Professional Communication
COMM.description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204

COMM.title: Forensics Laboratory
COMM.description: Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience. Open only to members of the University debate squad.

COMM.title: Issues in Contemporary Sport
COMM.description: Explores social, political and ethical issues in elite sports and how issues are addressed through popular media; examination includes the relationship between sports and politics.

COMM.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
COMM.description: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.

COMM.title: Sports, Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse;  application to sports organizations, the news and popular media;  representations of gender and race in sports.

COMM.title: Interpreting Popular Culture
COMM.description: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.

COMM.title: Organizational Communication
COMM.description: How communication processes both create organizations and are constrained by them. Theory and research into topics such as culture, technology, power, leadership and decision-making in a variety of organizational contexts.

COMM.title: Sports and Social Change
COMM.description: Application of critical, sociological and rhetorical theories to sports events and sport media; examination of the role of sports in enacting social change.

COMM.title: Gender, Media and Communication
COMM.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: mediarepresentations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's rolein communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

COMM.title: Fashion, Media and Culture
COMM.description: Fashion as a form of communication and culture; fashion's role in identity, body politics, art, nationhood, celebrity and Hollywood culture, youth cultures and subversive practices.

COMM.title: Canceled, Shamed, Accused: Contemporary Crisis Communication
COMM.description: Explores the theory, strategy and practice of assessing and responding to risks and crises, corporate and personal leadership, and follow-up reputation management.

COMM.title: Communication and Social Movements
COMM.description: Social and political movements as rhetorical phenomena; ideology, organization, and influence of such movements as civil rights, "New Left," feminism, "New Right," environmentalism.

COMM.title: Legal Issues and New Media
COMM.description: Examines laws and regulatory policies shaping new media, especially the Internet; impact of regulation on development and use of communication technology.

COMM.title: Global Entertainment
COMM.description: Survey of economic, political, and cultural dimensions of the global entertainment marketplace; focuses on the international production and distribution of media products and services.

COMM.title: Communicating Better Health: What Works and Why
COMM.description: How communication -- interpersonal, mass media, information technologies -- shapes health behavior. Topics: doctor-patient consults; marketing campaigns; health in entertainment, news; internet; social media; mobile devices.

COMM.title: Global Networks of Sport
COMM.description: Focuses on global technologies, media, money and labor in the sport sector. Investigates both deviant and regulatory networks of sport in the context of globalization.

COMM.title: Perspectives on the Networked Press
COMM.description: Critical survey of the forces defining today's networked press, examining the people, technologies and institutions that produce news in today's online environments.

COMM.title: Visual Culture and Communication
COMM.description: Examines issues of visual images in communication related to history, modernity, cityscapes, news media, advertising, evidence, science, digital technology, and globalization.

COMM.title: Entertainment, Marketing and Culture
COMM.description: Explores blurring of entertainment, marketing and culture in advanced information economies; intersections of culture and media and their social ramifications.

COMM.title: Youth and Media
COMM.description: Exploration of youth media and culture, including television, movies, video games, toys, magazines, music, social media. Examines representations of youth and youth as audience.

COMM.title: Directed Research
COMM.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduatecredit. Available to juniors and seniors only.

COMM.title: Research Practicum
COMM.description: Students gain research experience in the design, implementation,  analysis, and reporting of communication research.  Students serve  as research assistants to faculty members.  Not available for  graduate credit.

COMM.title: Honors Seminar
COMM.description: Advanced study of issues in communication; recent developments in communication and rhetorical theories. Open only to students in COMM honors program; recommended for seniors.  Recommended  preparation: COMM 301L.

COMM.title: Ethical Issues in Entertainment and Communication
COMM.description: Examines social and political controversies over conflicting ethical standards for communication in a variety of media: mass-media, communication technology and entertainment.

COMM.title: Theoretical Approaches to Multidisciplinary Design Projects
COMM.description: Focuses on theories and research in communication and social sciences to bridge disciplines to produce a proposal, business plan, publication, or a research project.

COMM.title: Kenneth Burke's Dramatistic Theory
COMM.description: Studies the contributions of Kenneth Burke, among the most         significant figures in the development of contemporary rhetorical  theory and criticism.  Not open to M.A. in Communication  Management majors.

COMM.title: Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication II
COMM.description: Overview of humanistic and social scientific approaches to the     study of communication; emphasis on macro and micro social         scientific, symbolic, and structural perspectives. Not open to  M.A. in Communication Management majors,

COMM.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Communication
COMM.description: Developing expertise in qualitative methods, including  participant-observation, ethnography, discourse analysis and  historiography in communication research.

COMM.title: Data Science for Communication and Social Networks
COMM.description: Learn to harness the power of data science and computational techniques to study social and communication networks and extract value, knowledge and insights from big data.

COMM.title: Globalization, Communication and Society
COMM.description: Comparative analysis of social, cultural and political impacts of communication technology and media; emphasis given to communication's influence in the social dimensions of globalization.

COMM.title: Organizational Communication
COMM.description: Theory and research; field experience in analyzing and solving    communication problems in organizations.  Not open to M.A. in  Communication Management majors.

COMM.title: Advanced Applied AI for Digital Media Product Development
COMM.description: A culmination of foundational training in communication, data science and machine learning. Building AI solutions for digital media and product development.

COMM.title: Applied Quantitative Methods
COMM.description: A project-based course that prepares students for working in a data/analytics team. Emphasis on communicating complex statistical concepts to collaborators and a non-technical audience.

COMM.title: Making it Matter: Turning Ideas into Policy
Health Communication
COMM.description: Evaluation of research about communication in patient care, health  campaigns for diverse publics, tools for disease management, and  outreach to producers in mass media.

COMM.title: The Practice of Research
COMM.description: Current problems in communication theory and research; advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

COMM.title: Network Society
COMM.description: Advanced research seminar examining the interaction between  communication technology, society, economy, politics, and culture  from interdisciplinary and cross-cultural perspectives.  Not  available for degree credit for M.A. in Communication Management  students.  Not available for Communication Management M.A.  students.

COMM.title: Methodologies in Cultural Studies
COMM.description: An exploration of theoretical, technical, and political implications of cross-disciplinary scholarship rooted in cultural studies.

COMM.title: Survey Construction and Validation
COMM.description: Principles of survey construction and validation; format  selection, sampling, question wording, adaptation for  international audiences, response option formats, order, and  avoiding acquiesence bias and breakoffs.

COMM.title: Independent Study
COMM.description: A supervised course tailored to specific student interests. The professor and student develop a syllabus that permits exploration of advanced or specialized topics. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Preliminary Research Paper
COMM.description: Independent research designed to demonstrate the student's ability to conceptualize, conduct, and present scholarly research.         Parallel to COMM 794. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Research
COMM.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

DSM.title: Introduction to Digital Social Media
DSM.description: Explores the sector of digital social media and online communities, with a focus on user experience, social impact, strategic content creation and models for success.

DSM.title: Website Strategies for Organizations
DSM.description: Assess organizations' online needs, to examine the use of the Internet in terms of electronic commerce and global pressures, and design Web page strategies.

DSM.title: Digital Media Product Management
DSM.description: Digital media product management using case studies and real-world projects. Customer discovery, strategy, roadmaps and product requirements.

DSM.title: The Future of Advertising: AdTech Innovations and AI Trends
DSM.description: Programmatic advertising, adtech and AI trends through hands-on digital marketing projects with real clients, media dollars, ad platforms and student team-led client partnership.

DSM.title: Brand Strategy for Digital Media
DSM.description: Exploration of the essential art of branding in the digital age; building relationships between consumers and brands

DSM.title: Analytics and Research Methodology
DSM.description: Teaches the use and interpretation of digital analytics as well as the use of research design, methodology, and basic statistics for digital sites and apps.

DSM.title: Digital Social Media Internship
DSM.description: Integration of practical experiences with academic learning to apply digital media strategies, design and innovation in creating impactful solutions, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

DSM.title: Final Project Capstone
DSM.description: Students produce a working site, app or embedded social platform project with digital/multimedia elements. Development includes pitching, conceptualization and launching of the final project.

DSM.title: Digital Campaign Management
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Podcasting for Brand Building
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Storytelling with Emerging Technologies
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Streaming Entertainment: Innovation and Disruption in        Culture, Technology and Business
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DMM.title: Principles and Theories of Digital Media Management
DMM.description: Explores the digital media environment, its sociohistorical evolution and the impact of digital technologies and media on practices within cultural and business ecosystems.

DMM.title: Digital Audience Research and Analysis
DMM.description: Explores research methodologies and digital audience analytics, evaluating online audience needs and wants and focusing on data-driven and ethical decision making.

DMM.title: Digital Media Buying, Measurement and Analytics
DMM.description: Examines digital media advertising sales technologies: digital advertising, media buying, digital asset performance measurement and data collection methodologies used for business planning.

DMM.title: Digital Content, Production and Distribution
DMM.description: Explores the evolution of digital media content, content categories in digital media, innovations in content production techniques and technologies and the digital distribution revolution.

DMM.title: Strategic Digital Media Marketing
DMM.description: Case studies and examples to ideate, create and evaluate cutting-edge techniques used to implement long-range strategies for ethical digital media management and marketing.

DMM.title: Digital Media Leadership
