DMM.description: Examines personal leadership principles and practices applicable to digital media, focused on leading within organizations, building diverse, high-performing teams and delivering digital media initiatives.

DMM.title: Managing Digital Media Teams and Projects
DMM.description: Covers the principles and skills needed to manage teams and projects within the digital media environment and achieve organizational goals through strategic planning.

DMM.title: Digital Content Direction
DMM.description: Covers principles and strategies for directing digital content across platforms to achieve organizational objectives beyond creating awareness, informing or entertaining.

DMM.title: Developing Effective User Engagement Strategies
DMM.description: Covers strategies to balance the needs of creating a user experience and content with the ethical imperatives of fostering equity, diversity and inclusion.

DMM.title: Digital Platforms: Disruptions and Directions
DMM.description: Explores how the platform economy is disrupting traditional marketplaces and industries with new, digital technologies and ways for optimizing outcomes from those changes.

DMM.title: Digital Media Innovation and Entrepreneurship
DMM.description: Covers management of digital media innovation within digital media organizations and new entrepreneurial ventures, and ways for alleviating challenges to equity and diversity.

DMM.title: Digital Media Management Capstone
DMM.description: Students create an innovative idea or initiative that solves a problem or achieves a goal within a digital media organization or business unit.

PR.title: Effective Writing for Strategic Public Relations and Adverti
PR.description: Focus on the unique writing requirements of social, online, broadcast, print and other media in public relations/advertising; emphasis on judgment, context and audience understanding. Non-majors who are interested in enrolling must have at least a 2.5 GPA.

PR.title: Strategic Public Relations and Advertising: An Introduction
PR.description: Strategies/practices in the growing field of public relations and advertising, including landmark cases, campaign planning; special emphasis on historical roots, current and future practice.

PR.title: Introduction to Advertising
PR.description: History and development of advertising; basic advertising campaigns showing relationships of marketing, creative, print and electronic media.

PR.title: Multichannel Strategy and Content Creation
PR.description: Introduction to media relations, social media and influencer engagement; intensive writing and creating multimedia content for traditional, emerging and social media.

PR.title: Multichannel Strategy and Content Creation
PR.description: Advanced course in writing, digital content and multimedia creation; production of communications collateral for social and owned media channels targeting an array of audiences.

PR.title: Practicum for PR Media Center
PR.description: A hands-on learning lab, exploring how to create original social media content while adhering to media production cycle.

PR.title: Structured Inquiry in Public Relations and Advertising
PR.description: Apply contemporary research methods to create actionable insights for integrated, multi-channel communication campaigns, including social media monitoring, measurement and evaluation.

PR.title: Business and Economic Foundations of Public Relations and Ad
PR.description: Relationship between public relations/advertising and other organizational disciplines; understanding business goals and objectives; economic literacy; financial/investor relations; how PR/communication agencies are built and managed.

PR.title: Concepting: Advertising Strategy and Creative Development
PR.description: Learn how to develop an idea and transform that idea to create advertisements that cut through the clutter and communicate persuasively.

PR.title: Advertising and Technology
PR.description: Hands-on introduction to advertising's digital tools, platforms, media, channels and techniques through an insider's view of LA's technology companies.

PR.title: Lifestyle Public Relations
PR.description: An extensive overview of the Lifestyle Public Relations category with special emphasis on social media, non-traditional influencers and audience segmentation.

PR.title: Fundamentals of Food Communication
PR.description: Examines the role of food, food-related communication and media in our daily lives, our various cultures and our local, national and global economy.

PR.title: Building Integrated Campaigns
PR.description: In-depth study of methods for planning, managing and evaluating strategic communication campaigns; critical analysis of contemporary cases; development of campaigns for real world clients.

PR.title: Public Relations in Entertainment
PR.description: Public relations in the design, promotion, and presentation of popular entertainment, including films, broadcasting, music, expositions, amusement parks, resorts and arenas.

PR.title: Public Relations Strategies for Working with Athletes
PR.description: Sports Public Relations isn't only getting press for a team or player; it's managing communications among influencers. Complements overview course giving students advanced look at practitioners' role with professional athletes.

PR.title: Sports Public Relations
PR.description: Introduction to the field of sports information and promotion, including lectures, media assignments, role-playing, and presentations by sports professionals.

PR.title: Public Relations for Non-Profit Organizations
PR.description: Introduction to the specialized field of public relations for non-profit and non-governmental organizations; emphasis on case studies, strategic and critical thinking, and campaign development.

PR.title: Political Public Relations and Advocacy
PR.description: Application of public relations principles to the context of political campaigns; emphasis on message development and delivery; relationship between candidate, news media, and electorate.

PR.title: Social Media Analytics: Data, Content Creation and Campaign
PR.description: Application of monitoring tools to become social media analysts and real-time content creators; interpretation of large data sets drawn from the social web; understanding of how to present data visually for optimal impact.

PR.title: Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Digital Design Tools
PR.description: Hands-on lab; producing multimedia content; basic principles of design; tools and techniques to create digital images and layouts.

PR.title: Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Audio/Video Tools
PR.description: Hands-on lab; audio/video tools for conceiving, shooting, editing, delivering and archiving compelling stories for online audiences; personal brand building; digital storytelling trends and applications.

PR.title: Multimedia PR Content: Visual Communication of   Information
PR.description: Overview of tools and techniques available to convey messages and experiences; exploration into graphic design, visual branding, design methods and processes.

PR.title: Directed Research
PR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PR.title: Public Relations and Advertising Fundamentals and Strategy
PR.description: Explores the practice of public relations and advertising in a broader strategic communication and digital context; emphasizing strategy, critical thinking and problem solving.

PR.title: Storytelling with Data Intelligence
PR.description: Provides the foundations of quantitative research methods, the basics of storytelling with data and critical thinking skills in public relations, advertising and related fields.

PR.title: Advanced Audience Insight Mining
PR.description: Provides student training with cutting-edge digital research methods and applied data analytic skills relevant to current and future public relations and advertising practices.

PR.title: Multimedia Content Creation for Brand Storytelling II
PR.description: Conceptualization and creation of strategic, research-based, primarily image and video multimedia content for use by organizations of all types.

PR.title: Persuasive Writing
PR.description: Teaches persuasive writing for practitioners in public relations, advertising, influencer relations and brand activation  through in-class writing drills with and without deadline pressure.

PR.title: Public Relations and Branding
PR.description: Concept of branding, including brand definition, brand engagement, brand management and the role of public relations in creating brand value.

PR.title: Image Management in Entertainment
PR.description: In-depth study of the creation and protection of reputations for entertainment properties of all types and the characteristics that distinguish it from other disciplines.

PR.title: Branding through Partnerships, Activations and Influencers
PR.description: Analyze celebrity partnerships, influencer campaigns and brand integrations. Create innovative entertainment marketing strategies across media platforms. Evaluate ROI and risk management.

PR.title: AI-Assisted Strategic Communication
PR.description: Covers coding in Python, AI fundamentals, advanced AI-assisted communication and ethical considerations. Hands-on workshops, client collaboration and real-world AI applications.

PR.title: Foundations of Effective PR Writing
PR.description: Specialized writing for persuasive and strategic communication contexts. Intensive focus on public relations writing for print, online, broadcast, and social media.

PR.title: Corporate Public Relations and Reputation
PR.description: Learn all aspects of corporate communications and reputation management through real-time news analysis, cases and senior guest speakers from the world's largest, most admired companies.

PR.title: Directed Research
PR.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

PR.title: Master's Thesis
PR.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

PR.title: Improvisational Leadership
PR.description: Leadership workshop inspires stepping outside of comfort zones to be braver and more creative.  Encourages discovery of leadership potential by exploring new ideas and challenges.

PRSM.title: Strategic Planning for Multichannel Communication Campaigns
PRSM.description: Explores the contemporary practices of branding, advertising and public relations, and their expanding role in the development of multichannel communication campaign plans.

PRSM.title: Data-Driven Brand Storytelling
PRSM.description: Explores the evaluation of research and analysis methods, generating data insights and creating compelling and accurate stories using data visualization techniques.

PRSM.title: Leadership and Ethics for Communication Practitioners
PRSM.description: Explores the leadership skills and ethics required in todays complex organizations, communication with key stakeholders, creative problem solving and promoting diversity, equity, inclusion and access.

PRSM.title: Business and Economic Literacy for Communicators
PRSM.description: Covers fundamental business, finance and economics knowledge needed to better align the communication function with organizational goals and communicate effectively with key stakeholders.

PRSM.title: Influencer Relationship Management
PRSM.description: Explores how influence works, influencer-related functions in public relations, marketing, brand management and advertising, managing influencers and ethical considerations in influencer campaigns.

PRSM.title: Crisis Communication
PRSM.description: Explores crises, their potential impacts and ethical considerations and the role of communication practitioners in crafting strategic messaging and developing comprehensive crisis communication plans.

PRSM.title: Brand Purpose Communication
PRSM.description: Explores best practices for brand communication, social issue engagement and advocacy, value alignment, guiding stakeholders on purpose communication and planning purpose-led campaigns or projects.

PRSM.title: Emerging Game-Changers for Communication Practitioners
PRSM.description: Explores impacts of emerging technologies, innovation and organizational culture concepts and the centrality of emerging technologies in shaping the digital future.

JOUR.title: The Power and Responsibility of the Press
JOUR.description: Explores the role of journalism and social media in society - its influence on government, technology, business, national security, sports, science and entertainment.

JOUR.title: Culture of Journalism: Past, Present and Future
JOUR.description: Understanding key moments, debates and ideas that have shaped journalism in the United States from the Revolutionary War period through today.  Examination of the social, cultural, political and technological aspects of journalism and its impact on the profession and public service.

JOUR.title: Journalism Practicum
JOUR.description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing Practicum
JOUR.description: Report, write and distribute in-depth stories for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing I
JOUR.description: Provides students with foundational skills to report, write and produce journalism content across multiple platforms, including broadcast, digital and text.

JOUR.title: Basics of News Production for Non-Majors
JOUR.description: Introduction to television, radio, and/or digital news production. Examination of issues in journalism. Graded CR/NC.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing II
JOUR.description: Report, write, produce and distribute in-depth stories produced off beats on multiple platforms for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting and emerging digital tools.

JOUR.title: Introduction to Coding for Storytelling

JOUR.title: Visual Journalism

JOUR.title: Introduction to Investigative and Data Journalism
JOUR.description: Reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for portraying and evaluating contemporary newsworthy events using basic data journalism techniques and tools for statistical analysis.

JOUR.title: Journalism and the Audience
JOUR.description: Build a personal website that features a culmination of your previous undergraduate journalism work; craft a professional digital profile using various social media platforms; understand the economics of the news business; prepare to enter the industry.

JOUR.title: Photojournalism

JOUR.title: Introduction to Sports Media

JOUR.title: Engaging Diverse Communities
JOUR.description: Explores how to engage diverse local communities through participatory journalism and communication strategies. Focuses on using digital tools to increase engagement with communities via field reporting and mobile platforms to produce stories across platforms.

JOUR.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
JOUR.description: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.

JOUR.title: Entertainment, Business and Media in Today's Society

JOUR.title: Advanced Video Reporting
JOUR.description: Role of the broadcast journalism reporter; similarities and differences between print and electronic media; application of audio-video equipment; analysis and practical experience.

JOUR.title: Television News and Sports Production
JOUR.description: Production of television news and sports programs while developing video, writing and communication skills and managing content in collaboration with others under deadline pressure.

JOUR.title: Produce and Host Sports Content in Studio A
JOUR.description: Interview, present and design sports segments for television/video in Studio A.

JOUR.title: Non-Fiction Television
JOUR.description: Presentation and selection in non-fiction television programs including documentaries, electronic magazines and news series; ethical problems, field research, reporting, interviewing, pre-production.

JOUR.title: Social Media Storytelling for Latinx Audiences
JOUR.description: Create native journalistic content for current social media and emerging platforms with an emphasis on engaging content for Latinx audiences and underrepresented communities.

JOUR.title: The World of Podcasting

JOUR.title: Advanced Digital Media Storytelling

JOUR.title: Advanced Radio News Production
JOUR.description: Production of public radio news: producing real-time newscasts for Annenberg Radio News. Newsgathering, assigning stories, anchoring, interviewing, working with reporters, editing and producing live programming.

JOUR.title: Feature Writing
JOUR.description: Techniques of writing newspaper feature stories, including the profile, the light feature, the news feature, the in-depth story; the art of narrative writing.

JOUR.title: Sports Commentary
JOUR.description: Techniques of reporting and writing sports columns and commentary for print, video, radio and Web-based media.

JOUR.title: Sports Reporting

JOUR.title: Entertainment Reporting

JOUR.description: Analyzes the ways media tell the story of our food and examines the critical issues surrounding what we eat.

JOUR.title: The Athlete, Sports Media and Popular Culture
JOUR.description: Analysis of the images of the athlete and sports media helps us understand how sports dramatically affects such social issues as race, class and gender.

JOUR.title: Multiplatform Olympic and Paralympic Storytelling
JOUR.description: Develop the skills necessary to produce multiplatform coverage of mega-events like the Olympic and Paralympic Games.

JOUR.title: Directed Research
JOUR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JOUR.title: Bridging the Media Gap Between L.A. Influencers and          Independent Journalists
JOUR.description: Selected topics in journalism.

JOUR.title: Power, Players and Platforms in Global Sports
JOUR.description: Selected topics in journalism.

JOUR.title: Entertainment
JOUR.description: Beat reporting with a deep dive into research, source development, and writing/reporting skills. Focus on current trends, history, major actors and key issues.

JOUR.description: Students write, report, produce, code, promote (through social media) and publish/air cross-platform stories in a converged news environment.

JOUR.description: Report, write and distribute in-depth stories for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting.

JOUR.title: Introduction to Investigative Reporting
JOUR.description: Focus on basic investigative reporting; understand its history, how to access records, identify sources, use computer assisted reporting, report in a fair and ethical manner.

JOUR.title: Video Reporting and Production
JOUR.description: Writing, reporting and producing content for video and digital platforms; similarities and differences between media; application of audio-visual and digital equipment.

JOUR.description: Explores outstanding narrative journalism across wide range of platforms, subjects. Through readings, discussions, guest lecture "salons," students learn reporting, writing skills necessary for in-depth storytelling.

JOUR.title: Journalism Internship
JOUR.description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

JOUR.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

JOUR.description: Researching and writing about how not to get fooled as a journalist; includes research, writing and discussion. Open only to journalism and specialized journalism majors.

PUBD.title: Historical and Comparative Approaches to Public Diplomacy
PUBD.description: Examines historical and comparative approaches to public  diplomacy.  Explores public diplomacy operations in public and  private settings, by individuals and institutions.  Reviews  traditional, critical, war, and peace perspectives.

PUBD.description: Development and production of original research-based project in  the area of public diplomacy.  Graded CR/NC.

CMGT.title: Managing Communication

CMGT.title: Communicating Strategy and Change

CMGT.description: Examination of the impact of global economic changes on communications industries, the political and economic forces shaping these industries and the roles of its managers.

CMGT.title: Partnerships in the U.S. Media Industry

CMGT.title: The Industry, Science and Culture of Video Games

CMGT.title: Creating Differentiation for Organizations: Meaning and Grow
CMGT.description: Explores how organizations combine values, culture, experience and markets to create meaning, engage audience and customers, and grow.

CMGT.title: Sports Media and Society
CMGT.description: History and evolution of sports media industry; traditional, new  and alternative sports media; globalization of sports; sports  promotions and personalities.

CMGT.description: Understanding dynamics in entertainment markets enabled by emerging digital technologies; broad and niche strategies to target appropriate audiences, building audience engagement with entertainment content identities.

CMGT.description: Global influences on linear and streaming television and theatrical. Case analyses of organizations and content focusing on interconnected partnerships and promotions to attract local audiences.

CMGT.title: Methodological Fundamentals of Big Data in Communication
CMGT.description: Understanding of fundamental methodological issues about big data: types, platforms, tools, analysis techniques, and relevant theoretical frameworks.

CMGT.title: Influencer Strategies
CMGT.description: Students master skills and strategies to distinguish the truly influential from the merely popular, manage international influencer campaigns and develop successful influencers.

CMGT.title: Artificial Intelligence and Communication Technologies
CMGT.description: Foundational concepts surrounding communication-related artificial intelligence, focus on generative AI products and services in contemporary communication, content and media industries, organizations and work.

CMGT.title: Communication Strategies for Conflict Management
CMGT.description: Communication strategies for effective negotiation, mediation and facilitation of disputes; structures for public interventions; emergence of online dispute resolution systems.

CMGT.title: Audience Analysis
CMGT.description: Conceptualization of client research problems: sampling and segmentation; advanced questionnaire design; audience observation; quantitative-qualitative analyses and synthesis; effective communication of findings and solutions.

CMGT.title: Global Storytelling: The Power of Narrative
CMGT.description: Theory, structure and effects of culture on narrative. Story in non-profit and health organizations; new fields that recognize the importance of storytelling; storytelling in diverse media.

CMGT.title: Storytelling, Culture and Experiential Communication
CMGT.description: How to communicate through storytelling in contemporary culture. Strategic story development for brands, for self-branding, and for social impact. Story creation utilizes narrative theories and workshop-style participatory activities.

CMGT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded    CR/NC.

CMGT.description: Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems.

CMGT.description: Communication management research project design and execution - thesis formulation, literature review, methods choice and instrument design. Analysis and reporting with appropriate quantitative or qualitative techniques.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning--Human Structure I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal structures including anatomy, cell biology, embryology, histology, pathology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Function I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal function including biochemistry, endocrinology, genetics, immunology, microbiology, nutrition, pharmacology, physiology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Behavior I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with the treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Clinical Dentistry I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning approach to the delivery of dental health care. Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance into DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Structure II
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal structures including anatomy, cell biology, embryology, histology, pathology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Function II
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal function including biochemistry, endocrinology, genetics, immunology, microbiology, nutrition, pharmacology, physiology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Behavior II
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with the treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Clinical Dentistry II
DPBL.description: Problem based learning approach to the delivery of dental health care. Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Structure III
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal structures including anatormy, cell biology, embryology, histology, pathology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

All material discussed with direct relationship to a well characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Function IV
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal function including biochemistry, endocrinology, genetics, immunology, microbiology, nutrition, pharmacology, physiology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Behavior IV
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with the treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.

COH.title: Community Health Sciences
COH.description: Examination of common theoretical and conceptual models, health education methodologies and emerging technology to provide health services in community settings.

COH.title: Social and Behavioral Sciences
COH.description: Social and behavioral factors of diverse groups that can affect the health status and choices of communities.

COH.title: Practicum 1
COH.description: Provides the opportunity to apply acquired competencies to real world settings to improve health promotion and disease prevention.

COH.title: Community Health Practice Standards
COH.description: Standards of practice, regulations, policies and ethical principles that affect healthcare providers, payers and other stakeholders in community healthcare settings.

DPHR.title: Advanced Pharmacology
DPHR.description: Pharmacologic principles and practice of drug use to control anxiety, pain, and infection. Treatment of drug and medical emergencies as they relate to dental specialty practice.

DHIS.title: Advanced Oral Histology
DHIS.description: Microscopic anatomy, ultrastructure and histochemistry of developing and functional oral tissues; based on recent advances in oral LM, TEM, and SEM histology. PREREQUISITE: Departmental approval

DENT.title: Clinic Completion
DENT.description: Course is provided only for the purpose of demonstrating skills in the clinic. It is not available for subject, unit or degree credit. The course may be registered for only as an audit.

DENT.title: Advanced Dentistry Third Year
DENT.description: For registration and fee purposes only.

OPER.title: Advanced Dental Morphology for Esthetic Restorations
OPER.description: In-depth study of the dental morphology, dental optical properties, and laboratorial procedures for restorative replication of esthetical and morphological aspects found in the natural tooth.

OPER.title: Operative Dentistry and Biomaterials Literature Review
OPER.description: Weekly seminar devoted to review of the historic, classic, and current literature in advanced operative dentistry and dental biomaterials.

OPER.title: Operative Dentistry and Biomaterials Literature Review
OPER.description: Weekly seminar devoted to review of the historic, classic, and current literature in advanced operative dentistry and dental biomaterials.

OPER.title: Dental Photography
OPER.description: Basic principles of dental photography and its use in clinical dentistry for shade selection, replication of dental esthetic components, and clinical case documentation.

OPER.title: Applied Adhesion Sciences
OPER.description: Advanced adhesive procedures for esthetic dental rehabilitation. Open only to Advanced and Adhesive Dentistry majors. Graded CR/NC.

OPER.title: Cariology
OPER.description: Cariology and proficiency of dental caries management using preventive methods and minimally invasive restorative techniques. Open only to Advanced Operative and Adhesive Dentistry majors. Graded CR/NC.

OPER.title: Research Methodology
OPER.description: Study of research methodologies for scientific investigation on dental biomaterials.

OPER.title: Treatment Planning in Operative Dentistry
OPER.description: Seminars led by students and invited guests to discuss, analyse and propose a treatment sequence for esthetic challengeclinical cases involving complex multidisciplinary treatment.

OPER.title: Treatment Planning in Operative Dentistry
OPER.description: Seminars led by students and invited guests to discuss, analyse and propose a treatment sequence for esthetic challenge clinical cases involving complex multidisciplinary treatment.

OPER.title: Clinic: Advanced Operative Dentistry
OPER.description: Advanced clinical and laboratorial treatment of patients in need of complex multidisciplinary treatment, with special emphasis on esthetic and bonded restorations.

OPER.title: Clinic: Advanced Operative Dentistry
OPER.description: Advanced clinical and laboratorial treatment of patients in need of complex multidisciplinary treatment, with specialemphasis on esthetic and bonded restorations.

GDEN.title: Internal Medicine and Systemic Disease for Dental Residents
GDEN.description: Seminars on common systemic diseases and the potential interactions with oral disease and treatment

GDEN.title: Epidemiology, Nutrition and Aging for Dental Residents
GDEN.description: Seminars on the various mucosal, cutaneous, gingival and salivary diseases and lesions in the oral and maxillofacial region.

GDEN.title: OFPM Case Portfolio Preparation for Dental Residents
GDEN.description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients with orofacial pain and oral lesions through online conferences in preparation, development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases.

GDEN.title: GDEN Case Portfolio Preparation for Dental Residents
GDEN.description: Examination of clinical cases of geriatric patients with complex medical conditions through online conferences in preparation, development and defense of portfolio of multiple cases.

GDEN.title: Research Methodology
GDEN.description: A coordinated approach to understanding, critically assessing and applying the principles of scientific inquiry through the study of clinically relevant, discipline specific literature.

GDEN.title: Case Portfolio Defense for GDEN Students
GDEN.description: Case portfolio development for certificate students, including final presentation and assessment by a panel of faculty.

OFPM.title: TMD, Orthopedics, Rheumatology and Physical Therapy for Dental Residents
OFPM.description: Seminars on various topics relating to the diagnosis and  management of Temporomandibular disorders.

OFPM.title: Pharmacology Series for Dental Residents
OFPM.description: Seminars on common medications used in the practice of oral medicine and chronic orofacial pain.

OFPM.description: Seminars on common systemic diseases and the potential interactions with oral disease and treatment

OFPM.title: Epidemiology, Nutrition and Aging for Dental Residents

OFPM.description: Seminar course on immunology and immunosuppression as it relates to diseases in the oral and maxillofacial region.

OFPM.title: Infectious Disease, Oral Microbiology and Virology for Dental Residents
OFPM.description: Seminar organized around infectious diseases in the oral,  pharyngeal and nasal region.

OFPM.title: Capstone Project for OFPOM Residents
OFPM.description: Residents complete their capstone research project in a topic in the area of their chosen focus/specialization.

OFPM.title: Case Portfolio Preparation by Online OFPOM Residents
OFPM.description: Multiple elements including weekly online conferences, presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases; learning need assignments; preparation and defense of case-based e-Portfolio.

PERI.description: Review and critical evaluation of the current periodontal literature.

PERI.title: Seminar: Review of Current Periodontal Literature
PERI.description: Review and critical evaluation of the current periodontal         literature.

PERI.title: Seminar: Periodontal Treatment Procedures
PERI.description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal treatment.

PERI.title: Seminar: Periodontal Therapy
PERI.description: Presentation and discussion of treatment of clinical cases        involving soft tissue and osseous management; rationale for the    therapy; surgical wound healing. Graded CR/NC.

PERI.title: Seminar: Periodontal Therapy
PERI.description: Presentation and discussion of treatment of clinical cases involving soft tissue and osseous management; rationale for the therapy; surgical wound healing; dental implant surgery.  Graded CR/NC.

PERI.title: Seminar: Periodontal Therapy
PERI.description: Presentation and discussion of treatment of clinical cases         involving soft tissue and osseous management; rationale for the    therapy; surgical wound healing; dental implant surgery.  Graded  CR/NC.

PERI.title: Clinical Periodontal Photography
PERI.description: Demonstration of techniques used in intraoral photography for periodontal purposes, emphasis on proper clinical case documentation in seminar presentation and Specialty Board Certification.

PERI.title: Treatment Planning in Periodontics
PERI.description: Presentation of clinical findings, diagnoses, and plan of treatment of clinical cases by advanced students.  Graded CR/NC.

PERI.description: Thematic review of the contemporary literature, knowledge, discoveries, inventions, and developments in periodontology and implantology.

PERI.title: Seminar: Special Topics in Periodontology and Implantology
PERI.description: Discussion of topics of immediate importance and controversy. Experts in the field are invited to participate as guest speakers.

PERI.title: Seminar: Special Topics in Periodontology and Implantology
PERI.description: Thematic review of the contemporary literature, knowledge, discoveries, inventions, and developments in periodontology and implantology.

PERI.title: Seminar: Special Topics in Periodontology and Implantology
PERI.description: Thematic review of the contemporary literature, knowledge, discoveries, inventions, and developments in periodontology and implantology.

PERI.title: Advanced Periodontal Instrumentation
PERI.description: Advanced root preparation techniques including design and manufacturing characteristics of various instruments, sharpening techniques, and root morphology as it relates to advanced instrumentation principles.

PERI.title: Clinic: Advanced Periodontics
PERI.description: Clinical experience in the treatment of patients with all types  and degrees of involvement of periodontal disease.  Includes  placement of dental implants.  Graded CR/NC.

PERI.title: Clinic: Advanced Periodontics
PERI.description: Clinical experience in the treatment of patients with all types and degrees of involvement of periodontal disease. Includes placement of dental implants.  Graded CR/NC.

PERI.description: Clinical experience in the treatment of patients with all types and degrees of involvement of periodontal disease. Includes placement of dental implants.  Graded CR/NC.

PERI.title: Clinic: Implant Surgery
PERI.description: Clinical procedures in dental implant surgery and site development for prosthodontic rehabilitation.

OPR.title: Oral Pathology and Maxillofacial Medicine
OPR.description: Review of oral diseases affecting the oral cavity which includes developmental conditions, pigmented lesions, Immune-Mediated and Allergic Conditions, mucosal and connective tissue abnormalities.

GPR.title: Dental Ethics
GPR.description: Residents prepare for ethical dilemmas which may occur when they are practicing dentistry. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Practice Management
GPR.description: Residents learn the tools and principles of running or working in a private practice. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Review of General Dentistry Literature
GPR.description: Residents learn how to research various topics and to critically review each article in order to practice evidence-based dentistry. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Emergency Medicine
GPR.description: Residents utilize medical knowledge to detect and identify early signs of medical emergencies. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Forensic Dentistry
GPR.description: Introduction to Forensic Odontology. Residents to learn the principles of Dental Forensics. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Treating Medically Compromised Dental Patients
GPR.description: Residents learn of various medical problems, how they relate to dental treatment and how to manage patients with various medical problems. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Endodontics for GPR Residents
GPR.description: Reviews and teaches the residents to understand various endodontic topics via seminars and patient cases.

GPR.title: Periodontal Treatment Procedures
GPR.description: Presentation of various techniques in current periodontal          treatment. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Treatment Planning
GPR.description: Residents lead seminars with case presentations of complex multidisciplinary treatment plans, completed therapy and staff conferences. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
GPR.description: More advanced instruction in oral and maxillofacial surgery and related diseases as appropriate to the practice of general dentistry; extensive clinical experience. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Implantology
GPR.description: Residents recognize the importance of implant dentistry and various implant systems and their restorative options. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Implantology
GPR.description: Residents recognize the importance of implant dentistry and various implant systems and their restorative options. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Occlusion, TMJ Dysfunction, Orofacial Pain
GPR.description: Residents review the important role that Occlusion plays in General Dentistry and neuromuscular problems of the head and neck. Graded CR/NC.

GPR.title: Advanced and Maxillofacial Prosthodontics
GPR.description: Residents train to treat patients requiring various types of removable and fixed prosthetics, including Maxillofacial prostheses. Graded CR/NC.

OFP.title: TMD, Orthopedics, Rheumatology, and Physical Therapy
OFP.description: Prevalence, differential diagnosis, prevention and management  for the common and uncommon temporomandibular, arthrogenous, motor, mobility and growth disorders occurring in the oral  region.

OFP.title: Pharmacology Series
OFP.description: Educate dental graduate students about the general pharmacologic principles and appropriate use of specific pharmaco-therapeutic classes of drugs.

OFP.title: Case Portfolio Preparation
OFP.description: Case portfolio preparation with weekly online  presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases.

OFP.title: Case Portfolio Preparation
OFP.description: Case portfolio preparation with weekly online presentations and discussions of de-identified patient cases.

PEDO.title: Seminar: Advanced Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Discussion of literature related to specialty practice of  pediatric dentistry.  Biologic considerations in operative  dentistry, odontogenesis, dental trauma, physiology of occlusion,  pulpal biology.  Graded CR/NC.

PEDO.title: Comprehensive Review of Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Critical analysis of current pediatric dentistry literature and    case conferences related to the application of contemporary issues in dentistry for the complex child patient.

PEDO.title: Comprehensive Review of Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Critical analysis of current pediatric dentistry literature and case conferences related to the application of contemporary issues in dentistry for the complex child patient.

PEDO.title: Interceptive Orthodontics
PEDO.description: Recognition, evaluation, and treatment of developing orthodontic problems appropriate to the pediatric dentist; emphasis on diagnosis; laboratory experience included.

PEDO.title: Interceptive Orthodontics
PEDO.description: Recognition, evaluation, and treatment of developing orthodontic problems appropriate to the pediatric dentist; emphasis on diagnosis; laboratory experience included.

PEDO.title: Pediatric Diseases
PEDO.description: Discussion of medical conditions seen by the pediatric dentist in  the hospital environment.  Conditions include childhood cancer,  HIV, heart disease, diabetes mellitus and blood dyscrasias.   Graded CR/NC.

PEDO.title: Seminar: Cleft Palate Rehabilitation
PEDO.description: 3 Trimester Course Discussions and case conferences related to treatment of patients with oral and facial anomalies: includes interceptive and corrective orthodontics, preventive and restorative treatment, and selected oral surgery-prosthetic rehabilitative procedures. Seminar, 3 hours.

PEDO.title: Practice Management
PEDO.description: Discussion of issues related to the contemporary practice of  pediatric dentistry (seminars and office visitations).  Topics  include: purchasing a practice, associateships, hospital  affiliations, practice administration and marketing, computers,  jurispudence and auxiliary utilization.  Graded CR/NC.

PEDO.title: Clinic: Advanced Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Clinical application of advanced pediatric dentistry techniques in  routine and special problem cases in the outpatient environment.   Hours vary.  Graded CR/NC.

PEDO.title: Clinic: Hospital Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Treatment of the child patient in the hospital envionment. Emphasis placed on treatment and management of children with physical, mental or emotional disabilities.

PEDO.title: Clinic: Interceptive Orthodontics
PEDO.description: Clinical application and treatment procedures for tooth guidance,  stet and interceptive orthodontics.

PEDO.title: Clinic: Interceptive Orthodontics
PEDO.description: Clinical application and teatment procedures for tooth guidance,  stet and interceptive orthodontics.

PEDO.title: Hospital Pediatric Clinics
PEDO.description: Observation and participation in affiliated hospital clinics:     anesthesiology, hematology, and genetic clinics; grand pediatric   rounds andother conferences.

PEDO.title: Clinical Genetics in Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: Genetic principles of oral, facial, and cranial malformations;     technique and theory of clinical genetics, differential diagnosis, and treatment of disorders of the craniofacial complex.

PEDO.title: Directed Research: Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in  dentistry for children leading to completion of an original  research project.  Graded CR/NC.

PEDO.title: Directed Research: Pediatric Dentistry
PEDO.description: An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in  dentistry for children leading to completion of an original  research project.  Graded CR/NC.

DANC.title: Colloquium I: Joining the Creative Community
DANC.description: Introduction to a vibrant creative community. Students will explore university resources, engage with faculty, guest artists and staff, and establish goals for sustainability and growth.

DANC.title: Conditioning for Dancers
DANC.description: Designed for the specific needs of the dancer in preparation for professional training, combining somatic work with the foundation of scientific principles.

DANC.title: World Perspective on Dance Performance
DANC.description: The practice and aesthetics of international dance styles through lecture and participant-driven interaction.

DANC.title: Dance Technique I
DANC.description: Fundamental technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development. Placement audition required.

DANC.title: Repertory and Performance I
DANC.description: Study and guided practice of choreographic repertory. Emphasis in choreographic intention, stylistic approaches and performance technique.

DANC.title: Composition: Improvisation and Exploration
DANC.description: An introduction to diverse approaches in improvisation and dancemaking, with special emphasis on how compositional concerns play out in space, time, and physical form.

DANC.title: Sound and Music Studies for Dancers
DANC.description: Acquire skills that can be used to further develop movement, choreography and collaborative work through musicianship, musical score reading and the elements of music composition.

DANC.title: Choreography and Performance
DANC.description: Compositional methods and approaches to developing choreographic ideas; integration of improvisational techniques as a means to generate movement ideas and expand movement vocabulary, edit choreographic material, and evaluate and execute choreography and performance.

DANC.title: Contemporary Dance
DANC.description: An introduction to methods developed from modern and post-modern dance techniques, including the study of the rebellious, individualistic, and democratic nature of dance in the 20th and 21st centuries.

DANC.title: Ballet
DANC.description: An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

DANC.title: Ballet
DANC.description: Continued study of Classical Ballet technique with intermediate-level barre and center work, focusing on developing greater clarity, coordination, musicality, and knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

DANC.title: Ballet
DANC.description: Intermediate/advanced study of Classical Ballet technique with emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Introduction of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.

DANC.title: Ballet
DANC.description: Advanced/pre-professional study of Classical Ballet, continuing and deepening emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Further development of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.

DANC.title: Jazz Dance
DANC.description: An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.

DANC.title: Jazz Dance
DANC.description: Advanced study of Jazz Dance technique, focusing on Broadway, commercial, and concert Jazz Dance, with a continued emphasis on improvisation, center work, and performance techniques.

DANC.title: Hip Hop Dance
DANC.description: An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.

DANC.title: Breaking
DANC.description: An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.

DANC.title: Hip Hop Dance
DANC.description: Continued study of Hip Hop Dance elements on an intermediate level, augmenting the historical context, technique, fluidity, and musicality required to execute the form with greater movement acuity.

DANC.title: International Style Ballroom Dance
DANC.description: Introduction to International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of ballroom dance, emphasizing partner connection, communication, and creativity, with the practical application of dance within a social setting.

DANC.title: International Style Ballroom Dance
DANC.description: Continued study in International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed for advanced knowledge in ballroom styles, emphasizing rhythmic sequences, partnering techniques, complex patterns, and performance quality.

DANC.title: Tap Dance
DANC.description: An introduction to basic Tap Dance technique, rhythms, syncopation, and musicality, developing into complex steps and elementary dances with progressive understanding of weight change, improvisation, and combinations of sound.

DANC.title: Gaga: People
DANC.description: Explore the movement language, rooted in guided improvisation, developed by Ohad Naharin of Batsheva Dance Company. Open to all, regardless of dance or movement background.

DANC.title: Colloquium II: Investing in the Collaboratory
DANC.description: Continued investment in the creative community, with a focus on best practices for sharing work, soliciting feedback and establishing healthy relationships with fellow creators.

DANC.title: Dance Technique II
DANC.description: Intermediate technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development.

DANC.title: Dance in Popular Culture
DANC.description: Examination of the role of dance in popular culture in a classroom setting. Studies of dance styles and their evolution in recreational and professional contexts through research, observation, and practice.

DANC.title: Repertory and Performance II
DANC.description: Continued studies and guided practice of choreographic repertory. Investigation of choreographic vocabulary, intention, stylistic approaches, and performance technique for group work.

DANC.title: Composition: Collaborative Foundations
DANC.description: An introduction to collaborative creation across disciplinary boundaries, working toward the integration of varied design elements into choreographic composition.

DANC.title: Introduction to Dance as an Art Form
DANC.description: Gateway to the minor in dance.  An interdisciplinary overview of dance relating to the aesthetic and art in various subjects. Applications of the elements of dance studies, art criticism, and viewing productions to explore topic such as architecture, photography, poetry, technology, cinematic arts, sports, medicine, and more.

DANC.title: Colloquium III: Clarifying Personal Pathways
DANC.description: Clarification of long-term goals, establishment of a unique artistic identity, and contextualization of creative work within broader social, political and cultural contexts.

DANC.title: Hip Hop Don't Stop: Black Social Dance Culture and Media
DANC.description: Introduction to the history and practice of Urban Folk Dance including hip hop, freestyle, street dance and the relevant social dances of the 20th century.

DANC.title: Dance Science: Analysis of Dance Movement
DANC.description: A broad overview of the scientific principles of exercise physiology, functional anatomy, kinesiology, and bio-mechanics with applications to dance.

DANC.title: Dance and Feminine Sexuality
DANC.description: Analyzes gender and sexuality in dance by investigating a broad, international framework of embodied performance including film, television, music videos and live performance.

DANC.title: Dance Technique III
DANC.description: Advanced technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development.

DANC.title: African American Dance
DANC.description: Exploration of the discursive foundations, political motivations, and aesthetic strategies of dance writers and artists whose works have enabled the category of "black dance."

DANC.title: Repertory and Performance III
DANC.description: Study and guided practice of new works and developing roles. Emphasis on the dancer as collaborator in the creative process.

DANC.title: Origins of Jazz Dance
DANC.description: Examining the role that vernacular dance and music play in the creation of Jazz Dance, taught in lecture format; practical studies in Jazz Dance, from recreational to professional settings.

DANC.title: International and Historical Perspectives on Dance
DANC.description: Exploration of dance as an art form in its artistic, political, and socio-cultural climate. Studies of the continuum of dance within its historical context.

DANC.title: What is Contemporary Dance Today?
DANC.description: An embodied encounter with prominent practitioners in the field. Students will experience an array of technical vocabularies, repertory and strategies for improvisation and composition.

DANC.title: Advanced Composition
DANC.description: Explore a variety of compositional forms and methods to develop a personalized choreographic approach.

DANC.title: Pilates Mat Training
DANC.description: Mat exercises designed to promote healthy movement practices, develop strength, balance, flexibility and coordination.

DANC.title: Dance Technique IV
DANC.description: Pre-professional technique studies in a studio setting with concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development.

DANC.title: Repertory and Performance IV
DANC.description: Study and guided practice of significant roles in new and existing choreography. Emphasis on refinement of partnering, solo and group performance technique.

DANC.title: Fourth-Year Seminar
DANC.description: Seminar and studio course in preparation of the senior project to be presented in spring semester, in performance, choreography, scholarship or entrepreneurship.

DANC.title: Directed Research
DANC.description: Individual research and readings.

EDCO.title: Ethical and Legal Issues in Counseling
EDCO.description: Examination of current legal, ethical, and other professional issues in the practice of counseling and psychotherapy.

EDCO.title: Theories in Counseling
EDCO.description: Theory, research, and practice of psychological counseling.        Includes laboratory experience.

EDCO.title: Counseling as an Act of Love
EDCO.description: Love is explored as a guiding force in educational counseling towards movements of equity and social justice.

EDCO.title: Internship
EDCO.description: Supervised practicum experience in a clinical setting.

EDCO.title: Internship
EDCO.description: Supervised practicum experience in a clinical setting.

EDUE.title: History of Higher Education
EDUE.description: Examination of roles and functions of higher education from historical and contemporary perspectives, with a focus on equity and urban education.

EDUE.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
EDUE.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

EDUE.title: Leadership as a Critical Practice
EDUE.description: Focuses on leadership identity and critical self-reflection to develop effective, equity-minded and human-centered leadership practices.

EDUE.title: Foundations of Research
EDUE.description: Quantitative and qualitative research methods; critical analysis of existing studies;  effective academic writing and synthesis skills.

EDUE.title: Cultural Humility in Leadership and Practice
EDUE.description: Facilitate culturally responsive interventions in mental health leadership. Address racial disparities; design, apply and assess diversity, equity and inclusion programming.

EDUE.title: Organization Leadership:  Theory and Practice
EDUE.description: Apply organizational frameworks for mental health leadership. Introduce theory to enhance service delivery, prioritize client care and promote societal impact.

EDUE.title: Foundations in Urban Education
EDUE.description: Explores urban P-20 education through social, historical, and political lenses and how research and policy shape professional practice in Los Angeles and the United States.

EDUE.title: Foundations in Leadership in Education
EDUE.description: Provides foundational knowledge about leadership theory and practice to support students development as critically conscious leaders who take action to address inequities in urban contexts.

EDUE.title: Learning and Instruction in Professional Contexts
EDUE.description: Develop skills to teach in diverse professional settings. Emphasize adult education philosophy, instructional design, technology integration, assessment and personal teaching philosophy development.

EDUE.title: Advanced Clinical Assessment
EDUE.description: Enhance skills related to analysis and application of assessment, psychometric trends, ethical diagnosis, treatment and culturally competent leadership. Interpret and critique psychological testing.

EDUE.title: Curriculum and Instructional Leadership
EDUE.description: Social, political, economic and scholarly factors determining curriculum and instructional design and implementation and implications for formal and informal leaders in P-20 contexts are explored.

EDUE.title: Inter-Disciplinary Curriculum, Instruction and   Assessment P-20
EDUE.description: Educational leaders utilize spatial data and technologies to study their leadership trajectories across urban P-20 settings and bring inter-disciplinary approaches to curriculum, instruction, and assessment.

EDUE.title: Research Methods 1
EDUE.description: Explores the historically complex relationship between education research, education (in)equity and personal practice, and will highlight the possibilities of research to foster justice in education through the examination of the utility of basic and applied quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods research.

EDUE.title: Dissertation in Practice, Data Analysis
EDUE.description: Builds students' knowledge and skills for analyzing quantitative and qualitative data and reporting results and findings for their Dissertations in Practice.

EDUE.title: Dissertation in Practice, Data Analysis
EDUE.description: Builds students' knowledge and skills for analyzing quantitative and qualitative data and reporting results and findings for their Dissertations in Practice.

EDUE.title: Dissertation in Practice, Data Analysis
EDUE.description: Builds students knowledge and skills for analyzing quantitative and qualitative data and reporting results and findings for their Dissertations in Practice.

EDUE.title: Dissertation in Practice, Data Analysis
EDUE.description: Builds students knowledge and skills for analyzing quantitative and qualitative data and reporting results and findings for their Dissertations in Practice.

EDUE.title: Dissertation in Practice, Data Analysis
EDUE.description: Builds students knowledge and skills for analyzing quantitative and qualitative data and reporting results and findings for their Dissertations in Practice.

EDPT.title: Learning and Individual Differences
EDPT.description: Theory and research in learning, development and individual differences, and social psychology related to education in instructional or training contexts.

EDHP.title: Practicum in Higher, Adult and Professional Education
EDHP.description: Structured participation in supervised teaching or administrative activities. Assignments matched with student's goals, training, experience.

EDHP.title: Master's Seminar
EDHP.description: An examination and analysis of research and literature in the  student's area of focus.  Required for all master's candidates who  do not enroll in the Master's Thesis (594abz).  Graded CR/NC.

EDHP.title: Master's Thesis
EDHP.description: Required for all master's candidates who do not enroll in the  Master's Seminar (593ab).  Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded  IP/CR/NC.

EDHP.title: Legal Issues in the Administration of Higher Education
EDHP.description: Analysis of legal issues related to the administration of higher education; emphasis on relations with students, faculty, staff, alumni, and campus communities.

EDHP.title: Student Development in Higher Education
EDHP.description: Theories of college student development and application of developmental models to program design, interventions, outreach, and research programs.

EDUC.title: Undergraduate Research Methods
EDUC.description: Examination of processes of scholarly research; quantitative and qualitative research methods; faculty mentorship; experiential learning; research proposal writing; careers in research. Sophomore or junior standing in the major. Departmental approval.

EDUC.title: Global Issues: Impact on Educational Outcomes
EDUC.description: Situates U.S. education within the global context and examines the impact of global issues on national and international schooling in the 21st Century.

EDUC.title: Unrealized Promise and Hope for Education in 21st Century
EDUC.description: Investigates the promise of education and often-failed outcomes though the lens of literacy/language.  Focuses on literacy to promote student agency for successful educational attainment.

EDUC.title: The Counseling Process
EDUC.description: Theoretical foundations, models, values, and assumptions underlying psychological counseling; cross-cultural perspectives, ethical and legal considerations.

EDUC.title: Principles of Learning and Motivation for Design
EDUC.description: Design and advancement of learning and motivation outcomes in various environments through a systematic examination and application of current research.

EDUC.title: Interrogating Systems of Inequity in Professional Practice
EDUC.description: Framing the graduate experience for master's students. Examining self and field of professional practice in the context of achieving equity.

EDUC.title: Introduction to Counseling
EDUC.description: The role of the school counselor. An overview of key elements in increasing access to and equity for primary and secondary education for all students.

EDUC.title: Career and College Readiness Counseling
EDUC.description: Theoretical foundations of individual and systemic characteristics that impact college and career choices. Consideration of economic, political, social and policy issues.

EDUC.title: Assessment and Instruction for Diverse Language Learners
EDUC.description: Assessment practices and strategies in English language instruction with special attention to learner differences (social, cultural, physical, intellectual) that influence academic performance. Open only to MAT TESOL and TESOL (online) students.

EDUC.title: Accountability for Organizational Change
EDUC.description: Accountability through an organizational change and leadership perspective.

EDUC.title: Equity and Inclusion in Organizational Contexts
EDUC.description: Diversity issues in urban educational settings. Open only to EdD students.

EDUC.title: Challenges in Urban Education: Leadership
EDUC.description: Theories, principles, and concepts of leadership in urban K-12  schools and institutions of higher education.  Open only to Ed.D.  students.

EDUC.title: Inquiry Methods I
EDUC.description: Logic and methods of quantitative data analysis in the examination  of educational issues and the framing of solutions for them.  Open  only to Ed.D. students.

EDUC.title: Inquiry Methods II
EDUC.description: Logic and methods of qualitative data analysis in the examination of educational issues and the framing of solutions for them. Open only to EdD students.

EDUC.title: Collaboration, Consultation and Assessment in Counseling
EDUC.description: Understand educational and psychological instruments, psychometric concepts and rationale for the use of instruments in the school counseling setting.

EDUC.title: Substance Abuse Counseling
EDUC.description: Focus on theoretical models of substance abuse counseling and understanding the role of assessment, treatment, medical and psychological complications, family and recovery.

EDUC.title: Family Counseling
EDUC.description: Master family counseling approaches, systemic models of K-12 family functioning and therapeutic interventions to work with families of diverse backgrounds.

EDUC.title: Psychopathology for Marriage and Family Therapy
EDUC.description: Theories of psychological impairment emphasizing diagnosis of child and family dysfunction. Practice in utilizing DSM-IV classification of case studies.

EDUC.title: Career Development: Theory and Process
EDUC.description: Theories and process of career development; principles of career and leisure planning and counseling applicable throughout life.

EDUC.title: Applied Linguistics for Language Teachers
EDUC.description: Supports candidates in becoming reflective practitioners who approach language teaching with the knowledge of language structures and processes of language acquisition and learning.

EDUC.title: Research Methods and Data Analysis
EDUC.description: Various research designs and their appropriateness for addressing different research questions. Threats to validity and other challenges in research. Basic statistical methods and their use. Recommended preparation: beginning statistics course.

EDUC.title: Language Teaching:  Planning, Instruction, and Assessment
EDUC.description: Creating and facilitating inclusive language learning activities grounded in the latest technology. Emphasizing equitable instruction, targeted feedback and reflective practice for continuous teaching environment.

EDUC.title: Counseling through the Lifespan
EDUC.description: Developmental issues and life events from infancy to old age and  their effect upon individuals, couples, and family relationships.

EDUC.title: Master's Studio A
EDUC.description: Students propose and design a capstone project that applies knowledge and skills learned throughout the program and prepare a coursework portfolio.

EDUC.title: Directed Research
EDUC.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which  may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

EDUC.title: Transformative Advocacy in Language Education
EDUC.description: Students will identify critical issues in language learning, conducting action research, and developing community support plans for collaborative advocacy with stakeholders to drive transformative change.

EDUC.title: Transformative Advocacy for Language Educators
EDUC.description: Selected topics in various areas of education.

EDUC.title: AI and Learning Technologies
EDUC.description: Selected topics in various areas of education.

EDUC.title: Seminar in Social Psychology
EDUC.description: Problems and theories of the person in the social context. Person perception, interpersonal relations, attitude dynamics, social systems.

EDUC.title: School Connectedness, Climate, and Classroom Management
EDUC.description: Prevention, education, and training for achievement. Data collection for assessment and evaluation of school climate, crisis and classroom management conducive to learning and success.

EDUC.title: Application of Human Development Theory in School Counseling
EDUC.description: A theoretical perspective of human development across the lifespan. Issues and challenges faced by school counselors.

EDUC.title: The Student Athlete in Higher Education
EDUC.description: Examination of student athletes in higher education. Effective  strategies for counseling and advising college student athletes;  issues and challenges of athletic amateurism.

EDUC.title: Educational Organizations: Governance and Finance I
EDUC.description: Overview of economic concepts of education. Linkages between economic growth, development, and education. Impact of globalization.

EDUC.title: Education Performance Problems: Role of Learning
EDUC.description: Contemporary perspectives on learning and motivation. Strategies and tools for identifying, diagnosing, and solving learning and motivational challenges and opportunities.

EDUC.title: Educational Organizations: Governance and Finance II
EDUC.description: Diversification and differentiation of educational institutions globally. The finances of higher education. Open only to doctoral students.

EDUC.title: Perspectives on Human Sexuality
EDUC.description: The physiological-psychological and socio-cultural variables associated with sexual identity and sexual behavior with an emphasis upon sexual dysfunctions.

EDUC.title: Group Counseling: Theory and Process
EDUC.description: Theory, research, and practice of group counseling. Includes laboratory experience.

EDUC.title: Multicultural Counseling: Research and Practice
EDUC.description: An examination of the cultural, socioeconomic, and language factors that impact historically marginalized populations; alternative multicultural counseling approaches.

EDUC.title: Practicum II
EDUC.description: Supervised practicum experience in a clinical setting.

EDUC.title: Teaching Practice to Support Language Learners
EDUC.description: Introduces components of effective teaching, including lesson and unit planning, creating a classroom environment conducive to learning, and classroom management strategies.

EDUC.title: Inquiry Methods III
EDUC.description: Logic and methods of qualitative data analysis in the examination of educational issues and the framing of solutions for them.

EDUC.title: Clinical Practice Seminar in Language Teaching
EDUC.description: First of two-course series focused on helping students translate theory to practice. Designed for students completing fieldwork required for the teaching credential.

EDUC.title: Race and Racism in Education
EDUC.description: Race, racism, racial equity, Critical Race Theory (CRT) will be explored particularly within educational institutions, with a heavy focus placed on practice.

EDUC.title: Foundations and Design of Educational Research
EDUC.description: Build knowledge, skills and perspective to design and carry out scholarship as an educational researcher.

EDUC.title: Mixed Methods Research
EDUC.description: Explore theoretical and practical issues surrounding quantitative and qualitative methods in educational research.

EDUC.title: Applications of Curriculum and Pedagogy, Part A
EDUC.description: Candidates apply content-area knowledge utilizing a repertoire of pedagogical practices responsive to the needs and interests of diverse learners.

EDUC.title: Identifying and Teaching to Student Differences
EDUC.description: Building on EDUC 671, course proceeds with greater focus on learner behavior, ability, and language to access strategies to differentiate, scaffold, and assess learning.

EDUC.title: Literacy Development and Instruction in Elementary Education
EDUC.description: Literacy development and instruction, with a focus on the importance of literacy for academic success and civic participation.

EDUC.title: Literacy Development and Instruction in Secondary Education
EDUC.description: Prepares prospective secondary teachers to integrate literacy instruction within their content area by creating authentic opportunities for learners to develop literacy skills.

EDUC.title: Research, Policy and Practice in Urban Education
EDUC.description: Development of urban education through the social, historical and political lens as it shapes and influences education research and policy.

EDUC.title: Introduction to Quantitative Research Methods in Education
EDUC.description: Basic concepts of quantitative/statistical methods common in education research, emphasizing applications with data.  Introduces sampling, types of validity, statistical inference, bivariate analysis, internal/external validity.

EDUC.title: Proseminar in Education
EDUC.description: Introduction to faculty and their research; provides professional development on a variety of topics.

EDUC.title: Enhancing Student Retention
EDUC.description: Examines how student characteristics are associated with persistence and graduation, how rates vary with institutional type, and the institutional role in student success.

EDUC.title: Administration in Higher Education
EDUC.description: Administrative issues in higher education. Academic leadership  related to undergraduate and graduate education. Quality standards  and assessment. How administrators create efficiency,  effectiveness, performance, and change.

EDUC.title: Financing and Assessing Colleges for Equity
EDUC.description: Examination of federal, state, local and individual roles in financing of higher education towards enhancing equity and reducing opportunity gaps.

EDUC.title: Advanced Study of Motivation: Theory, Research and Applicati
EDUC.description: Analysis of motivational principles; diagnosis and solutions to motivation gaps in learning environments; and motivation and efficacy theories and principles.

EDUC.title: Measurement and Evaluation for Decision-Making
EDUC.description: Collecting, analyzing, and using quantitative data to solve  problems of practice and in evaluating educational institutions,  programs, and policies.

EDUC.title: Resourcing Schools for Equity and Excellence
EDUC.description: Applying economic theory to the study of education. Application of market theory to education, partnerships, allocation of resources and the examination of educational enterprises.

EDUC.title: Education Policy and Politics
EDUC.description: Major issues facing educators in the 21st century. Emphasis on how educational policy can focus on incentives for schools to improve student learning.

EDUC.title: Analyzing Organizational Change and Its Effectiveness
EDUC.description: Designed to help leaders apply research about learning and motivation to the strengthening of organizational performance in organizations around the world.

EDUC.title: Making Choices: Deciding Among Policy Alternatives
EDUC.description: Models of decision making including cost-benefit analysis, risk-benefit analysis, and decision analysis. Ethical considerations and the political environment. Open only to doctoral students.

EDUC.title: Global Trends: Emerging Ideas, Emerging Markets
EDUC.description: Examination of a range of emerging markets in education. Global efforts of institutions of higher education to access new markets through collaborations and offshore endeavors.

EDUC.title: Organizational Change and Communication Practices
EDUC.description: Examine importance of communication in facilitating organizational change, motivation and buy-in during times of transition. Learn how effective communication is dependent on trust and empathy.

EDUC.title: Economics of Organizational Change and Learning Environments
EDUC.description: Leadership, problem solving, communication, research, reflection, and professional dispositions will concurrently expand. Candidates will acquire the knowledge and skills to identify and implement economic change.

EDUC.title: Building Capacity for Organizational Change
EDUC.description: Focuses on learning issues related to building organizational capacity for change through leadership and development of personnel within an organization.

EDUC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation in Practice.
