CHE.title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
CHE.description: Problem-solving techniques in chemical engineering, including an introduction to engineering problem analysis, mass balances, and energy balances.

CHE.title: Numerical and Statistical Analysis for Chemical Engineers
CHE.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms, computational tools, principles of probability and statistics, and their application to chemical engineering problems.

CHE.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
CHE.description: Basic laws, energy and entropy balances.  Multi-component phase behavior. Physical and chemical equilibria. Energy conversion and equilibrium separation processes, estimation and use of property data.

CHE.title: Principles and Applications of Systems Biology
CHE.description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.

CHE.title: Chemical Engineering Fluid Mechanics
CHE.description: Fundamental principles of fluid mechanics and momentum transfer applied to chemical engineering and chemical processing operations.

CHE.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CHE.description: Conduct experiments and analyze data to generate results used to solve chemical engineering problems. Communicate results, data, and solutions in written reports and oral presentations.

CHE.title: Sustainable Energy
CHE.description: Overview of sustainable energy, with emphasis on quantitative approaches to evaluate sustainability and examination of renewable sources of energy from the perspective of sustainability.

CHE.title: Chemical Process Dynamics and Control
CHE.description: Dynamic analysis and automation of chemical processes using closed loop control schemes.  Control schemes are analyzed, simulated and implemented in the laboratory.

CHE.title: Physical Properties of Polymers
CHE.description: Introduction to polymer physical properties and characterization, relationship to synthesis techniques and processing techniques, natural and synthetic materials, property optimization and modern applications.

CHE.title: Computer-Aided Chemical Process Design
CHE.description: Simulate, design and optimize chemical engineering unit operations and process using modern process simulation software.

CHE.title: Directed Research
CHE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CHE.title: Modeling and Analysis of Chemical Engineering Systems
CHE.description: Advanced treatment of mathematical modeling and analysis of Chemical Engineering core topics including fluid flow, heat and mass transfer, reaction engineering, and deformation of materials.

CHE.title: Energy and Process Efficiency
CHE.description: Systematic engineering practices to augment energy efficiency while minimizing associated economic expenditures; encompasses a wide-ranging analysis of various power generation modalities.

CHE.title: Mathematical Methods for Deep Learning
CHE.description: Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical  and life sciences and computer science with mathematical  background.

CHE.title: Transport Processes I
CHE.description: Fundamentals of transport processes - momentum, heat and mass transfer - in systems of interest to chemical engineering.

CHE.title: Chemical Engineering Kinetics
CHE.description: Advanced concepts in Reaction Engineering and Reactor Design.

CHE.title: Seminars in Chemical Engineering
CHE.description: Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers.

CHE.title: Directed Research
CHE.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHE.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CE.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering
CE.description: Introduction to the civil engineering discipline, subdisciplines, technology and problem solving; technical report writing; contemporary civil engineering topics; engineering ethics.

CE.title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
CE.description: Basic concepts of environmental engineering including topics of water, land, energy, air, climate, resource management, human society and professional development.

CE.title: Statistical Data Analysis in Engineering
CE.description: Data exploration and visualization, fundamentals of probability distributions and statistical inference (including notions of confidence interval, maximum likelihood, regression).

CE.title: Statics and Dynamics
CE.description: Statics, kinematics and kinetics of  systems of particles and rigid bodies; equivalent force systems; distributed forces and applications; moments of inertia, momentum, energy; vibrations; Eulers equations.

CE.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
CE.description: Basic material science, atomic bonding, crystalline structures, structural and mechanical behavior and characterization of metals, concrete, wood, composites and asphalt.

CE.title: Elementary Theory of Structures
CE.description: Deformations and deflections of elastic systems; statically indeterminate beams, arches, and frames; secondary stresses; computer analysis of simple structural systems.

CE.title: Risk and Decision Analysis in Civil Engineering
CE.description: Introduction to probabilistic concepts and to the formulation and solution of related problems in civil and environmental engineering.

CE.title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering Microbiology
CE.description: Fundamentals and applications of microbiology in the context of natural and engineered environmental systems.

CE.title: Coastal Engineering and Design
CE.description: Fundamentals of wave motion and coastal wave transformation. Statistical analysis of oceanographic conditions. Basics of coastal infrastructure design and coastal planning.

CE.title: Water Quality Science and Engineering
CE.description: Water quality criteria and fundamentals of acceptability; processes employed in treatment of water and wastewater; water reclamation and reuse; sustainability in water and wastewater systems.

CE.title: Structural Design I
CE.description: Structural design processes for wood, steel, concrete, and masonry structural beams, columns, and connections; determination of structural loads; framing systems; and applications of structural mechanics to the design process.

CE.title: Introduction to Structural Dynamics
CE.description: Response of single and multiple degree of freedom systems to dynamic excitation; structural modeling and approximate solutions; introduction to earthquake resistant design.

CE.title: Construction Engineering
CE.description: Introduction to the construction processes; estimating and bidding, construction administration, planning and scheduling, equipment and methods, labor relations, cost control systems, safety and ethics.

CE.title: Sustainable Design and Construction
CE.description: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED); green building strategies; carbon footprinting; calculating the embodied energy of building materials; cyclical processes in design and construction.

CE.title: Building Information Modeling: Project Visualization and Sim
CE.description: Building Information Modeling, current BIM technologies; coordination of design and construction; information management throughout building lifecycle; project visualization and simulation for integrated practice.

CE.title: Principles of Transportation Engineering
CE.description: Planning, design, construction, maintenance, and operation of facilities for air, water, rail and highway transit systems.

CE.title: Subsurface Foundation Design
CE.description: Site exploration and characterization; analysis and design of structural foundations, including spread footings, mats, piles and drilled shafts; retaining wall and braced excavation design.

CE.title: Water and Wastewater Treatment Design
CE.description: Engineering design of unit operations and processes for water and wastewater treatment: coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, disinfection; primary, secondary, tertiary, advanced treatment; sludge treatment and processing.

CE.title: Innovation in Engineering & Design: Global Grand Challenges
CE.description: The innovative and human-centered design of products, services, and technologies to help solve the needs of people affected by global crises

CE.title: Directed Research
CE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CE.title: Innovation in Engineering & Design: Global Grand Challenges
CE.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in civil engineering and related fields.

CE.title: Architecture, Engineering and Construction Practices
CE.description: Systems, processes, and constraints governing the initiation, direction, engineering, and delivery of major construction projects. Professional construction management, responsibilities, and practice.

CE.title: Construction Accounting, Finance and Strategy
CE.description: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

CE.title: Mechanics of Solids I
CE.description: Fundamental theory of  linear elasticity applicable to multiple branches of solid mechanics.

CE.title: Transportation Systems Analysis
CE.description: Economic and systems level aspects of transportation; traveler decision models; network performance; congestion pricing; resource allocation; revenue forecasting and project evaluation.

CE.title: Physiochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering
CE.description: Concepts and applications of physicochemical processes in engineered systems, including coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption and membrane processes.

CE.title: Finite Element Analysis
CE.description: Basic concepts; variational methods; isoparametric formulation; plane stress; plane strain; axisymmetric structures; plates and shells; structural dynamics; stability and buckling; computer applications; nonlinear analysis.

CE.title: Quantifying Uncertainty in Civil & Environmental Engineering
CE.description: Introduction to uncertainty quantification; fundamentals of probability theory, forward propagation of uncertainties, probabilistic inference from data; civil and environmental engineering applications.

CE.title: Advanced Steel Structures
CE.description: Structural steel and its properties, the design of typical steel buildings and design and performance of steel buildings for earthquake loads.

CE.title: Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
CE.description: Design of aerobic and anaerobic biological treatment processes for organic and inorganic pollutant removal and resource recovery from waste streams.

CE.title: Construction Planning and Preconstruction
CE.description: The steps and processes for the planning and pre-construction phases of a project using tools and technologies for budgeting, scheduling and planning.

CE.title: Advanced Technologies in AEC Practices
CE.description: Data-centric engineering paradigms, modeling and simulation technologies; applications for Architecture, Engineering and Construction (AEC) projects or challenges.

CE.title: Construction Means and Methods
CE.description: Job site logistics, field management, means and methods as they pertain to the builder, with an emphasis on constructability, productivity and schedule impacts for building construction.

CE.title: Data Analytics for Surface Transportation
CE.description: Investigating, analyzing, and incorporating data sources, case studies, and statistical tools to explore surface transportation systems.

CE.title: Directed Research
CE.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CE.title: Seismic Design of Structures
CE.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of civil engineering.

CE.title: Shallow Water Hydrodynamics
CE.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of civil engineering.

CE.title: Institutional and Policy Issues in Transportation
CE.description: Analysis of policies relating to transportation alternatives;     institutional environment and background; federal, state,          regional, and local agency responsibilities and interactions.

CE.description: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EIS.title: Information Literacy: Navigating Digital Misinformation
EIS.description: Analyze misinformation and disinformation on digital platforms using library research methodologies and applying information literacy principles. Examine how technology creates and disseminates information in society.

EIS.title: Technology and Society
EIS.description: Exploring and analyzing the ethical and social impact of technological innovation and advancement through humanities-based inquiry.

EIS.title: Ethical Issues in Artificial Intelligence
EIS.description: Ethical issues in artificial intelligence including algorithmic bias and interpretability, data privacy and control, autonomous systems and relationships with AI entities.

EIS.title: German Sustainability Discourse and Engineering              Communication
EIS.description: Selected topics in Engineering in Society.

EIS.title: Writing Skills for Engineering PhD Students
EIS.description: Writing of engineering curriculum- and research-related projects for PhD students. Focus is on conference papers, dissertations and proposals, journal articles and other forms.

ASTE.title: Introduction to Astronautics
ASTE.description: Gateway to the Astronautical Engineering major.  Introduction to  space, space exploration and the space business.  Elements of  orbits, spacecraft systems, rocket propulsion, and  communications.  Laboratory: introduction to graphics, computation  and simulation.

ASTE.title: Rpl-Lpl
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior  project experience.  Departmental approval.

ASTE.title: SERC Projects
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior  project experience.  Departmental approval.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Systems Engineering
ASTE.description: Spacecraft subsystems and the space environment. Systems engineering as applied to spacecraft.  Propulsion; attitude; control and data handling; flight software; telecommunications; power; thermal control; payloads.

ASTE.title: Computational Programming and Numerical Methods
ASTE.description: Development of simulation code with high-performance languages such as C++ and Fortran; numerical techniques for continuum and rarefied gas flows, GPU utilization; data visualization, machine learning.

ASTE.title: Rocket Propulsion
ASTE.description: Liquid-fueled and solid-fueled rocket engines; adiabatic flame temperature; duct flows with area change, heat addition, mass addition; rocket heat transfer; staging; and electric  thrusters.

ASTE.title: Directed Research
ASTE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ASTE.title: Rpl-Lpl
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for students with prior project experience.  Departmental  approval.

ASTE.title: SERC Projects
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for students with prior project experience.  Departmental  approval.

ASTE.title: Physical Gas Dynamics
ASTE.description: Molecular structure; radiative processes; microscopic description  of gas phenomena; translational, rotational, vibrational, and      electronic freedom degrees; particle energy distributions;         microscopic representation of thermodynamic functions.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft System Design
ASTE.description: System components; vehicle structure, propulsion systems, flight dynamics, thermal control, power systems, telecommunication. Interfaces and tradeoffs between these components. Testing, system reliability, and integration.

ASTE.title: Human Spaceflight
ASTE.description: Engineering, technologies, and systems for human spaceflight. Life support, space environments, crew accommodations. Mission operations, safety. Astrodynamics, launch and space vehicles, space stations, planetary bases.

ASTE.title: Space Exploration Architectures Concept Synthesis Studio
ASTE.description: Programmatic/conceptual design synthesis/choice creation methods  for complex space missions.  Aerospace system  engineering/architecting tools to create innovative projects.   Evaluated by faculty/industry/NASA experts.  Graduate standing in  engineering or science.  Recommended preparation: ASTE-520 or  experience in space industry

ASTE.title: Reliability of Space Systems
ASTE.description: Reliable space system design and operations for human and robotic space, applications, and commercial space.  Reliability of space systems, subsystems, hardware, software and human reliability.

ASTE.title: Space Environments and Spacecraft Interactions
ASTE.description: Space environments and interactions with space systems.  Vacuum,  neutral and ionized species, plasma, radiation, micrometeoroids.   Phenomena important for spacecraft operations.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Thermal Control
ASTE.description: Spacecraft and orbit thermal environments; design, analysis, testing of spacecraft thermal control system and components; active and passive thermal control, spacecraft and launch vehicle interfaces. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Structural Strength and Materials
ASTE.description: Spacecraft structural strength analysis and design concepts overview; spacecraft material selection; analysis of composite materials; finite element method; spacecraft configuration; structural testing; bolted joint design.

ASTE.title: Ground Communications for Satellite Operations
ASTE.description: Theory, practice, architecture, operations of ground satellite communications with satellites. Practical implementation of satellite communications system and reception and analysis of satellite transmitted signals.

ASTE.title: Orbital Mechanics I
ASTE.description: Physical principles; two-body and central force motion; trajectory correction maneuvers; position and velocity in conic orbits; Lambert's problem; celestial mechanics; orbital perturbations.

ASTE.title: Space Navigation: Principles and Practice
ASTE.description: Statistical orbit determination: (weighted) least squares, batch  and sequential (Kalman) processing, illustrative examples; online  ephemeris generation: potentially hazardous asteroids, comets,  satellites; launch: vehicles, payloads, staging.  Graduate  standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE  580

ASTE.title: Directed Research
ASTE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the division.  Graded  CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Engineering Honors Colloquium
ENGR.description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Engineering Honors Colloquium
ENGR.description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Engineering Freshman Academy
ENGR.description: Introduction to the profession of engineering. Ethical, political and societal consequences of engineering innovations and the impact of engineering on everyday life. Team projects and guest lectures. Open to freshmen only.

ENGR.title: Technology Entrepreneurship
ENGR.description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

ENGR.title: Cooperative Education Work Experience
ENGR.description: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR.title: Cooperative Education Work Experience
ENGR.description: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR.title: Cooperative Education Work Experience
ENGR.description: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by department approval.

ENGR.title: Cooperative Education Work Experience
ENGR.description: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR.title: Engineering Honors Projects
ENGR.description: Supervised interdisciplinary studies and projects.  Enrollment  limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program.   Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Principles and Practices of Global Innovation
ENGR.description: Basic principles that govern the dynamic socio-technical interactions of open technology innovations on competitive global markets, emphasizing real-world practices to uncover blue-ocean innovation opportunities.

ENGR.title: Thought Leadership in a Technologically Changing World
ENGR.description: Development of engineering leaders by providing a solid foundation of leadership principles and their practice while studying the impact of technological achievements in leadership structures.

ENGR.title: Technology Development and Commercialization
ENGR.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of technology development and commercialization with an emphasis on how new technologies are formed and implemented into society.

ENGR.title: Internship in Engineering
ENGR.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's  field of study.  The internship must be located at an off-campus  facility.  Students are individually supervised by faculty.  May  not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester  of enrollment in the graduate program.  Graduate standing in  engineering.  Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Internship in Engineering with Professional      Writing and Communication
ENGR.description: Practical work experience; professional communication and writing skills.

ENGR.title: Professional Internship Experiences
ENGR.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in a particular field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility.

BME.title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BME.description: Historical development and survey of major areas comprising biomedical engineering: theoretical neurobiology and systems physiology, biomedical instrumentation, artificial organ and prosthetic devices, biomedical computer applications.

BME.title: Control and Communication in the Nervous System
BME.description: Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system for biomedical engineers. Modeling of neurophysiological processes at single neuron and systems levels.

BME.title: Medical Electronics
BME.description: Electronic design and measurements for medical applications. Use of integrated circuits, biopotential measurements, static and dynamic calibration of physiological transducers.

BME.title: Physiological Systems
BME.description: A thorough bioengineering treatment of the physiological properties of various mammalian organ systems: e.g., cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and musculoskeletal.

BME.title: Senior Projects: Measurements and Instrumentation
BME.description: Application of instrumentation and measurement techniques to biomedical engineering projects involving measurement, replacement or augmentation of biomedical systems.

BME.title: Introduction to Bioengineering in Medicine
BME.description: Bioengineering concepts and technologies applied to cancer diagnosis, drug discovery, immunotherapeutic development, stem cell techniques and therapies, mechanistic research.

BME.title: Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technologies
BME.description: Introduction to technologies used for rehabilitation and improved function, including limb and spinal orthoses and prostheses, gait analysis and sensory aids and augmentation.

BME.title: Bioengineering Signals and Systems
BME.description: Introduction to concepts relating to linear signals and systems theory, time and frequency domain analysis, and application of these concepts to problems in Biomedical Engineering.

BME.title: Statistical and Data Science Methods in Biomedical Engineeri
BME.description: Applications of statistical and data science methods to biomedical data, including analysis of variance, multivariate linear and logistic regression, nonparametric tests, machine learning, survival analysis.

BME.title: Principles and Applications of Systems Biology
BME.description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.

BME.title: Directed Research
BME.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

BME.title: Introduction to Deep Learning for Biomedical Engineering
BME.description: Current trends and developments in the field of biomedical        engineering.

BME.title: Senior Design Project
BME.description: Current trends and developments in the field of biomedical        engineering.

BME.title: Neuromuscular and Bio-Robotic Systems
BME.description: Introduces the fundamentals of mathematical, Newtonian, and robotic analysis applicable to multi-muscle biomechanical systems. Combines physiology with numerical simulations to understand and predict motor function.

BME.title: Laboratory Projects in Biomedical Engineering
BME.description: Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory.

BME.title: Physiological Control Systems
BME.description: Application of control theory to physiological systems; static analysis of closed-loop systems; time-domain analysis of linear control identification methods; nonlinear control.

BME.title: Signal and Systems Analysis
BME.description: Classification; representation; statistical analysis; orthogonal expansions; least-squares estimation; harmonic analysis; Fourier, Laplace and Z transforms; the linear system; filtering; modeling and simulation; linear control theory.

BME.title: Deep Learning and Applications in Biomedical Engineering
BME.description: Deep neural networks, machine learning, microscopic and pathological image analysis and classification, sequence analysis, convolution neural networks, recurrent neural networks, deep learning models, parameter tuning.

BME.title: Thermal and Biological Transport Phenomena I
BME.description: Analytical techniques for heat and mass diffusion problems in various geometries; application to heat/mass transfer in solids, liquids, porous media and bioporous materials.

BME.title: Integration of Medical Imaging Systems
BME.description: Introduce basic concepts of Medical Imaging Informatics with an introduction to clinical information systems (eg, PACS, RIS, EMR) related to the imaging workflow in a clinical healthcare enterprise

BME.title: Seminar in Bioengineering
BME.description: Graded CR/NC.

BME.title: Introduction to Bio-MEMS and Nanotechnology
BME.description: Principles and biomedical applications of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and nanotechnology, including microfluidics, nanowire sensors, nanomotors, quantum dots, biofuel cells and molecular imaging.

BME.title: Health Product Development
BME.description: Prototyping, testing and reporting of health-related, technological products; test methods and spreadsheet data analysis; report writing and oral presentations.

BME.title: Nanomedicine and Drug Delivery
BME.description: Drug delivery and use of nanoengineered materials, including cutting-edge nanoparticle-based therapy, imaging and tissue engineering. Nanotoxicology and the regulatory landscape is introduced.

BME.title: Directed Research
BME.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BME.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

BME.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

BME.title: Applied Electrophysiology
BME.description: The theoretical basis and applied design principles for medical  devices and instrumentation that interact with electrically  excitable tissues of the body.

BME.title: Biomedical Measurement and Instrumentation
BME.description: Design of biomedical instrumentation and diagnostic devices (aspects such as mechanics, electronic architecture and chemical and biological components) used to measure physiological parameters

BME.title: Research
BME.description: Research applicable to the doctorate. Graded CR/NC.

DSCI.title: Introduction to Data Science
DSCI.description: Fundamentals of data science: representation of data and knowledge, role of a data scientist, data storage/processing/analytics, machine learning, big data and data visualization.

DSCI.title: Foundations of Data Management
DSCI.description: Data modeling, data storage, indexing, relational databases, key-value/document store, NoSQL, distributed file system, parallel computation and big-data analytics.

DSCI.title: Applied Machine Learning and Data Mining
DSCI.description: Foundational course focusing on the understanding, application and evaluation of machine learning and data mining approaches in data-intensive scenarios.

DSCI.title: Security and Privacy
DSCI.description: Basic concepts in information security and privacy; implications of security and privacy breaches; security and privacy policies, threats and protection mechanisms; security and privacy laws, regulations and ethics.

DSCI.title: Principles of Programming for Data Science
DSCI.description: Programming in Python for retrieving, searching and analyzing data from the Web. Learning to manipulate large data sets.

DSCI.title: Research Methods and Analysis for User Studies
DSCI.description: Introduction to research methods and data analysis techniques for human subject research; experimental research design, correlational research, data analysis, ensuring validity and ethics.

DSCI.title: Foundations and Policy for Information Security
DSCI.description: Threats to information systems; technical and procedural approaches to threat mitigation; policy specification and foundations of policy for secure systems; mechanisms for building secure security services; risk management. Background in computer security preferred. Recommended previous courses of study include computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems and/or mathematics.

DSCI.title: Computer Systems Assurance
DSCI.description: Assurance that an information system will behave as expected; assurance approaches for fielding secure information systems; case studies. Recommended preparation: Prior degree in computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems and/or mathematics. Some background in computer security preferred.

DSCI.title: Computer Forensics
DSCI.description: Preservation, identification, extraction and documentation of computer evidence stored on a computer. Data recovery; File System Analysis; Investigative Techniques and Methodologies; Forensic Reports and Presentations.

DSCI.title: Introduction to Computational Thinking and Data Science
DSCI.description: Introduction to data analysis techniques and associated computing concepts for non-programmers. Topics include foundations for data analysis, visualization, parallel processing, metadata, provenance and data stewardship. Recommended preparation: mathematics and logic undergraduate courses.

DSCI.title: Data Science at Scale
DSCI.description: Big data informatics fundamentals. Data lifecycle; the data scientist; machine learning; data mining; NoSQL databases; tools to store, process, analyze large data sets on clusters.

DSCI.title: Foundations of Data Management
DSCI.description: Function and design of modern storage systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.

DSCI.title: Machine Learning for Data Science
DSCI.description: Practical applications of machine learning techniques to real-world problems. Uses in data mining and recommendation systems and for building adaptive user interfaces.

DSCI.title: Foundations and Applications of Data Mining
DSCI.description: Data mining and machine learning algorithms for analyzing very large data sets. Emphasis on System Building with Spark. Case studies.

DSCI.title: Data Visualization
DSCI.description: Graphical depictions of data for communication, analysis and decision support. Cognitive processing and perception of visual data and visualizations. Designing effective visualizations. Implementing interactive visualizations.

DSCI.title: User Experience Design and Strategy
DSCI.description: The practice of User Experience Design and Strategy principles for the creation of unique and compelling digital products and services.

DSCI.title: Building Knowledge Graphs
DSCI.description: Foundations, techniques and algorithms for building knowledge graphs and doing so at scale. Topics include information extraction, data alignment, entity linking and the Semantic Web.

DSCI.title: Data Science Professional Practicum
DSCI.description: Student teams working on external customer data analytic challenges; project/presentation based; real client data and implementable solutions for delivery to actual stakeholders; capstone to degree.

DSCI.title: Predictive Analytics
DSCI.description: Supervised learning. Linear regression, cross validation, ridge and lasso regression, logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbors, decision trees, random forest and gradient-boosting models, support vector machines, neural networks.

DSCI.title: Integration of Medical Imaging Systems
DSCI.description: Introduce basic concepts of Medical Imaging Informatics with an introduction to clinical information systems (eg, PACS, RIS, EMR) related to the imaging workflow in a clinical healthcare enterprise

DSCI.title: Probability and Statistics for Data Science
DSCI.description: Fundamental concepts in probability and statistics from a data science perspective; rigorous probabilistic reasoning and problem solving; statistical methods used in data science.

DSCI.title: Introduction to Deep Learning for Data Science
DSCI.description: An introduction to core deep learning algorithms combined with practical experience in building and applying deep learning networks.

DSCI.title: Directed Research
DSCI.description: Research leading to the masters degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

AME.title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
AME.description: Gateway to a BS degree in Mechanical Engineering. Introduction to statics, strength of materials, fluid mechanics, energy, electric circuits, computer-aided drafting, dimensional analysis, team projects.

AME.title: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering
AME.description: Gateway to the Aerospace Engineering major. Introduction to flight vehicle performance and propulsion. Elements of the physics of gases. Laboratory: computers and graphics; model rocket and glider test flights.

AME.title: Statics
AME.description: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.

AME.title: Mechanics of Materials and Structures
AME.description: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; plates, shells, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design, trusses.

AME.title: Computational Methods in Engineering
AME.description: Common tools for Aerospace and Mechanical engineers: vectors, matrices, fundamentals of python, data manipulation and analysis, statistics, data presentation, optimization, large data sets.

AME.title: Advanced Composites Design Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  lower division students or those with little prior project  experience.  Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Dynamics
AME.description: Reference frames and coordinate systems; relationships between forces, moments, power, linear/angular momentum, and energy for particles and rigid bodies; particle and rigid body systems.

AME.title: Systems
AME.description: Mathematical modeling of constrained mechanical systems at different levels of complexity, design-oriented approach to dynamic systems, transfer function formulation, state-space models and block diagram representation.

AME.title: Systems
AME.description: Modeling of combined dynamic systems at different levels of complexity; time domain open-loop system analysis; system stability; approximation with lower-order systems; engineering applications.

AME.title: Mechanical Design
AME.description: Design and analysis of mechanical elements including shafts, bearings, springs, screws, belts and gears; strength, fatigue and deflection considerations in machine design.

AME.title: Computer-Aided Engineering
AME.description: Introduction to the finite element method; practical application of computer analysis tools for structural analysis and design.

AME.title: Dynamics of Fluids
AME.description: Fluid statics; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in integral and differential form; applications. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow; compressible flow; potential flow over bodies.

AME.title: Engineering Thermodynamics I
AME.description: Laws of thermodynamics applied to actual and perfect gases and vapors; energy concepts, processes, and applications; energy, entropy, and exergy analysis; power and refrigeration systems

AME.title: Mechoptronics Laboratory
AME.description: Coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation, test and measurement, integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components and technical communication.

AME.title: Stress Analysis
AME.description: Theories of failure, shear center, unsymmetrical bending, curved beams, torsion of non-circular sections; cylinders, rotating discs, thermal stresses, inelastic strains, energy methods.

AME.title: Computational Solutions to Engineering Problems
AME.description: Mathematical aspects of the solutions to typical advanced mechanical engineering problems. Modeling, simulation, computational aspects, computer solutions, and computational tools. Recommended preparation: FORTRAN, MATLAB, and Maple

AME.title: Computer-Aided Design of Mechanical Systems
AME.description: Design of mechanical systems using advanced graphics techniques; computer-aided drafting, design optimization, elements of computer graphics, solids modeling; introduction to computer-aided manufacturing.

AME.title: Engineering Design Theory and Methodology
AME.description: Product planning and task clarification, voice of customers,  quality function deployment, conceptual and embodiment design,  axiomatic theory of design, product quality and manufacturability,  design decision-making.  Junior standing. Recommended preparation:  AME 305

AME.title: Turbine Design and Analysis
AME.description: Physics of turbine operation; design and analysis for the development of turbine hardware for propulsion and power generation. Recommended Preparation: Familiarity with Matlab.

AME.title: Heat Transfer
AME.description: General principles underlying heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; steady and transient conditions; heat exchangers.

AME.title: Senior Projects Laboratory
AME.description: Team engineering design project to model, construct and test a physical principle or system. Complete industrial research project including proposal, design review, presentation, technical report.

AME.title: Linear Control Systems I
AME.description: Transform methods, block diagrams; transfer functions; stability; root-locus and frequency domain analysis and design; application to flight control, state space and multiloop systems.

AME.title: Flight Mechanics
AME.description: Applications of basic aerodynamics to aircraft and missile performance, power and thrust, stability and control, compressibility effects.

AME.title: Aerospace Structures I
AME.description: Design, qualification, and workmanship verification of aerospace structures. Analysis for assessing buckling and crippling, welds, and analysis of connections and thin-walled structures.

AME.title: Directed Research
AME.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AME.title: Advanced Composites Design Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Advanced Robotic Combat
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Advanced Spacecraft Propulsion and Energy Laboratory
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Aerodesign Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Formula SAE Electric Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Formula SAE Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Human Powered Vehicle Project
AME.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended  for entry in local and national design competitions.  Intended for  students with prior project experience.  Upper division standing.   Graded CR/NC.

AME.title: Sustainable Aviation
AME.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in aerospace and mechanical engineering and related fields.

AME.title: Modern Topics in Aerospace Design
AME.description: Current topics in Aerospace Engineering are addressed by a number of industry panelists. Students, under panelists' supervision and guidance, complete independent research reports and briefings. Recommended preparation: AME 261, AME 441, AME 481 or equivalents. Genuine interest in design of flight vehicles. Open only to Senior, Master, and Doctoral students.

AME.title: Machine Learning for Engineering Applications
AME.description: Modeling engineering challenges, supervised and unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, evolutionary algorithms, support vector machines, Bayesian learning, large language models, transform engineering with machine learning.

AME.title: Continuum Mechanics
AME.description: A unified mathematical description for modeling the mechanics and thermodynamics of continua, including topics like elasticity, inelastic material modeling and fluid behavior.

AME.title: Mechanics of Solids I
AME.description: Fundamental theory of  linear elasticity applicable to multiple branches of solid mechanics.

AME.title: Advanced Computational Design and Manufacturing
AME.description: Study concepts behind computational representations, algorithms and mathematical foundations, and their applications in computer-aided design and manufacturing. Develop hands-on computational skills in team projects.

AME.title: Fundamentals and Applications of Combustion
AME.description: Chemical equilibrium, flame temperature, chemical kinetics, transport phenomena, conservation equations of multi-component reacting flows, laminar flames, droplet combustion, flame speed, combustion pollutants, atmospheric pollution processes.

AME.title: Thermal and Biological Transport Phenomena I
AME.description: Analytical techniques for heat and mass diffusion problems in various geometries; application to heat/mass transfer in solids, liquids, porous media and bioporous materials.

AME.title: Engineering Vibrations II
AME.description: Multi-degree of freedom systems; continuous systems; modal analysis. Beams, rods, membranes, plates, shells. Approximate methods; Galerkin, Rayleigh Ritz; assumed-mode, finite elements.

AME.title: Linear Algebra in Engineering Science
AME.description: Systems of linear equations; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; singular values and singular vectors; linear transformations; regression and optimization; data-driven learning.

AME.title: Finite Element Analysis
AME.description: Basic concepts; variational methods; isoparametric formulation; plane stress; plane strain; axisymmetric structures; plates and shells; structural dynamics; stability and buckling; computer applications; nonlinear analysis.

AME.title: Dynamics of Incompressible Fluids
AME.description: A unified discussion of low-speed fluid mechanics including exact solutions; approximation techniques for low and high Reynolds numbers; inviscid flows; surface waves; dynamic stability; turbulence.

AME.title: Introduction to Computational Fluid Mechanics
AME.description: Convergence, consistency, stability: finite difference, finite element, and spectral methods; direct and iterative procedures for steady problems; linear diffusion and advection problems; nonlinear advection problems. Recommended preparation: AME 526.

AME.title: Probability and Statistics in Engineering Science
AME.description: Probability theory; random variables and vectors; joint, marginal, and conditional distributions; Bayes' theorem; introduction to stochastic processes; statistical inference; regression and generative models.

AME.title: Linear Control Systems II
AME.description: State space representation, linearization, solution of state equations; controllability and observability; state feedback, state observers; optimal control; output feedback.

AME.title: Systems Architecting
AME.description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical,     computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

AME.title: Seminar in Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering
AME.description: Recent developments and research in aerospace and mechanical engineering and related fields. Oral and written reports.

AME.title: Mechanical Behavior of Engineering Materials
AME.description: Mechanical properties of materials; macroscopic mechanical behavior related to structure and microstructure of the material; elementary dislocation theory related to basic strengthening mechanisms; fatigue and fracture; nanomaterials.

AME.title: Additive Manufacturing Technologies
AME.description: Overview and working principles of commonly used additive manufacturing processes; process models; process and material selection; cost estimation methods; current applications and future directions.

AME.title: Robot Dynamics and Control
AME.description: Introduction to dynamics and control of robotic systems including Model Predictive Control (MPC), Quadratic Program (QP)-based nonlinear control and trajectory optimization.

AME.title: Computational Design of Machine Components
AME.description: Computer-aided design of machine components widely encountered in automotive and aerospace applications including fasteners, stiffeners, airfoils, etc. Intended for students with little CAE experience.

AME.title: Directed Research
AME.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENE.title: Environmental Organic Chemistry
ENE.description: Qualitative and quantitative prediction of partitioning constants governing fate of organic chemicals in the environment; transformation pathways, reaction kinetics, and analysis of organic contaminants.

ENE.title: Machine Learning for Climate Change and Sustainability
ENE.description: The application of supervised machine learning to environmental concerns such as climate change, air pollution, energy and sustainability; predictions of future outcomes from existing datasets.

ENE.title: Energy and the Environment
ENE.description: The environmental impacts of energy extraction, cultivation, transformation, transportation, and consumption.

ENE.title: Physiochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE.description: Concepts and applications of physicochemical processes in engineered systems, including coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption and membrane processes.

ENE.title: Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE.description: Design of aerobic and anaerobic biological treatment processes for organic and inorganic pollutant removal and resource recovery from waste streams.

ENE.title: Directed Research

PTE.title: Applied Subsurface Characterization and Engineering
PTE.description: Characterization and modeling of subsurface reservoirs. Extraction of  energy and minerals. Storage of energy and greenhouse gases.

PTE.title: Mathematical Methods for Deep Learning
PTE.description: Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical  and life sciences and computer science with mathematical  background.

PTE.title: Directed Research
PTE.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PTE.title: Geomechanics for Energy and Environment
PTE.description: Physical, mathematical and simulation aspects of coupled flow and geomechanics in petroleum/geothermal reservoirs. Coupled flow-geomechanics simulator development using finite element and finite volume methods.

PTE.title: Integrated Subsurface Flow Modeling
PTE.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of Petroleum Engineering.

EE.title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
EE.description: Electrical engineering overview: communications, computers, circuits, components, signals, electromagnetics, microelectronics; data encoding and compression, USPS and UPC product codes, DVDs, semiconductor devices, and integrated circuits.

EE.title: Introduction to Embedded Systems
EE.description: Information representations, embedded programming, digital and serial I/O, analog-to-digital conversion, and interrupt mechanisms. Elementary analog, logic and state-machine design.

EE.title: Applied Linear Algebra for Engineering
EE.description: Introduction to linear algebra with engineering applications.  Weekly laboratory exercises using MATLAB.

EE.title: Introduction to Computer Programming for         Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Introduction to solving engineering problems using computational methods.  Survey of various programming languages and their strengths and weaknesses.  Program structure, input/output, conditionals, loops, functions, arrays.

EE.title: Linear Circuits
EE.description: Lumped circuit elements; network equations; zero-input and zerostate responses; sinusoidal steady-state analysis; impedance; resonance; network functions; power concepts; transformers; Laplace transforms.

EE.title: Distributed Systems for the Internet of Things
EE.description: Introduction to hardware, operating systems, signal processing and control, network protocols, mobile applications, databases, cloud computing, machine learning and security for the Internet of Things.

EE.title: Linear Systems
EE.description: Representation and analysis of linear time-invariant systems primarily for the continuous time case. Convolution, Fourier series and transform, Laplace transform, controls and communications applications.

EE.title: Physical Electronics
EE.description: Semiconductor device characteristics and applications. Physical models of electronic conduction in solids, p-n junctions, bipolar and field effect transistors and other solid-state devices.

EE.title: Electronic Circuits
EE.description: Basic analog and digital circuit design using Bipolar Junction Transistors, Field Effect Transistors and integrated circuits.

EE.title: Introduction to Digital Circuits
EE.description: Digital system design and implementation; synchronous design of datapath and control; schematic/Verilog-based design, simulation, and implementation in Field Programmable Gate Arrays; timing analysis; semester-end project.

EE.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for   Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
EE.description: Introduction to concepts of randomness and uncertainty: probability, random variables, statistics. Applications to digital communications, signal processing, automatic control, computer engineering and computer science.

EE.title: Electromagnetics for Engineering Systems
EE.description: Electromagnetic plane-wave propagation and interactions with simple media, transmission/reception of wireless signals in complex environments. Optimization design methods for system applications.

EE.title: Introduction to Power Systems
EE.description: Components of power systems; analysis techniques in electrical power generation transmission and utilization; and environmental and economic considerations in system operations and planning.

EE.title: Power Systems Technology
EE.description: Comprehensive assessment of the technical, environmental, and regulatory challenges that affect the future delivery and utilization of electric power. Case-study analysis.

EE.title: Foundations of Robotics
EE.description: Designing and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, planning, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Weekly robot programming labs; final project.

EE.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
EE.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

EE.title: Introduction to System-on-Chip
EE.description: Design flow, tools, and issues related to System/Network-on-Chip (S/Noc) design for real-time embedded systems with applications in mobile, cloud, aerospace, and medical electronics. Prerequisite: EE 354.

EE.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
EE.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

EE.title: Computer Systems Organization
EE.description: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

EE.title: MOS VLSI Circuit Design
EE.description: Analysis and design of digital MOS VLSI circuits including area, delay and power minimization. Laboratory assignments including design, layout, extraction, simulation and automatic synthesis.

EE.title: Introduction to Digital Signal Processing
EE.description: Fundamentals of digital signal processing covering: discrete time linear systems, quantization, sampling, Z-transforms, Fourier transforms, FFTs and filter design.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EE.title: Undergraduate Thesis
EE.description: For the undergraduate degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.  IP (EE 494a) or letter grade (EE 494b).

EE.title: Undergraduate Thesis
EE.description: For the undergraduate degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. IP (EE 494a) or letter grade (EE 494b).

EE.title: Probability for Electrical and Computer Engineers
EE.description: Rigorous coverage of probability, discrete and continuous random variables, functions of multiple random variables, covariance, correlation, random sequences, Markov chains, estimation, and introduction to statistics. Duplicates credit in former EE 464 and EE 465.

EE.title: Micro- and Nano-Fabrication Technology
EE.description: Physical basis of technologies for the fabrication of micro- and nano-scale devices. Thin-film deposition, etching, and material modification processes; pattern transfer methods.

EE.title: Nanophotonics and Metamaterials
EE.description: Overview of electromagnetic theory and numerical design needed to understand and design photonic devices. Includes discussion of integrated photonic waveguides and resonant cavities, photonic crystals, plasmonics, and metamaterials.

EE.title: Linear Algebra for Engineering
EE.description: Introduction to linear algebra and matrix theory and their underlying concepts; applications to engineering problems; mathematically rigorous and foundational to other classes in communication, control, and signal processing.

EE.title: Machine Learning Hardware Accelerators
EE.description: Machine-learning accelerator architecture design; network architecture optimization, quantization, pruning; hardware/software codesign and cross layer optimizations for machine-learning models

EE.title: Stochastic Processes for Financial Engineering
EE.description: Theory and applications of stochastic processes relevant to  financial engineering. Stochastic processes, Brownian motion, martingales, stochastic calculus, Monte Carlo Simulations with financial application examples.

EE.title: Quantum Error Correction
EE.description: A comprehensive introduction to quantum error correction and decoherence control, from the basics to the cutting edge, enabling students to delve into current research topics.

EE.title: Quantum Sensing: Machine Learning, Inference and Information
EE.description: Basics of quantum mechanics, quantum sensing, quantum theory of inference, information and machine learning.

EE.title: High-Voltage DC Transmission Systems
EE.description: AC/DC conversion processes, converter technologies, and design; harmonics, controls, and protection; AC/DC interactions and system performance; modeling, application, and installation; current-source versus voltage-source converters.

EE.title: Mathematics and Tools for Financial Engineering
EE.description: Students will build a mathematical background for studying Financial Engineering. Emphasis is on analysis, proofs and examples. Mathworks Financial toolbox will be introduced.

EE.title: Introduction to Quantum Information Processing
EE.description: Basics of quantum computation and information: quantum bits and registers, unitary gates, algorithms, error correction and cryptography. Experimental realizations and near-term quantum technology.

EE.title: Power System Protection
EE.description: Theory of system and equipment protection, characteristics of relays, relay coordination, and system considerations.

EE.title: Materials Characterization
EE.description: Characterization of solid structure by X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy, atomic force and tunneling microscopy and elemental analysis by photoemission, X-ray fluorescence, Auger, energy loss spectroscopies.

EE.title: Analog Integrated Circuits
EE.description: MOSFET operation and models; elementary amplifier configurations; biasing and references; frequency response; noise; feedback; operational amplifiers; frequency compensation; non-linearity and mismatch; passive and active filters.

EE.title: Modern Solid-State Devices
EE.description: Integrated-circuit technologies for mixed-signal communication and data systems. Constituent device models and their limitations. Contemporary research topics.

EE.title: Computing Principles for Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Survey of computing principles and practice of software design: object-oriented and non object-oriented, testing, template libraries, time-space complexity, data structures, algorithms, and dynamic programming.

EE.title: Engineering Quantum Mechanics
EE.description: Quantum mechanics for engineering majors who work with solid-state devices, quantum electronics, and photonics. Schroedinger equation, perturbation theory, electronic and optical processes.

EE.title: A Computational Introduction to Deep Learning
EE.description: Deep learning frameworks for training multilayer perceptrons, convolutional and recurrent neural networks; Python, virtual environments, linux and shell scripting, cloud computing, including GPUs and datasets.

EE.title: Internet and Cloud Computing
EE.description: The theory, architecture, hardware/software, and programming of the Internet and its protocols, cloud computing, networks for cloud computing, how they interact with Internet of Things.

EE.title: Robotics
EE.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

EE.title: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Data
EE.description: Modern developments in data representation/analysis, nonconvex optimization, high-dimensional probability, sketching, clustering, low-rank models, inverse problems, applications in imaging, machine learning, computer vision and neuroscience.

EE.title: Applied and Cloud Computing for Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Introduction to cloud applications; software development and deployment within cloud platforms; interactive user-facing interfaces; API development; databases, virtualization, asynchronous execution, testing and scalability.

EE.title: Cyber-Physical Systems: A Computing Perspective
EE.description: Cyber-physical systems; models of computation; programming models; compiler analysis; automatic parallelization; heterogeneous computing and memory systems; multicores; interconnect; mapping; scheduling; real-time operating systems; reliability; fault-tolerance.

EE.title: Computer Systems Architecture
EE.description: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

EE.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
EE.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning.

EE.title: Electromagnetic Wave Engineering
EE.description: Application of Maxwell's equations to electromagnetic waves and  electrical engineering devices.

EE.title: Integrated Memory Devices and Technologies
EE.description: Fundamental device physics, integration technology and cutting-edge innovations in integrated microelectronic memory devices and systems, and their applications in data storage and emerging beyond-von-Neumann computing.

EE.title: VLSI System Design
EE.description: MOS logic; system design; memory design; datapath subsystem design; circuit simulation; basic device physics; simple device layout: structured chip design; timing; project chip; silicon compilers.

EE.title: VLSI System Design
EE.description: Semi-custom ASIC VLSI design flow; RTL coding, logic synthesis, automatic placement & routing, memory and interface design, signal integrity solutions, hardware acceleration and approximation

EE.title: Robotic Mobility
EE.description: Robot gait design; the kinematics and dynamics of locomotion; control adaptations for complex terrains.

EE.title: Linear System Theory
EE.description: Analysis of linear dynamical systems by state-space and input-output techniques; stability, controllability, observability; observer-based controller; linear quadratic regulator.

EE.title: Optimization for the Information and Data Sciences
EE.description: Convex sets, functions, and optimization problems. Basic convex analysis and theory of convex programming. Novel, efficient first-order algorithms. Applications in the information and data sciences.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Complex Digital ASIC System Design
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Neural Networks and Accelerator Design
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Reinforcement Learning and Large Language Models
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Deep Learning Systems
EE.description: Neural networks for nonlinear regression, classification, reinforcement learning; back-propagation learning for multilayer perceptrons, convolutional and recurrent networks; applications in audio processing vision and autonomy.

EE.title: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems
EE.description: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies; search techniques; memory testing.

EE.title: Machine Learning II: Mathematical Foundations and Methods
EE.description: Supervised, semi-supervised, and unsupervised machine learning; domain adaptation and transfer learning; human interpretability.  Feasibility of learning, model complexity, and performance (error) on unseen data.

EE.title: Data Analysis and Control Techniques for Neurotechnology Des
EE.description: Data analysis, machine learning and control-theoretic mathematical tools used in studying the brain and designing neurotechnologies such as brain-machine interfaces.

EE.title: Advanced Computer Vision
EE.description: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

EE.title: Law, AI and Intellectual Property for Engineers
EE.description: Detailed introduction to the modern American legal system with a special focus on current artificial-intelligence techniques and intellectual-property doctrines.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the       degree Engineer in Electrical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Doctoral Seminar Series
EE.description: A weekly seminar series led by ECE faculty and guest lecturers about current and emerging areas of electrical and computer engineering research.

EE.title: Research
EE.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SAE.title: Systems Engineering Theory and Practice
SAE.description: Integration of engineering problem solving methodologies based on systems concepts. Application to complex, large scale technical systems and problems faced by engineering managers. Case studies.

SAE.title: Advanced Topics in Systems Engineering
SAE.description: Probability theory  in systems engineering: test design and performance, reliability and maintainability, quantitative decision models. Constraint theory to manage and de-conflict complex requirements. Complexity theory.

SAE.title: Model-Based Systems Architecting and Engineering
SAE.description: Approaches for modeling systems using software such as SySML; modeling system, requirements, structure, behavior, and parametrics; mapping to hardware description language and behavioral code generation. Recommended preparation: Modeling and simulation courses.

SAE.title: Systems/System-of-Systems Integration and Communication
SAE.description: Essentials of systems and system-of-systems integration from the perspectives of business, programs, and technology. Process, Legacy, and Systems-of-Systems Integration. Verification and Validation methods. Case studies. Recommended preparation: Bachelor's degree in engineering or physical sciences.

SAE.title: Systems Architecting
SAE.description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical,     computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

SAE.title: Systems Architecting and the Political Process
SAE.description: Analysis of risks inherent in managing high-tech/high-cost  government-funded engineering programs; tools and techniques for  coping with the impacts of politically-driven budgets on the      engineering design process.  Recommended preparation: 2 years of  work experience.

SAE.title: Economic Considerations for Systems Engineering
SAE.description: Impact of economic factors for systems architects and engineers,  tools for understanding these factors, fundamental quantitative  analysis of cash flow, life-cost estimating for systems and  software engineering.

SAE.title: Artificial Intelligence for Systems Engineers
SAE.description: Linear modeling, knowledge representation, supervised and unsupervised learning, optimization and evolutionary algorithms; augmented intelligence for decision-making, intelligent monitoring and control; real-world applications.

SAE.title: Directed Research
SAE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

SAE.title: Master's Thesis
SAE.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.
