SAE.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

SAE.title: Master's Thesis
SAE.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

ISE.title: Introduction to Industrial and Systems Engineering
ISE.description: A combination of plant tours, laboratory experiences, and lecture  are used to introduce the philosophy, subject matter, aims, goals,  and techniques of industrial and systems engineering.

ISE.title: Foundations of Probability Modeling
ISE.description: Techniques for modeling uncertainty: discrete and continuous random variables, probability distributions, expectations and conditional probability; Poisson processes, Markov chains and queuing decision models.

ISE.title: Foundations of Data Analysis
ISE.description: Sampling distributions; confidence intervals and hypothesis testing; analysis of variance; regression; data aggregation; prediction and classification.

ISE.title: Engineering Project Management
ISE.description: Managing a project intended to create an engineered system.  Methods, processes, tools.  Lessons-learned from actual practice.  Case studies from real projects.  Presentations by student teams.

ISE.title: Optimization
ISE.description: Modeling, solution analysis and applications of complex decision problems using linear, dynamic and integer optimization.

ISE.title: Enterprise Data Analytics
ISE.description: Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.

ISE.title: Principles and Practices of Systems Engineering
ISE.description: Systems as complex collaborative ensembles of interconnected components. Theory and practice of requirements, design, implementation, testing, deployment, operation and disposal. Case studies from real projects.

ISE.title: Human Factors in Work and Systems Design
ISE.description: Role of humans in technological systems; human-systems integration; ergonomics; anthropometry and workstation design; work methods and measurement; human error, safety and accident analysis.

ISE.title: Database Systems: Storage and Retrieval using SQL
ISE.description: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

ISE.title: Planning and Scheduling for Production and Supply Chains
ISE.description: Production, resource and service planning, forecasting, scheduling, vendor and location selection, inventory; integrated decision systems for the control of production, services and supply chains.

ISE.title: Discrete Systems Simulation
ISE.description: Modeling of complex discrete event systems, input and output analysis, system evaluation via experimentation on the simulation model, applications to industrial and systems engineering problems.

ISE.title: Socio-Technical Systems and Work Organizations
ISE.description: Design, modeling and analysis of complex systems, challenges they present and methods for resolving those challenges. Impact of technology on work and organizational design.

ISE.title: Principles and Practices of Global Innovation
ISE.description: Basic principles that govern the dynamic socio-technical interactions of open technology innovations on competitive global markets, emphasizing real-world practices to uncover blue-ocean innovation opportunities.

ISE.title: Directed Research
ISE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ISE.title: Senior Design Project
ISE.description: Investigate client organization operations, evaluate alternative designs to meet client needs, complete preliminary design review.

ISE.title: Senior Design Project
ISE.description: Develop the detailed design including countermeasures for risks, complete critical design review, implement the project plan, close-out the project.

ISE.title: Statistics for Engineering Managers
ISE.description: Framing engineering management situations with statistical methods. Experiments, distributions, regression, ANOVA, hypothesis, introduction to Bayesian analysis.

ISE.title: Construction Accounting, Finance and Strategy
ISE.description: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

ISE.title: Health Care Operations Improvement
ISE.description: Strategies to improve hospital operations, including supply chains, staffing, informatics, data analytics and patient flow.

ISE.title: Software Management and Economics
ISE.description: Theories of management and their application to software projects. Economic analysis of software products and processes. Software cost and schedule estimation, planning and control.

ISE.title: Advanced Production Planning and Scheduling
ISE.description: Dependencies among long, intermediate and short-range planning and scheduling of production systems considering objectives, technological constraints and solution algorithms.

ISE.title: Engineering Project Management
ISE.description: Methods, processes and tools for managing projects to create engineered systems. Project management; engineering economics; risk management. Industry-drawn large-scale engineering case studies. Team project presentations.

ISE.title: Engineering Management of Systems Integration
ISE.description: Foundations of systems integration; advanced topics in systems integration including generative artificial intelligence (AI); data analytics for predicting and supporting engineering decisions.

ISE.title: Foundations of Analytics
ISE.description: Foundational tools, technologies and methodologies for analytics. The statistical basis of analytics. Understanding and preparing data. Python, SQL and exploratory data analysis.

ISE.title: Quality Management for Engineers
ISE.description: Principles of quality management, quality philosophies and frameworks, role of leadership and strategic planning to improve quality, process management, measurements to improve quality and performance.

ISE.title: Predictive Analytics
ISE.description: Supervised learning. Linear regression, cross validation, ridge and lasso regression, logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbors, decision trees, random forest and gradient-boosting models, support vector machines, neural networks.

ISE.title: Optimization Methods for Analytics
ISE.description: Fundamentals of Linear Programming, Integer Programming, quadratic and nonlinear programming for analytics and data science problems.

ISE.title: Data Analytics Consulting
ISE.description: Consulting project concepts, frameworks, analytical tools and managerial skills with a focus on the use of data analytics, design thinking and insight-driven frameworks.

ISE.title: Data Mining
ISE.description: Data preprocessing, data cleaning, data summarization, dimension reduction, data visualization, anomaly detection, classification and clustering. Modeling dependencies using association rules.

ISE.title: Linear Programming and Extensions
ISE.description: Linear programming models for resource allocation; simplex and revised simplex methods; duality; sensitivity; transportation problems; selected extensions to large scale, multiobjective and special structured models.

ISE.title: Financial Analytics
ISE.description: Modern portfolio theory and optimal decision-making problems in finance. Market microstructure and high-frequency trading. Machine learning models for quantitative finance.

ISE.title: Markov Models for Performance Analysis
ISE.description: Stochastic processes: conditional expectation, Poisson process, discrete time Markov chains, continuous time Markov chains with queueing applications, non-Markovian queues and reliability.

ISE.title: Enterprise Cloud Analytics
ISE.description: Project-based course covers developing scalable analytics solutions using major cloud platforms, focusing on data management, machine learning and enterprise applications.

ISE.title: Leading and Managing Engineering Teams
ISE.description: Design and management of engineering teams. Group decision-making, motivation, leadership, infrastructure requirements, performance measurement, team diversity, conflict and integration.

ISE.title: Technology Development and Implementation
ISE.description: Principles and practices of technology development and  implementation, with application to products and systems in  manufacturing and services.

ISE.title: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Data
ISE.description: Modern developments in data representation/analysis, nonconvex optimization, high-dimensional probability, sketching, clustering, low-rank models, inverse problems, applications in imaging, machine learning, computer vision and neuroscience.

ISE.title: Applied Generative Artificial Intelligence for Enterprises
ISE.description: Foundational concepts and methods in large language models and generative artificial intelligence; fine-tuning and pre-training strategies; applications in dialogue systems and text generation.

ISE.title: Fundamentals of Data Engineering
ISE.description: Essentials of data engineering, focusing on data architecture, data warehousing, ETL processes, big data technologies, and data quality.

ISE.title: Analysis of Algorithms
ISE.description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

ISE.title: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
ISE.description: Economic evaluations of engineering systems for both government and private industry; quantitative techniques for evaluating non-monetary consequences; formal treatment of risk and uncertainty.

ISE.title: Decision Analysis
ISE.description: Decisions under uncertainty; utility theory; multiattribute utility; probability elicitation; conjugate distributions; decision analysis applications, framing, modeling using spreadsheets or software; cognitive biases, behavioral decision theory.

ISE.title: Machine Learning
ISE.description: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

ISE.title: Industrial Ecology
ISE.description: Concepts and methods to analyze the environmental impacts of industrial systems, including lifecycle assessment, material flow analysis, design for environment and sustainable consumption.

ISE.title: Performance Analysis with Simulation
ISE.description: Introduction to modeling and analysis of stochastic systems, with an emphasis on discrete-event simulation of non-Markovian systems.

ISE.title: Enterprise Wide Information Systems
ISE.description: The role enterprise resource planning systems (ERPs) play in organization; integrating and coordinating the many business processes such as demand planning, procurement, production and sales.

ISE.title: Risk Analysis
ISE.description: Concepts of risk analysis, risk in engineered systems, environmental risk, security risks; fault trees, event trees, risk simulations; risks and decision-making.

ISE.title: Management of Rapid Product Development
ISE.description: Rapid Product Development (RPD) including: agile frameworks for RPD; minimum viable products; rapid prototyping; continuous improvement techniques; user feedback integration; data-driven decision-making.

ISE.title: Directed Research
ISE.description: Research leading to the master's degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ISE.title: Seminar in Operations Research and Artificial Intelligence
ISE.description: Current topics in Operations Research and Artificial Intelligence; guest lecturers, reviews of recent papersnand guidance for preparing research proposals.

ISE.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Data-Driven Decision-Making
ISE.description: A unified treatment of data-driven decision-making for both single- and multi-agent systems from the perspectives of artificial intelligence and operations research.

ISE.title: Foundations of Stochastic Processes
ISE.description: Stochastic processes, conditional expectation, Poisson processes, renewal processes, regenerative processes, and discrete and continuous time Markov chains.

ISE.title: Advanced Topics in Applied Stochastic Models
ISE.description: Stochastic processes, reversed continuous-time Markov chains, coupling, martingales, random walks, Brownian motion, stochastic order relations and probability inequalities.

ISE.title: Linear Programming
ISE.description: Understanding optimization problems with constraints and extensions to the treatment of problems involving nonlinearity, uncertainty, discrete variables, logical constraints, multi-agent non-cooperative games and hierarchical problems.

ISE.title: Large Scale Optimization and Machine Learning
ISE.description: Large-scale optimization algorithms that arise in machine learning: stochastic optimization, accelerated methods, parallelization, nonsmooth optimization, online optimization, variance reduction, min-max games.

ISE.title: Seminar in Industrial & Systems Engineering
ISE.description: Current research, guest speakers in the field; review papers; guidance in preparing research proposals and special projects. Duplicates credit in the former ISE-650abc. Open only to Fifth Year Seniors and MasteraE*s Students.

ISE.title: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms
ISE.description: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

ISE.title: Research
ISE.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ISE.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

MASC.title: Materials Science
MASC.description: Chemical bonding and structure in crystalline, amorphous and       molecular solids; tendency and mechanisms for chemical             change; homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria.

MASC.title: Materials Behavior and Processing
MASC.description: Mechanical behavior of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Structure-process-property relationships. Mechanical testing, stress-strain relationships, microstructural characteristics and analysis. Material failure (fracture, fatigue, creep) and degradation.

MASC.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
MASC.description: Basic material science, atomic bonding, crystalline structures, structural and mechanical behavior and characterization of metals, concrete, wood, composites and asphalt.

MASC.title: Physical Properties of Polymers
MASC.description: Introduction to polymer physical properties and characterization, relationship to synthesis techniques and processing techniques, natural and synthetic materials, property optimization and modern applications.

MASC.title: Thermodynamics of Materials
MASC.description: Classical thermodynamics, chemical potential, pure phases and mixtures; interphase relationships; binary and ternary solutions; free energy and activity; galvanic cell, electrochemical potential and Pourbaix diagram.

MASC.title: Crystals and Anisotropy
MASC.description: Stereographic projection; Laue back reflection method; crystal orientation; line and planar crystalline defects; tensors; susceptibility; permeability and permittivity; stress and strain; piezoelectricity; elasticity.

MASC.title: Micro- and Nano-Fabrication Technology
MASC.description: Physical basis of technologies for the fabrication of micro- and nano-scale devices. Thin-film deposition, etching, and material modification processes; pattern transfer methods.

MASC.title: Mathematical Methods for Deep Learning
MASC.description: Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical  and life sciences and computer science with mathematical  background.

MASC.title: Materials Characterization
MASC.description: Characterization of solid structure by X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy, atomic force and tunneling microscopy and elemental analysis by photoemission, X-ray fluorescence, Auger, energy loss spectroscopies.

MASC.title: Engineering Quantum Mechanics
MASC.description: Quantum mechanics for engineering majors who work with solid-state devices, quantum electronics, and photonics. Schroedinger equation, perturbation theory, electronic and optical processes.

MASC.title: Mechanical Behavior of Engineering Materials
MASC.description: Mechanical properties of materials; macroscopic mechanical behavior related to structure and microstructure of the material; elementary dislocation theory related to basic strengthening mechanisms; fatigue and fracture; nanomaterials.

MASC.title: Introduction to Photovoltaic Solar Energy        Conversion
MASC.description: The physical principles, implementation materials, devices and manufacturing costs of solar cells and panels for photovoltaic conversion of solar radiation to electricity.

MASC.title: Basics of Atomistic Simulation of Materials
MASC.description: Introduction to atomistic modeling and simulations of materials usingMolecular Dynamics and Monte Carlo methods, basic concepts and how tocharacterize materials properties.

MASC.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may   be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded CR/NC.

TAC.title: Introduction to Business Information Technologies
TAC.description: Business technologies. Operating systems. Networks. Application software.

TAC.title: Introduction to Web Development
TAC.description: Web publishing using HTML, CSS and other Web technologies. Concepts and theory of Web site creation, page layout and production. Introduction to advanced topics.

TAC.title: Programming in Python
TAC.description: Introduction to Python; intended for students without prior programming experience.

TAC.title: Accelerated Programming in Python
TAC.description: Accelerated introduction to Python; intended for students with prior programming experience.

TAC.title: From Hackers to CEOs: Introduction to Information Security
TAC.description: Introductory course in computer security. Fundamentals of information security management. Threats to information integrity. Ethical hacking concerns and practice. Policies and Procedures.

TAC.title: Introduction to C++ Programming
TAC.description: Introduction to programming using C++, including variables, operators, conditionals, loops, arrays, vectors, strings, functions, files, structs, pointers, dynamic allocation and an introduction to classes.

TAC.title: Introduction to MATLAB
TAC.description: Fundamentals of MATLAB: a high-performance numeric computation and visualization environment. Overview of linear algebra and matrix manipulation; using 2-D and 3-D plotting routines; programming in MATLAB; basic numerical analysis.

TAC.title: Video Game Production
TAC.description: The process of video game production. Video game history, genres, development process (concept, preproduction, production and post-production) and roles (producers, artists, programmers, etc.).

TAC.title: Introduction to Adobe Photoshop
TAC.description: Digital tools for image creation, editing, composition, layout, web page development, professional page layout and printing with color accuracy.

TAC.title: Introduction to 3D Modeling, Animation and Visual Effects
TAC.description: An applied introduction to the techniques used for modeling, animating, texturing, lighting, rendering, and creating 3D content for games, cinematics, visual effects, animation and visualizations.

TAC.title: Applied Python
TAC.description: Development of practical Python programming skills through project-based applications; "Pythonic" ways of solving problems in modern computational domains.

TAC.title: Computer-Aided Modeling for 3D Product Design
TAC.description: Think, plan and create in three-dimensional space using 3D printing technology and 3D modeling techniques for prototyping.

TAC.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
TAC.description: Introduction to data analytics. Basics of databases, applied statistics, data visualization. Leverage data to make critical business decisions.

TAC.title: Basics of Artificial Intelligence
TAC.description: Concepts and techniques in artificial intelligence; approaches in artificial narrow intelligence; applications of AI that are already changing society; ethical and social questions in AI.

TAC.title: Object-Oriented Programming
TAC.description: Continuation of the fundamentals of programming; problem solving skills within the object-oriented programming paradigm.

TAC.title: Law Without Borders Law in a Cyber Universe
TAC.description: Selected topics in Technology and Applied Computing.

TAC.title: Front-End Web Development
TAC.description: Concepts and technologies used to create front-end for web applications. Introduction to programming and client-side web development. User-driven website manipulation and animation.

TAC.title: Full-Stack Web Development
TAC.description: Modern web development techniques and technologies used to create web applications from ground up. Topics include front-end, back-end and web servers.

TAC.title: Back-End Web Development
TAC.description: Concepts and technologies used to create database-driven websites. Database design and implementation. Server-side development to connect web applications to databases.

TAC.title: Design for User Experience
TAC.description: Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.

TAC.title: Ethical Hacking
TAC.description: Ethical hacking; penetration testing; vulnerability assessment; red teams; hacker environments, infrastructure and frameworks; lateral movement and data exfiltration techniques; evasion and anti-forensics.

TAC.title: iOS App Development
TAC.description: Introduction to the Swift programming language, various frameworks, and design patterns needed to develop applications for iOS mobile devices such as iPhones and iPads.

TAC.title: Making Smart Devices: Introduction to Electronics/Wearables
TAC.description: Design of electronic devices that interact with the physical world; electronic interfaces; development of software algorithms; micro-controller implementation.

TAC.title: Enterprise Data Analytics
TAC.description: Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.

TAC.title: 3D Character Modeling for Games
TAC.description: Character design principles, visual communication and planning for games; polygonal construction, use of image guides and edge flows for realistic deformation.

TAC.title: Blockchain: Decentralized Applications
TAC.description: Blockchain technology; transactions without the need for a trusted third-party; and decentralized applications on public blockchains.

TAC.title: Enterprise Networks: Design and Architecture
TAC.description: Network technologies. Routers and managed switches. Integrated operating systems (IOS). Strategies for endpoint management. Subnets and securing subnetworks. Reliability with networks and network infrastructure.

TAC.title: Applied Neural Networks
TAC.description: Design, build, and train applied neural networks to solve real-world problems; implement neural networks for machine vision, image recognition and object detection and tracking.

TAC.title: Managing Data in C++
TAC.description: Data structures in C++ including vectors, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs and parallelism.

TAC.title: Cross-Platform App Development
TAC.description: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles and user experience.

TAC.title: Cybersecurity Management and Operations
TAC.description: Cybersecurity project design. Incident response. Teambuilding, management and communications for cybersecurity. Scalable approaches for implementation of Information Security Management Systems.

TAC.title: Technical Character Animation for Games
TAC.description: 3D character animation with a video game focus; movement clarity versus game reaction speed, LOD visibility and automated export systems.

TAC.title: Digital Forensics and Cybersecurity Investigations
TAC.description: Forensic science techniques. Digital evidence preservation. Processes and methodologies for digital examinations. Cyber crime investigations. Windows file system analysis. Real case scenario analysis and reporting

TAC.title: Video Game Programming
TAC.description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

TAC.title: Mobile Game Development
TAC.description: Application of techniques used to develop games for mobile devices. Sprites, mobile input, mobile graphics and monetization.

TAC.title: Database Systems: Storage and Retrieval using SQL
TAC.description: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

TAC.title: Advanced Front-End Web Development
TAC.description: The technologies, techniques, conventions and best practices used in contemporary front-end web development.

TAC.title: Web Application Security
TAC.description: Examine web applications from an offensive security standpoint. Topics include information gathering, vulnerability discovery and validation, exploitation and privilege escalation techniques.

TAC.title: Professional C++
TAC.description: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.

TAC.title: Advanced Gameplay Programming
TAC.description: Advanced gameplay programming techniques for both single player and networked multiplayer games using an industry-standard game engine.

TAC.title: Apple Forensics and Security (macOS and iOS)
TAC.description: Digital forensics, evidence collection and analysis of Apple devices including macOS and iOS. Mac, iPhone, iPad and other Apple device analysis.

TAC.title: Applications of Machine Learning
TAC.description: Hands-on approach to the fundamental modeling techniques and machine learning algorithms that enable students to build robust predictive models of real-world data and test their validity.

TAC.title: High Performance Computing in Applied Machine Learning
TAC.description: Theoretical and practical high performance computing approaches to various computational methods in applied machine learning.

TAC.title: Defending and Investigating Compromised Networks
TAC.description: Designing, building, securing and hardening enterprise network infrastructures, investigating compromised infrastructures; red, purple and blue team capabilities; detecting, following and ejecting attackers.

TAC.title: Applied Natural Language Processing and Generative AI
TAC.description: Applied topics in machine learning, including transfer learning, reinforcement learning, generative adversarial networks and natural language processing using neural networks.

TAC.title: Building the High Tech Startup
TAC.description: Basic technologies and processes involved in building web and mobile startup; aspects of building a web startup including online business models, product management, agile development processes, technology platforms and operations, customer development and online marketing.

TAC.title: Technology and Applied Computing Practicum
TAC.description: Independent technology project related to specific topics under    the direction of a faculty member.

TAC.title: Technologies for Interactive Marketing
TAC.description: Technologies, concepts and strategies in the emerging online advertising ecosystem; learn to drive traffic to a website and measure efficacy; work with a real client and budget to craft and execute an online marketing plan.

TAC.title: Cyber Law and Privacy
TAC.description: Cyber legal issues, search and seizure, 4th amendment and digital evidence, warrants, private searches, wiretaps, tracking devices, workplace privacy.

TAC.title: Technology and Applied Computing Internship
TAC.description: Practical experience in applying information technology skills in  real-world settings. Supervised internship at companies and        start-ups. Balancing academic rigor with corporate challenges and  deadlines.

TAC.title: In-Memory Data Modeling and Analytics
TAC.description: Examines the design, architecture and capabilities of in-memory databases and their application to real-time analytics.

TAC.title: Defending and Investigating Enterprise Networks
TAC.description: Recent developments in computers and data processing.

CSCI.title: Explorations in Computing
CSCI.description: A behind-the-scenes overview of the computational/algorithmic principles that form the basis of today's digital society. Exploration areas include social media, web search, videogames and location-based services.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Programming
CSCI.description: Fundamental concepts of algorithmic thinking as a primer to programming. Introduction to C++.

CSCI.title: Object Oriented Programming
CSCI.description: Basic datatypes, assignments, control statements (if, switch, for, while), input/output (printf, scanf, cin, cout), functions, arrays, structures, recursion, dynamic memory, file handling. Programming in C/C++.

CSCI.title: Data Structures
CSCI.description: Data structures including linked lists, balanced search trees, heaps, hash tables; probability and number theory applicable to the analysis of randomized data structures.

CSCI.title: Programming Fundamentals for Computing
CSCI.description: Introduction to Python and C++ with examples from various domains in computational science; intended for students without prior programming experience.

CSCI.title: Programming for Applications of Computing
CSCI.description: Solutions to computational science problems using Python and C++; data structures; searching and sorting algorithms; computational efficiency.

CSCI.title: Discrete Methods in Computer Science
CSCI.description: Boolean algebra, propositional and first-order logic, proof techniques. Sets, functions, series, summations. Big-O notation; algorithm analysis. Recursion; basic sorting algorithms.  Graphs and basic graph algorithms.

CSCI.title: Principles of Software Development
CSCI.description: Object-oriented paradigm for programming in Java; writing concurrent applications using threads; writing web client/server applications using Web Services and SQL databases; team project.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Algorithms and Theory of Computing
CSCI.description: Algorithm analysis. Greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, graph algorithms. NP-completeness and basic recursion theory and undecidability. Sorting lower bounds. Number-theory based cryptography.

CSCI.title: Software Engineering
CSCI.description: Introduction to the software engineering process and software lifecycle. Covers project management, requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance phase activities in team based projects. Prerequisites: CSCI 201. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 377.

CSCI.title: Fundamentals of Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system.

CSCI.title: Internetworking
CSCI.description: Global Internet: design principles, layering, protocol design/analysis. Networked applications, Internet structure/architecture, Protocols for transport/congestion control, network layer/routing, link layer/MAC. Network security.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems
CSCI.description: Computer organization; entity abstraction and representation; program execution; code optimization; memory usage; exception handling; processing control; computer performance; hands-on work done in C and assembly.

CSCI.title: Artificial Intelligence: Principles and Foundations
CSCI.description: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, machine learning.

CSCI.title: Cross-Platform App Development
CSCI.description: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles and user experience.

CSCI.title: Video Game Programming
CSCI.description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

CSCI.title: Capstone: Design and Construction of Large       Software Systems
CSCI.description: Group project with an outside stakeholder to develop real-world    software solutions to large-scale problems. Topics include         software engineering, professional preparation, and recent         computer science research. Duplicates credit in CSCI 477a and CSCI  477b.

CSCI.title: Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization, process and thread scheduling, memory management, file systems, security and access   control, communication and networking, distributed file systems,   data management. Duplicates credit in CSCI 350.

CSCI.title: Computer Graphics
CSCI.description: Computer graphics, OpenGL, 2D and 3D transformations, Bzier splines, computer animation, rendering including ray tracing, shading and lighting, artistic rendering, virtual reality, visualization.

CSCI.title: Computer and Network Security
CSCI.description: A broad overview of security threats and defenses, security systems and functionalities. Includes homeworks and in-class exercises to provide practical experience working with such systems. Prerequisite: CSCI 104.

CSCI.title: Principles of Functional Programming
CSCI.description: An introduction to alternative programming paradigms including functional programming and logic programming.

CSCI.title: Professional C++
CSCI.description: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.

CSCI.title: Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Natural language processing; language modeling; deep neural networks for language processing; language technologies and their socioeconomic and societal impacts

CSCI.title: Foundations of Robotics
CSCI.description: Designing and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, planning, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Weekly robot programming labs; final project.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
CSCI.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

CSCI.title: Introduction to System-on-Chip
CSCI.description: Design flow, tools, and issues related to System/Network-on-Chip (S/Noc) design for real-time embedded systems with applications in mobile, cloud, aerospace, and medical electronics. Prerequisite: EE 354.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
CSCI.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems Organization
CSCI.description: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

CSCI.title: Numerical Methods
CSCI.description: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

CSCI.title: Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Development
CSCI.description: Hands-on AI: data mining, machine learning, optimization and fairness in the context of applications with environmental and societal benefit.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Machine Learning
CSCI.description: Algorithms for learning behavior from data, including both mathematical underpinnings and practical techniques. Covers supervised learning, deep learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

CSCI.title: Cryptography: Secure Communication and Computation
CSCI.description: Introduction to modern Cryptography; Mathematical/algorithmic studies of methods for protecting information in computer and communication systems: Public-Key Cryptosystems, zero-knowledge proofs, data privacy. Prerequisites: CSCI 270.

CSCI.title: Directed Research
CSCI.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CSCI.title: Advanced Game Project
CSCI.description: Design, iterative prototyping, and development of a 1st playable level.

CSCI.title: Senior Project
CSCI.description: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

CSCI.title: Software and Hardware Security
CSCI.description: Selected topics in computer science.

CSCI.title: Numerical Analysis
CSCI.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear       systems of equations; approximation theory using functional        analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential  equations.

CSCI.title: Applied Probability
CSCI.description: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions, conditional probability and expectation,; binomial, poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor.

CSCI.title: Software Management and Economics
CSCI.description: Theories of management and their application to software projects. Economic analysis of software products and processes. Software cost and schedule estimation, planning and control.

CSCI.title: Autonomous Cyber-Physical Systems
CSCI.description: Components, software and applications of cyber-physical systems; autonomy; control techniques; development and testing; artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms.

CSCI.title: Research Methods and Analysis for User Studies
CSCI.description: Introduction to research methods and data analysis techniques for human subject research; experimental research design, correlational research, data analysis, ensuring validity and ethics.

CSCI.title: Game Engine Development
CSCI.description: The principles of developing game engines targeted at modern PC  and game console hardware.

CSCI.title: Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles
CSCI.description: Explore the complex engineering process required to design and build a real-time graphics engine to support physical realism on mobile devices. Recommended preparation: CSCI 420 or CSCI 580 or an equivalent course in graphics.

CSCI.title: Graduate Advanced Game Project
CSCI.description: Team projects intended to address the multifaceted technical and creative challenges that are inherent to comprehensive game development.

CSCI.title: Security Systems
CSCI.description: Protecting computer networks and systems using cryptography,  authentication, authorization, intrusion detection and response.   Includes lab to provide practical experience working with such  systems.

CSCI.title: Linear Programming and Extensions
CSCI.description: Linear programming models for resource allocation; simplex and revised simplex methods; duality; sensitivity; transportation problems; selected extensions to large scale, multiobjective and special structured models.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Modern Data Management and Processing
CSCI.description: Modern database system architectures; indexing for analytical and transactional workloads, query pipelining; materialization, vectorization, optimization, scheduling; join algorithms, consistency and concurrency control.

CSCI.title: Applied Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Introduction to key components of human language technologies, including: information extraction, sentiment analysis, question answering, machine translation.

CSCI.title: Robotics
CSCI.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

CSCI.title: Robot Dynamics and Control
CSCI.description: Introduction to dynamics and control of robotic systems including Model Predictive Control (MPC), Quadratic Program (QP)-based nonlinear control and trajectory optimization.

CSCI.title: Computer Networking
CSCI.description: Protocol design for computer communication networks, network routing, transport protocols, internetworking.

CSCI.title: Cyber-Physical Systems: A Computing Perspective
CSCI.description: Cyber-physical systems; models of computation; programming models; compiler analysis; automatic parallelization; heterogeneous computing and memory systems; multicores; interconnect; mapping; scheduling; real-time operating systems; reliability; fault-tolerance.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems Architecture
CSCI.description: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
CSCI.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning.

CSCI.title: Building Knowledge Graphs
CSCI.description: Foundations, techniques and algorithms for building knowledge graphs and doing so at scale. Topics include information extraction, data alignment, entity linking and the Semantic Web.

CSCI.title: Deep Learning and Its Applications
CSCI.description: Deep learning research in computer vision, natural language processing and robotics; neural networks; deep learning algorithms, tools and software.

CSCI.title: Machine Learning
CSCI.description: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

CSCI.title: Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI.description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

CSCI.title: Web Technologies
CSCI.description: Advanced study of programming languages with application to the Web. Languages for client-side and server-side processing. Examples taken from: HTML, Java, JavaScript, Python, JSON, NodeJS and others.

CSCI.title: Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines
CSCI.description: Examines key aspects of information retrieval as they apply to search engines; web crawling, indexing, querying and quality of results are studied.

CSCI.title: Quantum Computing and Quantum Cryptography
CSCI.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum cryptography; quantum Fourier sampling with applications to factoring, quantum search, quantum key distribution.

CSCI.title: Multimedia Systems Design
CSCI.description: End-to-end multimedia systems -  content creation, compression, distribution using modern standards, DRM solutions,  Digital-Cinema pipeline, multimedia classification, virtual-augmented reality, natural-language multimedia queries, multimodal media analysis, stereoscopic-holographic  technologies.

CSCI.title: Software Architectures
CSCI.description: Study of concepts, principles and scope of software system architectures, including architectural styles, languages, connectors, middleware, dynamism, analysis, testing and domain-specific approaches.

CSCI.title: 3-D Graphics and Rendering
CSCI.description: Course outlines the process of creating images from 3D models. Includes transformations, shading, lighting, rastorization, texturing, and other topics.

CSCI.title: Database Systems
CSCI.description: Database system architecture; conceptual database models; semantic, object-oriented, logic-based, and relational databases; user and program interfaces; database system implementation; integrity, security, concurrency and recovery. Recommended Preparation: Knowledge of relational databases, SQL, relational algebra and physical database design is required. Open only to graduate students.

CSCI.title: Directed Research
CSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Computer Science Research Colloquium
CSCI.description: Exploration and critical assessment of research activities in computer science. Course will serve as a forum for current research presentations from academia and industry. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Software Engineering for Security
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Data
CSCI.description: Modern developments in data representation/analysis, nonconvex optimization, high-dimensional probability, sketching, clustering, low-rank models, inverse problems, applications in imaging, machine learning, computer vision and neuroscience.

CSCI.title: Optimization for the Information and Data Sciences
CSCI.description: Convex sets, functions, and optimization problems. Basic convex analysis and theory of convex programming. Novel, efficient first-order algorithms. Applications in the information and data sciences.

CSCI.title: Seminar in Operations Research and Artificial Intelligence
CSCI.description: Current topics in Operations Research and Artificial Intelligence; guest lecturers, reviews of recent papersnand guidance for preparing research proposals.

CSCI.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Data-Driven Decision-Making
CSCI.description: A unified treatment of data-driven decision-making for both single- and multi-agent systems from the perspectives of artificial intelligence and operations research.

CSCI.title: Text as Data
CSCI.description: Focuses on applications of natural language processing, guided by psychological theories, for identifying various social and cognitive properties evident in language.

CSCI.title: Advanced Computer Networking
CSCI.description: Computer communication protocols and systems, including classic and contemporary literature. The emphasis is on conceptual issues in the design and implementation of computer internetworks.

CSCI.title: High Performance Computing and Simulations
CSCI.description: Advanced high-performance computer simulation techniques; multiscale deterministic and stochastic simulation algorithms on parallel and distributed computing platforms; immersive and interactive visualization of simulation data. Prerequisite: CSCI 596.

CSCI.title: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems
CSCI.description: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies; search techniques; memory testing.

CSCI.title: Advanced Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Computational models of natural language. Formalisms for describing structures of human language, and algorithms for learning language structures from data. Recommended preparation: Proficiency in programming, algorithms and data structures, discrete math, probability theory, and calculus. Open only to doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former CSCI 562)

CSCI.title: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI.description: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Advanced Computer Vision
CSCI.description: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

CSCI.title: Seminar in Computer Science Research
CSCI.description: Introduction of Ph.D. students to the broad range of computer science research. Two semesters registration required. Open to Computer Science doctoral students only. Graded CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 597.

CSCI.title: Practicum in Teaching Computer Science
CSCI.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching in Computer Science. Intended for teaching assistants for classes offered by the Computer Science department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Elements of Human-Computer Interaction Research
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Fair and Efficient Collective Decision Making
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Probabilistic and Generative Models
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Robotic Perception
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.title: Trustworthy Machine Learning from an Optimization Lens
CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

THTE.title: Foundations of Vocal Performance
THTE.description: Exploration of the foundations of vocal technique in a group setting, with an emphasis on musical theatre repertoire.

THTE.title: Acting for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Analysis and investigation of role interpretation and character development by working on two or more scenes from the same play. Introduction of techniques to unlock objectives based on the text.

THTE.title: Acting for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Continuation of analysis and investigation of role interpretation and character development by working on two or more scenes from the same play. Introduction of techniques to unlock objectives for character creation.

THTE.title: Musicianship for Musical Theatre Actors I
THTE.description: Introduction to the basic musicianship and ear training essential for a Musical Theatre performer.

THTE.title: Movement for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Introduction to foundational skills in musical theatre movement, including safe alignment and a movement vocabulary.

THTE.title: Movement for Musical Theatre II
THTE.description: Movement for Musical Theatre, practicing and refining techniques and social dance forms in a studio setting.

THTE.title: Musical Theatre Integration Workshop II
THTE.description: Building upon techniques introduced and developed in THTE 340L and  practice applying those skills to heighten dramatic text for musical theatre.

THTE.title: Musical Theatre Individual Instruction
THTE.description: Introduction to foundational healthy vocal performance/singing skills needed to sustain a career in the musical theatre.

THTE.title: Contemporary Scene Into Song
THTE.description: Exploration of popular music styles and their direct application to professional musical theatre.

THTE.title: Movie Musical Development
THTE.description: Survey and analysis of musical films from the 1960s to the present towards the creation of an original musical project.

THTE.title: Media Training as Performance
THTE.description: The use of acting techniques to capitalize upon media interest opportunities across all platforms (print, audio and video) including podcast and social media.

THTE.title: Musical Theatre Repertoire
THTE.description: Development of a broad range of vocal book material to reflect the versatility of the performer.

THTR.title: Introduction to Acting
THTR.description: Study of diverse genres and disciplines of acting; fundamental techniques necessary for performance; scene study from contemporary text.

THTR.title: Introduction to Screen Acting
THTR.description: Introduction to the theoretical and foundational practices, techniques and strategies specific to screen acting in relation to the basic dynamics of acting for the stage.

THTR.title: Movement I
THTR.description: Basic training for the actor's body for expression and communication. Awareness and control through mind-body techniques.

THTR.title: Acting I
THTR.description: Basic principles and techniques of acting through theatre games and improvisation. Introduction to contemporary texts, basic characterization and cold reading techniques.

THTR.title: Improvisation and Theatre Games
THTR.description: Individual and group exercises to free the actor physically and emotionally and to stimulate creativity, imagination, and  self-expression.

THTR.title: Text Studies for Production
THTR.description: Focuses on the questions, artistic choices, methodologies, and approaches of an actor/director/designer in the preparation of a production score prior to rehearsal.

THTR.title: Introduction to Theatrical Production
THTR.description: Introduction to the non-performance areas of theatrical production(administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-onparticipation in USC productions.

THTR.title: Advanced Theatrical Production
THTR.description: Advanced understanding of non-performance areas of theatrical production (administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-on participation in USC productions.

THTR.title: Art of Theatrical Design
THTR.description: A guided student exploration of the fundamentals of applied design elements and their use as creative tools in the design process

THTR.title: History of Stand-Up Comedy
THTR.description: A comprehensive overview and understanding of how stand-up evolved in the United States, from the mid-1800's to the current touring performers.

THTR.title: Theatre on Film
THTR.description: Introduction to the theater and its relationship to society through major plays in film versions. Separate screenings to be arranged.

THTR.title: Comedy and Performance
THTR.description: Comedy and Performance traces the history of comedy in performance from its earliest incarnations to the present day.

THTR.title: Stardom: Creation, Management and Culture Impact
THTR.description: An exploration of the phenomena of stardom and celebrity across media, entertainment, sports and social influence, ranging from early modern theatre to current day.

THTR.title: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body
THTR.description: A comprehensive exploration of voice, speech and acting to strengthen the actors physical instrument.

THTR.title: Movement for Actors
THTR.description: Training and practice in the coordination of the physical          apparatus of the actor utilizing various movement techniques       through improvisation.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I
THTR.description: Continuing development of imagination leading to an increased range of dramatic expression through the formalized text of William Shakespeare.

THTR.title: Stage Make-up
THTR.description: Principles of stage make-up materials and skills allowing the  actors to enhance their features and techniques for moderate and  extreme aging, injuries, and character roles.

THTR.title: Communicating Theatrical Design Concepts
THTR.description: The visualization and communication of design ideas through free-hand and mechanical drawing: orthographics, isometrics,perspective, shades and shadows, plans, sections and elevations.

THTR.title: Costume Construction
THTR.description: Historical survey, theory and practice in construction of costume.

THTR.title: Stage Lighting
THTR.description: Theory and practice of theatrical lighting design including electricity, radiant energy, refraction, reflection, absorption, chromatic variation and electronic controls.

THTR.title: Stage Sound
THTR.description: Basic audio engineering science, how sound is measured, basic transducers and signal flow. Operation of recording and playback equipment used in theatrical sound design/mixing.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I: Drama/Comedy
THTR.description: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I: Drama/Comedy
THTR.description: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.

THTR.title: Introduction to Medical Clowning
THTR.description: Explores the art of clowning in hospitals for the purpose of improving the well-being of those in need.

THTR.title: Theatre in Los Angeles
THTR.description: Current state of American theatre, through a study of acting, playwriting, criticism, stage design, lighting, and dramatic styles.

THTR.title: Directing
THTR.description: Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.

THTR.title: LGBTQ Theatre
THTR.description: Explores the range and genealogy of LGBTQ theatre and performance across political, historical, and theatrical contexts.

THTR.title: Creating the Hit Podcast
THTR.description: Develops the ability to create a podcast. Focuses on skills to produce, perform, market and monetize a podcast across a variety of genres.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR.description: Further development of range and breadth of performance skills with emphasis on texts of heightened language and style.

THTR.title: Improv 2: Advanced Improv
THTR.description: An in depth study of improvised comedy scene work.  An exploration of the primary tools and structure for creating improvised scenes and developing characters for stage and screen.

THTR.title: Casting for Stage and Screen
THTR.description: Introduction of the casting principles and practices for four of the mediums that dominate entertainment: theatre, film, television and commercials.

THTR.title: Scene Design I
THTR.description: Historical styles, methods, and dramatic analysis for scene design as applied in contemporary practice.

THTR.title: Costume Design I
THTR.description: Historical styles, methods, and dramatic analysis in costume design as applied in contemporary practice. Execution of costume designs for assigned works.

THTR.title: Lighting Design I
THTR.description: Historical styles, methods and dramatic analysis in lighting design as applied in contemporary practice.

THTR.title: Stage Management I
THTR.description: Basic skills, including assembly of prompt book, blocking notation, and organizational and communication procedures applied in theater production.

THTR.title: Scenic Construction
THTR.description: Technology, organization, and operation of the theatrical scene shop centered around the proper and safe use of tools, the choosing of materials, and methods of construction.

THTR.title: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body II
THTR.description: Continued training in the areas of breath awareness, physical awareness, voice, speech work and movement training.

THTR.title: Basic Voice
THTR.description: a: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR.description: Building and sustaining character with special focus on stylized realism, subtext and heightened language. Multi-cultural text and methodologies.

THTR.title: Acting Shakespeare
THTR.description: Basic approach to the acting and analysis of the highly formalized texts of William Shakespeare.

THTR.title: Acting for Sitcoms
THTR.description: Provide an understanding as to how to work in half-hour television and streaming media.

THTR.title: Playwriting I
THTR.description: Essential elements of playwriting through weekly assignments, students' initiative, occasional productions of scenes, and extensive classroom analysis.

THTR.title: Drama as Human Relations
THTR.description: A focus on American ethnic and multicultural diversity from the  perspectives of gender, race, and myth as revealed in plays, film,  and other performance media.

THTR.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Substantive participation in a production sponsored by the School and supervised by the faculty.

THTR.title: Projection Design II
THTR.description: Projection design process, software, equipment, multi-media and digital technology concepts, and related documentation.

THTR.title: Acting Theory
THTR.description: Examination of the theoretical foundations of acting as an art form through the reading of primary historical texts.

THTR.title: Performing Identities
THTR.description: This course explores the live performance medium as a creative means of social redress and personal expression. Duplicates credit in the former THTR 393m.

THTR.title: Drawing and Rendering for the Theater
THTR.description: Drawing and rendering techniques appropriate for theater designers. Drawing and rendering.

THTR.title: Dialects
THTR.description: The study of standard American stage dialect using the international phonetic alphabet.

THTR.title: Advanced Drafting: Vectorworks
THTR.description: An exploration of computer aided drafting (CAD) software, including drafting standards as achieved with Vectorworks and related software.

THTR.title: The Digital Actor
THTR.description: Empowers the student to forge a career in acting by managing and utilizing the many facets of social and digital media.

THTR.title: The Business of Acting
THTR.description: Develops the student's ability to connect and combine managerial, economic and business-related skills with the craft and career of acting.

THTR.title: Senior Project
THTR.description: Contemporary material from plays and screenplays with an emphasis on individual challenges and problems.

THTR.title: Public Speaking as Performance: A Course for Non-Actors
THTR.description: Public speaking approached as performance, using acting techniques to communicate with confidence, clarity and charisma.

THTR.title: Magic
THTR.description: The dramatic art of making an audience believe something is impossible. the history and performance of magic including illusion, mentalism, vanishing, coin and card tricks.

THTR.title: Creator as Entrepreneur
THTR.description: Explores the tools required to forge a career as a contemporary creator, with an emphasis on producing and monetizing new work through modern platforms.

THTR.title: Audition Technique for Film, Television and New Media
THTR.description: Develop on-camera auditioning skills for actors at a professional level in a variety of film, television and new media venues.

THTR.title: Scene Design II
THTR.description: Continuation of 330.  Evolution of scene design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR.title: Costume Design II
THTR.description: Evolution of costume design through analysis of script,  environmental factors, and styles.

THTR.title: Lighting Design II
THTR.description: Continuation of THTR 332. Evolution of lighting design through analysis of script, environmental factors and styles.

THTR.title: Sound for Theatre
THTR.description: Introduction to electronic sound and sound reinforcement,  including basic equipment, recording, editing, and show operation.

THTR.title: Stage Properties
THTR.description: Organization, management, and construction of properties for the theatre.

THTR.title: Voice-over Acting
THTR.description: Acting techniques, recording studio technology and editing for the field of voice acting and voice-overs.

THTR.title: Production Management
THTR.description: The context and scope of work done by a Theatrical Production Manager. Students will learn about different types of theatrical organizations and how they are structured. Prerequisite: THTR 333. Recommended preparation: two units of THTR 397.

THTR.title: English Language Dubbing
THTR.description: Adapt the fundamentals tools of scene and character analysis to the specialized world of voice acting for English dubbing.

THTR.title: Fashion Influencing
THTR.description: Analysis of key influencers and aesthetics within relevant digital platforms for the fashion industry.

THTR.title: History of Fashion and the Costume
THTR.description: Introduction to four hundred years of fashion history drawing parallels between the fashion and period that it existed.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Focus on advanced acting, theatrical interdisciplinary storytelling styles explored in epic theatre.

THTR.title: Latinx Theatre
THTR.description: Explores the range and genealogy of Latinx theatre and performance from its origins in the last fifty years to the present.

THTR.title: Going Viral: Performance for New Media
THTR.description: A writing and performance course (partially online) for new media. Students will learn to create original short form and web series content for new media including YouTube, Funny or Die, Periscope and other Internet platforms.

THTR.title: Sketch Comedy for Theatre
THTR.description: A writing-performance workshop in which the students create, rehearse and perform original sketch comedy material.

THTR.title: Introduction to Stand Up Comedy
THTR.description: An introduction to the discipline of conceiving, writing, and creating original Stand Up Comedy routines

THTR.title: Acting on Camera: The Collaborative Process
THTR.description: Acting students will learn to develop on-camera acting skills and to collaborate with student directors and cinematographers from the School of Cinematic Arts.

THTR.title: African American Theatre, Dance, and Performance
THTR.description: A survey of African American theatre and cultural performance traditions as a reflection of both African American culture and American history.

THTR.title: Solo Performance
THTR.description: A writing-performance workshop in which students write, develop,  and rehearse original, autobiographical and character monologues  and perform them at the end of the semester.

THTR.title: Performance for Camera
THTR.description: Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students' understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Performance for Camera
THTR.description: Continued exploration of acting for film/television. Furthering the student's understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Stand Up 2: Becoming A Pro
THTR.description: Interactive performance and writing intensive focusing on creating professional level comedy material plus onstage performance strategies.

THTR.title: Acting in Television Commercials
THTR.description: An on-camera, workshop-style introduction to techniques, perspectives and theories unique to performing in television commercials.

THTR.title: Theatre Internship
THTR.description: Practical experience in the entertainment industry.

THTR.title: Directed Research
THTR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

THTR.title: Periods and Styles
THTR.description: A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Classical to Jacobean.

THTR.title: Experimental Theatre Workshop I
THTR.description: Guidance and direction in the production of new and experimental plays for a public audience. By audition.

THTR.title: Advanced Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Intensive participation in a production sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty, to increase and develop artistic growth.

THTR.title: Dramaturgical Perspectives and Approaches
THTR.description: Investigates art and craft of dramatic writing initiated/completed in other MFA in Dramatic Writing courses or that was submitted as a sample for program entry.

THTR.title: Advanced Movement
THTR.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage.

THTR.title: Advanced Movement
THTR.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage.  Includes Viewpoints and Clown.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs and solo performance.

THTR.title: Writing the Pacific Rim: Global and Western Dramatic Writing
THTR.description: Writing dramatically, utilizing the Pacific Rim and the Western United States as cultural sites of knowledge and as inspirations.

THTR.title: Textual Studies for Performance
THTR.description: Close textual reading of dramatic texts as a fundamental tool for  rehearsal and performance.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Advanced individual vocal development and application to a variety of professional and performance circumstances.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.

THTR.title: Diction and Dialects
THTR.description: Fundamentals of speech, diction, dialects and accents, including work in the International Phonetic Alphabet.

THTR.title: Singing for Actors
THTR.description: An introduction to the various facets of singing in theatrical performance

THTR.title: Dramatic Writing Studio
THTR.description: Investigates gestalt of the student dramatic writer's professional development from the empty page and writing fundamentals to the first-draft script, business affairs, and dramaturgical advancement.

THTR.title: Dramatic Writing Across Media for Playwrights
THTR.description: Intensive overview of career paths for playwrights in a wide array of media as they exist now, and as new opportunities arise.

THTR.title: Creative Production Projects
THTR.description: Advanced creative projects

THTR.title: Performance with Camera
THTR.description: Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Directed Research
THTR.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

THTR.title: Thesis Development and Attainment
THTR.description: Designed to guide the MFADW student toward refinement of thesis including vision, development, and execution.

THTR.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Substantive participation in productions sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty.

GRSC.title: Studies for the Qualifying Examination
GRSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Students may enroll in GRSC 800, once they have completed all other degree requirements, to prepare for their Qualifying Examination.

GRSC.title: Studies for the Qualifying Examination
GRSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Students may enroll in GRSC 800, once they have completed all other degree requirements, to prepare for their Qualifying Examination.
