GRSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Students may enroll in GRSC 800, once they have completed all other degree requirements, to prepare for their Qualifying Examination.

GRSC.title: Enrollment for PhD Students on an Approved Health Leave
GRSC.description: This course is administratively created to ensure continuing PhD  students have access to health insurance and other support while  on an approved health leave.

GRSC.title: Enrollment for PhD students on an Approved       Parental Leave
GRSC.description: This course is administratively created to ensure continuing PhD  students have access to health insurance and other support while  on an approved parental leave.

GRSC.title: Studies for Master's Examination
GRSC.description: Completion of all course work for the master's degree and  permission of the Graduate School.  Graded CR/NC.

ADSC.title: Fundamentals of Addiction Science
ADSC.description: Causes and consequences of addiction as they relate to the individual, family, community, and society are discussed. Addiction issues related to diverse populations are presented.

ADSC.title: Foundations in Addiction Science
ADSC.description: Transdisciplinary study of addiction science bridging the gap between science, practice and policy. Explores facets of addiction and applies theories to the study of addiction.

ADSC.title: Research Methods in Addiction Science
ADSC.description: Introduces research in addiction sciences through directed readings, live lectures and development of an independent research project.

HP.title: Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease     Prevention
HP.description: Introduction to strategies for promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.

HP.title: Nutrition and Health
HP.description: Nutrition as it relates to health promotion across the lifespan  and disease prevention.  Discussion of nutrients, factors  affecting food choices, food safety and global nutrition issues.

HP.title: Introduction to Global Health
HP.description: Introduction to concepts of global health and disease control.  Issues of globalization, global governance, emerging diseases,  infectious disease treatment, and outbreak challenges.

HP.title: Introduction to Research Apprenticeship
HP.description: Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under  supervision of a departmental faculty member.  Graded CR/NC.   Departmental approval.

HP.title: Principles of Human Behavior
HP.description: Overview and analysis of human behavior and the influences of behavior on health and disease.

HP.title: Biological and Behavioral Basis of Disease
HP.description: Examination of the major systems of the human body; disease  processes and behavioral risk factors.

HP.title: Health Behavior Statistical Methods
HP.description: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.

HP.title: Health Behavior Research Methods
HP.description: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health  behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches  to research and analysis. Recommended preparation: HP 340L

HP.title: Culture, Lifestyle, and Health
HP.description: Comparison of national and international differences in health status as influenced by cultural practices and lifestyles within geographic, economic, and political environments.

HP.title: Introduction to Epidemiology: Methods and Applications
HP.description: Examines the primary goals and methods of epidemiology, the study of factors that influence health and disease in individuals and populations.

HP.title: Gender and Minority Health Issues
HP.description: Examines the nature and roots of health disparities among women,men, and different ethnic and age groups; methods for reducing such disparities; strategies for prevention services.

HP.title: Violence as a Public Health Issue
HP.description: Patterns and prevalence of violence; psychosoical, environmental,  and biological influences on violent behavior; youth gangs; drugs  and violence; family violence; and prevention and intervention  strategies.

HP.title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology
HP.description: Overview of causative factors and demographic distributions of the  major chronic diseases in the western world; edpidemiologic  concepts and research designs.  Recommended preparation: HP 320

HP.title: Communicating Better Health: What Works and Why
HP.description: How communication -- interpersonal, mass media, information technologies -- shapes health behavior. Topics: doctor-patient consults; marketing campaigns; health in entertainment, news; internet; social media; mobile devices.

HP.title: Traditional Eastern Medicine and Modern Health
HP.description: Overview of traditional Eastern approaches toward health and  disease; relevance to modern health issues, emphasizing a  comparison between traditional Chinese and modern Western medicine. Recommended Preparation:  Fundamentals of Medicine

HP.title: Adolescent Health
HP.description: Survey of the development of healthy and the prevention of health-risk behaviors during adolescence. Prevention and promotion techniques will be explored emphasizing cultural differences.

HP.title: Global Health and Aging
HP.description: Examines global health in developed and developing countries in the context of population aging, including HIV/AIDS, malaria, obesity, inequality, global institutions, healthcare systems and drugs/pharmaceuticals.

HP.title: Directed Research
HP.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Open to HP majors only. Recommended preparation: HP 350L

CBG.title: Molecular Biology of Cancer
CBG.description: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity; retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology; treatment strategies.

CBG.title: Cancer  Biology and Genomics Research Seminar  Series
CBG.description: Cancer biology research seminar for doctoral students enrolled in the CBG program.

DSR.description: Selected topics in Development, Stem Cell, and Regeneration.

ANST.title: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia Practice
ANST.description: Advanced theory of anesthesia management for general and specialized procedures, diagnostic procedures, pediatrics and obstetrics.

ANST.title: Research: Investigative Inquiry
ANST.description: Utilization of research, which includes the evaluation of research, problem identification within the practice setting, awareness of practice outcomes and the clinical application of research. Recommended preparation: research course; basic statistics.

ANST.title: Analytical Methods for Evidence-Based Practice
ANST.description: Evaluation of the appropriateness of statistical methods applied to answer research questions and impact of statistical choice on applying evidence-based medicine to nurse anesthesia practice.

ANST.title: Healthcare Policy for Advocacy in Health Care
ANST.description: Examining the health care system focusing on policy development, health care costs, quality and patient safety, access to care, disparities, and future trends.

ANST.title: Advanced Health Assessment
ANST.description: Focuses on the patients health history, on inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation of major organ systems and differential diagnosis.

ANST.title: Leadership and Collaborative Practice
ANST.description: Emphasis on the professional components of nurse anesthesia practice including scope of practice, organizational leadership, accountability, ethics and collaborative practice.

ANST.title: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

ANST.title: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

ANST.title: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

ANST.title: Clinical Synthesis I
ANST.description: Lecture and simulation curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management and delivery.

ANST.title: Clinical Synthesis IV
ANST.description: Part four of a four-semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management and delivery.

ANST.title: PeriOperative Evaluation and Management I
ANST.description: Emphasizes the differential diagnosis, illness management, and perioperative optimization in patients presenting with hyperacute, acute, and chronic health alterations using illness scripts.

ANST.title: Doctoral Capstone Project
ANST.description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate.  The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

BIOC.title: Foundations for Molecular Medicine
BIOC.description: Structure, function and metabolism of nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates and lipids and related regulatory mechanism including transcription factor and upstream signaling pathways initiated at the cell membrane.

BIOC.title: Optimal Research Presentations
BIOC.description: Lectures by peers; formal critique; prepare and present own research to faculty and peer audiences.

BIOC.title: Toolbox for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
BIOC.description: Explores the principles and applications of traditional and state-of-the-art methods in molecular biology, biochemistry and cell biology with intensive problem-solving exercises in class.

BIOC.description: Research leading to the master of science degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree will be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

ACMD.title: Introduction to Academic Medicine Worldwide
ACMD.description: Introduces the master's program including four key roles of clinician educators: teacher, leader, scholar and mentor and a key theme, career development.

ACMD.title: Becoming a Leader in Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Current approaches to leadership within the context of academic medicine and health professions education, leadership styles, emotional intelligence, critical reflection, well-being and personal leadership journeys.

ACMD.title: Professionalism in Academic Medicine and Health
ACMD.description: Promoting, assessing and remediating performance of communication skills, culturally responsive care and professionalism within the context of health care complexity and challenges to well-being.

ACMD.title: Accreditation and Program Evaluation in Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Evaluating health professions training programs within guidelines of relevant accreditation organizations; models of evaluation, designing plans and tools for evaluation of program elements.

ACMD.title: Designing Research on Innovations in Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Introduction to design and scholarly review of innovations in health professions education; needs assessment, problem selection, use of research methods to study an innovation.

ACMD.title: Fieldwork: Designing Innovations for the Health Professions
ACMD.description: Individual projects designing curricular or other innovations for an individual program or specialty as an extension of program concepts or deepening the capstone experience.

IAS.title: Human Gross Anatomy
IAS.description: A complete dissection of the adult human body. Supplementary lectures and demonstrations. Emphasis on correlating development, structure and function. This course duplicates credit in former CNB 501a.

IAS.title: Human Gross Anatomy
IAS.description: A complete dissection of the adult human body. Supplementary lectures and demonstrations. Emphasis on correlating development, structure and function. This course duplicates credit in former CNB 501b.

IAS.title: Microscopic Anatomy I
IAS.description: Study of microscopic anatomy emphasizing embryonic origin of the body plan, cells, tissues, and organs; ultrastructural and functional correlations. Duplicates credit in former CNB 511a.

IAS.title: Neuroanatomy
IAS.description: Structure and function of the human nervous system with emphasis on central conduction pathways, especially those of clinical significance.

IAS.title: Cell Biology
IAS.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

IAS.title: Teaching in the Anatomical Sciences
IAS.description: Introduces pedagogical principles of learning and assessment, effective content delivery and instructional design for anatomical teaching.

IAS.title: Directed Research
IAS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

IAS.title: Research
IAS.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

INTD.title: Ethics and Accountability in Biomedical Research
INTD.description: The purpose of this course is to engage current (and potential)  research trainees in discussions about the responsible conduct of  science.  The course is designed as an option for meeting current  federal regulations which require that all predoctoral and  postdoctoral fellows paid from federal contracts and grants have a  component of ethical training.  Graded CR/NC.

INTD.title: Molecular Biology of Cancer
INTD.description: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity; retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology; treatment strategies.

INTD.title: Cell Biology
INTD.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

INTD.title: Introduction to Pathology
INTD.description: Normal histology and introduction to basic pathological concepts. Provides a solid and basic understanding of normal structures and how they relate to function.

INTD.title: Medical Biology Seminar
INTD.description: Selected topics in systems biology and disease.

INTD.title: Writing in the Biomedical and Biological Sciences
INTD.description: Writing instruction for graduate students focusing on grant proposals and scientific papers. Includes both writing and providing critiques of classmates work. Lectures and discussion. Open only to doctoral students in the school of Medicine.

INTD.title: Student Research Presentation
INTD.description: Students prepare and present their own research to an audience of faculty and peers. Graded CR/NC. Open only to graduate students.

INTD.title: Medical Students Elective Program
INTD.description: Opportunities for Medical students as preceptors, in research  laboratories or in field medical services under guidance of  sponsors approved by faculty committees. Graded CR/NC.

INTD.title: Pre-clinical System Block for Health, Technology and Engineering
INTD.description: A three-to-nine week block of lectures and laboratories focused on particular body system (e.g. Cardiovascular, Renal, etc.). Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

INTD.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
INTD.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

INTD.title: Research
INTD.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

MDED.title: Narrative Medicine I: Witnessing, Listening, Reflecting
MDED.description: Introduction to Narrative Medicine and history of health humanities; examine theories of narrative, trauma, witnessing, identity as related to health care and the clinical encounter.

MDED.title: Creative Writing and Its Applications in Narrative Medicine
MDED.description: Introduction to creative writing in the clinical setting; study of nonfiction/journalism, memoir, fiction and poetry; work toward a creative project that incorporates narrative medicine methods.

MDED.title: Research Methods in Narrative Medicine
MDED.description: Explore philosophical underpinnings of qualitative research and its use in health research; develop specific methodologies for data collection and assessment in Narrative Medicine.

MDED.title: Narrative Ethics: Illness, Disability, Equity and Community
MDED.description: Examine the relationship between illness and disability narratives and their familial, social and institutional contexts; develop skills in interviewing, close reading and writing toward publication.

MBPH.title: Directed Research
MBPH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MBPH.title: Research
MBPH.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MEDS.title: Skills and Strategies for Future Medical Professionals
MEDS.description: Development of academic strategies and exploration of pre-professional preparation for careers in medicine and healthcare.  Open only to students in the Keck PREP Scholars Program.

MEDS.title: Healthcare Foundations: Core Concepts and Terminology
MEDS.description: Introduction to and discussion on clinically relevant topics such as social determinants of health, medical ethics and legal and regulatory aspects, in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Professionalism and the Practice of Medicine
MEDS.description: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.

MEDS.title: What Is Primary Care Medicine?
MEDS.description: An exploration of the practice of primary care medicine which will discuss what primary care is and differences between primary care and specialist care.

MEDS.title: The Community Impact of Historical Trauma
MEDS.description: Examines collective experiences of historical trauma in various populations through a macro lens, focusing on promotion of mental health equity in impacted populations.

MEDS.title: Adverse Childhood Experiences and Trauma
MEDS.description: Examine the impact of adversity experienced during childhood with social development and neurodevelopment throughout the lifecycle and the bi-directional relationship with society through a trauma lens.

MEDS.title: Human Anatomy, Physiology, and the Technology of Medicine
MEDS.description: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how technology has transformed western medicine throughout history.

MEDS.title: Neurochemistry of Addiction: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior
MEDS.description: The neurochemistry of psychiatric illness and addiction, introduction to brain and nervous system biochemistry, anatomy and disease states. Covers prescribed medications and drugs of abuse.

MEDS.title: Organ Failure: Non-Communicable Chronic Disease
MEDS.description: An examination of frequently treated diseases with the greatest impact on society. Involvement of medical specialists as guests.

MEDS.title: Vertebrate Development and Regeneration
MEDS.description: Overview of the biological processes involved in vertebrate development and regeneration, including the cellular interactions and signal transduction pathways guiding organ development and repair.

MEDS.title: Medical Examiner-Coroner: Investigating Death
MEDS.description: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.

MEDS.title: Cancer: Biology, Prevention and Therapy from the Bench to th
MEDS.description: The basic aspects of cancer biology, prevention, diagnosis and therapy, as well as guest lectures by oncology researchers and health professionals.

MEDS.title: Emergency Health Care
MEDS.description: Principles of emergency medical services, ranging from pre-hospital care and advanced life-saving, to minor injuries and illnesses. Interactive experience with ER physicians/emergency health care providers. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Recommended preparation: MEDS 260.

MEDS.title: Directed Research in Biomedical Science
MEDS.description: Individual research and readings.

MEDS.title: Social Emergency Medicine: Practicum with the  CHLA CHAT Team
MEDS.description: Explores the social determinants of health through supervised on-site practicum with the Community Health Advocates Team at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles and didactic sessions.

MEDS.title: Basic Concepts in Global Health
MEDS.description: Exploration of global health issues facing resource-poor societies; emphasizes contributing factors including behavioral and physiological bases, economic, social, and political context.

MEDS.title: Core Principles System I
MEDS.description: Introduction to basic medical concepts and biological system functions; examination of core principles of science and medical treatment.

MEDS.title: Core Principles System II
MEDS.description: Continuation of concepts from MEDS 503L: basic medical concepts and biological system functions; examination of core principles of science and medical treatment.

MEDS.title: Global Health Modules, Malaria
MEDS.description: Critical issues in international control and treatment of malaria. Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of human-parasite interaction including dynamics of transmission among populations.

MEDS.title: Global Health Modules, Tuberculosis
MEDS.description: Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of tuberculosis including dynamics of transmission among populations. Overview of clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and treatment of infections.

MEDS.title: Cultural Humility in Health and Medicine
MEDS.description: Practical approach to the development of professional skills for providing culturally sensitive clinical health services to ethnically and linguistically diverse patients.

MEDS.title: Global Oral Health
MEDS.description: Better understand the key issues impacting global oral health, how better care can help reduce the disease prevalence, and ways to prepare the next generation of global health leaders to address the key issues. Open only to Global Medicine majors.

MEDS.title: Foundation of Medicine: Anatomy, Physiology, and Pathology
MEDS.description: Fundamentals of physiology, chemistry, anatomy, biochemistry and microbiology, as well as pharmacological issues, mathematical basis of lab instruments or techniques, and computational modeling

MEDS.title: Case Studies in Interprofessional Healthcare
MEDS.description: Survey of the specific roles each member of an interprofessional health team plays in the provision of care, based on their professional training. Application of diverse health professional expertise to case studies in healthcare.

MEDS.title: Directed Research
MEDS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MED.title: First Year Medicine
MED.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

MICB.title: Molecular and Cellular Immunology
MICB.description: Provides an in-depth examination of topics in molecular and cellular immunology through lectures, discussions, data analysis and oral/written student presentations.

MICB.title: Molecular Biology of Cancer
MICB.description: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity; retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology; treatment strategies.

MICB.title: Cell Biology
MICB.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

MICB.title: Student Seminar Series
MICB.description: Microbiology students will present research seminars describing their thesis progress.

MICB.title: Recent Advances in Microbiology
MICB.description: Intensive examination of selected topics in microbiology. Student presentations and critiques. Required of all graduate students.

MICB.title: Microbiology Research Seminar
MICB.description: Critical discussion of current research topics. Students present   published and unpublished research results for discussion and      critique.

MICB.title: Directed Research
MICB.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MICB.title: Master's Thesis
MICB.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MICB.title: Master's Thesis
MICB.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MICB.title: Master's Thesis
MICB.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MICB.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
MICB.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

NIIN.title: Neuroimaging and Systems Neuroscience
NIIN.description: Detailed overview of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neural systems with an emphasis on human neuroanatomy and imaging. Examples from clinical cases and their consequences will be explored.

NIIN.title: Fundamentals of Human Neuroimaging
NIIN.description: Survey of anatomical and functional neuroimaging approaches and their use to explore the healthy as well as diseased human brain. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN.title: Neuroimaging Data Acquisition w/ Magnetic Resonance Imaging
NIIN.description: Introduces the various approaches used to image the living brain using MR-based techniques. Covers neuroimaging scanning technologies, pulse sequence design, and sources of image artifact. Recommended preparation: familiarity with Matlab. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN.title: Neuroimaging Data Processing Methods
NIIN.description: Comprehensive investigation of data processing methods, software strategies, and workflow design and execution methodologies.

NIIN.title: Current Topics in Neuroimaging Informatics
NIIN.description: Leading researchers in the areas of basic and clinical brain imaging, computational methods, and informatics formally discuss their work for which students provide written critical review and comment.

OHNS.title: Communication Development and Disorders Across the Life Span
OHNS.description: Introduction to speech, language and hearing issues across the lifespan; examination of how issues of communication relate to social, medical and educational services needed.

OHNS.title: The Practice of Medical Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Introduction to the practice of medical speech language pathology; examination of the role of the speech language pathologist as a member of the medical speech pathology team.

OHNS.title: Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology for Speech, Language and He
OHNS.description: Neuroanatomy and neurophysiology with a concentration on basic human communication and swallowing processes, specifically pertaining to disorders and differences in speech, language and hearing.

OHNS.title: Speech Sound Disorders
OHNS.description: Focus on speech-sound production, assessment and treatment of childhood articulation and phonological disorders, emphasizing the study of efficient and effective procedures and service delivery models.

OHNS.title: Language and Literacy Disorders
OHNS.description: Focus on language and literacy disorders in children from birth through adolescence. Special emphasis on assessment, prevention and intervention methods across populations and multi-cultural backgrounds.

OHNS.title: Research Methods in Communication Sciences and Disorders
OHNS.description: Basic and applied research procedures in communication sciences and disorders, including research design, data collection and analysis and application to evidence-based practice for clinical practice.

OHNS.title: Speech-Language Pathology Methods and Evidence-Based Practic
OHNS.description: Overview of the clinical process for the prevention and remediation of communication disorders with emphasis on clinical methodology.

OHNS.title: School-Based Issues in Speech-Language Programs
OHNS.description: Legislative foundations for speech-language programs in schools, including due process, prevention, referral and assessment, Individualized Education Program (IEP) processes and procedures, service delivery and accountability.

OHNS.title: Motor Speech Disorders/Craniofacial Disorders
OHNS.description: Motor speech disorders including the dysarthrias and apraxia of speech, as well as craniofacial disorders. Neurological bases, characteristics, differential diagnosis, assessment, treatment and interprofessional collaboration.

OHNS.title: Multicultural Issues in Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Assessment and intervention considerations and methods for  individuals with communication disorders from multicultural and  multilingual populations. Focus on cultural sensitivity and  commitment to community and belonging.

OHNS.title: Externship in Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Speech-language pathology clinical experience in a supervised school-based, medically-based or private practice setting.

OHNS.title: Research Capstone in Communication Sciences and Disorders
OHNS.description: Capstone Research Project addressing a problem in the field of communication sciences and disorders. Students work under the guidance of a faculty member; culminates in a submission for presentation in a poster session at a professional conference.

PAIN.title: Where is the Pain: Mind-Body Interface and Pain Physiology
PAIN.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological components of pain, and pharmacological and non-pharmacological management strategies.  Cultural and social aspects of chronic pain are covered.

PAIN.title: Pharmacotherapeutics for Pain
PAIN.description: Introduction into the complex area of treatment with opioids and other pharmacological options.

PAIN.title: Pain Classification and Diagnosis - Part 1
PAIN.description: Introduction of pain classification and diagnosis to familiarize the student with a standardized approach to painful conditions.

PAIN.title: Psychological Aspects of the Pain Experience:    Individual and Family
PAIN.description: Explore the psychological and social perspectives that influence chronic pain, reinforcing the need to look beyond the initial physical diagnosis.

PAIN.title: Opioids
PAIN.description: Explores opioid therapeutics including proper use, dosing, side effects and its management, use in special populations, and legal/ethical considerations for prescribers and dispensers.

PAIN.title: Pain Classification and Diagnosis - Part 2
PAIN.description: Knowledge and ability to recognize fine differences in various common pain conditions.

PAIN.title: Advanced Pain Physiology and Neuroscience
PAIN.description: Advanced neurophysiology of pain including immunology and epigenetics, neuropathic pain, inflammation, with a series of lectures and sessions to analyze clinical cases.

PAIN.title: Research Methodology
PAIN.description: Conduct a systematic review, research question, searching the literature, summarizing the evidence and interpreting the findings.

PAIN.title: Pain Medicine Capstone
PAIN.description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

PAIN.title: Pain Medicine Capstone
PAIN.description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Complementary Approaches
PAIN.description: Treatment options in pain management; framework for integrative models of care.

PAIN.title: Palliative Care in End of Life
PAIN.description: Key concepts in palliative medicine and hospice care, ranging from management of common symptoms, to best practices in communication with patients and their families.

NEUM.title: Advanced Topics in Neuromedicine
NEUM.description: Introduces current research and advances in technologies related to diagnosis and treatment of neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and progress in research projects of student peers.

NEUM.title: Directed Research
NEUM.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

PBHS.title: Science and Practice of Building Resilience
PBHS.description: Promotes learning principles and skills that enhance resilience to effectively navigate common stressors throughout a professional career through course lecture, group discussion, reflection and practice.

PBHS.title: The Community Impact of Historical Trauma
PBHS.description: Examines collective experiences of historical trauma in various populations through a macro lens, focusing on promotion of mental health equity in impacted populations.

PBHS.title: Adverse Childhood Experiences and Trauma
PBHS.description: Examine the impact of adversity experienced during childhood with social development and neurodevelopment throughout the lifecycle and the bi-directional relationship with society through a trauma lens.

PHBI.title: Advanced Overview of Neurosciences
PHBI.description: Study of the nervous system at multiple levels through the analysis of four themes: Motor Control; Emotion, Motivation, and Decision-Making; Memory and Learning; and Vision. Prerequisites: BISC 421. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 524.)

PHBI.title: Cell Biology
PHBI.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

PATH.title: Cell Biology
PATH.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

PATH.title: Introduction to Pathology
PATH.description: Normal histology and introduction to basic pathological concepts. Provides a solid and basic understanding of normal structures and how they relate to function.

PATH.title: Emerging Methods in Cellular and Clinical Pathology
PATH.description: Discuss key methodologies in biomedical research, applications/case studies in cell biology, protein analysis, flow cytometry, identification of microorganisms, drug development, cellular and molecular cancer immunotherapy.

PATH.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Behavioral Sciences I
PCPA.description: Current concepts of behavioral medicine as applied to providing  health care to diverse populations and investigations of medical  care organization and the physician assistant.  Open to Physician  Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA.title: Behavioral Sciences III
PCPA.description: In a seminar format, information management and research methods  are explored as well as ethical issues of PA practice will be  discussed.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA.title: Clinical Skills I
PCPA.description: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to  medical practice.  First of four courses.  Open to Physician  Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA.title: Clinical Skills III
PCPA.description: Designed to prepare the physician assistant to complete a series of medical procedures.

PCPA.title: Basic Medical Sciences I
PCPA.description: Focuses on clinical anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology, and pathology, essential to understanding disease mechanisms commonly encountered in medicine.

PCPA.title: PA Critical Thinking Course I
PCPA.description: Team-based learning to prepare the physician assistant to learn  and practice applying critical thinking in clinically relevant  scenarios.

PCPA.title: PA Critical Thinking Course III
PCPA.description: Builds upon PCPA 537; team-based learning to prepare the physician  assistant to learn and practice applying critical thinking in  clinically relevant scenarios.

PCPA.title: Topics in Medicine I
PCPA.description: Designed to prepare the physician assistant learn the requisite medical and pharmacologic knowledge to diagnose and treat patients.

PCPA.title: Topics in Medicine III
PCPA.description: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in  the study of human disease.  The third of three courses that  includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic  studies, and medicine.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice  majors only.

PCPA.title: Basic Medical Sciences III
PCPA.description: Builds upon PCPA 540; focuses on clinical anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology and pathology, essential to understanding disease mechanisms commonly encountered in medicine.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment II
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment III
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment VI
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-appoved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment VII
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment VIII
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Laboratory Techniques in Developmental and Stem Cell Biology
SCRM.description: Laboratory course that focuses on the theory and practice of embryology to study developmental biology, and cell culture to study stem cell biology.

SCRM.title: Vertebrate Development and Regeneration
SCRM.description: Overview of the biological processes involved in vertebrate development and regeneration, including the cellular interactions and signal transduction pathways guiding organ development and repair.

SCRM.title: Regenerative Medicine: Principles, Paradigms and Practice
SCRM.description: Examination of molecular and cellular processes that generate, maintain and repair body systems. Special emphasis on stem cell biology with clinical applications to regenerative medicine.

SCRM.title: Directed Research
SCRM.description: Individual research and readings under the guidance of a faculty member.

SCRM.title: Developmental Biology and Human Embryology
SCRM.description: Survey of anatomical, cellular and molecular processes that underlie human development and congenital malformations, with discussion of other species for comparison. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM.title: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine
SCRM.description: A comprehensive investigation of embryonic, fetal and adult stem cells and the application of stem cell biology to treat disease. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM.title: Tools and Techniques in Stem Cell Biology
SCRM.description: Introduces students to classical and cutting-edge techniques used to assess stem cells and regenerating systems.

SCRM.title: Writing About Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine
SCRM.description: Instruction in writing for various audiences on topics related to stem cell biology and regenerative medicine.

SCRM.title: Stem Cell and Developmental Biology Seminar Series
SCRM.description: Selected topics in Development, Stem Cell, and Regeneration.

SCRM.title: For master's students only
SCRM.description: Selected topics in Development, Stem Cell, and Regeneration.

SCRM.title: SCRM External Speaker Seminar Series
SCRM.description: Reading and discussion of recent papers by the SCRM speaker of the week, and attendance at the speaker's seminar. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM.title: Independent Research
SCRM.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of faculty in the Department of Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine.

SCRM.title: Master's Thesis
SCRM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Master's Thesis
SCRM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Master's Thesis
SCRM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
SCRM.description: Part- or full-time, practical work experience or research in the  field of stem cell biology and regenerative medicine. Students are  individually supervised by faculty.

SCRM.title: For master's students only Reading scientific papers 101
SCRM.description: Selected topics on sub-fields within stem cell biology and organogenesis. Includes review of contemporary literature and research. Open only to master and doctoral students.

SCRM.title: For PhD students, Cell Fate Specification in Development and Regeneration
SCRM.description: Selected topics on sub-fields within stem cell biology and organogenesis. Includes review of contemporary literature and research. Open only to master and doctoral students.

PM.title: Foundations of Health Behavior
PM.description: Overview of behavioral theory and research in disease prevention and health promotion and in adaptation to chronic disease, including an introduction to measures of outcomes. Prerequisite: Admission to HBR Ph.D. Program or permission of instructor.

PM.title: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
PM.description: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of  health education and promotion.  Examines the determinants of  health behavior and strategies for change at the individual, group  and community level.

PM.title: Foundations of Public Health
PM.description: Overview of public health concepts and issues, including population health; ethics; health disparities, determinants, and systems of care; global health; policy; health promotion; environmental health.

PM.title: Overcoming Real World Challenges in Global Health
PM.description: Overview of program implementation challenges in global health contexts, including best practices for establishing effective cross-cultural collaborations, working with key leaders, and operationalizing complex interventions.

PM.title: Public Health Services Research Methods
PM.description: A practical examination of methods and data sources used to evaluate public health services and conduct policy research and evaluation within health care delivery systems.

PM.title: Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
PM.description: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

PM.title: Principles of Biostatistics
PM.description: Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of  health statistics; practice in the application of statistical  procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL,  SPSS, nQuery.  Laboratory.

PM.title: Data Analysis
PM.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

PM.title: Data Analysis
PM.description: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package.  Includes laboratory.

PM.title: Data Analysis
PM.description: Methods and applications for modeling longitudinal, time-to-event and multi- level data. Includes laboratory using R package. Lecture 2 hrs; laboratory 2 hrs. Prerequisites: PM-511b.

PM.title: Principles of Epidemiology
PM.description: Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of  population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment;  common sources of bias in population studies; principles of  screening. Recommended preparation: algebra

PM.title: Biostatistical Consulting
PM.description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems. Introduces students to the field of biostatistical consulting.

PM.title: Research Methods in Epidemiology
PM.description: Study design, ascertainment of study objects, questionnaire development, various methodological issues in  study design and interpretation including bias, measurement error, confounding and effect modification.

PM.title: Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
PM.description: a: Density distribution and hazard functions; normal, chi-square, student's t and F distributions; and sampling procedures for single factor and multiple factor designs, distributions. Recommended preparation: working knowledge of multivariable calculus and familiarity with linear algebra.

PM.title: Culture and Health: Global Perspectives
PM.description: International variations in health status with a focus on the impact of socioeconomic status, politics, environment, education and gender in etiology of illness, access to health care, progression of disease, and recovery.

PM.title: Environmental Health: An Epidemiological Approach
PM.description: An overview of environmental health, identifying issues in assessing effects of exposure on health and potential interventions for reducing adverse health risks. Prerequisite: PM-512

PM.title: Statistical Genetics
PM.description: Familial aggregation, segregation analysis, linkage analysis, association, regressive models, gene-environment interactions, genetic heterogeneity and linkage disequilibrium.

PM.title: Program Evaluation and Research
PM.description: Overview of concepts, tools, data collection, analysis methods and  designs used to evaluate health promotion programs.  Examples from  substance abuse prevention, family planning and reproductive  health programs.

PM.title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology
PM.description: Overview of causative factors and demographic distribution of major chronic diseases in the western world. Epidemiologic concepts, methods and research design as applied to chronic disease prevention will be emphasized. Prerequisite: PM 512.

PM.title: Statistical Programming With R
PM.description: The contents include: R objects, control structure, data input and output, subsetting objects, data manipulation and aggregations, character manipulation, graphics, and writing user-defined functions. Recommended preparation: Knowledge of one programming language other than R or a half-year experience programming in R.

PM.title: Organizing and Mobilizing Communities for Public Health
PM.description: Survey of effective community organizing and mobilization efforts in the U.S. and abroad, using participatory, organizational, community empowerment and public-private partnership models.

PM.title: Public Health Leadership and Management
PM.description: Introduction to leadership and management concepts, tools, and practices in the context of domestic and global public health and healthcare delivery settings.

PM.title: Introduction to Global Health
PM.description: Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.

PM.title: Introduction to Health Data Science
PM.description: An introduction to the toolsets needed to create workable and reproducible datasets, conduct exploratory analysis and visualizations, learn from data, summarize and communicate analytic results.

PM.title: Public Health Disaster Management and Response
PM.description: Definition and chronology of natural and man-made disasters and their effects on the global community. Structure and organization of disaster management systems and the role of humanitarian organizations.

PM.title: Ethical Issues in Public Health
PM.description: Ethical principles in the distribution of health resources, conduct of global public health research, and implementation of public health initiatives across different nations, cultures, religions.

PM.title: Spatial Statistics
PM.description: An introduction to statistical methods for analyzing and interpreting spatially referenced data topics include: geostatistics, areal data, point pattern data and visualization.

PM.title: Directed Research
PM.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Regression Analysis for Health Data Science
PM.description: Provides a rigorous introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data with a focus on regression modeling for continuous and binary outcomes.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PM.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty.

PM.title: Practicum in Public Health
PM.description: Applied practical experience through field placement in federal, state, and/or local public health agencies/organizations, including community-based organizations; research and school-based settings.

PM.title: Capstone in Public Health
PM.description: Provides the culminating, integrative learning experience for students enrolled in the Master of Public Health program.

PM.title: Seminar in Biostatistics and Epidemiology
PM.description: Special topics of current interest to provide background for  research in biostatistics and epidemiology.  Based largely on  student dissertation research.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Clinical Translational Reseach I
PM.description: First of three courses in CTR, a discipline that fosters multidirectional integration of basic, patient-oriented and population-based research with long-term goal of improving public health. Recommended preparation: PM 510.

PM.title: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
PM.description: Concepts and major methods in artificial neural networks and deep learning, including backpropagation, CNN, RNN, GAN.

PM.title: Introduction to Causal Inference in Epidemiology
PM.description: Introduces students to modern causal inference methods for epidemiological research including both theoretical background and practical applications.

PM.title: Theory of Statistics for the Health Sciences
PM.description: Theory of statistics behind most commonly used statistical inference and machine learning methods in biomedical applications.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior. Recommended preparation PM 604.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of Health Behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of Health Behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior.

PM.title: Directed Research In Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of health behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Research Seminar in Health Behavior
PM.description: Short seminar presentations and discussions on issues             accompanying the development of the field of health behavior and   implementation of research in this field.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Research
PM.description: Research applicable to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

TRGN.title: Basic Foundations in Translational Biomedical Informatics
TRGN.description: Translational biomedical informatics analysis of next-generation sequencing genomic data, fundamentals, foundations, and concepts for applied analysis, human ontology, application molecular tools, basic computing.

TRGN.title: Introduction to Human Genomic Analysis Methods
TRGN.description: Translational next generation sequencing genomics microarrays, RNA-seq, exome sequencing, annotation, transcriptome, ontology, pipelines, variants, expression, methylation.

TRGN.title: Translational Biomedical Informatics Capstone Portfolio
TRGN.description: Portfolio, translational biomedical informatics, bioinformatics, genomics, application development, web-based application.

TRGN.title: Translational Biotechnology Practicum
TRGN.description: Experiential training based on a project in a biomedical, biotechnology or pharmaceutical setting.

TRGN.title: Translational Biotechnology Capstone Defense
TRGN.description: Finalization and defense of capstone project.

TRGN.title: Biotechnology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization I
TRGN.description: Global biotechnology industry, idea generation, business plan formulation, intellectual property protection, funding, personnel management including board composition, regulatory body interaction, company exits.

TRGN.title: Exploring Chemical and Biological Therapeutic Modalities
TRGN.description: Turning molecules into drugs and cells into therapeutics. Emphasizing selection, development and optimization of appropriate modalities to target specific key defects in diseases.

TRGN.title: Communicating Science: Writing
TRGN.description: Written communication modalities for accurate and effective transmission of scientific information to a wide audience in biomedical, healthcare, and related industries.

TRGN.title: Directed Research
TRGN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

GERO.title: Gerontology: The Science of Adult Development
GERO.description: Introduction to adult development through the lifespan;  biological, psychological, and social processes; gerontology as a  career for the future.

GERO.title: Introduction to Geroscience Research
GERO.description: Understand central concepts of aging which form the basis of current age-related research in diverse areas of gerontology.

GERO.title: Current Topics in Geroscience Research
GERO.description: Advanced training in reading primary research articles on current topics related to the science of aging and longevity.

GERO.title: Physiology of Aging
GERO.description: Effects of normative aging processes on homeostatic mechanisms and how these changes relate to development of disorder and disease in later life.

GERO.title: Psychology of Adult Development
GERO.description: How psychologists study thinking, memory, emotions, personality, and behavior, and how people change in these throughout adulthood to old age.

GERO.title: Introduction to Psychology and Aging
GERO.description: An introduction to the core curriculum in the study of Gerontology. Research perspectives on adult development and aging; methodological issues; personality and relationship issues; general mental and emotional components of aging; research methods.

GERO.title: Society and Adult Development
GERO.description: How social relationships affect adults of different ages; the changing contract across generations; interaction of culture, race, family and social values with adult development.

GERO.title: Diversity in Aging
GERO.description: Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.

GERO.title: Physiology, Nutrition, and Aging
GERO.description: Explores nutritional needs and the physiological, psychological, and sociological relationships to nutrition. Laboratory experiments in assessment and evaluation.

GERO.title: Neuroaffective Disorders of Aging
GERO.description: Methods of studying, evaluating, and treating cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral problems associated with medical conditions of old age.

GERO.title: The Cellular Basis of Learning and Memory
GERO.description: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.

GERO.title: Aging and Business
GERO.description: An introduction to the dynamic roles of business in an aging  society focusing on workplace issues, marketing to mature  consumers, and careers for business gerontologists.

GERO.title: Ethical Issues in Geriatric Health Care
GERO.description: Biomedical ethical issues that are encountered in working with geriatric patients. Examination of ethical theory and the application of theory to clinical settings.

GERO.title: Genetics of Aging in UK, Ireland and the United States
GERO.description: Fundamentals of genetics and the role the environment plays related to  longevity and health outcomes in three specific populations.

GERO.title: Global Health and Aging
GERO.description: Examines global health in developed and developing countries in the context of population aging, including HIV/AIDS, malaria, obesity, inequality, global institutions, healthcare systems and drugs/pharmaceuticals.

GERO.title: Directed Research
GERO.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GERO.title: Practicum
GERO.description: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies.  Graded  CR/NC.

GERO.title: Practicum in Geriatric Care
GERO.description: Supervised experience in a geriatric health care setting which  allows students to put theories and ideas into practive.  Graded  CR/NC.  Lecture, discussion, and fieldwork.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Perspectives on a Changing Society: An Introduction to Aging
GERO.description: A web based course analyzing physical, mental, and social age-related changes as well as implications of population aging trends for individuals and society.

GERO.title: Applied Legal and Regulatory Issues in Aging
GERO.description: Analysis of shifting legal and regulatory issue affecting the  delivery of aging services.

GERO.title: Marketing and Shifts in Consumer Decision Making
GERO.description: Branding, marketing, and consumer behavior through examination of  established, transitioning and emerging aging services and  organizations.

GERO.title: Current Issues in Aging Services Management
GERO.description: Basic skills needed for an executive working in an aging services  environment. Recommended for entry level administrators and  managers.

GERO.title: End of Life Care
GERO.description: Examination of programs related to end of life care. Cultural  competencies in working with a diverse population on end of life  issues.

GERO.title: Physiology of Development and Aging
GERO.description: Examination of lifespan physiology of human development, growth, and aging; major emphasis in the physiology of the later years and implications for health maintenance.

GERO.title: Fundamentals of Clinical Nutrition Screening and Assessment
GERO.description: Examines tools and resources used to evaluate the nutrition status of individuals across the lifespan including biochemical, anthropometric and subjective global assessment. Open only to graduate students.

GERO.title: Communicating Nutrition and Health
GERO.description: Overview of current understanding of the dietary and nutritional needs of individuals across their lifespan. Open only to graduate students.

GERO.title: Fundamentals of Nutrition: Macronutrients
GERO.description: Principles of metabolism of macronutrients (carbohydrates, lipids and proteins) and human nutrition; life stages, disease states, consumption, digestion, absorption, transport and storage of macronutrients.

GERO.title: Food Production and Food Service Management
GERO.description: A study of principles and procedures for food systems including techniques of food preparation, development, modification and evaluation of recipes, menus and products. Open only to graduate students.

GERO.title: Current Topics in Clinical Nutrition
GERO.description: Discuss various factors that affect nutrition and aging. Topics include allergies in nutrition, food toxins, weight factors, and prevention and treatment of multiple organ systems. Open only to graduate students.

GERO.title: Life Span Developmental Psychology
GERO.description: Behavior from adulthood to old age; study of major components of behavior such as perception, cognitive processes, personality, intergenerational relationships, sexuality, and life styles.

GERO.title: Life Span Developmental Sociology
GERO.description: Life-span perspective on the sociological theories of marriage and the family, intergenerational relationships, work and retirement, and other forms of social organization.

GERO.title: Social Policy and Aging
GERO.description: Major legislation and programs; examination and analysis of policy-making and political processes affecting development and implementation of programs for older persons.

GERO.title: Integrating Gerontology: A Multidisciplinary Approach
GERO.description: Aging (commonalities and distinctions) as addressed by biologists,psychologists, and sociologists. Topics include researchperspectives, normative agings, functional decline and disability,and aging and society.

GERO.title: Multiple Chronic Conditions, Polypharmacy and Geriatric Synd
GERO.description: Complexities of treating older persons with multiple chronic diseases and conditions.

GERO.title: Cognitive Decline: Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia and Adva
GERO.description: Covers cognitive decline for people with Alzheimers Disease or other forms of dementia.  Imaging technology to identify and find treatment options.

GERO.title: Prevention of Chronic Diseases through Nutrition, Physical A
GERO.description: Nutrition, psychical engagement and social interaction. Interventions, assessments, screening protocols and guidelines for nutrition in older adults.

GERO.title: Adaptive Age-Friendly Environments and Injury Prevention
GERO.description: Covers adaptive, age-friendly environment and injury prevention for older adults. Adaptations in household safety, assistive technology, ergonomics and universal design principles.

GERO.title: Leadership and Management in Senior Living
GERO.description: Management and leadership in senior living organizations. Managerial techniques as well as leadership styles will be analyzed and reviewed.

GERO.title: Finance and Senior Living
GERO.description: Unique aspects of senior living financial structures, revenue management and accounting principles.

GERO.title: Revenue Management for Senior Living
GERO.description: Understanding of revenue sources for senior living. Develop skills and approaches to managing sustainable strategies.

GERO.title: Fundamental Skills in Gerontology
GERO.description: Hard and soft subject specific-skills integral to success in social sciences and which enhance understanding and learning through courses offered in gerontology.

GERO.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
GERO.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

GERO.title: Case Studies in Leadership and Change Management
GERO.description: Examination of case studies of issues affecting the aging services  industries and the role industry leaders play in reacting to  change.

GERO.title: Directed Research
GERO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Field Practicum
GERO.description: Supervised experiential learning in one or more organizations     that serve older adults; includes a regularly scheduled seminar.   Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Multidisciplinary Research Seminar in Aging
GERO.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on current research in Gerontology including physiology, neurobiology, health and medicine, psychology, sociology and public policy. Topics will change each semester.

GERO.title: Research Methods
GERO.description: An introduction to research methods and their application to gerontology including problem formation, research design, data collection, descriptive and analytical statistics, interpretation, and report preparation.

GERO.title: Financial Gerontology
GERO.description: Examination of special topics in the area of Gerontology.

GERO.title: Geroscience: Molecular and Cellular Biology
GERO.description: Emphasizes the molecular and cellular biology of aging and age-related pathology and other aspects of basic aging research, including evolutionary biology, demography, epidemiology and bioinformatics.

GERO.title: Seminar on Discoveries in Biogerontology
GERO.description: Critical analyses of primary scientific data and interpretations presented in the literature. (Duplicates credit in former GERO 602)

GERO.title: Research Integrity
GERO.description: Explores scientific integrity, mentoring, scientific record keeping, authorship, peer review, animal and human experimentation, conflict of interest, data ownership and intellectual property, and genetic technology.

GERO.title: Geroscience Scientific Writing
GERO.description: Scientific writing for F31 grant proposals to the National Institute on Aging (NIA); translates to other grant and fellowship mechanisms.

GERO.title: Laboratory Rotations in the Biology of Aging
GERO.description: Mandatory organized laboratory rotation. Allows students to participate in laboratory activities. Designed to help select dissertation advisor and research.

GERO.title: Neuroscience of Human Aging
GERO.description: Identifying structural and functional changes, methodologies used, psycho-social and environmental factors, age-related changes and the future of brain aging.

GERO.title: Politics and Policy Processes in an Aging Society
GERO.description: Dynamics of the policy-making process in the context of aging policy in the United States; focus on the political system and its social dynamics.

GERO.title: Research
GERO.description: Research leading up to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied toward the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ARTL.title: Arts Leadership and Arts Entrepreneurship
ARTL.description: Introduction to key issues involved in both managing an arts organization and creating sustainable enterprise. For students in music, arts, public policy, and related fields.

ARTL.title: Executive Leadership in the Arts
ARTL.description: Investigation into a variety of leadership approaches within an arts organization, with a focus on the development of the students own leadership capacity.

ARTL.title: Arts Organizations: Innovation and New Models
ARTL.description: Designed for current and future arts leaders interested in looking critically at organizational practice and bringing innovative solutions to old problems in a contemporary context.

ARTL.title: Arts Leadership Practicum
ARTL.description: Year-long practicum which puts ideas and concepts into practice. Each student will conceptualize, develop, and complete an arts project of his/her own choosing.

ARTL.title: Arts Leadership Intensive
ARTL.description: Five-day, intensive course that serves as a deep-dive introduction to the field for all Arts Leadership students.

ARTL.title: Directed Research

MTEC.title: Music Production I
MTEC.description: Introduction to computer-based audio recording systems and audio recording, editing and mixing procedures and techniques.

MTEC.title: Fundamentals of Audio Recording
MTEC.description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of audio recording. Students will gain a basic understanding of signal flow, gain structure, microphones, monitoring systems, signal processing, mixing. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275a.

MTEC.title: Critical Listening
MTEC.description: Introductory course where students will develop an understanding of audio quality, the musical aspects of audio production and the vocabulary necessary to offer audio critique. Recommended preparation: MTEC-175. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275a.

MTEC.title: Music Production II
MTEC.description: Study of small ensemble (rhythm section, vocal, background vocals) music production in a variety of popular music styles.

MTEC.title: Introduction to MIDI Sequencing
MTEC.description: Introductory course where students will learn to use professional MIDI sequencing software to sequence, edit, and realize music compositions.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Audio Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Introduction to the techniques and applications of recording, editing and mixing sound on personal computers.

MTEC.title: Fundamentals of Audio Engineering
MTEC.description: Fundamentals of Audio Engineering is an intermediate course in the principles and techniques of professional audio production as related to music. Recommended preparation: MTEC-175 and MTEC-176. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275b.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Music Technology
MTEC.description: A survey of the technology used to create, prepare, perform, and distribute music, with an emphasis on recording, MIDI, music production, mastering and Internet technologies. Not available for major credit to B.M. and B.S., Music Industry majors. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 277.)

MTEC.title: Individual Instruction
MTEC.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction in the applications of technology to the creation and performance of music. Recommended preparation: Experience with audio recording and synthesizers.

MTEC.title: Music Production III
MTEC.description: Small group instruction to develop the student's arranging, production and project management skills as related to small budget music and multimedia projects.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Mixing and Mastering
MTEC.description: Fundamental principles and techniques used to fuse multiple audio elements into clear, comprehensive final products.

MTEC.title: Music Production IV
MTEC.description: Advanced study of working as a songwriter-producer in the modern music industry.

MTEC.title: Advanced Instrumental Recording
MTEC.description: An in-depth study of the standard practices and techniques used in contemporary multi-track recording.

MTEC.title: Advanced Music Production for Non-Majors
MTEC.description: The study of small music production in a variety of popular music styles with the goal of developing the students arranging, production and project management skills.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Sound Reinforcement
MTEC.description: An overview of the acoustic, technical and musical aspects of amplifying audio for live performance.

MTEC.title: Desktop Music Production
MTEC.description: Intermediate course where students will learn to use professional MIDI sequencing and digital audio software to compose, edit, and mix songs and other music compositions. Recommended preparation: MTEC-245. Duplicates credit in former MUIN 305.

MTEC.title: Non-Linear MIDI Sequencing
MTEC.description: An in-depth course focusing on the principles and techniques of sequencing and performing musical compositions using a non-linear sequencer. Recommended preparation: MTEC 245.

MTEC.title: Advanced Desktop Music Production
MTEC.description: Students will learn to apply their musical and technical skills to create professional quality computer-based arrangements in a variety of musical styles. Recommended preparation: MTEC 443 or MTEC 444 and MTEC 474a.

MTEC.title: Computer Assisted Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Techniques and applications of recording and editing sound on personal computers. Hardware, software, editing for song, sound effects and dialog for film. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 446a.)

MTEC.title: Computer Assisted Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Techniques and applications of recording and editing sound on personal computers. Hardware, software, editing for song, sound effects and dialog for film. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 446b.)

MTEC.title: Computer Music Notation and Preparation
MTEC.description: Techniques and principles of computer music notation including conventions of music notation, idiomatic practices, preparation of significant score types, and MIDI basics. Duplicates credit in former MUIN 448.

MTEC.title: Electronic Synthesizer Techniques
MTEC.description: Electronic music procedures in a multi-track studio. Duplicates credit in former MUEA 474ax.

MTEC.title: Electronic Synthesizer Techniques
MTEC.description: Electronic music procedures in a multi-track studio. Computer applications. Duplicates credit in former MUEA 474b.

MTEC.title: Remote Recording Techniques
MTEC.description: Special problems of location recording; specialized equipment; microphone design and operation. Prerequisite: MTEC 275. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 477.)

MTEC.title: Advanced Multichannel Remix
MTEC.description: Special problems of multi-channel re-mixing with simultaneous audio re-processing. Album, film, television and multimedia formats will be covered. Prerequisite: MTEC 446a. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 478.)
