MUIN.title: Introduction to the Music Industry
MUIN.description: A survey of the music business with emphasis on distribution of recorded music, music publishing, performance rights societies, record companies, agents, personal managers and contracts. Open to  music majors (B.M. and B.S. degrees) only.

MUIN.title: Basics of the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Introductory survey of the music business. Topics include: copyright, record companies, contracts, music publishing, performance rights societies, managers, agents, and other artist team/income considerations. Not for major credit for Music Industry Majors. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 372ax.)

MUIN.title: Communications in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: A comprehensive course on communications specific to the music industry with a focus on press and publicity for artists.

MUIN.title: Introduction to Music Law
MUIN.description: A study of entertainment law with a focus on the music industry.Areas of study include contracts, domestic practices,international practices, copyright protection, trademarks. Prerequisites: MUIN 270.

MUIN.title: Music Publishing and Licensing
MUIN.description: A contemporary survey of the methods used to monetize music through licensing/media placement, covering music publishing, songwriter agreements, performance rights and licenses for traditional/new media. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Business and Legal Aspects of the Music Industry
MUIN.description: An intermediate/advanced-level survey of music copyright law, artist contract analysis, infringement case studies as they affect modern/emerging business models and global music licensing.

MUIN.title: Marketing, Branding and Strategic Alliances in Music
MUIN.description: An in-depth study of music marketing, non-traditional revenue streams for artists, musicians, and labels including artist endorsements, artist tour sponsorships, digital music programs, music licensing, merchandise, and a primary focus on brand partnership deals in the music space. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: DIY Music Marketing
MUIN.description: An exploration of the most current and effective marketing strategies and online branding tools for promoting, monetizing, and sustaining the career of the independent creative artist. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Live Music Production and Promotion
MUIN.description: A survey of the presentation of the live musical experience. Both classical and popular concert presentation will be examined including venue selection, promotion and security.

MUIN.title: Music Supervision
MUIN.description: An advanced focus on the music supervisors role, working with directors, producers, licensing representatives and executives to select, budget and clear songs for broadcast/new media.

MUIN.title: Practicum in Music Industry Issues (Internship)
MUIN.description: Field application of music industry theories and practices; part-time employment. Project jointly defined by student, employer and professor.

MUIN.title: Streaming Economy in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Focus on identifying the economic impact current music streaming models have on artists, record labels, publishing and consumers.

MUIN.title: Music Festival Design and Management
MUIN.description: Focus on planning, booking, marketing, promoting, ticketing and operating a festival in an ever-changing marketplace.

MUIN.title: Technology, Big Data and Marketing in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Analyzing technologys relationship to the music industry. Use of data and analytics to develop successful strategies for new and existing artists.

MUIN.title: Ethics in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Focus on the intellectual/philosophical foundations of the modern interpretation and application of ethics within the music industry.

MUIN.title: DIY Touring
MUIN.description: A "hands-on" approach to learning the essential components of a successful small-market tour through the DO IT YOURSELF artist lens.

MUIN.title: Directed Research
MUIN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MUIN.title: Artificial Intelligence in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: DIY Record Company
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Legal Writing for the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Music, Money & Magic: Creative Innovation and Design         Thinking
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: The Intersection of Music and Sports
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Final Capstone Project
MUIN.description: Culmination of the four-year course of study. Affords students the opportunity to experience guided work to meet the professional demands of the industry.

MUIN.title: The Music Industry: Careers, Rights and Income Streams
MUIN.description: History, procedures, economics and evolving technologies involved with careers, rights and income connected with artists, songwriters, producers, labels, music publishing, performance rights and visual media.

MUIN.title: The Management of Live Performances
MUIN.description: Focus on the Artist, Promoter and Venue, and the roles they play in the Live Performance space, applying theory, technology, and practice.

MUIN.title: Live Touring Strategy
MUIN.description: Part of an emphasis track that focuses on advanced live touring strategies, methods and practices. Projects will apply theory and practice in a directed team oriented approach.

MUIN.title: Music Marketing, Branding and Campaigns
MUIN.description: An overview of music specific concepts and opportunities spanning various roles, tools, forms of music consumption, and campaign stages as it pertains to music marketing.

MUIN.title: Mentorship
MUIN.description: A semester bridge for students working on job preparation, career skills, and continued efforts before launching their final campaign projects and graduation portfolio.

MUIN.title: Artist Management: Campaign Execution and Hindsight Analysis
MUIN.description: Lecture and experiential learning focused on the role of an artists personal manager including executing various release campaigns and hindsight assessment to inform future endeavors.

MUIN.title: Data Analytics: Music Marketing Decisions and Presentations
MUIN.description: The when, why and how data analysis tools are used to assist music professionals and better support marketing decisions, beyond the realm of intuition and aesthetic appeal.

MUIN.title: Developing Copyright Laws and Business Models
MUIN.description: Study of advanced copyright law, conflicts and entrepreneurial opportunities to gain insight into what is evolving for the globalized digital music industry.

MUIN.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO.title: Fundamentals of Music Theory
MUCO.description: An introductory course in music theory required for those majors in need of remedial training, and available to the general student who wishes to develop music writing skills. Not available for  credit to B.M. and B.A. music majors.  Recommended preparation:  ability to read music

MUCO.title: Basics of Music Theory
MUCO.description: Introduction to music theory; scales, intervals, principles of common practice and popular music harmony; melodic, harmonic, and structural analysis; 20th-century developments. Not available for credit to BM majors.

MUCO.title: Harmony in Popular Music
MUCO.description: Study of harmony used in the popular music idiom, as well as diminished chord patterns, modulation techniques, basic modal theory, and principles of melodic construction. Prerequisite: MUCO 133b.

MUCO.title: Aural Skills I
MUCO.description: Sight-singing, dictation, related keyboard application.

MUCO.title: Theory I
MUCO.description: a: Notation, scales, intervals; introduction to counterpoint; harmonic principles of the common practice period; analysis, written work. b: Continuation of 133a; elements of form; application of analysis to performance. Concurrent registration in Aural Skills required.

MUCO.title: Counterpoint I
MUCO.description: The study of the techniques of modal counterpoint; exercises in two-, three-, and four-part writing in 16th century style. Corequisite: MUCO 137a.

MUCO.title: Composition I
MUCO.description: Beginning exercises in composing, initial composition projects, study, lectures and class discussions of selected compositions from the repertory.

MUCO.title: Composition for Non-Majors
MUCO.description: Introduction to the composition of concert music.  Includes set  exercises, free composition, study of selected compositions.   Intended for interested, qualified students not majoring in composition. Not available for degree credit to composition majors. Recommended preparation: MUCO 130bx or MUCO 133b

MUCO.title: Aural Skills II
MUCO.description: Continuation of 132ab.

MUCO.title: Theory II
MUCO.description: a: Analysis of representative pieces from the classic and romantic periods; exercises in composition. b: Survey of 20th century developments; composition utilizing 20th century techniques.

MUCO.title: Composition II
MUCO.description: Composition in shorter forms, continuation of score analysis and listening assignments.

MUCO.title: Theory Review
MUCO.description: Review of materials covered in Theory I and II. For students whose entrance examination in music theory indicates the need for further study.

MUCO.title: Composition for Non-Majors II
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition for non-composition majors. Continuation of MUCO 221abx. Not open to B.M. in Composition majors.

MUCO.title: Aural Skills Review
MUCO.description: Review of the materials covered in Aural Skills I, II, III. For students whose entrance examination in aural skills indicates the need for further study.

MUCO.title: Composition III
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition; preparation for the senior recital.

MUCO.title: Composition IV
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition; preparation for the senior recital.

MUCO.title: Intro to Programming for Digital Media and Computer Music
MUCO.description: Visual-based programming language Max is learned to investigate the computer as a tool for generative and interactive multimedia performance, composition and improvisation environments.

MUCO.title: Directed Research
MUCO.description: Individual research and readings. Not avaliable for graduate credit.

MUCO.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO.description: Survey of common practice period (1650-1900) approaches to phrase  design, tonal organization and type-forms (binary, ternary, rondo,  sonata.)

MUCO.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Post-Tonal Music
MUCO.description: Introductory survey of 20th/21st century approaches to the  organization of pitch (serial, modal, extended tonal, etc.),  rhythm, texture and form.

MUCO.title: Composition for Non-Majors III
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition.  Not open to graduate  students in composition.  Prerequisite: submission of portfolio of  musical compositions.

MUCO.title: Advanced Analysis of Tonal Music: Reduction
MUCO.description: Consideration of recent developments in music theory and their application to the analysis of tonal music, focusing on techniques of musical reduction.

MUCO.title: Advanced Analysis of Post-Tonal Music: Pitch
MUCO.description: Introduction, application and critiques of canonical pitch-based analytical techniques applied to post-tonal music.

MUCO.title: Advanced Composition I
MUCO.description: For graduates with evidence of preparation for advanced work.

MUCO.title: Directed Research
MUCO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO.title: Selected Topics in Graduate Composition
MUCO.description: Seminar for graduate students in composition that addresses aesthetic, technical and analytical issues from a composer's perspective. Open only to theory and composition majors.

MUCO.title: Advanced Composition II
MUCO.description: Continuation of MUCO 537. For students holding the MM degree in composition.

MUCO.title: Advanced Composition III
MUCO.description: Continuation of MUCO 637.

MPPM.title: Individual Instruction
MPPM.description: Weekly individual instruction.

MPPM.title: Popular Music Performance II
MPPM.description: Study of popular music repertoire from the 1970s to the present. Students will learn, rehearse and perform in a collaborative, interactive environment.

MPPM.title: Drumming Proficiency for the Popular Musician
MPPM.description: Beginning and elementary instruction in drum set techniques.

MPPM.title: Keyboard Proficiency for the Popular Musician
MPPM.description: Development of practical keyboard skills, including reading and  realizing chord symbols, basics of voice leading, study of various  harmonic and rhythmic styles.

MPPM.description: Development of ensemble and communication skills through the performance and interpretation of American popular music in concert and studio settings. Development of original compositions.

MPPM.title: Arranging in Popular Music
MPPM.description: Principles and techniques of arranging for voice and rhythm section in the popular music idiom.

MPPM.title: Intermediate Drum Set Proficiency
MPPM.description: Intermediate level instruction in drum set performance including accompaniment techniques,fills, beat and brush patterns in jazz, Afro-Caribbean and Brazilian styles, interpreting drum charts. Recommended Preparation: MPPM 240

MPPM.title: A History of Popular Music
MPPM.description: The history of popular music particularly as developed in America in the 20th and early 21st centuries.

MPPM.title: Individual Instruction

MPPM.description: A study of the practical aspects of vocal performance and skills necessary to increase one's opportunities within the music industry.

MPPM.title: Advanced Rhythm Section Techniques in Popular Music
MPPM.description: The detailed exploration of a specific style or genre in Popular Music through study of repertoire, history and practice with particular emphasis on performance. Recommended preparation: MPPM 120 and MPPM 320.

MPPM.title: Latin Pop
MPPM.description: The detailed exploration of a specific style or genre in Popular Music through study of repertoire, history and practice with particular emphasis on performance. Recommended preparation: MPPM 120 and MPPM 320.

MPGU.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as  well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists  such as The Beatles and Dave Matthews.

SCOR.title: Introduction to Scoring Movies and Television
SCOR.description: Practical composition course covering the unique art, craft, and technology involved in writing and integrating music for animated and live-action visual media.

SCOR.title: Introduction to Scoring Video Games
SCOR.description: Practical composition course covering the unique art, craft, and technology involved in composing and integrating video-game music.

SCOR.title: Directed Research
SCOR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SCOR.title: Screen Scoring
SCOR.description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for graduate non-music majors.

SCOR.title: Individual Instruction in Advanced Screen Scoring
SCOR.description: Individual instruction and review of students work. Selected composers, orchestrators, filmmakers, and other important industry collaborators offer their insights on scoring and career building.

SCOR.title: Advanced Scoring for Motion Pictures and Television
SCOR.description: Scoring principles involved in designing, timing, and composing scores for video projects, including documentaries, animated, and live-action projects. Will also include composing for live recording sessions.

SCOR.title: Orchestral Scoring
SCOR.description: Explores the sounds of and notations for the major orchestral instruments; provides instruction on implementation of those instruments in scoring and orchestrating for the screen.

SCOR.title: Advanced Game Scoring and Integration
SCOR.description: Explores more sophisticated principles and techniques involved in the unique aspects of composing and integrating music for video games.

SCOR.title: Applied Techniques in Contemporary Scoring
SCOR.description: Explores the most recent artistic and technological innovations in film/television scoring, and includes creating cues from adapted themes.

SCOR.title: Studio Conducting and Contemporary Score Analysis
SCOR.description: Study of two distinct areas: 1) The methods and protocols involved in conducting scoring sessions; and 2) Analysis of innovative scores from current television- and feature- films.

SCOR.title: History of Film Scoring
SCOR.description: Examines the evolution of movie music from 1920s to present. Includes recorded interviews with the most significant film composers and film clips of their work.

SCOR.title: Recording, Mixing and Editing for the Screen Composer
SCOR.description: Addresses the need for modern-day screen composers to produce and digitally record, sweeten, mix, and edit much of their own music.

SCOR.title: Advanced Screen Scoring Technology
SCOR.description: Explores sophisticated principles and applications of technologies for screen scoring, including the use of synthesizers, samplers, and sequencers.

SCOR.title: Directed Research
SCOR.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SCOR.title: Research
SCOR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MPKS.description: Methods, study of college curriculum keyboard classes.Studio/group instruction. Business practices; audition, interview techniques. 450a: Survey and observation. 450b practice teaching;secondary piano classes.

MPKS.description: Solo piano literature; emphasis on composers' influences, performance practices and the development of the pianoforte. a:Late Baroque through Beethoven. b: Schubert to the present. Prerequisites: MUHL 331 and MUHL 332.

MPKS.title: Interpretation of Baroque Music
MPKS.description: Repertoire and performance practice in music of the period: style,  phrasing, embellishments, dynamics, improvisation, tempi.         Performance in class of solo and ensemble works, instrumental and  vocal.

MPVA.title: Acting for Singers
MPVA.description: Use of dramatic techniques in the interpretation and performance  of music; basic acting techniques for the operatic and recital  stages; sensory exercises, movement, improvisation, relaxation and  make-up. Recommended preparation: MPVA 153

MPVA.title: Voice
MPVA.description: Weekly individual instruction and vocal performance forum.

MPVA.title: German Language and Diction
MPVA.description: Developing competence in listening, vocal pronunciation, speaking, singing, International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), reading, and writing German. Emphasizes musical texts including German song and operatic arias.

MPVA.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction designed for non-music majors.

MPVA.description: Study of the acting, musical and movement elements involved in the performance of the Broadway musical repertoire.

MPVA.description: Continuation of MPVA 203ab.  Acting of operatic roles in different  periods and styles; specific recital and audition techniques.  Recommended preparation: MPVA 203ab

MPVA.title: Word and Music in Opera
MPVA.description: Performance class for singers and pianists; analysis of recitatives, arias, and ensembles of various operatic styles; study of the technique of effective musical delivery. By audition only.

MPVA.title: USC Opera
MPVA.description: Preparation, rehearsal, and performance of operatic works and excerpts; study of different operatic styles; public appearances. By audition only.

MPVA.title: Directing for the Operatic Stage
MPVA.description: Various approaches to operatic style; basic blocking; stage management. Student direction of scenes produced in USC Opera.

MPVA.title: Foundations of Vocology
MPVA.description: Voice physiology, voice hygiene, voice acoustics, and the cognitive substrates of Motor Learning.

MPVA.description: Weekly individual instruction and vocal performance forum.

MPVA.title: Song Literature
MPVA.description: Song literature of Italy, France, Germany, Russia, Norway, Sweden, England, America; comparative analysis of various composers and their influence on song literature.

MPVA.description: Voice physiology, both classical and non-classical vocal techniques, voice hygiene, advanced voice acoustics, survey of literature from expertise studies, and the cognitive substrates of motor learning.

MPVA.description: A review of the rules of pronunciation, International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and grammatical structure of the Italian language through the texts of select repertoire in both Italian song and operatic arias.

MUSC.title: World Music
MUSC.description: Exploration of music and cultures of the world. Engagement with international musicians, global issues, field work and musical diasporas in Los Angeles.

MUSC.title: Exploring Our Musical Campus
MUSC.description: Exploration of musical styles and elements, creative process and social context through active listening and engagement with live performances on the USC campus.

MUSC.title: Western Music as Sounding History
MUSC.description: An introduction to Western art music and culture from the Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and Modern eras through reading, listening, analyzing and writing about music.

MUSC.title: The Broadway Musical: Reflections of American Diversity
MUSC.description: A uniquely American genre, the Broadway musical serves as a catalyst for inquiry into human diversity, cross-culturalism, and significant social and political issues.

MUSC.title: Electronic Music and Dance Culture
MUSC.description: The origins and development of EDM and its relatives such as disco, house, techno, rave and electronica, focusing on cultural and technological influences.

MUSC.title: The Music of Black Americans
MUSC.description: A chronicle of the musical contribution of Africans and African Americans to American society and to the foundations of musical genres and styles throughout the world.

MUSC.title: Songwriting I
MUSC.description: Development of musical and lyrical skills, composing, listening, analysis, and critiques of popular original music.

MUSC.title: Hip-hop Music and Culture
MUSC.description: A history of hip-hop music from its inception to the present: its musical processes and styles, as well as attendant social, political and cultural issues.

MUSC.title: Songwriting II
MUSC.description: Continuation of Songwriting I; particular emphasis on the analysis of the techniques of important popular songwriters and the application of these techniques to original songs.

MUSC.title: Music, Turmoil and Nationalism
MUSC.description: An exploration of musical practices and styles which reflect and shape national identities and which focus on those created in response to political turmoil in many forms.

MUSC.title: Writing About Popular Music
MUSC.description: Immerses students in criticism, scholarship, and creative writing dealing with popular music.  Students participate in that discourse through developing their own authorial voices.

MUSC.title: Beatles, Stones, Bowie: Empire and Masculinity
MUSC.description: Historical survey of the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and David Bowie that explores their contributions to contemporary notions of "masculinity," "Empire," and "classic rock."

MUSC.title: Songwriting III: The Performing Songwriter
MUSC.description: Continuation of Songwriting I and II with emphasis on the development of performance skills of original popular music in preparation for songwriting showcases.

MUSC.title: Film Music: History and Function From 1930 to the Present
MUSC.description: A survey of the art and craft of film music as practiced by  outstanding composers in motion pictures.

MUSC.title: Young Artist Project II
MUSC.description: Refinement, execution and reflection on unique individualized, mentored projects related to students' diversified and often hybrid work as classical musicians.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by   faculty.  Open only to Bachelor of Music and Bachelor of Arts,  Music majors only.  Not available for graduate credit.  Graded  CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by  faculty.  Open only to music majors.  Graded CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by  faculty.  Open only to doctoral students in music.  Graded CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Studies for the Qualifying Examination in Music
MUSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Duplicates credit in GRSC-800.  CR/NC.

LAW.title: Stereotypes, Prejudice and the Rule of Law
LAW.description: Examines how stereotypes and prejudice undermine equal justice under the law but also how creative word work and art can promote racial justice.

LAW.title: Law and Society
LAW.description: Sources and structure of law; history of Bill of Rights emphasizing effect on criminal justice system; limits of law in solving problems in American society.

LAW.title: Law and Politics
LAW.description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.

LAW.title: Criminal Punishment in the Age of Mass  Incarceration
LAW.description: Examines the social, political, legal and psychological forces  that created the most punitive democracy in history. Materials  include documentaries, journalistic investigations, NGO reports.

LAW.title: Introduction to Criminal Law
LAW.description: Provides a comprehensive analysis of the criminal justice system and an overview of the fundamentals of substantive criminal law.

LAW.title: Personal Data in the 21st Century
LAW.description: Examine how governments and corporations confront information privacy conflicts. Analyze various perspectives on information privacy laws and their place in society.

LAW.title: Fundamentals of the U.S. Legal System
LAW.description: Introduces the U.S. legal system and its relationship to basic principles of the rule of law. Examines lawmaking institutions, judicial processes and contemporary legal issues.

LAW.title: Immigration Law for a New America
LAW.description: Examines current immigration law in America, the normative debates over immigration policies and the role the government plays in expanding or limiting immigration rights.

LAW.title: The Legal Profession
LAW.description: Introduces students to the basic aspects of the legal profession.

LAW.title: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on the Law
LAW.description: Examines law and the legal system from different disciplinary perspectives. It explores how various disciplines provide different insights to the legal regime.

LAW.title: Children and the Law
LAW.description: Examines topics such as children's suggestibility, decision-making, and risk and resiliency all as they apply to legal settings.

LAW.title: Concepts in American Law
LAW.description: The main concepts and topics in American law, in the historical, economic and cultural contexts in which they have developed.

LAW.title: International Influence: Law and Power
LAW.description: Examination of the philosophic and political concepts that underpin international influence, while learning how this structure impacts the modern incentives and interests of international actors.

LAW.title: Issues in the Use of AI in Law and Regulation
LAW.description: Focuses on the role artificial intelligence plays in a variety of aspects of the law through humanities-based approaches like ethics, linguistics, sociological and economics approaches.

LAW.title: Fundamentals of Entertainment Law
LAW.description: Examines key legal principles governing the entertainment industry by exploring legal challenges faced by professionals in music, film, sports, gaming and other areas of entertainment.

LAW.title: Introduction to Law and Economics
LAW.description: An exploration of core aspects of the US legal system (property, contracts, torts, criminal law, civil procedure) from the perspective of basic economics theory.

LAW.title: Cybersecurity and Cybercrime
LAW.description: Studies the rise of cybercrimes and cybersecurity measures in recent years and their impact on society. Topics include cyberattacks, digital forensics, information privacy and others.

LAW.title: Psychology and Law
LAW.description: Explores issues of responsibility and credibility.  Intentional  and unintentional behavior.  Clinical biases.  Topics include  witness credibility, confessions, cults, hostages, battered  persons, and repressed memories.

LAW.title: Directed Research
LAW.description: Individual research and readings.

LAW.title: Undergraduate Law Review
LAW.description: Introduces students to the basics of legal writing and research, with a focus on legal scholarship and law review-type journal articles.

LAW.title: Legal Studies Capstone Project
LAW.description: A cumulative experience demonstrating a student's depth of knowledge in applying research and writing skills on examining the legal system.

LAW.title: Law Internship
LAW.description: Intensive experience with a law-related non-profit organization, or public agency.

LAW.title: Bond
LAW.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution  appears as a section title.

LAW.title: Bocconi
LAW.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution  appears as a section title.

LAW.title: Lyon
LAW.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution  appears as a section title.

LAW.title: FGV Direito SP Brazil
LAW.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution  appears as a section title.

LAW.title: Hong Kong University
LAW.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution  appears as a section title.

LAW.title: Procedure I
LAW.description: Consideration of the participants in litigation; private and public plaintiffs, defendants, and courts. Information exchange, process, outcomes, and costs of lawsuits.

LAW.title: Contracts
LAW.description: The interpretation and enforcement of promises and agreements.

LAW.title: Legal Profession
LAW.description: Functions of the lawyer in modern society; history and organization of the legal profession; the adversary system; equal access to justice; other problems of ethics and professional responsibility.

LAW.title: Constitutional Law: Structure
LAW.description: Considers the delineation of spheres of responsibility between the judiciary and legislature, the nation and the state, and the government and the individual.

LAW.title: Torts I
LAW.description: Individual's obligation not to harm others; bases for compensating persons who are harmed, either by holding responsible whoever is at fault or by invoking other principles of liability, including the efficiency of resource allocation and the spreading of losses.

LAW.title: Legal Research
LAW.description: Examination of the basic sources of law for federal and California jurisdictions, utilizing a vast array of sources from books to     computer-assisted research and analyzing research methodology and  techniques. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW.title: Legal Writing
LAW.description: Two-semester course focusing on developing analytic and communication skills. Lawyers will analyze legal principles and incisively apply them to facts. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW.title: Legal Research, Writing, and Advocacy I
LAW.description: Development of legal research, writing, and advocacy skills.   Emphasis on objective legal writing, including memoranda, and  researching case law through primary and secondary sources.   Registration restricted to Law students.

LAW.title: Introduction to U.S. Legal System
LAW.description: The basic structure of government in the U.S., including the  constitutionally mandated division of power in the federal  government and the federal system of power sharing between state  and federal systems.  A comparative perspective on selected  substantive and procedural matters, such as common law reasoning,  jury trials, adversary process, and various aspects of civil  procedure.  Open to incoming LL.M. students only.

LAW.title: Topics in American Law
LAW.description: This course will provide LL.M. and M.C.L. students with a survey  of various topics in American law including criminal law,  evidence, family law, constitutional law, torts, wills and trusts,  administrative law and property law.  Open to LL.M. and M.C.L.  students only.

LAW.title: Constitutional Law: Rights
LAW.description: Examines constitutional rights particularly ones protected under the Equal Protection/Due Process Clauses and related questions of judicial role and theories of interpretation.

LAW.title: Law for Business
LAW.description: A student-run periodical that publishes student-written and peer-edited  articles relevant to the intersection between law and business.

LAW.title: Law and the Fundamentals of AI
LAW.description: Provides a robust understanding of artificial intelligence, emphasizing its relevance and applications in the legal domain and delves into the foundational concepts of AI.

LAW.title: Business of Law: Future of Legal Service Delivery
LAW.description: Explores the business of law, legal service delivery as it has  traditionally been undertaken and its current transformation, and  the primary drivers of change throughout the business of law  ecosystem.

LAW.title: Academic and Professional Skills for U.S. Law Studies I
LAW.description: Explores and develops the legal communication and analytical skills necessary to the practice of law.

LAW.title: Fundamentals of Legal Writing Skills
LAW.description: Explores purpose and form of legal documents and emphasizes effective communication.

LAW.title: Presentation Skills for International Lawyers
LAW.description: Explores the art of public speaking and effective communication in legal settings.

LAW.title: U.S. Common Law Analysis and Skills
LAW.description: Explores how judicial opinions interact with other sources of law and develop law in the U.S.

LAW.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
LAW.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

LAW.title: Taxation
LAW.description: Federal tax statutes, technical issues and social problems involved in tax planning, tax litigation, and reform of the tax laws.

LAW.title: Criminal Procedure
LAW.description: Criminal procedure in the courts, and the regulation of lawenforcement by the courts through rules of evidence andinterpretation of the Bill of Rights.

LAW.title: Business Organizations
LAW.description: Organization of economic activity especially the modern corporation as institutions of social power. The roles of managers, owners, and regulatory agencies in shaping processes ofdecision making.

LAW.title: Real Estate Transactions and Finance
LAW.description: An in-depth look at the most prevalent transactions and finance tools related to both residential and commercial real estate. Topics include: purchase and sale of realty; property valuation; brokerage agreements; land conveyance and the recording acts; escrows, title insurance and closings; investment vehicles and deal structures; mortgage lending and commercial finance; and foreclosures.

LAW.title: Gifts, Wills, and Trusts
LAW.description: Gratuitous transfer of wealth, especially the transmission of wealth from one generation to the next as a settlement of family affairs. Comparative analysis of the legal mechanisms of gifts, wills, and trusts. Introduction to problems of fiduciary administration.

LAW.title: Evidence
LAW.description: The purpose and character of trial. Problems of adversary presentation and the nature of proof. The basis for admission and exclusion of evidence in judicial proceedings.

LAW.title: Accounting for Lawyers
LAW.description: The lawyer's skills needed to understand the financial affairs of a business client.

LAW.title: Practicing Commercial Real Estate Transactional  Law
LAW.description: Provides an in-depth exposure to the practice of commercial real estate transactional law, including an analysis of the differing perspectives of each side of a transaction and a hands-on study of how lawyers negotiate and document various types of commercial real estate transactions.

LAW.title: Family Law
LAW.description: Creating, regulating and dissolving family relationships. Explore moral and power relations among men, women, children, and the State. Develop skills to help clients in families.

LAW.title: Remedies
LAW.description: Comparison of the remedial goals of contracts, torts, and property and the impact of procedural devices in law and equity. Damages, injunctions, specific performance and restitution. Remedial theory and transactional application.

LAW.title: Mediation Clinic I
LAW.description: Students receive the training required to become professional mediators for civil cases in the L.A. County Superior Court, and mediate these cases.

LAW.title: Business for Lawyers
LAW.description: This course introduces law students to the tools, concept, and language of business. It is premised on the belief that to excel as a business lawyer, one must understand the business world from the perspective of the clients one counsels and assists. The course will cover, in compressed form, the basic subjects from the MBA program which are most useful to lawyers.  Open only to law  students.

LAW.title: Trauma-Informed Lawyering
LAW.description: An introduction of trauma and trauma-informed practice within the  legal field. Learn the skills to represent trauma survivors and  address vicarious trauma.

LAW.title: Issues in Employment Law
LAW.description: Explore the ever-evolving patchwork of statutes and caselaw that  make up the dynamic corpus of modern American employment law.

LAW.title: Secured Transactions
LAW.description: This is a course on Chattel paper and secured transactions involving personal property under Article 9 of the Uniform Commerical Code and some related bodies of law.

LAW.title: Public Interest Housing Practicum
LAW.description: Disassembling structural racism using law, research and community  organizing through work with the Coalition for Property Tax Justice.

LAW.title: Transactional Practice - The Syndicated Loan Agreement
LAW.description: Involves issues including loan restructuring; what loan agreements cover; how representations, covenants, default and financial and repayment terms interrelate; and how security documents fit in. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW.title: Spotlight
LAW.description: Contemporary topics in the field of entertainment law.

LAW.title: Entertainment Law
LAW.description: An examination of how the courts are handling selected, "cutting edge" topics in entertainment law. The topics will include the scope of and limitations on the right of publicity; fair use and parody defenses to copyright infringement; future technology clauses in rights contracts; and copyright and defamation issues arising in the online world. Previous entertainment law courses recommended, but not required.

LAW.title: Computer Crime Law
LAW.description: Examines the legal and policy issues involved with the emergence of cyber crimes and cyber security issues, including government access and privacy issues.

LAW.title: Business and Legal Issues
LAW.description: An in-depth study of television industry legal concepts, contracts, business structures and economic models.

LAW.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
LAW.description: Problems of integrating the corporate, securities, tax, business,  antitrust, accounting and contractual aspects of corporate mergers and aquisitions.

LAW.title: Art Law
LAW.description: Provides an overview, often from a litigation perspective, of      legal issues affecting artworks and cultural property.

LAW.title: Trademark Moot Court
LAW.description: An intensive, two-semester course preparing students interested in U.S. trademark and unfair competition law for participation in the annual Saul Lefkowitz Moot Court Competition.

LAW.title: Hale Moot Court Brief
LAW.description: Invitation-only course offered to second-year students as part of  the Hale Moot Court Honors Program. Students write an appellate  brief.

LAW.title: Moot Court Supervision
LAW.description: Evaluation and supervision of the preparation of briefs and oral arguments in the Hale Moot Court honors competition.

LAW.title: Review of Law and Social Justice Staff
LAW.description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and  comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice.   For second year students serving as staff members on the Review.   Open to law students only.  Graded CR/D/F.

LAW.title: Mediation Theory and Practice
LAW.description: Develop knowledge and skills associated with the mediation process as a third party neutral. Explore mediation theories, practices, ethical issues and policies.

LAW.title: Review of Law and Social Justice Editing
LAW.description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles  and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social  Justice.  For officers of the Review.  Open to law students only.   Graded IP to CR/D/F.

LAW.title: Cyberlaw: Legal Issues Impacting Providers and Users of Inte
LAW.description: An overview of common legal issues impacting both providers and users of Internet services.

LAW.title: Criminal Law in Social Context (Seminar)
LAW.description: Contextualizes criminal law through analyzing the legal and social  characterizations of "victims" and "perpetrators" in U.S. law,  politics and popular culture.

LAW.title: Topics in Business Organizations Law
LAW.description: Legal analysis of selected sub-topics of business organizations  law using problems designed to improve analytic skills and  problem-solving. Taken in conjunction with Business Organizations.

LAW.title: Equity and the Legal and Social Determinants of Health
LAW.description: Explores how legal, social, racial, cultural and economic factors contribute to health disparities and the role that physicians and lawyers can play in advocating for patients and policy changes to promote health equity.

LAW.title: Child Interviewing Practicum
LAW.description: Learn how to effectively interview child witnesses. Students will practice mock interviews, and may be eligible to conduct actual interviews of child witnesses.

LAW.title: Poverty Law
LAW.description: An introduction to the problem of poverty in the United States and  to the response of government and the legal system to the problems  of the poor.

LAW.title: Community Property
LAW.description: The law of community property, including disposition of property on dissolution of the marriage and questions of conflict of laws.

LAW.title: Contract Drafting, Analysis and Negotiation
LAW.description: Covers the fundamentals of reviewing and analyzing business contracts and strategies for negotiating business issues with an emphasis on developing practical skills. Open only to Law students.

LAW.title: Contract Drafting and Negotiation
LAW.description: Contract drafting and negotiating will teach students the   mechanics of drafting and negotiating sophisticated contracts from  a variety of legal disciplines including entertainment law, real  estate law and general corporate law.

LAW.title: Negotiation Theory and Application
LAW.description: Develops enhanced negotiation skills and a working understanding of ADR processes and procedures in an interactive classroom experience.

LAW.title: ADR Law and Policy: Mediation and Arbitration
LAW.description: Exploration of the origin, development, and practice of mediation, arbitration and other forms of ADR, emphasizing the policies       underlying these increasingly significant and evolving areas.

LAW.title: Corporate Finance
LAW.description: Legal and economic aspects of corporate finance including capital structure, policy, mergers, takeovers, and freeze-outs; analysis of policy relating to present law and possible reforms.

LAW.title: Crime, Punishment and Justice
LAW.description: Explores the nature and evolution of criminal punishment, from the death penalty to imprisonment and beyond.

LAW.title: American Exceptionalism and Polarization
LAW.description: Explores the interrelationship between American exceptionalism and the growing polarization of American society.

LAW.title: Stereotypes, Prejudice and the Rule of Law
LAW.description: This course examines the role of race (and other markers of social marginality) in the administration of justice in American courts.

LAW.title: Small Business Clinic II
LAW.description: Continuation of Small Business Clinic I.  Open to Law students  only.

LAW.title: E-Discovery Law
LAW.description: Focuses on the electronic storage of information (ESI) and how it works in the litigation discovery process.

LAW.title: Federal Criminal Law
LAW.description: Covered topics include offenses relating to fraud and political corruption, terrorism, narcotics, money laundering, organized crime, false statements and obstruction of justice.

LAW.title: Labor Law and the Entertainment Industry
LAW.description: Explores labor law in the entertainment industry, where the  collective bargaining relationship between studios and their  unionized employees undergirds almost every facet of "Hollywood."

LAW.title: Securities Regulation
LAW.description: Regulation by state and federal agencies of issuance of, and trading in, stocks, bonds, and other securities. Particular reference to SEC regulations.

LAW.title: Contemporary Name, Image and Likeness
LAW.description: Examines the history and legal foundation of Name, Image, and  Likeness in college athletics, culminating in simulated NIL  contract negotiations.

LAW.title: Sex, Gender and the Law
LAW.description: Explores laws response to questions of sex discrimination and gender identity and expression, with emphasis upon legal issues facing transgender and intersex persons.

LAW.title: Inside the Legal Profession and the Business of Lawyering
LAW.description: Explores the business side of the legal profession, focusing on  law firm dynamics, in-house departments, and other career paths.

LAW.title: Interdisciplinary Law Journal Staff
LAW.description: Source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments  for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. For  second-year students serving as staff members on the Journal.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

LAW.title: Interdisciplinary Law Journal Editing
LAW.description: Supervision and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal.  Graded IP to  CR/69/65.

LAW.title: Federal Courts: The Federal System II
LAW.description: Problems of adjudication in a federal system. Allocation of authority between federal and state courts and among Congress, the Executive and the Courts; choice of federal and state law; jurisdiction of federal courts and significant rules of practice.

LAW.title: International Business Transactions
LAW.description: Survey of legal aspects of international trade and investment transactions, including tax considerations.

LAW.title: Writing for Publication Seminar
LAW.description: Special seminars to provide a forum for students who wish to produce a paper for academic publication to receive guidance and feedback.

LAW.title: Law Review Staff
LAW.description: Writing, source- checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For second year students serving as staff members on the Review. Graded IZ..

LAW.title: Law Review Writing
LAW.description: Writing, source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review.

LAW.title: Law Review Editing
LAW.description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For officers of the Review. Graded IP to CR/69/65.

LAW.title: Intellectual Property
LAW.description: The protection of intellectual property and encouragement of creativity. Explores copyright, trademarks, patents, and selected state law theories.

LAW.title: Immigration Law
LAW.description: Development of immigration law to its present state.

LAW.title: Immigration Clinic I
LAW.description: Students represent clients before Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the Immigration Court, and certain law enforcement agencies in cases including applications for relief under the Violence Against Women Act, for asylum, and for relief against deportation. Open only to LAW students.

LAW.title: Administrative Law and Regulatory Policy
LAW.description: Legal principles subject to judicial control and the alternative   ways in which agencies can be organized to serve their purposes.

LAW.title: Entertainment Disputes
LAW.description: An exploration of litigation and dispute resolution in the  entertainment industry, ranging from traditional conflicits to  emerging issues.

LAW.title: Externship I
LAW.description: An externship allows a student to gain hands-on legal experience in legal settings. Students will be assigned to a legal services program, government agency, or state or federal judge under faculty supervision. All externships include a classroom component.

LAW.title: Externship II
LAW.description: Advanced externship. All externships include a classroom component.

LAW.title: The Law and Economics of the US-China Tech Rivalry
LAW.description: This seminar examines a broad spectrum of legal areas where the  United States and China have clashed in their ongoing rivalry to  claim technological supremacy.

LAW.title: Global Regulation of Artificial Intelligence
LAW.description: This course explores the challenges posed by generative artificial  intelligence across various areas of law and evaluates the  regulatory responses from major jurisdictions.

LAW.title: Advanced Externships
LAW.description: Advanced externships consist of field work at a placement and a  bi-weekly instructed course. Assignments are designed to support  professional growth as a law student.

LAW.title: Race, Racism and the Law
LAW.description: Understand the reciprocal relationship through which race and racism have shaped American law and how law has shaped popular conceptions of race and racism.

LAW.title: Law and Society
LAW.description: Covers a wide range of perspectives and examples from diverse  legal settings to understand law as broader than statutes,  judicial decisions and regulations, but rather as a social  phenomenon embedded in culture, politics and markets.

LAW.title: International Taxation
LAW.description: Explores taxation of inbound and outbound international  transactions, including source rules, the Foreign Tax Credit,  Subpart F, taxation of intangible income, and other topics.

LAW.title: Law & Social Science Seminar
LAW.description: An introduction to cutting-edge social-science research about law  which meets, in part, in conjunction with Center for Law & Social  Science (CLASS) workshops.

LAW.title: The Role of the In-House Entertainment Lawyer
LAW.description: Hands-on experience performing legal work on a hypothetical  television program. The class will act as the legal department  under supervision of the department head (instructor).

LAW.title: Information Privacy Law
LAW.description: Surveys the legal framework concerning information privacy in the US, including developments in constitutional, tort, contract, property and statutory law to address emerging privacy threats.

LAW.title: Medical-Legal Community Partnership Practicum
LAW.description: Medical and law students, in conjunction with public policy advocates, work together to identify and improve health outcomes for vulnerable populations.

LAW.title: Deposition Strategies and Techniques
LAW.description: Emphasizes strategies and tactics in asking and objecting to questions at a deposition in a civil case. Students will conduct mock depositions.

LAW.title: Patent Law
LAW.description: Patent laws, litigation, and the process of prosecuting the patent application. The concept of invention and ownership of rights under patents.

LAW.title: Topics in Tort Theory Seminar
LAW.description: Enduring questions in the theory and practice of torts and related  fields. Topics to vary by semester.

LAW.title: ADR Ethics
LAW.description: Provides law students, lawyers and professional neutrals with an in-depth examination of the rules guiding our behavior in various dispute resolution processes. Open only to law students.

LAW.title: Pretrial Advocacy
LAW.description: Examines conceptual and practical aspects of interviewing,         counseling, negotiation, settlement, drafting and formal advocacy  in the handling of legal cases.

LAW.title: Trial Advocacy
LAW.description: Examines decicion-making by counsel in the litigation of cases. Emphasis is given to decisions involving tactics, strategies, and their implications for the functioning of legal institutions and substantive doctrine. Extensive use of simulated trial practice exercises.

LAW.title: Counseling the Startup Company
LAW.description: Role of the attorney in startup firms: business plan, employment  agreements, lease, stock option plan, financing documents and  distribution and strategic partnership arrangements.  Enrollment  restricted to law students.

LAW.title: Cross-Cultural Dispute Resolution
LAW.description: Brings an international perspective to understanding the impact of culture in the most commonly used international and domestic dispute resolution practices (negotiation, mediation, and arbitration).

LAW.title: Negotiation Skills
LAW.description: Develops students' negotiating skills through role plays, reflection and instructor feedback.

LAW.title: International Human Rights Clinic I
LAW.description: Students work under close faculty supervision on cases and projects that involve the application of international law to address human rights violations.

LAW.title: Housing Law and Policy Clinic I
LAW.description: Students work under close faculty supervision on cases and  projects that involve the application of housing law and policy.

LAW.title: Law and Psychology
LAW.description: Examines the psychological factors that hinder the making of accurate factual findings.

LAW.title: Housing Law and Policy
LAW.description: Introduce state and local housing law and policy with a focus on low-income tenants and undertake an exploration of current housing crisis.

LAW.title: International Negotiations and Mediation
LAW.description: Introduction to negotiation and mediation from an international  perspective.  Development of essential skills for effective client  representation in negotiation and mediation.  Open only to Law  students.

LAW.title: Counterterrorism, Privacy and Civil Liberties
LAW.description: Explores the spectrum of interrelated legal and policy issues known as "homeland security" since the events of September 11, 2001.

LAW.title: Legal Writing Fellows
LAW.description: Assist in teaching writing and advocacy. Responsibilities include helping prepare lesson plans and drafting writing assignments and sample answers; leading class exercises; and judging first-year moot court practice rounds. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW.title: First Amendment
LAW.description: Freedom of expression (political speech, symbolic expression, obscenity, commercial speech, defamation), rights of access to the media, religious protection and prohibition of establishment of religion.

LAW.title: Judicial Opinion Writing
LAW.description: Students write a majority opinion and a dissenting opinion based  on cases pending before the U.S. Supreme Court. This is a  writing-intensive course.

LAW.title: Advanced Legal Writing for Business Lawyers
LAW.description: Students interested in business law and other transactional practice areas will develop the skills to communicate clearly, concisely and correctly in a business law setting.

LAW.title: Major Trends in American Legal Thought
LAW.description: Major intellectual trends that have shaped both theory and  practice in American law since the twentieth century until the  present.

LAW.title: Directed Research
LAW.description: One CR/D/F unit for a research proposal approved by a full- or part-time faculty supervisor; up to four graded units with academic deans approval of proposal by LLM or third-year JD student to produce a publishable paper under full-time professor.

LAW.title: Post-Conviction Justice Project I
LAW.description: A year-long clinical program where second and third year students provide legal representation to men and women serving life terms in California prisons. Under faculty supervision  students represent clients on a variety of post-conviction matters, including parole hearings, state and federal habeas petitions, clemency applications and resentencing hearings and appeals. Experiential units.

LAW.title: Advanced Clinical Training
LAW.description: For third-year students who wish to continue their clinical  training.

LAW.title: Advanced Mediation Clinic
LAW.description: Students learn mediation skills, conduct live mediations and help to run the regular Mediation Clinic.

LAW.title: Stigma, Discrimination, and Mental Health Disorders
LAW.description: Examines the stigma against mental illness by and on behalf of the  U.S. government, with special attention to stigma within the  Department of Defense.

NURS.title: Theory: Clinical Management of Adult Patients
NURS.description: The scope of practice and responsibilities of the family nurse practitioner in prevention of disease, health maintenance and the diagnosis and management of patients with common illnesses are explored.

NURS.title: Pharmacology for Advanced Practice Nursing
NURS.description: Advanced pharmacology including pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapeutics of all broad categories of agents.

NURS.title: Clinical Practicum: Management of Adult Patients
NURS.description: Primary health care to patients throughout the life cycle with a focus on the prevention of disease, health maintenance, and the diagnosis and management of patients with common illnesses.

NURS.title: Theory: Clinical Management of the Childbearing/Childrearing
NURS.description: Diagnosing and managing childbearing women from preconception through uncomplicated pregnancy and postpartum periods and providing primary care to children and their families from newborn through adolescence periods.

NURS.title: Theory: Clinical Management of Adult Patients with Complex M
NURS.description: The scope of practice and responsibilities of the family nurse practitioner in the diagnosis and management of patients with acute, complex and chronic illnesses are explored.

NURS.title: Clinical Practicum: Management of the Childbearing/Childrear
NURS.description: Clinical practicum is intended to prepare FNP students to provide primary health care to childbearing/childrearing families from preconception through adolescent phase of the life cycle.

NURS.title: Research/Analytical Methods
NURS.description: Understanding and applying commonly used research methodologies and data analysis techniques in healthcare research.

NURS.title: Transforming Research Evidence into Practice
NURS.description: Preparing the advanced practice nursing student to critically evaluate knowledge, research and evidence for implementation of best practices in healthcare in order to deliver safe, ethical, culturally sensitive evidence based care for patients in diverse settings.

NURS.title: Clinical Practicum: Management of Adult Patients with Comple
NURS.description: Application of theoretical concepts studied in NURS 600. Comprehensive assessments, formulation of differential diagnoses, and the development of plans of care to manage acute and chronic complex in a variety of practice settings.

NURS.title: Professional Issues in Advanced Practice Nursing
NURS.description: The professional role and legal responsibilities of the nurse practitioner at entry to clinical practice and throughout a career are explored.

NURS.title: Health Policy Principles in Changing Health Care Contexts
NURS.description: Foundation for leadership in interprofessional collaborative endeavors to address health policy that prepares learners to analyze and influence health policy and explores the role of nurse practitioners in the creation and modification of health policy.

NURS.title: Theory: Family Primary Care
NURS.description: Capstone course draws on material and concepts learning throughout the FNP program and explores additional complex issues including management of pain, caregiver burden, palliative care and end of life.

NURS.title: Clinical Practicum: Family Primary Care
NURS.description: Prepares the family nurse practitioner student for entry into practice in the diagnosis and management of patients with acute, complex, and chronic illnesses in the primary care setting.

BPMK.title: Biopharmaceutical Marketing Management
BPMK.description: Develop insights into global marketing and build foundational skills in clinical development, commercialization and investment strategies for biopharmaceutical and medical device products, portfolios and companies.

BPMK.title: Biopharmaceutical Marketing Research and Analytics
BPMK.description: Research and analytical methods for synthesizing data-driven insights informing marketing decisions of biopharmaceutical products. Apply systematic frameworks of marketing research to assess commercial market opportunities.

CXPT.title: Critical Perspectives on Medicines, Health and Society
CXPT.description: Introduces key features of pharmacoepidemiology and drug utilization research in the context of pharmaceutical policy that affect the development and provision of safe, effective and affordable medications to the public in the United States.

CXPT.title: Biomedical Data Sciences
CXPT.description: Basics concept of code-based biomedical data analysis and  visualization. Introduction to rigorous and reproducible  analytical tools, including Python-based interactive notebooks.  Appropriate use of statistical analysis.

CXPT.title: Master's Thesis
CXPT.description: Credit on acceptance of Master's thesis.

CXPT.title: Preclinical Experimental Therapeutic Drug Development
CXPT.description: Evolution of a chemical entity as it is transformed into a drug candidate. Open only to students in Clinical and Experimental Therapeutics and Management of Drug Development.

CXPT.title: Clinical Problem Solving
CXPT.description: Experiential/case base course for graduate students who are enrolled in the Clinical Experimental Therapeutics (CXPT) MS or PHTS-PhD programs.

CXPT.title: Research
CXPT.description: Research-based course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who are preparing for their written and oral qualifying examination.

CXPT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CXPT.description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

CXPT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CXPT.description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

CXPT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CXPT.description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

CXPT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CXPT.description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

CXPT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CXPT.description: Independent research course for students enrolled in the CXPT PhD program who have passed their written and oral qualifying examination and advanced to PhD candidacy.

BPSI.title: CPT Internship in Biopharmaceutical Sciences
BPSI.description: Cooperative education providing international undergraduate pharmacy students opportunity to enhance biopharmaceutical sciences curriculum through practical, industry appropriate, work experience.

BPSI.title: Biopharmaceutics I
BPSI.description: Comprehensive overview of pharmaceutical sciences. Interdisciplinary areas of study that deal with the design, action, delivery, disposition and patient acceptance of drugs.

BPSI.title: Organ Systems Physiology, Drug Delivery and Drug Action
BPSI.description: Principles of cellular and organ physiology systems. Interplay between the physiology of organ systems, drug delivery and drug action.

BPSI.title: Biopharmaceutical Product Development and Brand Planning
BPSI.description: Introduces critical financial decisions and development milestones in biopharmaceutical drug product development and commercialization. Learn to align business strategies with decisions supporting a product lifecycle.

BPSI.title: Targeted and Precision Medicines
BPSI.description: Precision medicine utilizing data from basic science, clinical, personal, environmental and population settings; understanding biological processes and disease mechanisms; develop precise diagnostics, therapeutics and prevention.

BPSI.title: Directed Research
BPSI.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development.

BPSI.title: Senior Honors Seminar I
BPSI.description: Exciting and challenging opportunity to marshal and deploy research, analysis, interpretation and writing skills learned in their major.

BPSI.title: Senior Honors Seminar II
BPSI.description: An independent study course for students undertaking the research and writing of an Honors thesis.

MPTX.title: Pharmacology
MPTX.description: Fundamentals of pharmacology in the context of the rapidly  developing knowledge of related disciplines.

MPTX.title: Topics in Pharmacology: the Other Side of Drugs
MPTX.description: Nexus of pharmacology and toxicology; therapeutic use and toxicology of common drugs; and prescribing these drugs in clinical practice.

MPTX.title: Cell Biology
MPTX.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

MPTX.title: Directed Research
MPTX.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Master's Thesis
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Master's Thesis
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Master's Thesis
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Seminar in Molecular Pharmacology and Toxicology
MPTX.description: Contemporary advances in molecular pharmacology and toxicology research. Registration required during each year of residency.

MPTX.title: Research
MPTX.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be      applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MPTX.description: Credit on accetance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MPTX.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MPTX.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Research Design
PMEP.description: Introduction to the concept of research design and examples of the  variant research methods utilized in the field.  Both the  conceptual and practical issues of research including development  of the research question, selection of appropriate methods, data  sources and analytic approaches to address the research question  will be addressed.

PMEP.title: Pharmacoeconomics I
PMEP.description: Introduction to pharmacoeconomics with special emphasis on the role of pharmaceuticals and the pharmaceutical industry, insurance, managed care, regulation and pricing.

PMEP.title: Health Economics I
PMEP.description: Techniques of microeconometric analysis to inform health policy. Topics include: demand for health, medical care, and insurance, risk selection, medical innovation.

PMEP.title: Advanced Health Econometrics I
PMEP.description: The expansion of students' knowledge of econometric methods emphasizing, but not limited to, applications to health economics. Serves as a prelude to the advanced study of microeconomics.

PMEP.title: Seminar in Pharmaceutical Economics and Policy
PMEP.description: Current research in pharmaceutical economics and policy presented by outside scholars, faculty and students. Graded CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Research
PMEP.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be      applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

RXRS.title: Approaches to Pharmacology and Drug Development
RXRS.description: Pharmacology and Drug Development explored through the lens of Clinical Pharmacy, Translational and Bench Research, Regulatory Science and Global Policy and Economics.

RXRS.title: The History and Geography of Drugs
RXRS.description: Global perspectives; discovery and use of drugs (legal/illegal); poisons. How they helped shape, modify or change history as described in classical literature through present day.

RXRS.title: Comparative Neuropharmacology: A Kaleidoscope of Experiences
RXRS.description: How drugs impact culture in individual, society and global communities

RXRS.title: CPT Internship in Pharmacology and Drug Development
RXRS.description: Cooperative education providing international undergraduate pharmacy students opportunity to enhance pharmacology and drug development curriculum through practical, industry appropriate, work experience.

RXRS.title: Mysterious Deaths: From Poisons in History to Forensic Toxic
RXRS.description: The story of poisons told through the prism of history, as a way to discover forensic toxicology.

RXRS.title: Human Pharmacology: Challenge of Therapeutics in Society
RXRS.description: Principles of human pharmacology/toxicology related to prescription, over the counter medications; nutraceuticals; drug-drug interactions; polypharmacy; hot topics related to recently approved drugs.

RXRS.title: Breaking Brains: The Pharmacology of Addiction
RXRS.description: Neurological basis of addiction to drugs of abuse including alcohol, marijuana, opioids and sugar, focusing on neuropharmacology and challenges of current and future therapies.

RXRS.title: Clinical Pharmacology and Medication Management
RXRS.description: Comprehensive Medication Management Applications in Pharmacotherapy; evidence-based, pharmacist driven medication selection; improved and/or optimized medication therapy; patient compliance; better and safer health outcomes.

RXRS.title: Cancer Biology and Pharmacotherapy
RXRS.description: Cancer and the complex molecular basis leading to tumor oncogenesis, invasion and metastasis; current therapeutic strategies and strategies on the horizon.

RXRS.title: Ethics, Drugs and Society
RXRS.description: Ethical and moral issues have arisen from responsibilities within different fields of pharmaceutical practice.  Exploration of the broad solutions those responsibilities have presented.

RXRS.title: Medical Products: From Idea to Market
RXRS.description: Progress of medical product development through intellectual property, animal and clinical trials  and commercialization.  Emphasis on safety, quality systems and efficacy.

RXRS.title: Food Safety: The Good, The Bad and The Deadly
RXRS.description: Critical thinking, science translation, effective communications, personal health, and public policy development are at the interface of food safety, nutrition intervention and health controversies

RXRS.title: Regulation, Guidance and Control of Medical Products
RXRS.description: Overview of the regulatory, guidance, and compliance activities with federal, state and local governments as well as pharmaceutical industry.

RXRS.title: Principles of Pharmacy Compounding and Calculations
RXRS.description: Fundamental principles and practices of pharmacy compounding and calculations, medication preparation, regulatory aspects of compounding

RXRS.title: Directed Research
RXRS.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development.

RXRS.title: Senior Honors Seminar I
RXRS.description: Exciting and challenging opportunity to marshal and deploy research, analysis, interpretation and writing skills students learned in their major.

RXRS.title: Senior Honors Seminar II
RXRS.description: An independent study course for students undertaking the research and writing of an Honors thesis.

HCDA.title: U.S. Health System: Healthcare Access and Delivery
HCDA.description: Introduction to U.S. health system with comprehensive overview of insurance coverage and benefits, reimbursement, access to healthcare and biopharmaceuticals, and the delivery of healthcare services.

HCDA.title: Comparative International Healthcare Systems
HCDA.description: Comparative analysis of healthcare coverage and financing policies across countries. Examine its relationship to drug coverage, access, reimbursement, pricing policies and impact on biopharmaceutical market.

HCDA.title: Competitive Healthcare Intelligence
HCDA.description: Competitive intelligence techniques and analysis to evaluate opportunities in biopharmaceutical marketplace including product development, positioning and launch strategies with an aim to optimize business decisions.

HCDA.title: Health Economic and Outcomes Methodology
HCDA.description: Comprehensive review of the strategies used in drug value assessment with a focus on health economics and outcomes research and application to healthcare decision making.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Organization Management and Leadership
HCDA.description: Develop foundational leadership and business management skills  specifically within the context of dynamic global  biopharmaceutical, medical device and other healthcare enterprises.

HCDA.title: Introduction to Healthcare Data Analytics
HCDA.description: Learn methods for working with large health data sets, including developing an analytic plan and selecting an appropriate data source, as well as practical skills needed to manage and use large health data sets to accomplish an analytic goal.

HCDA.title: Seminars in Healthcare Decision Analysis
HCDA.description: Weekly seminar and literature series, review and discuss policy, biopharmaceuticals, insurance, global healthcare access issues. Student lead discussions, expert guest speakers, group projects, critical thinking.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Consulting Enterprise Team Project
HCDA.description: Work as a consultant to conduct market research and apply decision analysis methods to design strategies for healthcare products and services or company pipelines.

HCDA.title: Directed Research
HCDA.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HCDA.title: Internship in Healthcare Business
HCDA.description: Work on real business issues in the healthcare industry at an internship site with an existing business, company, firm or government entity.

HCDA.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
HCDA.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's  field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus  facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not  be taken until the student has completed at least one full  academic year of enrollment in the graduate program with a  cumulative 3.0 GPA.

PSCI.title: Drugs: Principles of ADME and Bioavailability
PSCI.description: Principles of drug formulation, delivery, metabolism and transport; influence of physicochemical properties, physiology, and pharmacogenetics on these properties; drug-drug interactions; and pharmacokinetics.

PSCI.title: Principles of Therapeutic Mechanisms
PSCI.description: Principles of mechanisms of actions of common drug classes, medicinal chemistry, pharmacology, drug interactions with protein targets, biologics, drug targeting and nanotechnology.

PSCI.title: Cell Biology
PSCI.description: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intra-cellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions.

PSCI.title: Principal Research Approaches and Scientific Writing
PSCI.description: Familiarizes new graduate students with basic approaches used in biomedical research, with a focus on approaches in pharmaceutical, pharmacological and translational sciences.
