Provides an understanding of what to expect in the coming years as a graduate student doing biomedical research and in scientific writing.

PSCI.title: Directed Research
PSCI.description: Research leading to the master`s degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PSCI.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

PSCI.title: Advanced Pharmacokinetics/Pharmacodynamics
PSCI.description: Principles of advanced pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics. Mathematical description of drug disposition processes. Design and evaluation of pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic studies. Advanced approaches to parameter estimates.

PSCI.title: Research
PSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum untis which may be  applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

RSCI.title: Quality Systems and Statistical Process Control
RSCI.description: Fundamentals and applications of Statistical Process Control (SPC) in development and monitoring of manufacturing processes; includes SPC in root cause analysis and CAPA.

RSCI.title: Introduction to Medical Product Regulation
RSCI.description: Introduction to regulatory environments surrounding medical product development, manufacturing and marketing; operation of federal, state and international regulatory bodies.

RSCI.title: Regulation of Pharmaceutical and Biological Products
RSCI.description: Ensuring safety and effectiveness of new drugs and biologics; marketing and monitoring approved pharmaceutical/biological products; management of genetically engineered products.

RSCI.title: Regulation of Medical Devices and Diagnostics
RSCI.description: Development and testing of new medical products according to U.S. and international regulatory requirements.

RSCI.title: Medical Products and the Law
RSCI.description: Legal issues affecting intellectual property, medical product development, marketing and safety, taught through case studies and lectures.

RSCI.title: Structure and Management of Clinical Trials
RSCI.description: Development and execution of clinical trials: bioethical principles, good clinical practices, project management and documentation.

RSCI.title: Seminars in Regulatory Science
RSCI.description: Current problems in regulatory affairs, legal management, preclinical and clinical testing, scientific evaluation and quality assurance. (Duplicates credit in former MPTX 521.) Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS Regulatory Science program.

RSCI.title: Chemistry Manufacturing and Controls
RSCI.description: Provides a firm foundation in the domestic and international CMC process, from concept to commercialization of new active pharmaceutical ingredients and products.

RSCI.title: Clinical Trial Writing and Documentation Management
RSCI.description: Clinical Trials management and operations are vital aspects in the design, planning, conduct and reporting of successful research projects and portfolios.

RSCI.title: Directed Research
RSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

RSCI.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training in  Regulatory Science
RSCI.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in Regulatory Science. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate or professional degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS (Regulatory Science).

RSCI.title: Regulatory Strategy in Asia
RSCI.description: Regulatory policy, standards and practices in different Asian markets: product licensing, import/export management, materials sourcing, quality systems compliance, reimbursement, prescribing practices. Travel may be required. Recommended Preparation: Undergraduate or professional degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience.

RSCI.title: Regulation of Emerging Technologies and Biological Products
RSCI.description: Policies, testing and regulatory requirements affecting commercialization of biologics and novel medical technologies. Focus on biologics, blood and tissue products, radiopharmaceuticals and nanotechnology

RSCI.title: Directed Field-Research Project
RSCI.description: Research/policy analysis conducted under preceptor supervision in an industrial or governmental setting.

RSCI.title: Directed Research
RSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied towards the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC

RSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
RSCI.description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree  in Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
RSCI.description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree  in Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
RSCI.description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree  in Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
RSCI.description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree  in Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
RSCI.description: Dissertation research required for completion of doctoral degree  in Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Studies for the Qualifying Exam
RSCI.description: Preparation for the qualifying exam. Graded CR/NC

PHRD.title: Physiology, Biopharmaceutics and Medicinal Chemistry I
PHRD.description: Explores drug absorption, molecular properties, gut physiology and factors affecting binding to pharmacological targets, including protein structure, enzyme inhibition and receptor agonism.

PHRD.title: Clinical Skills and Professional Development I
PHRD.description: Equips pharmacy students with clinical skills, patient-centered care, medication therapy management, physical assessment, and interprofessional education, fostering communication, clinical decision-making and ethical healthcare practice.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Literature Analysis and Drug Information
PHRD.description: Literature evaluation and biostatistics of clinical and health  services research, and drug information services.  Emphasis on  drug therapy, patient outcomes, and formulary development.

PHRD.title: Introduction to Healthcare Systems and Public Health
PHRD.description: Explores U.S. healthcare systems, pharmacy practice, public policy, medical billing and public health, including social determinants, preventive care and health disparities.

PHRD.title: Pharmaceutical Calculations & Biostatistics
PHRD.description: Develops mathematical, statistical and research skills for accurate drug dosing, pharmacokinetics, and evidence-based decision-making in pharmacy practice to improve patient outcomes.

PHRD.title: Metabolism and Cell Biology
PHRD.description: Basic principles of drug action and receptor actions. Includes their application to the understanding and treatment of disease. Provides the scientific basis of pharmaceutical action.

PHRD.title: Integrated Science and Clinical Therapeutics I
PHRD.description: First class of a longitudinal series offered to first year pharmacy students. Will explore introductory topics for self-care, hypertension, cholesterol, gastrointestinal and respiratory conditions.

PHRD.title: Pharmacoepidemiology
PHRD.description: Introduces pharmacoepidemiology and discusses key concepts and principles in the study of the utilization, safety and effectiveness of medications in large populations.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Education 1
PHRD.description: Understanding and application of learning theory and teaching methodology, small group teaching, active learning, student motivation, basic assessment methods, and general online teaching tools.

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: Pharmacokinetics
PHRD.description: Integrated teaching of basic and clinical pharmacokinetic/ pharmacodynamic concepts. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Career Pathways I
PHRD.description: Introduces pharmacy students to four Trojan Areas of Concentration, aligning education with career goals through expert-led sessions, some leading to academic certificates.

PHRD.title: Case Conference 1
PHRD.description: Case conferences and seminars focusing on contemporary pharmacy practice.

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: General Medicine
PHRD.description: Integrated course that combines the pathophysiology, pharmacology, and clinical use of drugs in the management of common renal, liver, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, joint and integumentary system related disorders.

PHRD.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
PHRD.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

PHRD.title: Sports Pharmacy Thesis
PHRD.description: Comprehensive exploration of special and emerging topics in the practice of pharmacy.

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: Infectious Diseases
PHRD.description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics, with emphasis on the therapy of infectious diseases caused by bacterial, viral, parasitic, and fungal organisms. (Duplicates credit in PHAR-605 and 606)

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: Cardiovascular System
PHRD.description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on pharmaceuticals affecting cardiovascular and circulatory diseases. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only. (Duplicates credit in PHRD 601)

PHRD.title: Case Conference 3
PHRD.description: Case conferences and seminars focusing on contemporary pharmacy practice.

PHRD.title: Hospital Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: Exploration of the pharmacy profession and the practice of hospital/institutional pharmacy.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Elective Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to an Elective Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE). The P2 and P3 Elective IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to various aspects of the pharmacy profession in a variety of settings.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Elective Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to an Elective Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 627a. The P2 and P3 Elective IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to various aspects of the pharmacy profession in a variety of settings.

PHRD.title: Interprofessional Collaboration for Patient Care
PHRD.description: Provides future pharmacists with the specialized knowledge, skills, and experiences for team-based care through interprofessional collaboration (IPC). Fulfills requirements in the Health Systems and Comprehensive Medication Management and High-Risk Populations areas of concentration.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Interprofessional Collaboration Experience
PHRD.description: The interprofessional collaboration (IPC) experience provides student pharmacists with the specialized knowledge, skills and experiences to provide team-based patient care through IPC. Lends expertise in the area of appropriate utilization of pharmaceuticals anchored in evidence-based medicine. The longitudinal IPC experience is designed to prepare students for optimizing team-based patient care through IPC.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Community Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to a Community Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 629a. The P2 and P3 Community IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to aspects of the pharmacy profession in the Community pharmacy setting.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Institutional Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: This course is for Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to an Institutional Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 631a. The P2 and P3 Institutional IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to aspects of the pharmacy profession in the institutional pharmacy setting.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Management and Economics
PHRD.description: Management principles for pharmacy practice, understanding of health care systems and pharmacoecomincs. Introduction to formulary management and outcome analysis.

PHRD.title: Scholarly Project 2
PHRD.description: Oral and poster presentation of the results of the Pharm.D. Scholarly Project.

PHRD.title: Sports Pharmacy
PHRD.description: An integrated course that brings together sports pharmacists, sports scientists and other health professionals to discuss the safe and ethical use of pharmaceutical substances and methods within sports.

PHRD.title: Sports and Dietary Supplements
PHRD.description: Insight into the dietary supplements market and regulations;  sports supplements and associated risks; how sports pharmacists  can help athletes become more well-informed consumers and reduce  the risks when using these products.

PHRD.title: Community Pharmacy and Business Management I
PHRD.description: Development of specialized knowledge and skills in community pharmacy practice involving location analysis, pharmacy management principles, and introduction to business law concepts.

PHRD.title: Principles of Managed Care
PHRD.description: Understanding formal and informal organizations in institutions, managed care, disease management, health care policy and financing, patients' chart organization, and clinical monitoring parameters.

PHRD.title: Geriatric Pharmacy I
PHRD.description: Specialized knowledge and skills in geriatric pharmacy, pharmacology of aging, and unique functions of health care team providing care to the elderly patient. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only.

PHRD.title: Basic Research Design
PHRD.description: Laboratory, clinical, health economics or regulatory science research experience for pharmacy students. Projects performed working directly with faculty advisers.

PHRD.title: Pharmaceutical Development
PHRD.description: Examination of pharmaceutical product development process including discovery, preclinical/clinical studies, regulatory-legal issues and marketing. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Education Seminar
PHRD.description: A seminar course with a focus on educational methods and teaching  skills providing career development for students interested in  academia.  Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only.

PHRD.title: Acute Care I
PHRD.description: Development of specialized knowledge and skills in evidence-based drug-therapy management in the acute care arena.

PHRD.title: Topics in Pharmacology: the Other Side of Drugs
PHRD.description: Nexus of pharmacology and toxicology; therapeutic use and toxicology of common drugs; and prescribing these drugs in clinical practice.

PHRD.title: Global Pharmacy
PHRD.description: Opportunity to work with pharmacists, student pharmacists, and other healthcare professionals to experience pharmacy education and practice outside of the United States.

PHRD.title: Acute Care Clinical APPE
PHRD.description: Application of pharmaceutical care principles to the adult patient population in an acute care environment. Clinical application and disease state management will be emphasized. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Primary Care APPE
PHRD.description: Disease state management and a primary care setting. Modification and design of drug therapy regimens and primary patient care using a team based approach. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Community Pharmacy APPE
PHRD.description: Pharmaceutical care principles applied in a community pharmacy environment. Participating in the development, implementation and outcome evaluation of patient care services in the community. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Nuclear Pharmacy APPE
PHRD.description: Provides practical and theoretical aspects of radiopharmacy services delivery.

PHRD.title: Hospital Pharmacy Practice APPE
PHRD.description: Practical experience in the practice of hospital pharmacy. Administrative, practice-based and therapeutic competencies emphasized.

PHRD.title: International Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRD.description: Practical experience in the practice of pharmacy in the international setting. Students will visit an international pharmacy practice setting and complete a project.

PHRD.title: Advanced Geriatrics APPE
PHRD.description: Directed projects/practical experience in geriatric drug therapy.

PHRD.title: Pharmaceutical Industry APPE
PHRD.description: Practical experience within a pharmaceutical company may include: clinical affairs, drug development, research and/or marketing process.

PHRD.title: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Elective (APPE)
PHRD.description: Pharmacy practice experience (internship) course in a health care  setting.

PHRD.title: Non-traditional Advanced Pharmacy Elective (APPE)
PHRD.description: Pharmacy practice experience (internship) course in a              non-traditional or emerging setting.

PHRD.title: Directed Research
PHRD.description: Research leading to doctorate in Clinical and Experimental  Therapeutics.

PHRD.title: Doctor of Pharmacy Capstone
PHRD.description: Capstone course required for completion of Doctor of Pharmacy degree. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

OT.title: THRIVE: Foundations of Well-Being
OT.description: Exploration of themes of thriving including well-being, self-care and connection. Application to university life, building community, developing identity and integrating learned topics into everyday life.

OT.title: Connection Section: Latinx Identity and Well-Being
OT.description: Exploration of themes of thriving including well-being, self-care and connection. Application to university life, building community, developing identity and integrating learned topics into everyday life.

OT.title: Connection Session
OT.description: Exploration of themes of thriving including well-being, self-care and connection. Application to university life, building community, developing identity and integrating learned topics into everyday life.

OT.title: Caring For Your Self: Engaging in Healthy Habits and Routines
OT.description: Application of self-care, lifestyle, and behavior change principles in occupational science and occupational therapy to students own lives, through self-analysis and learning through doing.

OT.title: Medical Terminology for Health Professions
OT.description: Foundation of medical terminology and hospital abbreviations useful for practice in health care.

OT.title: A Life of Play
OT.description: Exploration and incorporation of play as a meaningful activity to promote healthy living; emphasis on the importance of play in human development throughout the lifespan.

OT.title: Lifestyle Design: Self-Analysis of Activities for Health
OT.description: Introduction to theoretical concepts concerning the relationship of engagement in activities, or occupations, to health and well-being. Application of these perspectives to students' own lives.

OT.title: Introduction to Occupational Science and         Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Exploration of occupations, or meaningful activities, and how they may promote health and wellness, and the science behind why occupations are powerful tools for healing.

OT.title: Across the Lifespan: Occupations, Health and Disability
OT.description: Innovative team-based learning to explore theories and stages of development throughout the lifespan, as manifested in activity; representation of diverse contexts, perspectives, and abilities.

OT.title: Human Physiology for Allied Health Professions
OT.description: Overview of human physiology emphasizing systems that sustain homeostasis and motion with a focus on biological foundations for a healthy lifestyle. Relevant pathophysiologic issues discussed.

OT.title: Essential Occupations of Emerging Adulthood
OT.description: Examination of challenges associated with the emerging adulthood stage of development through an occupational science lens; strategies to promote health and well-being for this population.

OT.title: Exploring Creative Occupations
OT.description: Examination of theories and practices of the creative process in varied mediums; exploration of the relationship between creative occupation, identity, health, and quality of life.

OT.title: Living a Sustainable Life
OT.description: Exploration of relationship with nature in daily life, including impact on mental health, nutrition, and built environments; includes hands-on activities at USC Peace Garden.

OT.title: The Brain: Mind, Body, and Self
OT.description: Exploration of neuroscience in development as it impacts everyday living across the lifespan through the lens of the nervous system and its response to trauma.

OT.title: Our Families, Ourselves
OT.description: Definitions of families in an ever-changing cultural world, from colonial times to the present; relevance of meaningful activities to family life, values and structure.

OT.title: Animal and Human Interconnections in Daily Life
OT.description: Exploration of the vast and evolving relationships between animals and humans; how animals expand human capacity for action and contribute to health, well-being and participation.

OT.title: Tell Me a Story: Narratives in Health and in Illness
OT.description: Tell us your story!  Analysis of story structure and purpose, rich life descriptions and powerful stories of illness and courage that elicit empathy and understanding.

OT.title: Directed Research
OT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Adult Physical Rehabilitation
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in adult rehabilitation and geriatrics; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 401. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Mental Health
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in mental health practice; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 402. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Pediatrics
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in pediatrics; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 403. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Productive Aging and Geriatrics
OT.description: Examination of the aging process and introduction to the role of occupational therapy in working with older adults in a variety of settings.

OT.title: Seniors Rising:Occupational Foundations for Graduate Success
OT.description: Overview of individualized goals necessary for graduate school success using occupational therapy frameworks and assessment measures.

OT.title: Foundations of Occupation: Kinesiology in Daily Life
OT.description: Foundations of biomechanical and musculoskeletal concepts necessary for the analysis of movement in every day occupation, as they relate to occupational therapy practice.

OT.title: Reflection in Practice
OT.description: Self-reflection focused on awareness and articulation of one's therapeutic and communication styles, positionality, intersectionality, explicit and implicit biases, and privilege to form strong relationships.

OT.title: Survey of U.S. Health Systems
OT.description: Foundation for understanding and analyzing health systems in the United States and their impact on occupational therapy practice, from access to intervention and reimbursement.

OT.title: Foundations of Occupation: Neuroscience in Daily Life
OT.description: Application of basic neural function to the analysis of daily living tasks and activities; review of pathological conditions that interfere with performance in occupation.

OT.title: Foundations of Occupation: Creativity, Craft and Activity An
OT.description: Engagement in craft experience to develop proficiency in analysis of activity performance and occupation; exploration of creativity and craftsmanship in both historical and contemporary contexts.

OT.title: Foundations of Occupation: Sensory Processing in Daily Life
OT.description: Comprehensive overview of the basic neurobehavioral principles underlying sensory processing and sensory integration theory and their relationship to everyday occupations.

OT.title: Theoretical Foundations of Occupational Science and Occupati
OT.description: Development of knowledge and critical thinking relative to ongoing, situated discourses about occupation, occupational therapy and occupational science.

OT.title: Practice Scholar: Applying Quantitative Evidence
OT.description: Introduction to concepts of practice scholarship; emphasis on applying quantitative research evidence to clinical questions and appraising quantitative research evidence.

OT.title: Current Issues in Practice: Adulthood and Aging
OT.description: Exploration of adulthood, aging and occupation; current topics related to aging population and occupational therapy to promote health and participation throughout the lifespan. Duplicates credit in former OT 508. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Contemporary Issues in School-Based Practice
OT.description: Current issues in school-based occupational therapy evaluation,  ongoing assessment and intervention.  Topics include successful  collaboration in inclusive classrooms and on IFSP and IEP teams.   Open only to OT majors.  Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Sensory Integration Theory
OT.description: Comprehensive overview of the basic neurobehavioral principles underlying sensory processing and sensory integration, patterns of dysfunction and their relationship to everyday occupations and intervention.

OT.title: Evaluation and Clinical Reasoning: Sensory Integration
OT.description: Application of sensory integration principles in the clinical reasoning process and evaluation of sensory processing disorders. Includes integration of different methods of data collection.

OT.title: Therapeutic Communication: Facilitating Change in Clients
OT.description: Exploration of selected therapeutic communication styles intended to facilitate change including motivational interviewing, mindfulness practices, and cognitive approaches to therapeutic intervention.

OT.title: Building Technologies that Promote Health and Well-Being
OT.description: Development of technical and business skills to create innovative technologies that promote health and well-being.

OT.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
OT.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

OT.title: Directed Research
OT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
OT.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

OT.title: Visionaries: Innovation and Technology to Promote Occupation
OT.description: Exploration of the development, assessment, selection, and use of technologies to enable and enhance participation in a meaningful occupation in clinical, educational and research contexts.

OT.title: Visionaries: Global Health Systems, Policy and Advocacy
OT.description: Analysis of health systems, public policy, and social determinants impacting occupational participation of diverse and global populations; development of capacity for advocacy and professional engagement.

OT.title: Applying Occupational Science: Lifestyle Redesign
OT.description: Interactive exploration of Lifestyle Redesign framework and applications for health promotion, wellness and disease management. Emphasis on preventing/managing chronic health conditions, intervention design and implementation.

OT.title: Fieldwork with Seminar
OT.description: Clinical rotation with client/patient responsibilities under the supervision of an occupational therapist to achieve entry-level competence in specific practice area.

OT.title: The Nature of Occupation
OT.description: Theoretical and historical foundations for the study of  occupation, engagement in living and learning in everyday life.

OT.title: Research Practicum
OT.description: Experiential learning through immersion in one or more externally funded research groups in the Division, enabling intense participation in multi-skilled research groups.

OT.title: Residency
OT.description: Residency involving development, administration, evaluation, or policy formulation for occupation-centered programs in clinical or community settings. Development of portfolio for professional doctorate. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Teaching and Learning Seminar: Becoming a Fieldwork Educator
OT.description: Current professional issues related to fieldwork education; examination of best practices for teaching, learning and supervision; development of an envisioned future as a fieldwork educator.

OT.title: Doctoral Capstone Preparation: Seminar 1
OT.description: Seminar organized through Communities of Practice and facilitated by faculty mentors to further the knowledge and experience of students in a specific area of practice.

OT.title: Practice Scholar: Synthesizing Evidence and Practice Needs
OT.description: Synthesis of evidence to design occupation-based programs and interventions that are effective, meaningful, appropriate and feasible in a particular practice context.

OT.title: Mobilizing Knowledge for Impact: Concepts and Skills (KMb I)
OT.description: Introduction to knowledge mobilization practices and skills, including approaches to co-develop tailored communication with partners to accelerate real-world impact.

OT.title: Applied Leadership for Health Professionals
OT.description: Cultivation of impactful leadership within the dynamic healthcare landscape; in-depth exploration of interdisciplinary leadership theories; applications to strategic management, policy, emerging technologies, ethical decision-making.

OT.title: Occupational Science Origins and Evolutions
OT.description: Evolution of occupational science discipline, including conceptual and theoretical developments, relationships with occupational therapy and other fields and global contributions.

OT.title: Pedagogy in Higher Education: Seminar and Practicum
OT.description: Fundamentals of teaching and learning in higher education in preparation for work in an academic setting; experiential learning in methods of course development and delivery.

OT.title: Doctoral Capstone Experience with Seminar
OT.description: Full-time immersion in practice area; implementation and evaluation of doctoral capstone project; monthly seminar and self-reflection on envisioned future in relation to student learning outcomes.

OT.title: Research
OT.description: Research leading to the doctorate, maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BKN.title: Neuromuscular and Bio-Robotic Systems
BKN.description: Introduces the fundamentals of mathematical, Newtonian, and robotic analysis applicable to multi-muscle biomechanical systems. Combines physiology with numerical simulations to understand and predict motor function.

BKN.title: Musculoskeletal and Biomechanical Basis of Movement
BKN.description: Introduction to the mechanical properties of the musculoskeletal  system.  Review of connective tissue and muscle mechanics,  arthrology, anatomical design and statics.  Laboratory dissections  illustrate biomechanical concepts.

BKN.title: Experimental Methods for the Analysis of Human Movement
BKN.description: Introduces students to the techniques and hardware used to record movement, measure movement-related variables, and analyze those variables to address hypotheses.

BKN.title: Readings in Biokinesiology
BKN.description: Independent review and synthesis of papers appearing in the current literature.

BKN.title: Directed Research
BKN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determnined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

BKN.title: Sports Science Internship
BKN.description: A combination of observation, participation (testing/assessments, training) and analysis and interpretation of data. Supervision and guidance from the internship mentor will vary depending on the setting and credit hours. Allows students a progressively increasing amount of responsibility with respect to athlete/subject and/or data involvement.

BKN.title: Modeling the Motor System: An Introduction
BKN.description: Introduction of basic principles and models of the primate motor  system.  Emphasis on arm control.

BKN.title: Modeling the Motor System: Laboratory
BKN.description: Introduction of computer programming and implementation of  computational models in a laboratory setting.

BKN.title: Advanced Independent Study in Biokinesiology
BKN.description: Examination of selected mechanisms underlying normal movement and  pathological movement.  Study of methods used to investigate these  mechanisms.  Doctoral students only.

BKN.title: Research
BKN.description: Research leading to doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PT.title: Cellular and Systems Physiology
PT.description: Selected subjects in cellular and systems physiology.  Emphasis on molecular and cellular aspects of neuromuscular function; also hepatic; renal and endocrine physiology.

PT.title: Musculoskeletal Anatomy
PT.description: Musculoskeletal anatomy, innervation, blood supply, and function:  intensive study of the head, neck, trunk, and limbs.  Lecture,  dissection laboratory.

PT.title: Basics of Patient Management
PT.description: Development of basic decision making skills, professional  behaviors and impairment assessment in patients with  musculoskeletal, neurologic and/or cardiopulmonary dysfunction.   Lecture, laboratory.

PT.title: Neuroanatomy
PT.description: Organized approach to structures in the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nervous systems that subserve motor, sensory, and integrative functions, memory, cognition and special senses. Lecture, laboratory.

PT.title: Pathology of Cardiopulmonary Disease and General Medical Con
PT.description: Pathology and pathophysiological mechanisms in disease of the cardiac, pulmonary and circulatory systems; examination of diabetes, burns and other disabling medical disorders.

PT.title: Clinical Pharmacology
PT.description: Effects of commonly used drugs in patients with physical disability; side effects that alter physical performance or responses to exercise.

PT.title: Clinical Exercise Physiology
PT.description: Adaptation of the human body to exercise and the use of exercise to modify human function.

PT.title: Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
PT.description: Introduction to a patient-centered Evidence Based Practice model  with emphasis on professional communication skills, ethics,  professional guidelines, laws and regulations.

PT.title: Evidence for Physical Therapist Practice
PT.description: Advanced critical analysis and application of research of evidence.

PT.title: Clinical Management of Cardiopulmonary Dysfunction
PT.description: Physical therapy evaluation and intervention in the care of patients with circulatory, cardiac or pulmonary dysfunction. Lecture, case presentations, laboratory.

PT.title: Mechanics of Human Gait
PT.description: Introduction to both normal and pathological gait.  Emphasis on  the basic components of abnormal ambulation including  temporal-spatial factors, joint motion, kinetics, kinematics; and  muscle activity.  Lecture.

PT.title: Interprofessional Education and Collaboration for Geriatrics
PT.description: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

PT.title: Clinical Experience
PT.description: Practical experience in two-week physical therapy psychomotor skills, decision making and professional behaviors.

PT.title: Clinical Imaging
PT.description: Elements of reading roentgenographs, CAT and MRI scans for the physical therapist. Lecture, demonstration, practical experience.

PT.title: Integrated Patient Management Clinical Skills
PT.description: Advanced evaluation and management of patients with movement dysfunction spanning all diagnoses seen by physical therapists.

PT.title: Integrated Patient Management Seminar
PT.description: Integration of physical therapy management of complicated patients with concurrent musculoskeletal, cardiopulmonary and/or neurologic  disorders.

PT.title: Hybrid Integrated Patient Management Clinical Skills
PT.description: Advanced evaluation and management of patients with movement dysfunction spanning all diagnoses seen by physical therapists (musculoskeletal conditions focus on upper quarter body regions).

PT.title: Hybrid Integrated Patient Management Seminar
PT.description: Integration of physical therapy management of complicated patients with concurrent musculoskeletal (concentrating on upper quarter body regions), cardiopulmonary and/or neurologic disorders.

PT.title: Differential Diagnosis in Physical Therapy
PT.description: Consideration of principle of differential diagnosis with emphasis on mastering this skill.

PT.title: Advanced Clinical Experience with Academic Integration
PT.description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 24 hours per week in a part-time setting. Emphasis on the care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions.

PT.title: Advanced Clinical Experience
PT.description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 36 hours per week in a full-time setting. Emphasis on care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions.

PT.title: Hybrid Advanced Clinical Experience with Academic Integratio
PT.description: A 13-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 36 hours per week in a part-time setting. Emphasis on the care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions.

MS.title: Foundations of Officership
MS.description: Introduces students to issues and competencies that are central to  a commissioned officer's responsibilities.  Establish framework  for understanding officership, leadership, and Army values  followed and "life skills" such as physical fitness and time  management.

MS.title: Individual Leadership Studies
MS.description: Students identify successful leadership characteristics through  observation of others and self through experiential learning  exercises.  Students record observed traits (good and bad) in a  dimensional leadership journal and discuss observations in small  group settings.

MS.title: Leadership and Problem Solving
MS.description: Students conduct self-assessment of leadership style, develop  personal fitness regimen, and learn to plan and conduct  individual/small unit tactical training while testing reasoning  and problem-solving techniques.  Students receive direct feedback  on leadership abilities.

MS.title: Leadership and Management
MS.description: Develops student proficiency in planning and executing complex  operations, fuctioning as a member of a staff, and mentoring  subordinates.  Students explore training management, methods of  effective staff collaboration, and developmental counseling  techniques.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies I (Air Force Mission and Organization)
AEST.description: Introduction to U.S. Air Force and the military profession; USAF organization and functions; Strategic Air Command organization, command control and weapons systems; communications skills.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory I
AEST.description: Introduction to the military experience focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Officer. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies II (Air Force History)
AEST.description: Development of aerospace power in the U.S. through WWII; emphasis on the Army Air Corps; communication skills.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory II
AEST.description: Introduction to the military experience focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Officer. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies III (Air Force Management and Leadership)
AEST.description: Air Force management fucusing on the new manager in the Air Force milieu. Emphasis on communication skills peculiar to the Air Force.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory III
AEST.description: Practical introduction to Air Force leadership focusing on military communicative skills, group dynamics, and application of theories of leadership and management. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies IV (National Security Forces in Contemporary American Society)
AEST.description: Military professionalism and the context in which defense policy is formulated and implemented; national security policy, political/social constraints, and military justice.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory IV
AEST.description: Advanced Air Force leadership experience focusin on the practical development of the Air Force officer through command and staff positions within the Cadet Corps. Craded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory V
AEST.description: Advanced leadership experiences for AFROTC continuing cadets. Graded CR/NC.

HMGT.title: Leading People and Health Care Organizations
HMGT.description: Exploration of contemporary workforce issues and skills development in organizational design, performance measurement, teamwork, conflict resolution, leadership, and change management. Open to MHM students only.

HMGT.title: Strategic Management
HMGT.description: Provides skill development and application in the integrative  discipline of strategic management including assessment, strategy  formulation implementation and control.  Open to MHM students only.

HMGT.title: Managing and Improving Health
HMGT.description: Methods for monitoring and improving the health of populations.   Topics include outcomes management, risk-adjustment, development  and implementation of practice guidelines.  Open to MHM students  only.

HMGT.title: Managing Risk
HMGT.description: Overview of reimbursement models in clinical and institutional settings; legal, financial and clinical assumption of risk pursuant to new and evolving federal and state statutory and regulatory provisions. Open only to EMHA students.

HMGT.title: Developing & Monitoring of Quality & Patient Safety Outcomes
HMGT.description: Overview of contemporary methods used to develop and monitor patient quality and safety outcomes; develop skill in data collection and analysis of clinical care outcomes; focus on operationalizing outcomes that matter to payers, organizations, and clinicians. Open only to EMHA students.

NAUT.title: Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: An experiential approach to sailing and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship, leadership and communication skills.

NAUT.title: Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: An experiential approach to sailing and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship, leadership and communication skills.

NAUT.title: Advanced Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: Responsibilities and operations commanding an offshore sailing vessel including sailing theory and advanced techniques, advanced navigation, ships engineering and oceanography relevant to seamanship.

NSC.title: Introduction to Naval Science
NSC.description: Introduction to the structure, principles, and practices, lines of command and control, and functions of the various components of the naval service.

NSC.title: Leadership and Management
NSC.description: Principles of human relationships; principles of decision making and management at the junior officer level; theory and techniques of leadership.

NSC.title: Evolution of Warfare
NSC.description: Causes and practice of warfare from ancient times; impact of changes in strategy, tactics, and technology; modern revolutionary warfare, global conflict, and politico-military relationships.

NSC.title: Naval Ships Systems I (Engineering)
NSC.description: Types, structure, and purpose of Naval ships, compartmentation, propulsion systems, auxiliary power systems, interior communications, ship control; ship design and stability.

NSC.title: Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare
NSC.description: Characteristics, requirements and problems of maneuver warfare; modern tactical principles and current military developments; other aspects of warfare and impact on maneuver warfare doctrine; historical perspectives for present and future decision-making.

NSC.title: Naval Operations and Seamanship
NSC.description: Vector solutions of relative motion, tactical problems; tactical communications, instructions; fleet communications, organizations; rules of the Nautical Road; aviation and maritime meteorology; operation plans and orders.

PPDE.title: Professional Workshop in Public Administration
PPDE.description: Evidence-based argumentation, written reporting and communication  in public administration;  research skills for effective stakeholder engagement.

PPDE.title: Professional Residency in Public Administration
PPDE.description: Skills in written reporting, professional briefings and social media for public administrators; effective engagement for stakeholders and constituencies; research, analysis and reporting on current policy or management cases

PPDE.title: Consulting in Healthcare Organizations
PPDE.description: The application of decision analysis principles necessary for determining priorities for uses of strategic human, facility and financial resources in healthcare organizations; analytic and consulting skills; case studies.

PPDE.title: Behavioral Insights for Health Policy
PPDE.description: Practical strategies for promoting patient health and improving healthcare, based on psychology and behavioral science insights.

PPDE.title: Urban Spatial Ethnography and Critical Cartography
PPDE.description: Theories and methods of how to develop original data about, analyze, and produce visualizations of urban space; conventional conceptualization and representations of cities and urban spatial data. Recommended preparation: PPD 631 or other GIS coursework.

PPDE.title: Housing Dynamics for Policy and Planning
PPDE.description: Comprehensive introduction to the dynamics of the housing sector,  problems, programs, and policies. Attention to both publicly  assisted and market rate housing, recent trends and current  debates.

PPDE.title: Climate, Sustainability and Environmental Planning
PPDE.description: Fundamentals of climate, sustainability and environmental planning from an urban planning and policy perspective; planning for climate and hazard risks; environmental equity and justice issues; environmental planning practices, policies and tools.

PPDE.title: Financial Management of Nonprofit Organizations
PPDE.description: Accounting and financial management principles and practices in nonprofit organizations: budgeting financial analysis, internal controls, financial policies, grant making and financial reporting. Duplicates credit in PPD 541.

PPDE.title: Python for Public Policy and Management
PPDE.description: Quantitative Python data science applied to public  policy/management problems. Includes introduction to Python, data  workflows, replicable reporting and visualization, regression  analysis, basic machine learning.

PPDE.title: Environmental Policy Design and Analysis
PPDE.description: Analytical foundation for design of institutions and policies; environmental policy; welfare economics and market failure; policy evaluation; economic policy instruments; climate change policy issues; other policy issues.

PPDE.title: China from a US Policy Perspective
PPDE.description: Examination of China through the lens of the US federal government; trade issues; economic coordination and stability; environment and sustainability; defense and security; human development

PLUS.title: Applied Research Design and Inquiry
PLUS.description: Provide foundation in applied research skills required for advanced practice in policy, management, planning and development; design and use of applied research; development of research designs; constraints on application of research; translation of findings. Prerequisite: PPD 502x.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional   Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PPD.title: Economic Analysis for Public Policy
PPD.description: Economic foundations for public policy analysis; concepts of efficiency and equity, analysis of market failure and policy interventions; challenges in policy-making.

PPD.title: Solving Public Problems
PPD.description: Develops a framework for understanding public policy and its role in solving current complex issues. Theories, processes and institutions that shape policymaking and professional development for policymaking. Course sections may vary in policy subject emphasis.

PPD.title: Planning for the Future City
PPD.description: Gateway to BS, Public Policy, Management and Planning and minor in Planning and Development. City building and development process; who plans, politics of planning and development; major topics include land use, fiscal policy, transportation, sustainability, and economic development.

PPD.title: Citizenship and Public Ethics
PPD.description: Review of legal and ethical traditions of citizenship withemphasis on the latter; consideration of implications for currentpractice of public policy-making and management.

PPD.title: The Urban Context
PPD.description: The urban context for planning and policy decisions. Socioeconomic, physical and spatial structure of cities; and the underlying demographic, economic and social processes that drive their ongoing transformation.

PPD.title: Social Justice Issues in Public Policy and Urban Planning
PPD.description: Social justice issues through the lens of public policy and urban planning with main focus on Los Angeles; critical thinking skills about the fields and their relevance to social justice.

PPD.title: PPD Practices: Internship Seminar
PPD.description: Policy, planning, and development skills for practice; internship seminar; leadership, group dynamics and presentation skills; application of management; organizational diversity; reflection on experiences.

PPD.title: Statistics for Policy, Planning, and Development
PPD.description: Statistical applications applied to the real world; techniques including probability, sampling; hypothesis formation and testing; correlation, and linear regression.

PPD.title: Finance of the Public Sector
PPD.description: Justifications for and effects of government policies; tax and spending sides of government budgets; public goods; externalities; social insurance; redistribution and welfare; tax policy.

PPD.title: Public Policy and Law
PPD.description: Institutional foundations and analysis of public policy issues; policy formulation and implementation; application of theories; case analyses.

PPD.title: Fundamentals of Health Policy and Management
PPD.description: Learning the institutions of health care delivery and financing; evaluating key health policy issues; understanding and using economic, statistical and mathematical tools as ways to inform health policy issues.

PPD.title: Crime and Public Policy
PPD.description: Public policy agenda-setting, alternatives formulation, and implementation for crime and criminal justice; analysis of specific issues including crime control, death penalty, and gun control.

PPD.title: Environmental Policy and Sustainable Development
PPD.description: Introduction to critical issues of environmental policy in looking toward a more sustainable future; the science and policy of climate change; equity and justice; the greening of industry, governing for sustainable development; policy tools in addressing issues of environmental protection and sustainability

PPD.title: Government and Business
PPD.description: Interrelated roles of business and public institutions; effects of public policies and laws on business sector; incorporates public and business perspectives.

PPD.title: Urban Transportation Planning and Policy
PPD.description: Current transportation planning and policy critiques.   Transportation planning: the relationship to urban structure;  conventional and para-transit modes; analysis of local plans.

PPD.title: Sustainable Communities, Policy and Planning
PPD.description: Policy and planning as shaped by sustainability theories;          sustainability indicators; topics include water resources, air     quality, land use regulations, environmental design, carrying      capacity, ecological footprint analysis. Duplicates credit in  former PPD 461.

PPD.title: The Nonprofit Sector and the Public Interest
PPD.description: Theories of the voluntary nonprofit sector in society and its relationship to government and business; public policies toward the sector.

PPD.title: Public Policy and Planning Analysis
PPD.description: Applied analytic modeling and data manipulation; visual presentation; interpretation of data; needs assessment and market failure analysis; indexing; extrapolation and simple forecasting; simple risk analysis; benefit-cost analysis.

PPD.title: Management of Health Care Organizations
PPD.description: Healthcare trends affecting the management of healthcare organizations; impact of regulations and reimbursement; strategies for operational success; organizational roles and responsibilities.

PPD.title: Urban Informatics
PPD.description: Introduction to urban informatics including the fundamentals of coding, urban data analysis and statistics, visualization, mapping, smart cities/technology and telling stories with data.

PPD.title: Undergraduate Policy, Planning, and Development Studio
PPD.description: Application of methods in the exploration of a specific project, policy, or organization from the multiple perspectives of the five tracks in the undergraduate program.

PPD.title: Housing and Community Development
PPD.description: Evolution of government housing and community development programs; present practices, e.g., housing elements, economic development, neighborhood rehabilitation; housing needs and market analysis; housing and health.

PPD.title: Directed Research
PPD.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Departmental approval.

PPD.title: Senior Thesis
PPD.description: Writing of the honors capstone project in an area of interest related to the track of study; research and writing skills.

PPD.title: Economics for Public Policy
PPD.description: Economic theory as applied to public policy. Concepts of efficiency and equity, analysis of market failure and policy interventions.

PPD.title: Essential Statistics for Public Management
PPD.description: Essential statistics for public managers and administrators; application of statistical methods in addressing public policy and management questions.

PPD.title: Introduction to Microeconomics: Applications in Health
PPD.description: Key microeconomic concepts and economic fundamentals for health policy and management professionals. Ties economic principles to real-world applications in health and healthcare.

PPD.title: Health Care Operations Improvement
PPD.description: Strategies to improve hospital operations, including supply chains, staffing, informatics, data analytics and patient flow.

PPD.title: Problems and Issues in the Health Field
PPD.description: Introduction to concepts and facts regarding the healthcare system, healthcare policy, epidemiology and disease trends, prevention, healthcare organizations, personnel, diversity, evidence, delivery systems, population health, financing and reimbursement.

PPD.title: Legal Issues in Health Care Delivery
PPD.description: Rights of consumers; health-related powers of governments; rights and responsibilities of health care providers; interrelationships of rights, powers, and responsibilities. Recommended preparation: PPD 509 or substantial prior work experience in health care organizations. Open only to graduate students.

PPD.title: Financial Accounting for Health Care Organizations
PPD.description: Accounting as a management tool; accounting systems; basic accounting concepts and procedures; budgets; financial statements. Open only to graduate students.

PPD.title: Quality of Care Concepts
PPD.description: Quality issues and complexities affecting healthcare; fundamentals of quality improvement programs; examination of quality issues and improvement programs in various health care venues; strategies

PPD.title: Planning Theory and History for a Just Society
PPD.description: Explores the history and theories underlying professional planning practice; evolving theoretical frameworks that will shape the planning field. Focuses on theoretical/historical perspectives on social justice, inclusion, and diversity.

PPD.title: Planning Studio
PPD.description: Application of methods in planning, programming, research, andevaluation in a professional context; data collection andanalysis; case studies; practical applications.

PPD.title: Data, Evidence, and Communication of the Public Good
PPD.description: Introduction to data analysis for planning practice. Includes quantitative and qualitative methods. Traditional methods such as regression and emerging methods including social media, visual/spatial analysis, programming.

PPD.title: Fundamentals of Public Administration
PPD.description: Administrative concepts, institutions, legal systems, and practices; values; facilitation of responsibilities and rights; professional applications for personal, private sector and public achievement.

PPD.title: Public Financial Management and Budgeting
PPD.description: Financial management applied to public and nonprofit organizations; financial valuation, financial markets, budgeting, tax administration, debt financing, cost-benefit analysis and financial analysis. Duplicates credit in PPDE 645.

PPD.title: Policy and Program Evaluation
PPD.description: Methods and models for policy and program evaluation; methods of collecting and analyzing evaluation data; processes for linking evaluation to policy formulation and program management.

PPD.title: Internship Seminar
PPD.description: Supervised study of management, analytical, or other professional activities in government; integration of theory, practice and      relevant literature.

PPD.title: Public and Nonprofit Organizational Behavior
PPD.description: Behavior in organizations; focus on personal, interpersonal, and group level factors that influence such behavior.

PPD.title: Capstone in Public Administration
PPD.description: Constitutionally accountable and ethical practice, individually and organizationally; applications of core competencies; practical inquiry, analysis, systems; comparative frameworks; citizenship and public service.

PPD.title: Foundations of Policy Analysis
PPD.description: Introduction to public policy analysis; issue diagnosis and policy design; analytic reasoning and argumentation; the role of the public policy professional; ethical issues in policy analysis.

PPD.title: Multivariate Statistical Analysis
PPD.description: Applied multivariate statistics in support of policy, management, and planning problem solving. Includes regression analysis, logit models, and an introduction to time-series models and multi-equation estimation.

PPD.title: Policy Analysis Practicum
PPD.description: Application and integration of the knowledge and techniques of analytic, quantitative, managerial, political and ethical analyses to specific public policy problems.

PPD.title: Applied International Policy Analysis and Management Project
PPD.description: Enables students to integrate theory, research and practice into  an applied project of their own choosing.  The output of this  course is a professional report in a selected public policy or  management area.

PPD.title: Applied Statistics for Planning, Policy, and Management
PPD.description: Use of statistical reasoning to answer questions related to public  policy and management.  Students will review and understand  selected statistical techniques for analyzing data and for  addressing public policy and management questions of interest  using applied data analysis.

PPD.title: International Public Policy and Management Seminar
PPD.description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of public policy  analysis and management.  Highlights some of the constraints of  the policy process.  Includes examples from the United States but  also presents comparative views of the contours of public policy  in both developed and developing nations.  The course applies  public policy and management frameworks to selected areas of  social policy.

PPD.title: Risk Analysis
PPD.description: Concepts of risk analysis, risk in engineered systems, environmental risk, security risks; fault trees, event trees, risk simulations; risks and decision-making.

PPD.title: Directed Research
PPD.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.       Graded CR/NC.

PPD.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PPD.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

PPD.title: Nonprofit Advocacy and Social Change
PPD.description: Selected topics in Public Policy, Management and Planning.

PPD.title: Management of Long-Term Care Organizations
PPD.description: History, development, trends; major policy issues; organization of systems; principles and techniques of administration; management of institutional and community based programs. Open only to graduate students.

PPD.title: Frontline Issues in Health Services  Administration and Policy
PPD.description: Emphasis on current or emergent issues in the health care  industry.  Focus on impact of recent health legislation and/or  health care system responsiveness.

PPD.title: Participatory Methods in Planning and Policy
PPD.description: Approaches to community participation, introducing students to the  theories behind participatory methods as well as to the skills to  implement them.

PPD.title: Environmental Impacts
PPD.description: Legal, political/institutional, and technical aspects of          environmental impact reports for urban planning.

PPD.title: Community Development and Site Planning
PPD.description: Urban form and emerging community design practices; design project  development; evaluation and assessment of site planning in cities  and local communities.

PPD.title: Urban Planning and Social Policy
PPD.description: Urban planning and social work: theory, values, techniques of     inquiry, and problem- solving methods appropriate to urban         planning and social work.

PPD.title: Geographic Information Systems for Policy, Planning, and Development
PPD.description: Introduction to GIS systems and usage in the public sector;  spatial data; understanding software and the application of  technology; analysis of data using GIS.

PPD.title: Institutional and Policy Issues in Transportation
PPD.description: Analysis of policies relating to transportation alternatives;     institutional environment and background; federal, state,          regional, and local agency responsibilities and interactions.

PPD.title: Introduction to Community and Economic Development
PPD.description: Theories of community and economic development and a contextual  understanding of the forces that change the development and  community life of urban areas.

PPD.title: Shaping the Built Environment
PPD.description: Introduction to the theories and concepts and good city form.   Explores the options for designing more livable and sustainable  urban communities.

PPD.title: Finance of the Public Sector
PPD.description: Sources of government revenue, intergovernmental financial relations, budgeting, public goods theory. Theoretical and applied skills in analysis of equity and efficiency issues.

PPD.title: Collaborative Governance
PPD.description: Theory and practice of collaborative policy and planning processes involving stakeholders from public, private, and nonprofit sectors. Leadership skills in the design and facilitation of multi-party negotiations and consensus-building.

PPD.title: Nonprofit Management and Leadership
PPD.description: Issues in nonprofit management and leadership including: the role of boards; strategic planning; marketing and fundraising; financial management; and volunteer and human resource management. Recommended preparation: PPD 689.

PPD.title: Development of Effective Groups and Organizations
PPD.description: Theories and techniques of assessing and improving interpersonal relationships and group dynamics in an organizational context; action research-based approaches to implementing organizational change.

PPD.title: Homeland Security and Public Policy
PPD.description: Definition and history of terrorism, counterterrorism, domestic  policy and public sector management; intelligence/information  sharing and analysis; emergency preparedness planning, response  and recovery.

PPD.title: The Nonprofit Sector and Philanthropy
PPD.description: Nonprofit organizations and their relation to government and business; the role of philanthropy, social enterprise, and public support and implications for policy, strategy and management.

PPD.title: Communicating Public Policy
PPD.description: Exploring the complex relationships that exist among policies,  policymakers, and the media; analyzing the role of journalists and  policy analysts in the public policy process.

PPD.title: Research Design
PPD.description: Philosophy of social science; applied social research; research design; sampling & validity; overview of qualitative and quantitative methods

PPD.title: Qualitative Methods
PPD.description: Reflective and critical approach that questions data collection    techniques, positions relative to those being studied, and         explanatory methods. Recommended preparation: PLUS 502 or PLUS  504.

PPD.title: Research Seminar
PPD.description: Research fields and design; literature reviews; critical reading and critiquing; project development

PPD.title: Advanced Urban Development
PPD.description: Urbanization, urban economics, land use, the politics of growth,  governance, regulation, and the state, immigration, and place  promotion.

PPD.title: Econometrics for Policy, Planning and Management I
PPD.description: Implementation of microeconometric techniques and assessment of  studies; empirical strategies for research questions and data  preparation and analytic tasks in Stata.

PPD.title: Research
PPD.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
